fields.headline: Scottish round-up
fields.trailText: Livewire Latapy
fields.body:
Livewire Latapy

A brace from the Trinidad and Tobago striker Russell Latapy saw Hibernian through to their first Scottish Cup semi-final in five years with a 3-1 win over Falkirk.

The Hibs manager Alex McLeish had considered leaving him out after he returned late from international duty. But not content with a stunning strike and a penalty either side of Andy Lawrie's equaliser, Latapy set up Pat McGinley's late third to seal the win.

 First Division Ayr enjoyed a comfortable 2-0 win over Partick Thistle at Somerset Park to progress to their first semi-final since 1973. Goals from Neil Duffy and Neil Tarrant, on loan from Aston Villa, settled the tie.

 Celtic's forlorn chase of Rangers in the Premier League resumed with a 4-1 win against St Johnstone at Parkhead. Mark Viduka's brace was decisive after Paddy Connolly had cancelled out Mark Burchill's opener for Celtic. The 19-year-old Burchill later added a fourth.

"We never played well but it's even more creditable to still score four," said a relieved Kenny Dalglish.

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Gulls taking off
fields.body:
Gulls taking off

With none of the other sides in the top half managing a win on Saturday, Torquay moved to within sight of a play-off place by beating the leaders Rotherham at Plainmoor.

Brian Healy gave the Devon outfit a 12th-minute lead from the penalty spot and after Steve Thompson had levelled Tom Stocco's 49th-minute goal earned Wes Saunders' side the points.

 Third-placed Darlington came unstuck at Leyton Orient despite taking the lead through Marco Gabbiadini's 26th goal of the season. Matt Lockwood's free-kick drew the O's level before Steve Watts' last minute winner.

There was another last-gasp goal at London Road, where Lee Thorpe secured a point for Lincoln against promotion-chasing Peterborough. Posh, who hope to make Jason Lee's loan move from Chesterfield permanent this week, had led 2-0.

 Barnet ended a run of five successive defeats with a late Ken Charlery equaliser against Hartlepool at Underhill. James Coppinger, on loan from Newcastle, gave the visitors the lead 17 minutes from the end, but Charlery's goal - the first scored by the Bees in six games - salvaged a point.

 Cheltenham moved up to ninth after thumping Halifax 3-0, while Craig Taylor's goal helped Plymouth earn a point against Devon rivals Exeter at St James' Park.

At the bottom, Chester kept their third successive clean sheet to earn a point against Shrewsbury at the Deva.

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Vintage Clarets
fields.body:
Vintage Clarets

Burnley's decision to drop Ian Wright paid dividends as they rediscovered the winning feeling.

The Clarets, beaten twice at home in the previous seven days, won 1-0 at Wrexham, Andy Payton scoring the only goal for Stan Ternent's fifth-placed side six minutes into the game.

 Further up the table it was a good day for second-placed Preston, who halved Bristol Rovers' four-point advantage. Brett Angell, on loan from Stockport, got the only goal at Bournemouth three minutes into the second half as David Moyes' men took advantage of Bristol Rovers' 0-0 draw at Bury.

 Third-placed Millwall maintained their recent impressive run at Luton, Tim Cahill's first-half double giving them victory. The Luton manager Lennie Lawrence branded his team's performance "an absolute disgrace... We were swamped because Millwall outplayed us, outfought us and outbattled us".

 Wigan could manage only a 1-1 draw at bottom club Chesterfield after beating Blackpool 5-1 in midweek.

Stephen Payne gave the Spireites the edge in the 10th minute and Wigan had Scott Green sent off for violent conduct before the on-loan Terry Cooke earned the visitors a point seven minutes from time.

 Sixth-placed Stoke were held to a goalless draw by Notts County, lying seventh, and Gillingham capitalised at mid-table Bristol City, Andy Hessenthaler's 78th-minute goal being decisive.

fields.headline: First Division round-up
fields.trailText: Saddlers well
fields.body:
Saddlers well

On a day when of the top five only Barnsley managed a win, Huddersfield fell behind to lowly Walsall before Martin Smith's strike brought them a 1-1 draw at the McAlpine Stadium.

Siggi Eyjolfsson had given the Saddlers a shock lead midway through the second half. The point kept Huddersfield in the last play-off berth.

 The West Brom striker Lee Hughes took only 10 seconds of the match at Stockport to welcome Gary Megson to the club's hot seat.

Megson, appointed on Thursday to succeed Brian Little, saw Hughes give the Baggies a 1-0 victory against one of his former clubs.

 Two goals from Dean Holdsworth - the first a penalty - and a late strike from Eidur Gudjohnsen gave Bolton three points against Fulham at the Reebok. Lee Clark scored for the visitors.

fields.headline: Dons set up cup double
fields.trailText: Eoin Jess kept alive Aberdeen's hopes of a cup double with a late strike to shatter Dundee United's hopes for the second time in a month and book the Dons' place in the semi-final of the Scottish Cup with a 1-0 victory.
fields.body:
Eoin Jess kept alive Aberdeen's hopes of a cup double with a late strike to shatter Dundee United's hopes for the second time in a month and book the Dons' place in the semi-final of the Scottish Cup with a 1-0 victory.

The Scotland striker was making his first start since damaging ankle ligaments at St Mirren in the third round in February and did not disappoint with a cool finish when the game looked set for a replay.

The visitors already face Celtic in next week's CIS Insurance Cup final at Hampden Park, having beaten Dundee United in the semi, and now have a place in the last four of Scotland's top cup competition.

After a scrappy start, the visitors should have taken the lead in the 56th minute when Norwegian striker Arild Stavrum spurned the best chance of the game.

The Aberdeen boss Ebbe Skovdhal brought on Rachid Belabed in the 74th minute and it was the Moroccan's pass that set Andrew Dow racing down the left. His cross was aimed for Stavrum who took two defenders out with a dummy, leaving Jess with time to pick his spot past the United keeper Alan Combe.

webTitle: Wilson rhetoric lifts Owls winning nlifts Owls

fields.headline: Wilson rhetoric lifts Owls winning nlifts Owls
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday 3 - 1 West Ham
fields.body:
When Danny Wilson tires of football there will be no shortage of job offers. For instance Lord's could employ him outside Test grounds to drum up support. Nine wickets down, with England facing an innings defeat, Wilson is still ushering people in through the gates. "Come on, they can do it, I really believe they're going to win."

Before this game the Wednesday manager had set himself up for more ridicule, reiterating in his programme notes that his team's Premiership status will hold good for at least another season. This, from a starting position on Saturday morning ten points short of the safety mark. It was uncomfortable to see a sane man deluding himself.

For positive thinking Wilson's rhetoric takes some beating. "I would go as far as to say that I don't expect the lads to lose again all season... if we put a sequence of wins together, all of a sudden [the question is] do the teams immediately above us have what it takes to get the points they'll need when they're under pressure? In all honesty I am still very optimistic in spite of the way the league table looks at the moment."

Yet, as blindly optimistic as that sounded at 2.59pm, Wilson's upbeat message did strike a dressing-room chord. At least it did after half-time when Wednesday, one goal down, emerged from their feebleness to resemble something like a top-flight outfit.

It left them with seven points to make up on Derby, which is still a tall order. Even Wilson admits that. Four of the next five games are away from home and Leeds, Chelsea and Aston Villa have yet to visit this part of Yorkshire.

"Had we not won today the first paragraph of the obituary would have been written," said Wilson afterwards. "If we have everybody available we are a match for anyone."

The Hammers goal was typical of so many that have found their way into Wednesday's net. Pavel Srnicek caused panic with a poor attempt to push away John Moncur's cross and the ball eventually fell to Frank Lampard who drove in on the volley.

Paolo Di Canio had played a significant part in the construction and at least until halfway the Italian looked as if he would remember his return to Hillsborough with a great deal more pleasure than those who had come to abuse him.

However, Rio Ferdinand put too much faith in his own ability and tried to dribble his way out of trouble despite the proximity of two striped shirts. Richard Cresswell, a half-time replacement for the toiling Gerald Sibon, shot smartly on the turn. Hope was renewed.

Andy Hinchcliffe unleashed a ferocious shot from 25 yards and to cap an exhilarating ten minutes Craig Forrest then fumbled Niclas Alexandersson's half-volley over the line. Astonishingly Wednesday were two goals ahead and Harry Redknapp could not contain his fury.

"At half-time I couldn't see any way we wouldn't win the game," said the West Ham manager. "But then we wanted to show how clever we are."

It was a good afternoon for Wednesday and yet immediately after the final whistle the boos rang round Hillsborough once again. Di Canio was making his way down the tunnel and those who used to worship at his feet were only too glad to see the back of him.

webTitle: Swindon get lucky and do the business

fields.headline: Swindon get lucky and do the business
fields.trailText: Charlton 0 - 1 Swindon
fields.body:
Quite what Swindon Town's administrators were thinking after the bottom club produced this shock result is anybody's guess. Finding the money to pay win bonuses had not been a problem they had faced; now they have to pay up for two wins in a week.

"It's been very, very difficult this year; the wages have been late every month and at times we haven't known if we would have a club," said the manager Jimmy Quinn, referring to the decision to lay off 15 back-room staff in January and then call in Kroll Buchler Phillips to take care of business.

"The crowds have been down and there was a stage when they [the administrators] were talking about capping the wages," he added, "but thankfully the PFA came in to help."

So did last Tuesday's win against Huddersfield, Swindon's first for 19 games. But Quinn admitted that he would have been delighted with a point from this trip to the Valley, as the top-of-the table side were long odds-on to make it 13 league wins out of 13. "If we played Charlton 10 times we would probably lose nine, but suddenly we have given ourselves a chance [of staying up]."

However, Charlton should have won with plenty to spare even after their goalkeeper Dean Kiely contrived to bundle Steve Cowe's slow, low cross into his net despite the attentions of nobody in particular.

Charlton had a host of chances but, with the visitors packing the defence, Andy Hunt and Mathias Svensson missed theirs, Richard Rufus had a shot turned on to and over the bar and then blasted another over before, most culpably, John Salako shot wide with the goalkeeper grounded.

"We prepared in exactly the same way as always," said Alan Curbishley, Charlton's manager. "Nobody's been left in any doubt about anything, but we just couldn't get that break."

His only consolation was that Manchester City and Ipswich also lost, so Charlton's 12-point lead remains intact as they contemplate next weekend's trip to Maine Road.

"We'll have a couple of days' off, rest up and see what happens next Sunday," Curbishley added. "We're in a great position; we still have to win the majority of our games but it's a kick up the backside for one or two, myself included. But I feel pleased for Swindon with the problems they've had, and I hope the points will help them get out of trouble."

All very generous, and Charlton also had the decency to hand the £2,000 profit from their half-time raffle to Swindon to help them send a youth team to Ireland to contest the Milk Cup in July. Some comfort for the administrators, then.

webTitle: Rangers get serious to break Hearts

fields.headline: Rangers get serious to break Hearts
fields.trailText: Rangers 4 - 1 Hearts
fields.body:
Rangers made surprisingly hard work in claiming a place in the Scottish Cup semi-finals, going off the boil for lengthy spells in last night's quarter-final. Even if there was never any serious danger of the Edinburgh club winning, the holders seemed reluctant to put their visitors on the floor until two goals midway through the second period gave the result a more realistic scoreline.

After Celtic had been beaten last Wednesday to virtually secure the championship, the Rangers captain Lorenzo Amoruso said somewhat ominously, "and now we can concentrate on the Cup." It looked as if he was rubbing salt into an open wound, but early in this match it was clear he meant every word.

Hearts were stung with two goals in the first 17 minutes. Admittedly, Rangers' passing game was radar-like, but the visiting manager Jim Jefferies must have been tearing his hair out as a series of diagonal runs split his side open almost at will.

He was not short of bodies either. With Gary Naysmith and Thomas Flogel back in the side, Rangers had no right to expect to be given the freedom of the park. But they were, and they are far too talented a side not to take advantage of such disarray.

In the 12th minute Giovanni van Bronckhorst slipped a ball to the edge of the penalty area. Rod Wallace pulled away from his marker, sprinted to the by-line before turning the ball back across the face of goal for Barry Ferguson to tap home.

Five minutes later an exceptional goal doubled their advantage. Arthur Numan, deep on the left, began a reconnaissance and the Hearts defence, quite clearly waiting for an overlap to be orchestrated, bought the proposition. But the Dutchman changed gear, sprinted inside and hit a 15-yard shot which flew low past the former Rangers goalkeeper Antii Niemi.

Hearts may be having an average season but there was enough resilience about them to stage some kind of rally. They were helped by Rangers' complacency. In the 33rd minute Colin Cameron embarked on a lone forward run which seemed to be achieving little until Craig Moore brought him down. Cameron picked himself up to convert the penalty.

Their poise disturbed, Rangers would nevertheless have won out of hand had Wallace not wasted two perfect chances either side of half-time. But gradually their passing touch returned and they produced a scoreline which reflected the overall play.

In the 69th minute Van Bronckhorst arrowed a corner towards the near post and, in the crush of bodies, Amoruso appeared to make sufficiently strong contact to force the ball over the line.

Moments later, Flogel's tackle on the substitute Billy Dodds earned a penalty. After Jorg Albertz's misses in recent matches, the Rangers players hung around awkwardly looking for somebody to take it. Dodds, never the wallflower, put it safely into the net.

Rangers will face Ayr United in the semi-finals after last night's draw. The other tie pits Hibernian against Aberdeen.

webTitle: Money for nothing as Kearton prospers

fields.headline: Money for nothing as Kearton prospers
fields.trailText: Blackburn Rovers 0 - 1 Crewe
fields.body:
It was a day of contrasting fortunes for the Blackburn owner Jack Walker. Having discovered in his Sunday papers that his personal wealth is now valued at £500m, equal 44th in Britain with Sir Paul McCartney, he watched his beloved club slump to the most damaging result of a depressing season.

Money can't buy you love and, on this performance, can't buy Blackburn a place in the play-offs either. Last season they were representing the Premiership in the Uefa Cup; now eight points stand between them and a top-six finish in the First Division.

Colin Cramb's 80th-minute goal settled the outcome, but it was the breathtaking performance of Crewe's Australian goalkeeper Jason Kearton which undoubtedly won the points.

After numerous stunning saves, Kearton's role in the goal was appropriate. A deflection off his team-mate Dave Walton was crossing the line when he somehow twisted to scoop the ball to safety. From the ensuing break Mark Rivers sent Cramb ahead of the stretched Blackburn defence and the striker calmly converted.

"That's a game he's won for us," the manager Dario Gradi said of Kearton. "I think he grew a telescopic arm for one of the saves. We now have a very good chance of staying up."

A string of three saves inside four minutes early in the second half encapsulated Kearton's performance and Blackburn's inept, if highly priced, strike force. He somehow clawed back an Ashley Ward header before keeping out two terrific strikes from Keith Gillespie.

There were more to come, after an impressive string of first-half heroics. But on a day when thoughts, as is so often the case at Blackburn, were about money, it was refreshing that a free-transfer signing from Everton dominated the occasion.

fields.headline: Frazzled fans await Conference call
fields.standfirst: Third Division Carlisle finish a traumatic week down and out at No 92
fields.trailText: York City 1 - 1 Carlisle United
fields.body:
The world looks bleak from the bottom of the pile. Having witnessed an improved performance, a stunning goal and a spirited rearguard, the 552 away fans at the Grosvenor Road End on Saturday nevertheless left shaking their heads. "Typical Carlisle, that," one muttered. "We almost pulled it off but now we're no better off than before."

This point, gleaned through Steve Halliday's curled shot on the hour yet almost surrendered in York's late onslaught, was their first away from home since December 4. Cause for minor celebration maybe, but not enough to lift them from 92nd place in the Football League.

"We played much better today but it counts for nowt if we're still bottom," the fan continued. "We've got a good starting 11, but as for the rest... You could put my gran in there and she'd stand out as a good midfield grafter."

Given that Carlisle are in the league only because of a goal by the on-loan goalkeeper Jimmy Glass in the dying seconds of last season, their predicament is not unexpected.

Even by their standards last week was traumatic. The death of Chris Balderstone, whose 1974 penalty against Tottenham briefly took them to the top of the football ladder, was marked inappropriately by the club slipping to the bottom rung courtesy of Chester's draw at Plymouth on Tuesday.

"It's worse than last year," said another fan. "There's more apathy about; people are just saying 'sod it' and walking away. I'm just glad Chris didn't see us go down."

Balderstone was remembered with a minute's silence at Carlisle's midweek cup game against Rochdale. Some spectators came merely to pay their respects, leaving before the kick-off. Many blame the chairman Michael Knighton, the memories of promotions and Wembley trips during his eight-year tenure now tarnished by the prospect of Conference football next season.

"The Knighton years have been like going to university," said another fan. "You start penniless, you have a fantastic time for a few years, but you're penniless when you finish."

The general manager Martin Wilkinson considered quitting recently but was heartened by Saturday's performance. "That was D-Day," he said. "People have accused the lads of not playing for me and I take that as an insult. It's pressure and everyone's looking for a scapegoat: that's me."

For 80 minutes Carlisle were the better side. Spurred on by his goal, Halliday missed an easier chance and then hit the bar from 30 yards. But York's desperate late rally culminated in the substitute Barry Conlon's 86th-minute equaliser.

With three matches in hand and only a point behind Chester, all is not lost for Carlisle. But there is no Glass to save them this time. "I couldn't go through that again, but I don't think we'll be as lucky this season," added one fan. "Lightning doesn't strike twice."

fields.headline: Fine Flo and foul fortune
fields.trailText: Wolves 2 - 1 Ipswich
fields.body:
You could sniff the air around Molineux on Saturday evening and imagine that the auguries are evil for Ipswich. They swarmed all over Wolves but had nothing to show for it after running into Haavard Flo at the moment he came good and a referee whose unsteady judgment turned against them at the game's critical moment.

James Scowcroft had pulled a goal back after Flo had struck twice from unpromising positions when five minutes from the end Richard Naylor spun round Kevin Muscat in the penalty area and tumbled over an outstretched leg. The linesman raised his flag, but Michael Jones waved play on. Muscat himself, if Scowcroft is to be believed, said: "How he hasn't given that I don't know."

George Burley did not know either. "Everybody in the ground saw it was a penalty," said the Ipswich manager. "I thought it was a disgrace. I thought the referee was a disgrace."

It's a cruel game and here are the figures to prove it. Ipswich had 16 shots on target to Wolves's three. Ipswich may lack wingers but they still found ways around a Wolves team forced to spend much of the game lined up just outside their penalty area. Michael Oakes had to make some athletic saves, but Tony Mowbray, when offered a free header early in the second half, failed to test him.

File this result under aberration, then; like Charlton even the best and bravest should be allowed one.

fields.headline: Eclipsed by Given again
fields.trailText: Newcastle 1 - 0 Watford
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James' Park
fields.body:
You had to feel sympathy for Alec Chamberlain, the overworked Watford keeper who has endured more anguish than most Premiership performers this season.

His impeccable display was earning him a rare day in the spotlight, then along came Shay Given to relegate him to a bit part - and not for the first time. Given also relegated him to a place on the bench during the final three months of Sunderland's promotion to the Premiership four years ago.

Here, Chamberlain's series of first-class saves was eventually eclipsed by three from Given, but the Newcastle goalkeeper knows that Chamberlain will not bear a grudge. "It was good to work with Alec at Sunderland," he said. "I was there for three months [on loan from Blackburn] and took the first-team place away from him but he still supported me. He helped me improve and I owe him something."

Given's crucial contribution here came seven minutes into the second half when his brilliant reactions denied Allan Smart. Watford, the better team to that point, visibly faltered, somehow survived when Alan Shearer was guilty of one of the worst misses of his career, then succumbed to a well worked goal from Kevin Gallacher in the 59th minute.

"It was a vital three points," said Newcastle's manager Bobby Robson. "I'm not sure we are safe yet but we are close." In contrast Watford's fate is effectively sealed, although the resolve they showed yesterday will give hope for the future.

fields.headline: Curtis finds his true stage
fields.trailText: Barnsley 2 - 1 Man City
fields.body:
Old Trafford may be the Theatre of Dreams, but not if you are an aspiring player acting only as an understudy to Manchester United's all-star cast.

That has been the role of John Curtis, the England Under-21 defender on loan at Barnsley who put Dave Bassett's side on course for victory over their promotion rivals with his first senior goal. Curtis has three years left on his United contract but said: "There's so much talent there, and that's outside the first-team squad. It's still the dream ticket, I want to be a United player, but it's unlikely. It's awful playing for the reserves so I went to see the boss and pointed out I needed first-team football." Inside two weeks Sir Alex Ferguson told him Barnsley were on the phone and Curtis, 21, "jumped at the chance". "It's been great to play in front of proper crowds. My two ambitions now are to play in the Premiership and for Barnsley to do well, and they could turn out to be the same thing."

Barnsley moved above City into third place after Bassett left out Georgi Hristov, scorer of three goals in the previous two games, and restored Craig Hignett, who repaid his faith with the winner on the stroke of half-time. "It was a risk and if it hadn't come off everyone would have called me a complete idiot," said Bassett.

Shaun Goater scored a late consolation for the visitors but Barnsley deserved their victory despite the City manager Joe Royle's claims to the contrary.

fields.headline: Carbone throws down gauntlet
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 1 - 0 Coventry
fields.body:
John Gregory had just been extolling the virtues of Benito Carbone, pinpointing his ability to produce the unexpected, when the little Italian did just that. Emerging from the dressing rooms he read out a statement saying the uncertainty hanging over his Aston Villa career was "brutal" and that the chairman Doug Ellis "doesn't want me to stay".

Carbone seems sincere in this and several previous expressions of his desire to stay with Villa but he is increasingly frustrated about the delay in making his loan from Sheffield Wednesday a permanent move. "I also know four or five teams in Italy and Spain who want to sign me. If Villa don't want me they should let me know."

Ellis flatly denied blocking Carbone's transfer. "He's wrong to think that I don't want him here," said the chairman. "I do want him and the negotiations are ongoing."

Gregory conceded that the issue "has dragged on too long" but pointed out that the club were dealing with a small army of Carbone advisers. "The problem is getting everyone around the table all at once."

It is understood that the 28-year-old striker wants a three-year contract on £30,000 a week, making him possibly the highest-paid player at the club.

The Italian's statement was more dramatic than the one he had made on the pitch which, curiously, still won him the sponsor's man of the match award. He displayed a few delightful elaborations but the game only highlighted Villa's scoring deficiencies.

The award should have gone to a Villa defender, with Ugo Ehiogu pressing a claim with sound work at the back and a thunderous header for his first Premiership goal for more than a year. Villa boast the best defensive home record among the elite, but they were rarely stretched by a Coventry side who lost Robbie Keane at half-time with a recurrence of his knee injury.

Coventry have lost five out of six games and haven't scored in seven hours 12 minutes, and fighting a relegation battle on this form is giving Gordon Strachan sleepless nights.

It is not doing much for their Swedish goalkeeper Magnus Hedman either: "You start hiding in your house because you feel ashamed of yourself."

webTitle: Yorke polish puts gloss on dodgy motor

fields.headline: Yorke polish puts gloss on dodgy motor
fields.trailText: Manchester United 3 - 1 Derby County
fields.body:
Manchester United will be happy enough if their unerring ability to glean wins on off days necessitates stocking up on another crate of silver polish come the end of the season. But Saturday's performance will have provided ammunition for those who feel that the well-oiled machine requires some urgent fine-tuning.

Even though the bookmakers have all but given them the title, and despite the sight of Dwight Yorke flashing his full set of teeth for the first time in a long time, the feeling persists that the mechanism is labouring somewhat. Certainly of late it has been more like a vin tage car than a Ferrari: everything hunky-dory on the exterior but close inspection under the bonnet revealing a few rusty parts.

Apart from the World Club Championship, their recent deficiencies have gone largely unpunished. But as Sir Alex Ferguson will testify, the case for United's defence has been indefensible at times. So it was again here and for 20 uneasy minutes it threatened to hand Derby the game before Yorke, 75 days and 24,000 miles since his last domestic goal, ended a personal winter of discontent by completing his hat-trick.

Even so, this was the second successive home match that Ferguson has felt compelled to reshuffle his defensive pack after finding a joker or two. Mickaël Silvestre was banished from centre-half to left-back, having been as reliable as Silvester the Cat in the preceding 65 minutes. Gary Neville took the Frenchman's place and his brother Phil switched from left to right. Within 60 seconds Branko Strupar had scored for Derby.

"We need to eradicate some of the things we're doing in defence because we're taking unnecessary chances and there's some slack play," Ferguson smouldered. "At times Derby outplayed us. It's a lack of concentration, doing silly little things. But it's getting me more annoyed and frustrated because they are capable of better than that."

For someone not given to criticising his side openly, that is as close to a public flogging as will be heard during Ferguson's remaining days in office. He is clearly tired of trotting out the cliched line about the benefits of a team who win when they do not play well - even if it is true.

Certainly the chinks in United's armour will have been noted by the Fiorentina coach Giovanni Trapattoni as he prepares for a Champions League tete-a-tete with Ferguson at Old Trafford on Wednesday. His infiltrators in a record Premiership crowd - 61,619 - will have observed in particular that Silvestre has a tendency to wilt under pressure. Ferguson has tried to boost the Frenchman with public encouragement in recent weeks but may now decide that a period out of the firing line is the only workable option.

At least Italian minds will be occupied with the knowledge that Yorke is somewhere near his best again. Having played the part of a transatlantic commuter in recent weeks on Gold Cup duty, the Trinidadian bolstered his personal collection of match balls with a quick one-two shortly after Strupar's equaliser.

His clinical header and right-foot shot supplemented a first-half gift when he charged down Mart Poom's clearance and walked the ball into an empty net. Even though the Derby goalkeeper was to save Paul Scholes's penalty, the damage had been done.

fields.headline: Ince triggers Gunners meltdown
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 2 - 1 Arsenal
fields.byline: David Hopps at the Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
The big battalions are now lined up with intent to contest the third Champions League place, but the only sound this weekend has been of opportunities spurned.

Home draws for Chelsea and Liverpool presented Arsenal with a chance to go third had they beaten Middlesborough yesterday. But shorn of their all-English backline, plus the England goalkeeper David Seaman who departed at half-time, they lacked the resourcefulness to prosper.

If Middlesbrough's first goal, scored by Paul Ince three minutes into the second-half, ended a vague Arsenal ascendancy, then the second from Hamilton Ricard came when Arsenal's defensive chaos was at its height. An exquisite chip from Dennis Bergkamp 20 minutes from time ensured a frantic finale, but no recovery.

No away victory since December 4 tells its own story. "Our inconsistency away from home has cost us the championship," said Arsenal's manager Arséne Wenger. "But the short recovery period after European competition is a nonsense."

For Wenger, even an enactment of his football fantasy brought no release. He has been among those consulted as Fifa press for uniformity in European seasons and contends that summer football will become inevitable with England adopting a close season between November and February.

Teesside could not quite deliver summer but spring was abundant. The Cleveland Hills shimmered in the distance and Boro fans bared their beer bellies for the first time since September.

Fifa will no doubt get its wish - never underestimate the bureaucratic obsession with standardisation - but that ignores the fact that another mild English winter has been entirely conducive to football and that any rescheduling would make dark winter days even drearier. Wenger would probably pass them on a tropical beach.

This was a strange Arsenal: Emmanuel Petit back in central defence and Nigel Winterburn, complete with captain's armband, in central midfield. Neither looked happy.

The greatest surprise of all, however, was to see Ray Parlour imagine himself to be a flying winger between two defenders before thudding a 20-yard shot against Mark Schwarzer's right-hand post.

Arsenal's aerial shortcomings left them vulnerable against the likes of Ricard and Brian Deane. Twice Deane rose above Silvinho to meet crosses from the left, but his first header was grabbed by Seaman at the second attempt and his second flew wide.

However, Arsenal had most of the few creative moments before half-time. Thierry Henry, released by Nwankwo Kanu, shot against Schwarzer's legs and Kanu then almost stole in at the near post.

They never looked as impressive again. Seaman did not resume because of a cricked neck (the danger of a sloppy 70s hairstyle) and Alex Manninger had a tortuous start, beaten almost immediately by Ince's back-header after Curtis Fleming had headed back Christian Ziege's half-cleared corner.

Manninger then had no option but to fall on Freddie Ljungberg's back pass - Ziege blazing a hasty free kick over at the second attempt - and conceded a second goal when Andy Campbell's energy forced a wild pass inside from Patrick Vieira and Ricard nut megged Petit before finishing with rare subtlety.

Manninger's double-save from Ricard lifted his spirits and Arsenal could point to a disallowed goal for Henry and a possible penalty when Steve Vickers handled Petit's cross to claim that only their luck, not their spirits, was awry. That away record does not support their contention.

webTitle: Heskey's big day spoiled by Phillips

fields.headline: Heskey's big day spoiled by Phillips
fields.trailText: Liverpool 1 - 1 Sunderland 1
fields.body:
If it is fair to assume Liverpool invested a tidy sum in Emile Heskey so that he might wreak havoc at the heart of opposition defences, it is to be hoped that among the youngster's many attributes is an ability to look and learn.

Anfield has always tended to make what Scousers would term "outsiders" feel right at home and, irrespective of what happened once bullish Sunderland removed their iron fist from the velvet glove, this was always going to be Heskey's day.

He did well enough, marauding like the ultimate Sunday morning pub player to offer sufficient evidence to back up Gérard Houllier's view that, though far from the finished article, the 22-year-old has most of the qualities required to achieve greatness.

The red shirt of his new club suits Heskey in more ways than one: he looks slimmer, more lithe than in the unflattering blue of Leicester City. But at the moment - and possibly for the next 12 months or so - he may prove to be no more than a most useful addition to a side who are already hugely gifted, widely envied and properly lauded for the manner of their progress.

Houllier wants a burgeoning squad rather than simply to maintain a well-stocked first team, and in Heskey he saw not only enormous potential but a player openly coveted by those rivals he is seeking to overhaul.

In many ways Heskey is a most predictable striker but his great strength is that, even though those charged with shadowing him know precisely what he is going to do, they are usually incapable of halting his progress - a point underscored only three minutes into this fractured and feisty game.

The sight of Heskey rampaging towards him like a thirsty bull elephant en route to a water hole was exactly what the Sunderland full-back Chris Makin did not need after a week of public conjecture and debate about his dalliance with a B-list celebrity.

Having blocked Heskey's initial surge, Makin must have known the big man would turn through 180 degrees before heading for the byline; he knew but he couldn't stop him.

Well, he did stop him but only by hauling him down. The referee Graham Poll had no option but to award a penalty, which Patrik Berger duly converted.

"I think Emile had a great debut," said Houllier. "He showed many, many times what it is he can bring to the team. You must take into account that he had endured a troublesome week and that he only trained with his new team-mates for the first time on Friday."

It was down the flanks - right in the first half, left in the second - where Heskey was at his most diligent and enterprising. He rarely threatened down the centre, which left the marvellously game Erik Meijer hacking away unsupported at the rock face until the belated introduction of Michael Owen as a substitute.

It is to be hoped that Heskey absorbed for future reference every last second of Niall Quinn's performance at the sharp end of the Sunderland attack. Strong in the air and always sure-footed on the ground, Quinn was magnificent, causing Liverpool's celebrated centre-back pairing of Sami Hyypia and Stéphane Henchoz all manner of problems.

Strangely, the afternoon's last word went to neither Quinn nor Heskey but to Kevin Phillips, who blends better than any other English-born striker the conflicting character traits of gallant teamwork and vital selfishness.

After he had been recklessly brought down by the goalkeeper Sander Westerveld, Phillips rifled a late penalty high into the roof of the net to ruin Heskey's big day and remind everyone that money buys mere flesh and blood, not results and points.

webTitle: Cort in on the act as plot thickens

fields.headline: Cort in on the act as plot thickens
fields.standfirst: Three crucial points do little to clear up the Dons' off-field mysteries
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 2 - 1 Leicester
fields.body:
Three weeks of events bizarre even by the standards of a club who once tried to relocate to Ireland ended on Saturday with a much-needed victory on the pitch but further confusion off it.

Wimbledon's co-owner, paying a rare visit from Norway in an effort to stave off player unrest and allay fears about the club's future, arrived bearing gifts: a promise of a new ground and training facilities, plus money for transfers.

He also reaffirmed that the manager Egil Olsen does not have to sell players until Wimbledon are clear of relegation this season. However, Olsen revealed that Wimbledon are about £10m in debt, so the summer sale of players such as John Hartson and Ben Thatcher seems inevitable.

But selling big and buying small has long been a Wimbledon tradition. What is new is the uncertainty that has settled over the club.

Although relegation fears were eased by Saturday's victory over Heskey-less Leicester, who turned up in lethargic mood having already qualified for Europe via the Worthington Cup, Wimbledon's future stability has been in doubt.

Three weeks ago their self-styled "governor" Sam Hammam sold his remaining shares in the club and departed with a puddle-ducking from the players. Then, despite assurances from the new owners that no players would be sold, Thatcher was allegedly offered to Liverpool for £8m and Hartson was on the verge of being sold to Tottenham for £6m - with the "departed" Hammam reportedly conducting the transfer talks.

It has subsequently been alleged that neither the club's Norwegian owners nor Olsen had given permission for Hartson's transfer, which eventually fell through because of injury doubts. But the question remains: was Hammam working on his own initiative? And if so, why?

We may never know. But the mystery deepened the day after the Hartson deal collapsed, when Hammam was reported to have cleared out his office at Selhurst Park and the owners were forced to repeat their promise not to sell players. However, it turns out that Hammam has not cleared his office and on Saturday the little Lebanese businesman was there as ever, preceding the team out of the tunnel and back-slapping them off the pitch after the win.

When asked on Saturday to clarify who countenanced what over the Hartson transfer, Olsen declined the chance to exonerate his friend Hammam, saying only: "I won't answer any more questions about the Hartson case."

But the club's apparent willingness to sell Hartson has upset other players. The England Under-21 midfielder Jason Euell has asked for a transfer, accusing the club of losing its heart, and the highly rated striker Carl Cort has vowed to leave if Wimbledon go down.

Last Monday Olsen held a clear-the-air meeting with the players, who themselves initiated another get-together on Thursday. Then on Friday, at Olsen's suggestion, the club's co-owner Bjoern Gjelsten came to address the players.

"He was talking about money, about getting our own training fields and also a new ground in south London," said Olsen. "It is very important for the identity of the club to have a place of our own. So the ambitions are there and I think that was a real boost to the players."

However, Olsen then addressed the down side. "We are about £10m in debt at the moment," he admitted, "so we're probably going to have to sell sooner or later."

Should Wimbledon escape relegation they can look back on Saturday's game as a turning point after taking only four points from their previous seven games. They took the lead on 32 minutes when Euell was brought down in the area and Neil Ardley converted from the spot.

Leicester, brighter in the second half, equalised through Gerry Taggart's unmarked far-post header, but Wimbledon deserved their winner three minutes from time when Cort shot home from a corner. At the final whistle Gjelsten found himself cajoled on to the pitch by Hammam to join the celebrations.

webTitle: Sleepy Blues leave job half done

fields.headline: Sleepy Blues leave job half done
fields.trailText: Chelsea 1 - 1 Everton
fields.body:
Presumably Chelsea do want to finish in the top three. After another sleepy Saturday matinee at the Bridge, complete with understudies, it is tempting to wonder.

Though it is true that worse teams than Gianluca Vialli's technically correct side have won the European Cup, the safer route to next season's Champions League should not be ignored. And although an unbeaten run of 12 Premiership fixtures has left Chelsea better placed to take silver or bronze, they cannot afford many repetitions of the carelessness with which two points were tossed away against Everton.

For now Vialli's priorities are tomorrow's Champions League game against Feyenoord and, depending on the result in Rotterdam, Lazio at home on Wednesday week. Saturday's selection, which saw Tore Andre Flo and Gustavo Poyet start on the bench and Didier Deschamps and Marcel Desailly rested altogether, was therefore understandable.

Less easy to explain was Chelsea's failure to finish what they started. Maybe Everton deserved a point for a strong second half; certainly there is more backbone in Walter Smith's team nowadays. But Chelsea still had the talent to achieve a comfortable victory.

All right, George Weah was unfit which meant reuniting Chris Sutton first with Gianfranco Zola and later Flo, partnerships which have rarely worked, and Dan Petrescu's stealthy runs and astute centres were missed on the right. Yet playing Dennis Wise, Chelsea's most penetrating passer, on the same wing left the team looking ill-balanced.

In central midfield Jody Morris and Roberto Di Matteo locked horns with Mark Pembridge and Abel Xavier and only occasionally gave ground, but this suited Chelsea less than their opponents. With little coming from the flanks, Zola's tricks and Sutton's power in the air seldom disturbed Everton's centre-backs, David Weir and Richard Gough.

Much the same happened at the other end. Kevin Campbell's injury has left Everton with only two strikers, Danny Cadamarteri and Joe-Max Moore, both lightweights. From time to time Cadamarteri's speed caused Chelsea problems and midway through the first half he turned past Frank Leboeuf to find himself with a free run at goal, only to be let down by his first touch. Generally, however, Leboeuf and Emerson Thome were as unruffled as their opposite numbers.

Everton are about to sign Mark Hughes from Southampton. If Smith is expecting goals from the Wales manager he may be disappointed.

To accommodate another Hughes, Stephen, newly signed from Arsenal, Nicky Barmby switched from left to right on Saturday and demonstrated his versatility without looking like scoring. Indeed Everton reached half-time offering few hints of how they might save the match, having fallen behind near the half-hour.

Chelsea's goal was a result of instinctive execution rather than inspired planning. Zola nodded down a high lob and Di Matteo was blocked as he tried to turn towards goal, but the ball ran off Sutton to Wise and the Chelsea captain drove into the far corner of the net.

Wise's immaculate passing and his knack of stealing into scoring positions at the right moment remains one of the best features of Chelsea's football, along with Albert Ferrer's classical full-back play. But with Everton getting players forward, Chelsea were thrown on to the wrong foot immediately the second half began. In the 69th minute a long throw-in from Pembridge cleared Sutton and Gough as they rose together and the ball fell to Cadamarteri, who slipped it past Ed De Goey.

In stoppage-time Morris sent a header straight at Paul Gerrard. Vialli was right when he said his side's performance had contained good football. Unfortunately not enough of it was devoted to scoring goals.

fields.headline: Armstrong completes inside job
fields.trailText: Tottenham 7 - 2 Southampton
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
What a difference seven goals make. In the car park a whistling Alan Sugar signed autographs, probably on "Sugar Out" leaflets. A little earlier Chris Armstrong had been cheered to the echo. If this is what happens when Spurs try to sign John Hartson they should bring in Ronaldo for a medical next.

Having struggled all season to find the net, Tottenham found goals arriving like Frank Dobsons in the London mayoral contest. Steffen Iversen took the bubbly to go with his match ball but few could have begrudged Armstrong a glass of champagne.

The 28-year-old impressed not only with two well taken goals but with his courage and hard work. Ridiculed for missing an early open net, he refused to shrink. The goals followed, his confidence grew and he crowned it all with a delightful backheel. After the abuse he has taken from Spurs fans the Football Association might have understood had he shown a finger to one or two.

"I can go out and enjoy tonight a bit," he said, though he was not getting carried away. He has become the symbol of Spurs' deficiencies up front and knows that will be hard to change. "I will probably never answer all my critics," he said. "Maybe I will always be banging my head against a brick wall but I know I can handle the pressure.

"I have toughened up mentally over the past couple of seasons. As you get older you look at things in a different way. Maybe I wouldn't have played if John Hartson had signed. The crowd were on my side today but I have learned to wait until the next game." That is at Highbury.

Not surprisingly George Graham found Armstrong "extremely low" during a recent chat. This performance will help raise his spirits but the Spurs manager's search for strikers goes on. He praised Armstrong, said his performance belied the criticism but did not pretend he was the answer. Sticking with him has not been an act of faith. "I didn't have any other forwards," Graham explained.

He did not need any others here, though this was a ruthless Spurs performance rather than a brilliant one. Graham reckoned his players had looked more impressive in the first half of last week's 1-1 draw with Bradford but for once chances were taken rather than wasted. "It's been on the cards for a while," he said.

Southampton helped with their shambolic defending. Their manager Glenn Hoddle described it as "schoolboy" stuff, which was an insult to schoolboys. The last time a Graham team scored this many was in 1993-94, when Arsenal beat Standard Liege 7-0 in the Cup Winners' Cup.

Yet embarrassment probably does not explain why Armstrong showed so little emotion when he scored. More likely he is loth to celebrate with those who castigate him. "Inside," he said, "I was really happy."

Hoddle certainly was not. When Spurs beat Bristol Rovers 9-0 in 1977 he was in the team and scored. This was a humiliation, and a worrying one. Southampton were not as slick under Dave Jones but they were generally more solid. Jones may be wearing a wry grin.

Six of Southampton's remaining 10 matches are at home but here they were embarrassingly disorganised, allowing the full-backs and strikers too much space. Twice they took the lead, through Jo Tessem and the Moroccan debutant Tahar El Khalej, but each time they soon let Spurs back in. A Dean Richards own-goal was followed by a Darren Anderton finish, and before half-time Armstrong added a neat first-time shot and Iversen capitalised on an appalling failure to clear.

Armstrong clipped in his second from a cross by the outstanding Stephen Carr and Iversen completed his hat-trick with two late goals as David Ginola called the tune. Chris Marsden was lucky to stay on for two fouls on the Frenchman. "I thought the referee [Mark Halsey] looked unfit," Graham complained. A hard man to please.

fields.headline: Anelka tests Real's patience
fields.trailText: Real Madrid will hold an emergency meeting today to try to decide the future of Nicolas Anelka, who yesterday refused to train for a third consecutive day.
fields.body:
Real Madrid will hold an emergency meeting today to try to decide the future of Nicolas Anelka, who yesterday refused to train for a third consecutive day.

Real officials have confirmed unofficially that unless the moody France forward agrees to return to training he will be permanently suspended without pay and the club will commence internal disciplinary action to hit him harder in the pocket.

The former Arsenal striker is already being fined five million pesetas (£18,500) for every day he refuses to leave home, but from today the figure will be raised to eight times that amount.

Furious at Anelka's refusal to play football rather than his beloved PlayStation, Real's top brass are making more and more extreme statements. "The boy is sick in the head" was the president Lorenzo Sanz's terse analysis of the one-man strike. "Something does not turn around properly in his head, and we must make sure that it turns around again."

"We have seven years to play with him," said the vice-president Juan Onieva, meaning the amount of time before the striker's contract expires.

Real also want a full public apology. However, rather than patching things up with Anelka it is more likely that they will try to sell the Spanish league's most expensive player for around £7.4m. Marseille are understood to be a possible destination.

Given that the final instalment of Real's £23m transfer fee to Arsenal is not due until 2004, the Spanish club seem likely to face added financial difficulties.

webTitle: Relegation a rehearsal for the real thing

fields.headline: Relegation a rehearsal for the real thing
fields.trailText: Despite a victory over West Ham, which has never counted for much in the form book, the Sheffield Wednesday manager Danny Wilson remains longer odds-on than anything running at Cheltenham this week to become the first man to lead two clubs from the Premiership's promised land into the wilderness.
fields.body:
Despite a victory over West Ham, which has never counted for much in the form book, the Sheffield Wednesday manager Danny Wilson remains longer odds-on than anything running at Cheltenham this week to become the first man to lead two clubs from the Premiership's promised land into the wilderness.

Yet remarkably he has not received so much as a vote of confidence from the Wednesday board, let alone the suggestion that he should lock himself in the boot room with a service revolver. Nor, despite some rumbling from fans, has there been any call for Big Ron to launch another fire-fighting job.

In fact Wilson has been showered with so much approbation that one could be excused for believing that he is challenging Sir Alex Ferguson for the manager of the year award. Even after his side lost 8-0 to a struggling Newcastle in October the then chairman Dave Richards was unwavering in his belief that Wilson should stay in charge indefinitely.

Up the road at Bradford City, despite another damaging defeat by Leeds yesterday, their chairman Geoffrey Richmond sees no reason to reverse his decision that the manager Paul Jewell, who has also received more acclaim in defeat than many managers get for winning trophies, will not be sacked if the club return to the Nationwide League.

And at Watford, who already have both feet and an arm in the grave, it would be unthinkable that their manager Graham Taylor should be asked to leave. Which means we could, uniquely, see three demoted clubs beginning next season with the same managers.

Relegation has never been regarded as a career move, but the attitude of these clubs reflects the new realism among the lesser brethren of the Premiership, and not only those in the bottom few positions.

More than half the clubs in the top flight now begin each season with survival as their priority, and because they have abandoned all pretence that they are competing on a level playing field the easy fix of continually replacing the manager is no longer seen as a solution. This is clear from the astonishing stability at most Premiership clubs in recent years.

This season not one manager has been sacked. Ruud Gullit resigned at Newcastle when it was clear that he could not win his beauty contest with Alan Shearer, and Dave Jones was sent on gardening leave by Southampton because of the distractions of his impending court case.

Managers always complain that the most severe pressure is at the top, but patently that is no longer true. The ulcers have now been inherited by their colleagues in the Nationwide First Division, where an astonishing 12 clubs have changed manager in the past 12 months; many Premiership bosses are becoming almost as secure in their posts as civil servants.

There was no call for Harry Redknapp's resignation after the humiliation of losing to Wednesday and the 4-0 home thrashing by Everton a fortnight ago. Redknapp is already into his sixth year at Upton Park, as is Bryan Robson at Middlesbrough despite having nothing to show for trading on the transfer market with the abandon of Nick Leeson.

Gordon Strachan at Coventry has the loving approval of his employers, yet his side have failed to win a single away game this season and, after defeat at Leeds, he admitted to the press: "You guys might as well not have bothered coming."

Even Deadly Doug Ellis of Aston Villa has not sacked anyone since Ron Atkinson six years ago. Ellis even kept his dagger sheathed during a dreadful run under John Gregory earlier in the season. This is not so much loyalty as a question of where would he find a replacement?

Life may not be a rehearsal but the first season or two in the Premiership are increasingly seen as such by club directors. Thus Middlesbrough and Sunderland were able to return to the Premiership under the same management after relegation, a feat Alan Curbishley is about to emulate at Charlton.

Wilson, Jewell and Taylor should also get their chance to regroup if they are relegated, though if Wilson's old club Barnsley pass in the opposite direction it will be the ultimate test of the Wednesday board's resolve.

webTitle: The great pretenders: the inside workings of Labour's spin machine

fields.headline: The great pretenders: the inside workings of Labour's spin machine
fields.standfirst:
Programme editor, Peter Horrocks, reveals
         life in the glare of the government's media manipulators
fields.trailText:
The government often accuses the media of being obsessed with covering spin
         and government presentation, to the exclusion of issues of substance. But it's a
         criticism that's strange from this government, which believes in the crucial
         importance of presentation.
fields.body:
The government often accuses the media of being obsessed with covering spin and government presentation, to the exclusion of issues of substance. But it's a criticism that's strange from this government, which believes in the crucial importance of presentation.

In tonight's Panorama, Spin Doctors, we examine the use of spin in the NHS. John Ware reports how the use of PR has become not just an issue of media manipulation, but of direct relevance to the formation of policy. He concludes that the inflation of spending claims by the government has increased expectations of what Labour has done for the NHS since it came to office.

That meant that when the January NHS crisis hit the prime minster had to dip into his war chest to con vince the public that he was serious about changing the NHS. Now, that pledge has been downgraded to an aspiration, and the spin doctors are in a fierce debate trying to massage expectations of what Blair's promises on the David Frost programme meant.

Labour's concentration on presentation is vividly captured in Panorama's interview with Romola Christopherson, the former head of communications at the department of health. She says: `I think they have devoted an enormous amount of energy to that communications drive.' She reveals that she warned against the notorious triple counting involved in the government's announcement of a three year, £21bn spending plan on the NHS.

Christopherson says: `I certainly had reservations about it . . . The accusations of triple counting and the use of mirrors were accusations that I could anticipate.' She says she alerted ministers to the potential criticism, but in the end they decided to go ahead.

Like the Clinton team, Campbell and company are advocates of the `permanent campaign'. Blair has even described the war in Kosovo as having elements of a political campaign and he believes that an essential part of a campaign is good presentation.

In last night's BBC2 retrospective on Kosovo, Moral Combat, he told Allan Little: `It wasn't just a military campaign, it was also a propaganda campaign and we had to take our public opinions with us . . . I felt a bit like, you know, at the beginning of a big political campaign.'

If the Kosovo war was like a political campaign, Christopherson goes further. She says that for New Labour everything is like an election campaign: `I think they really have been in a campaigning mode, interestingly enough from virtually day one of getting into power.'

One of the tenets of that philosophy is that most voters pay almost no attention to political news, so to get messages through, they have to be repeated ad nauseam. Christopherson reveals the thinking: `I remember Alastair Campbell saying: `By the time you and me have got absolutely fed up to the back teeth with repetition, that's probably when it's beginning to get through to the wider constituency.''

Spin Doctors details how £20m for the new instant booking system for NHS patients has been announced on four separate occasions: in September 1998, November 1998, April 1999 and September 1999. On each occasion, the announcements talked of the service being `boosted' or `an extra £20m' or `a £20m boost'. None of the press notices at the time of the three repeated announcements made clear that this money had previously been made available. It is, of course, reasonable for the government to reiterate its message, but is it right when those announcements do not make clear that they are being repeated?

Whitehall civil servants have told Panorama that such statements are always cleared directly by ministers, who are keen that the words `modernised', `beacon', `extra' and `boost' are frequently used.

Clearly, the media techniques the government employs were used, although probably to a lesser extent, by the Tories in the past. There are also reasonable arguments to make for the professional implementation of information and you might expect to hear the health secretary making that case on tonight's programme. But, as we say in the trade, `he declined to appear'.

The battle over interviews is a vital one for broadcasters. Print can get away with not having on-the-record quotes, but TV and radio need interviewees. It is of particular importance for current affairs programmes to call the powerful to account. But ministers are increasingly careful about when to appear. It is no use researchers and producers arguing with government press officers that the public interest would be served by them coming on. They invariably ask: `What's in it for us?'

Of course, the Conservatives played this game very hard too. When I edited Newsnight from 1994 to 1997, predominantly in the Conservative era, government press officers would insist that ministers would not discuss directly with their Labour shadows. They wanted to be `lone and last'.

Labour, naturally, complained bitterly to us about the injustice of this, but the moment they were in power they immediately instituted a similar system. Just count the number of times that a minister discusses directly with his or her opposite number on Today or Newsnight. It's very much the exception.

For a pre-recorded programme, such as Panorama, the interviewing game is played at least as toughly. Cabinet ministers make a calculation about whether they want to appear. If they feel that a particular programme has little in it for them they may well put up a junior minister or decide that no one will appear.

As well as considering the merits of each case, the departments also take into account the track record of each programme. In some cases, New Labour can be very open. For instance, Downing Street has just announced that they will be granting access to Michael Cockerell to make a film about Number Ten's media operation. But Panorama is now very much out of favour (and this article won't help, but there you are).

Panorama's main offence has been three programmes we have done in the past year looking at devolution and Labour selection procedures in Wales, Scotland and London. The programme broadcast in December, The Blair Mayor Project, examined how the Labour party's London membership lists came to make their way from Millbank to Frank Dobson's campaign.

Margaret McDonagh, Labour's general secretary, complained about the programme repeatedly both in advance and after transmission. However, despite being responsible for the implementation of the rules for Labour's selection contests, she has always refused to be interviewed on this subject (or indeed on any other).

That does not prevent her complaining of bias. Of course, it might be that the perceived bias could be ameliorated by her appearing and making her case, but she decides not to. The BBC is then left in the Kafkaesque situation of responding to a complaint of bias, to which we cannot reply: `Well, why didn't you just come on the programme and explain yourself?' Our duty is to be fair, irrespective of whether interviewees appear.

This history of complaints against the programme certainly impedes us in our dealings with the highly co-ordinated government information machine. When BBC current affairs was making the Kosovo programme Moral Combat, we requested an interview with Blair, an interview which, given the outcome of the war, would probably be relatively benign for the government.

After many weeks, we had heard nothing from Downing Street. We then spoke to a press officer who explained the hold up. `We thought you were something to do with Panorama.' We explained that the programme was on BBC2 and was not therefore a Panorama. `Oh, that's all right then' said the press officer and the interview went ahead.

It no longer shocks me that the government machine plays such a blatant `favourites game'. But it may surprise viewers who believe that decisions about the presentation of information and the appearance of ministers on programmes is part of a compact with the public about their right to have information presented fairly and defended openly. That is increasingly not the case.

£#149;Peter Horrocks is editor of Panorama

fields.headline: Grammar lessons
fields.standfirst: The Ripon vote will not make the selective schooling issue disappear, writes education correspondent Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: Government policy on grammar schools has been put firmly under the spotlight in the last few days, after the decision by parents in Ripon, North Yorkshire, to retain academic selection at the town's historic grammar school and education secretary David Blunkett's subsequent comments on the issue.
fields.body:
Government policy on grammar schools has been put firmly under the spotlight in the last few days, after the decision by parents in Ripon, North Yorkshire, to retain academic selection at the town's historic grammar school and education secretary David Blunkett's subsequent comments on the issue.

If ministers had hoped that the Ripon result would make the grammar school issue go quietly away, they could not have been more wrong. Labour party activists strongly opposed to selection reacted angrily to Mr Blunkett's comments in a Sunday newspaper that he was not "hunting" grammar schools, and that his famous anti-selection pledge to party conference five years ago was "a joke". Television cameras captured for posterity those words, which were uttered with apparent sincerity: "Watch my lips, no selection, either by examination or interview, under a Labour government." The mystery was why it took him five years to claim that what is seen as a defining moment in a critical education debate was a bit of hilarity.

Now the most important question is what will happen to the remaining 165 grammar schools, and whether local parents who would like to see fully comprehensive education in these areas will have the time, energy and enthusiasm to follow the unsuccessful example of Ripon. Although petitioning is under way in some regions, far larger numbers of signatures are needed than in Ripon to allow a full-blown ballot to be triggered.

The government is probably hoping they will give up before they start. But with fresh doubt cast over ministers' real commitment to ending selection, parents may well be tempted to have a go. After all, if they don't, the government certainly won't.

Labour's proposals to allow parents to decide the fate of grammar schools through ballots were, of course, set out in its election manifesto, and it is sticking to the letter on that one. Whether it was right to put the fate of grammar schools in the hands of parents is one matter. But setting up a system so incredibly complicated that parents needed a degree in rocket science to understand it was hardly going to prompt a rush to the starting line.

The Ripon ballot was a small one, but in many ways a more difficult vote to win because the rules on voting eligibility gave disproportionate influence to parents living outside the borough and those with children at private schools. Even the pro-grammar school campaigners complained that the rules worked against them, as parents with children at both Ripon Grammar and the secondary modern were ineligible to vote.

In most other parts of the country a much larger proportion of genuinely local parents will be eligible to have their say. Now it remains to be seen whether they are deterred or encouraged by the Ripon result.

fields.headline: Grammar challenge
fields.trailText: With its chaps playing rugger in front of mellow old buildings and a stuffy-sounding head, Ripon Grammar seems beguilingly typical of Old Britain, ripe for the sort of reform which has painlessly destroyed hereditary peers and other such bunkum.
fields.body:
With its chaps playing rugger in front of mellow old buildings and a stuffy-sounding head, Ripon Grammar seems beguilingly typical of Old Britain, ripe for the sort of reform which has painlessly destroyed hereditary peers and other such bunkum.

So it may be, but the trap which was sprung on opponents of the grammar's selective entry stands on the other side of Clotherholme Road - Ripon College, which many of them routinely denounced as a dump, a secondary modern and a place for the little Yorkshire city's failures.

To slag off one local school may have been understandable but to damn the only other one was more than carelessness, and more seriously a denial of the dearest principles of those who believe in comprehensive education.

Any outsider conducted around Ripon College by its energetic head, Paul Lowery, sees within minutes what it is happening there: a turnround, and a transformation of a school which no longer accepts that it has to be content with being second best.

Scorn is heaped on this view by those who have grown up with the way things seem always to have been on Clotherholme Road, and who, very revealingly, are often loathe to use the new name of Ripon College and persist with the City of Ripon School label, which Mr Lowery and his governors symbolically abolished last year. Only time will tell if the College's drive and optimism can create excellence which makes the grammar an irrelevancy. But it certainly can be done.

Ripon parents too scared to commit to the College should pay a visit to King David's high school in Manchester, almost closed eight years ago because of awful results, but now top of the city's state school league table and taking pupils away from selective rivals including Manchester Grammar.

Or they can simply come down the A658 to my own sons' school, Benton Park (or Boston Spa, or Garforth Community College, or Prince Henry's, Otley, or St Mary's, Menston, or Guiseley Fieldhead) which make Leeds Grammar School a waste of any hard-headed Yorkshire parent's money.

Of course, Leeds and Manchester do not have the 11-plus and, of course, that list of Leeds comps is largely drawn from leafy suburbs. But the monstrous old exam is best dealt with by being ignored; not abolished but condemned to death by disuse. No parent has to put their child through it.

As for leafiness, what the heck else is Ripon, whose tree-obscured boundary signs accurately demand that you "rest awhile amid its ancient charms"?

The unused catalyst of change in the city is confidence, or rather the lack of it which drives the parents of some 400 children who do boycott the 11-plus to then send their children 12 or 15 miles to the outstanding comprehensives in Harrogate and Knaresborough.

It would be impertinent to challenge any argument that your own child is too precious to risk on an educational gamble like the optimism of Paul Lowery & Co. But it has to be recognised that this is exactly the argument which supporters of selective education use against comprehensives.

Joshua Rowe MBE, chair of governors at King David's, was accused of infanticide eight years ago, when he insisted that governors should lead the planned turnround by sending their own children to the "failure and dump". His daughters led the way and are now both at Cambridge university.

There must be a Joshua in Ripon, which has two other advantages of which King David's could only dream. Affluent North Yorkshire is a world away from Upper Broughton, where Rowe's school slums it in the usual grotty Sixties campus plastered with chewing gum gobs. And North Yorkshire, unlike Manchester and Leeds, is one of the best local education authorities in Britain.

The defeated party in Ripon is now predictably blaming prep school parents, the weird selectorate and other plausible factors in their trouncing. But their inquest would do better to consider the biblical admonition to "ye of little faith".

The city's Conservative MP, David Curry, whose father taught at the old City of Ripon, speaks tellingly of people who "seemed to want the College to be frozen forever in the Grammar School's headlights". He and Mr Lowery - and the parents who opt out of the city where they live - have got five years to prove the point before the issue can go to ballot again.

But it has to be recognised that this is exactly the argument which supporters of selective education use against comprehensives. Joshua Rowe MBE, chair of governors at King David's, was accused of infanticide eight years ago, when he insisted that governors should lead the planned turnround by sending their own children to the "failure and dump". His daughters led the way and are now both at Cambridge university. There must be a Joshua in Ripon, which has two other advantages of which King David's could only dream. Affluent North Yorkshire is a world away from Upper Broughton, where Rowe's school slums it in the usual grotty Sixties campus plastered with chewing gum gobs. And North Yorkshire, unlike Manchester and Leeds, is one of the best local education authorities in Britain. The defeated party in Ripon is now predictably blaming prep school parents, the weird selectorate and other plausible factors in their trouncing. But their inquest would do better to consider the biblical admonition to "ye of little faith". The city's Conservative MP, David Curry, whose father taught at the old City of Ripon, speaks tellingly of people who "seemed to want the College to be frozen forever in the Grammar School's headlights". He and Mr Lowery - and the parents who opt out of the city where they live - have got five years to prove the point before the issue can go to ballot again.

fields.body:
The resignation of Torsten Friedag at Islington Arts and Media School exposes the damage done to schools by the government's policies for dealing with so-called failing inner-city schools. Staff at George Orwell had to cope with pupils consistently demoralised by bad publicity after the school was named and shamed. When the closure was announced, parents and pupils joined staff in a campaign to save it. They saw a supportive environment with caring staff committed to the achievement of all pupils.

The then Blairite Islington council was prepared to let the school rot (literally) so an example could be made under the fresh start scheme. Experienced staff were made to feel unwelcome in the new school and were turned down for jobs. Rather than "benefiting" from new personnel, the school suffered from lack of continuity. Stability and structure were sacrificed for soundbite. The result was chaos - increased truancy, vandalism and discipline problems. It was not a fight last October over a bag of chips that defeated Mr Friedag. He was a victim of the very politics he so eagerly embraced - the attempt to blame teachers and unions for poor results rather than direct resources to where they are most needed.

There was an alternative: to bring in new staff to work alongside George Orwell staff without the chaos of closure and reopening. Staff, parents and pupils could have spent £8m building a successful comprehensive school with the interests of pupils, not political spin-doctoring, at heart.

Sue Caldwell
NUT representative, Islington Arts and Media School

webTitle: Why we chose a private education

fields.headline: Why we chose a private education
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: I am one of the state-educated parents who sent their children to private schools in the 80s and 90s. The reason was not because the state schools were short of money and resources but because the type of education offered by them seemed very limited and, in fact, harmful. The emphasis was very much directed towards the needs of the lower-ability children. Experimental reading schemes were introduced and very little importance given to learning basic academic skills.
fields.body:
I am one of the state-educated parents who sent their children to private schools in the 80s and 90s. The reason was not because the state schools were short of money and resources but because the type of education offered by them seemed very limited and, in fact, harmful. The emphasis was very much directed towards the needs of the lower-ability children. Experimental reading schemes were introduced and very little importance given to learning basic academic skills.

My children were very bright and like many other middle-class parents, I felt they would not be stimulated, challenged or rewarded for their talents. There certainly was a feeling of "levelling down" in the educational ideas which, unfortunately, were being promoted at the same time as comprehensive schools. To many of us these two became linked and made us search for something like the grammar education which had served us well, This meant we had to turn to private schools which had been free to resist the "progressive" educational ideas.

Nest Adams

Oxton, Merseyside

 I had to laugh, on reading Nick Davies's report, that I am one of the "rich and powerful", because I send my children to private school. I consider myself to be neither of these, like many parents, I was committed from the outset to the state system, but gave up after three years, feeling thoroughly let down. I now feel that it is disgraceful that I must fork out for the kind of excellent education which should be freely available to everyone. I know of many parents who are scrimping in, order to get their children through public school with mothers working as cleaners and childminders in order to pay school fees.

Beverley Trounce

Hove, East Sussex

 Resourcing issues are being addressed, according to David Blunkett. My old public school has recently opened a £1.25m sports complex for 500-plus boys. How many state schools aspire to such opulence? Nick Davies rightly points out the private sector has never been subjected to such legal imperatives as the national curriclum. Every change made by politicians to the running of state schools, and there have been many in the last 12 years, has created further pressures, tensions and stress within these schools.

Keith Butler

Fareham, Hants
