fields.headline: The unkindest cuts of all
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Nick Davies (Schools in crisis, March 7) sheds some light on the obscurities of school funding. In Stockport our ability to deliver anything like the government's headline level of increase has been at the expense of cuts in other council services. Davies exposes some of the myths of the standard spending assessment, but not the discrepancies between LEAs. Parents here find it hard to understand why their children are deemed to be worth £250 a year less than those in apparently comparable boroughs in the south-east.
fields.body:
Nick Davies (Schools in crisis, March 7) sheds some light on the obscurities of school funding. In Stockport our ability to deliver anything like the government's headline level of increase has been at the expense of cuts in other council services. Davies exposes some of the myths of the standard spending assessment, but not the discrepancies between LEAs. Parents here find it hard to understand why their children are deemed to be worth £250 a year less than those in apparently comparable boroughs in the south-east.

We will be spending at 3% above SSA. Our pupils deserve better, but there are limits to the sacrifices other services and council tax payers can be asked to make to redress the unfairness of a discredited system. That is why we are part of the Forum for Fairer Education Funding - the grouping of the 40 worst funded LEAs which hopes to influence the current review of these issues.

Cllr Mark Hunter

Chair of education, Stockport

 Here in Haringey education spending had been "passported" following a critical Ofsted report. This has meant diverting cash from other budgets, and most from social services which suffers total cuts of £3.2m in 2000-01 and £4m in 2001-02. The result is that education for mainstream children is safeguarded whilst services for vulnerable children with disabilities and in care - not to mention adult disabled and elderly - are made to suffer. The council's social services budgetary strategy is in no doubt that, "there needs to be an absolute reduction in the level of care provided to existing clients". This will affect a wide range of children's services such as residential, respite, rehabilitation and under-fives, and in time generate extra costs and lower standards.

Martin Hewitt

London

m.hewitt@herts.ac.uk

 Having quashed Nick Davies's concerns about education spending (Comment, March 10), I trust David Blunkett will now reply to our headteachers' letter wondering why all secondary schools in Northumberland are facing budget cuts next year.

Mark Robson

Morpeth, Northumberland

fields.headline: Blunkett defends 11-plus stance
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's education policy was plunged into confusion yesterday as it was forced to clarify its position on grammar schools after an embarrassing row over selection.
fields.body:
The government's education policy was plunged into confusion yesterday as it was forced to clarify its position on grammar schools after an embarrassing row over selection.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, insisted that Labour was opposed to grammar schools, dismissing claims by the party's former deputy leader Roy Hattersley that he had mislead members about his real plans when he famously pledged to end selection five years ago.

The row was triggered after parents in Ripon, North Yorkshire, voted decisively in the first ballot of its kind to retain academic selection at the city's historic grammar school. The result, by a two-thirds majority, was declared on Friday night, under new legislation introduced by Labour giving parents the right to decide the fate of Britain's surviving 166 grammar schools.

In a Sunday newspaper article, Mr Blunkett said the government was not "hunting" grammar schools, explaining that the priority was to focus on the broader standards agenda. He said his words at the 1995 Labour conference, when he told delegates: "Watch my lips, no selection, either by examination or interview, under a Labour govern ment," were "a joke".

But Lord Hattersley, who has been the most high-profile senior member of the Labour party to campaign against selection and grammar schools, said Mr Blunkett's explanation was "crass". He accused the education secretary of shifting his position and misleading party members. "Five years ago the man who is now secretary of state made a statement on which he has relied ever since," Lord Hattersley said. "Now he says it was a joke."

Mr Blunkett said that the media and some senior politicians had "completely lost their marbles". He explained that the first part of his comment was a parody of President George Bush's pledge on taxes. Sources added that Mr Blunkett had actually meant to say "no further selection", but had made a mistake during what was a highly-charged conference debate.

Yesterday the education secretary went on to explain that the government would stick to its policy on grammar schools, despite his own personal opposition to the 11-plus.

"We are against the 11-plus and we remain against it. But we aren't in favour of putting this issue over standards. The total commitment and energy of the government will go behind raising standards in all schools." Mr Blunkett said that although parents had voted against change in Ripon, "it doesn't mean that there won't be [change] elsewhere in the future."

Later in the week the government will use its standards-raising agenda to justify plans to extend the school day by up to two hours. In a speech on the future of secondary education on Wednesday, Mr Blunkett will say it is no longer acceptable for schools to send pupils home halfway through the afternoon, and he will propose that pupils longer to take part in sports and art activities and even supervised homework sessions.

In the speech to a conference organised by the Social Market Foundation thinktank, Mr Blunkett will announce a series of initiatives to help raise standards in secondary schools, including closer links with primary schools to help prepare youngsters for the transition. An expansion of the summer school programme will also be announced.

The Tories accused Mr Blunkett of hypocrisy and creating division. Theresa May, shadow education secretary, said: "He wants to hide behind decisions taken in local ballots. He wants to get rid of grammar schools, but he knows that parents want them to remain. By hiding behind ballots, which are creating enormous division, he is just being a hypocrite, while placating the left of his party by saying he is still against selection."

fields.headline: Lies and Lib Dem statistics
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Labour has fielded two defences against Nick Davies's captivating articles. Jeff Hanna (Letters, March 9) admitted that the calculations behind the government's record on education spending are electoral not mathematical. He accuses Nick Davies of failing "to acknowledge [the government's] in-built restraint on spending [based on] the electorate's desire for low taxes".
fields.body:
Labour has fielded two defences against Nick Davies's captivating articles. Jeff Hanna (Letters, March 9) admitted that the calculations behind the government's record on education spending are electoral not mathematical. He accuses Nick Davies of failing "to acknowledge [the government's] in-built restraint on spending [based on] the electorate's desire for low taxes".

The secretary of state's defence (Comment, March 10) was notable for its omissions. Given every opportunity to confirm that spending will be £19bn higher in 2002 than it was in 1998, he failed to do so. I hope the government will never again repeat that now-discredited number.

We are discovering ever more glaring discrepancies between government expenditure plans and spending outcomes. As this parliament moves into its latter stages, parents, pupils and teachers are entitled to some explanation of the present grim reality, rather than being given more visions of a future that never seems to arrive.

I won't revisit the telling statistics in Nick Davies's article, many of which were based on Liberal Democrat parliamentary questions. But it is a lie that our election pledge would have delivered less than Labour has done. If revenues from 1p on income tax had been added to current spending, £900m more would be invested in education in 2002 than under Labour's plans. If we were to join in Labour's mathematical conjuring we would call it £6.6bn higher - but that's a mistake we do not intend to make.

Phil Willis MP

Lib Dem education spokesman

fields.trailText: Let's test Chris Woodhead's hypothesis that the excellent results in private schools are the result of good teaching, and not the generous resources, selection procedures or smaller classes. Mr Woodhead should persuade our colleagues in the private schools to transfer their skills into the state schools with the poorest results. fields.headline: Reversals in Ripon and Islington
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: I write as a victim of the 11-plus, saddened to hear the Ripon Grammar school decision (School wins fight, March 11). Forty years ago I failed; I was not prepared by my teachers. That sense of failure and the awareness that at age 11 I was sidelined is with me to this day. At secondary modern access to the hard sciences, particularly physics and chemistry, was denied to me. There were no teachers, they cost too much money. Similarly French and Latin were not taught. I went to night school to pass O-level French.
fields.body:
I write as a victim of the 11-plus, saddened to hear the Ripon Grammar school decision (School wins fight, March 11). Forty years ago I failed; I was not prepared by my teachers. That sense of failure and the awareness that at age 11 I was sidelined is with me to this day. At secondary modern access to the hard sciences, particularly physics and chemistry, was denied to me. There were no teachers, they cost too much money. Similarly French and Latin were not taught. I went to night school to pass O-level French.

How can we even be discussing the continuance of this iniquitous system which decides at the age of 11 that a child is a failure? Are we going to continue throwing away our future talent on the basis of a single examination held when a child is still developing?

Dr RW Tucker
London
patucker@burton-villa.co.uk

 You admit that "neighbourhood schools will generate more inequality, since neighbourhoods are unequal" (Leader, March 9). You say we need to find "new ways of widening catchment areas", and support specialist schools for technology, modern languages and sport. Schools for children who are good at maths, physics, chemistry, English, history, geography and the rest, ie specialist schools for the academically able (otherwise known as grammar schools), are, one assumes, not on your list of catchment-widening devices, for that would be to label the rest as failures.

In short, if you're good at something which is not too popular, you get to choose, perchance to escape your area. But if you have the temerity to be good at most things, too bad, because your services will be needed to raise the morale of all those kids who might think they have failed if you're not sit ting alongside them to remind them of how much they have to catch up.

CR Owen
Birmingham
familyowen@compuserve.com

 The choice in Ripon was between a selective system that realises the potential of bright children at the expense of the majority labelled failures at 11, and a comprehensive system that holds back the brightest in the interests of integration and fairness for all. This is a valid issue for all families with children in the state primary system who face that choice to decide. The 5% of fee-paying parents should not have taken part, let alone had 25% of the votes: they get selective education for free for children who pass the 11-plus and just go on paying for selective education for those that don't.

John Stockdale
Lewes
john@plantpress.com

 So Mr Blunkett does not think comprehensive education worth worrying about? "No selection" is not his policy. Does he not see that raising standards in many schools depends upon able students not being "creamed off" by grammar schools which thus creates sink schools with a culture of failure? Isn't that the whole point about the resignation of a "superhead" who was unable to turn round a "failing" school?

Dave Powicke
Minster on Sea, Kent
DPowicke@aol.com

 At least Livingstone didn't try to weasel his way out of going back on his word.

Richard Tosswill
Workington, Cumbria

Staff at George Orwell had to cope with pupils consistently demoralised by bad publicity after the school was named and shamed. When the closure was announced, parents and pupils joined staff in a campaign to save it. They saw a supportive environment with caring staff committed to the achievement of all pupils.

The then Blairite Islington council was prepared to let the school rot (literally) so an example could be made under the fresh start scheme. Sue Caldwell

NUT representative, Islington Arts and Media School
fields.bodyText: I write as a victim of the 11-plus, saddened to hear the Ripon Grammar school decision (School wins fight, March 11). Forty years ago I failed; I was not prepared by my teachers. That sense of failure and the awareness that at age 11 I was sidelined is with me to this day. At secondary modern access to the hard sciences, particularly physics and chemistry, was denied to me. There were no teachers, they cost too much money. Similarly French and Latin were not taught. I went to night school to pass O-level French. How can we even be discussing the continuance of this iniquitous system which decides at the age of 11 that a child is a failure? Are we going to continue throwing away our future talent on the basis of a single examination held when a child is still developing? Dr RW Tucker London patucker@burton-villa.co.uk  You admit that "neighbourhood schools will generate more inequality, since neighbourhoods are unequal" (Leader, March 9). You say we need to find "new ways of widening catchment areas", and support specialist schools for technology, modern languages and sport. Schools for children who are good at maths, physics, chemistry, English, history, geography and the rest, ie specialist schools for the academically able (otherwise known as grammar schools), are, one assumes, not on your list of catchment-widening devices, for that would be to label the rest as failures. In short, if you're good at something which is not too popular, you get to choose, perchance to escape your area. But if you have the temerity to be good at most things, too bad, because your services will be needed to raise the morale of all those kids who might think they have failed if you're not sit ting alongside them to remind them of how much they have to catch up. CR Owen Birmingham familyowen@compuserve.com  The choice in Ripon was between a selective system that realises the potential of bright children at the expense of the majority labelled failures at 11, and a comprehensive system that holds back the brightest in the interests of integration and fairness for all. This is a valid issue for all families with children in the state primary system who face that choice to decide. The 5% of fee-paying parents should not have taken part, let alone had 25% of the votes: they get selective education for free for children who pass the 11-plus and just go on paying for selective education for those that don't. John Stockdale Lewes john@plantpress.com  So Mr Blunkett does not think comprehensive education worth worrying about? "No selection" is not his policy. Does he not see that raising standards in many schools depends upon able students not being "creamed off" by grammar schools which thus creates sink schools with a culture of failure? Isn't that the whole point about the resignation of a "superhead" who was unable to turn round a "failing" school? Dave Powicke Minster on Sea, Kent DPowicke@aol.com  At least Livingstone didn't try to weasel his way out of going back on his word. Richard Tosswill Workington, Cumbria The resignation of Torsten Friedag at Islington Arts and Media School exposes the damage done to schools by the government's policies for dealing with so-called failing inner-city schools. Staff at George Orwell had to cope with pupils consistently demoralised by bad publicity after the school was named and shamed. When the closure was announced, parents and pupils joined staff in a campaign to save it. They saw a supportive environment with caring staff committed to the achievement of all pupils. The then Blairite Islington council was prepared to let the school rot (literally) so an example could be made under the fresh start scheme. Experienced staff were made to feel unwelcome in the new school and were turned down for jobs. Rather than "benefiting" from new personnel, the school suffered from lack of continuity. Stability and structure were sacrificed for soundbite. The result was chaos - increased truancy, vandalism and discipline problems. It was not a fight last October over a bag of chips that defeated Mr Friedag. He was a victim of the very politics he so eagerly embraced - the attempt to blame teachers and unions for poor results rather than direct resources to where they are most needed. There was an alternative: to bring in new staff to work alongside George Orwell staff without the chaos of closure and reopening. Staff, parents and pupils could have spent £8m building a successful comprehensive school with the interests of pupils, not political spin-doctoring, at heart. Sue Caldwell NUT representative, Islington Arts and Media School

fields.headline: Parkes-y, Sparky and Sarky
fields.trailText: PARKES BENCHED
fields.body:
PARKES BENCHED

Tonight Blackburn Rovers boss Tony Parkes will be buried deep inside the cavernous Ewood Park library, looking up words in a dictionary. Words such as "caretaker" (definition: a managerial position when held by Tony Parkes) and "full-time" (definition: the employment status of every manager in football. Except Tony Parkes). He may look up other words too, but the Fiver is a family publication.

And who can blame Mr Parkes when, according to this morning's papers, his job has been offered to former Southampton and Torino boss Graeme Souness only a few months after he signed a contract with Rovers until the end of the season? In another eerie coincidence Bruce Rioch, former Arsenal boss and oft-mentioned candidate for the Rovers hotseat, has today resigned as manager of First Division make-weights Norwich City. Would you believe it?

Rovers themselves are not revealing whether they believe it or not. Like all smart clubs they have refused to comment on "media speculation". Which means the Fiver will have to do it for them. Ahem. If things go to form, the pathetically supported but well-endowed Lancashire club will recruit either Souness or Rioch as their new manager. They will dutifully spend £20m on new players. They will not achieve very much with this money. They will be sacked. Then Tony Parkes will step in as, erm, caretaker. Simple, isn't it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

OLD ON A MINUTE

Like many others with a less-than-chiselled physique the Fiver stood up to applaud Neville Southall's appearance for Bradford yesterday. Actually "stood up" is stretching it a little, but we did readjust our jogging pants in salute to the 41 stone [surely "year-old"?] custodian's performance. It was a bold wobble forward, not only for the obese, but for the old too, and one greying Mark Hughes is not frightened to exploit.

Mark Hughes has always been Mr Zeitgeist, since he dared to sport tight shorts and a tight perm at the same time during a league match in 1985. So it comes as no surprise to find him jumping on the oldie bandwagon and heading for upwardly-mobile Everton at the age of 36. Said Toffees manager, and Help the Aged stooge, Walter Smith: "Mark may be 36 but he has shown he is capable of playing like he can at any time in his career." Which must be stretching it a little.

Striker-turned-midfielder Hughes looks likely to be offered a 12-month contract at Goodison Park, where he will join 37-year-old Richard Gough and 38-year-old Dave Watson. Smith believes that the trio, along with fellow thirty-something John Collins, can add some necessary savvy to the side. "We need a more experienced player up front," he said. "And Mark is one of those who has an influence on players around him." Francis Jeffers was gluing on a chest wig at the time of going to press.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I can enjoy my time out with the wife a bit more than usual tonight." Profligate Spurs striker Chris Armstrong after scoring twice at the weekend. You wonder whether his wife has him on some sort of incentive scheme.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NURSE! THE TREPANNING EQUIPMENT!

The Fiver wonders whether Nicolas Anelka will still be playing football at 41. The lonely one's four-day strike came to an end today as he agreed to train for Real Madrid. By himself, naturally. Nic will also have to explain his constant sulking at an extraordinary meeting with the club's directors this evening. He is expected to tell that nice Lorenzo Sanz that it's all Steve McManaman's fault.

However, it seems that the man with more self-confidence than a bunch of bankers at the races could be heading for a fall. Madrid coach Vincente del Bosque has said: "He is just confused, lives in a world of his own and will have to get out of it," while Sanz, the club's chairman has declared Lonely Nic to be of unsound mind. "Something does not turn around properly in his head, " said Sanz this weekend, "and we must make sure that it turns around."

The Spanish press suggests that to achieve this goal, Real will fine Nic a quarter of his annual salary (probably about £1,000,000,000m) for his recent misdemeanours. Rumours also have the man whose best friends are ghosts on the move to Marseille in the summer for £7m. Another solution could be to drill a little hole in Lonely Nic's skull and attach some kind of handle. Not only would this control his temperamental urges but it would also provide something to hold on to in the (unlikely) event of Nic straying into an offside position.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Liverpool are at the head of the queue to sign 18-year-old River Plate starlet Andreas D'Allessandro.

Mark Viduka will not be leaving Celtic, according to his agent. The Australian striker had been linked with a move to various Premiership sides, but says his representative Bernie Mandic: "I keep getting asked what the situation is with Mark Viduka at Celtic and I keep telling them he has got another three years to go at Parkhead."

Middlesbrough are not expected to sign Juninho on a permanent basis after the Brazilian's less than scintillating form since his return to the Riverside.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Norwich City's statement on the resignation of Bruce Rioch. "Following an approach from first team manager Bruce Rioch and subsequent discussion, the Board and the first team manager have agreed to end his contract with the club with immediate effect. Whilst the Board was surprised and disappointed at this development, which was not expected, the Board and Bruce agree that it is now in the best interests of the club and Bruce to part company."

Sunderland and Scotland winger Allan Johnston has signed a pre-contract agreement with Glasgow Rangers. "Everyone knows I have supported Rangers since I was a boy, " said Johnston, "This is a dream come true for me."

Kanu has signed his new contract at Arsenal, thought to be worth around £25,000-a-week.

Sheffield United midfielder Michael Brown, 23, and Stockport defender Tony Dinning, 24, have been charged with public order offences following an incident in The Living Room bar in Manchester.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MMMMMM, HOLIDAYS

We're on the ball! travelstore.com, the new revolutionary online travel service offers complete online flight, car and hotel booking facilities.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Sports Show (11.30pm) Can anyone imagine Eamonn Holmes playing a sport? If so, which one?

Big Cup weekly (12.35am) Is it really only seven days since we were last bored to the high-teeth by Europe's premier competition? Oh yes, so it is.

Channel 5: Dutch football (4.20am) It's Herenveen v Feyenoord. If the players remember to set their alarm clocks that is.

Sky Sports 1: World Football show (6.30pm) Kind of like a trade fair, but without overhead projectors.

Football League review (7pm) This week Andersen size up the Nationwide's opportunity for real growth in the next quarter.

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (10.30pm) This week they have mainly been scoring in... Andorra.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: American Beauty picks up more awards, Blair Witch trickery strikes again, Elizabeth Taylor to be immortalised as a doll, and Helen Baxendale and Johnny Depp on the casting couch
fields.body:
 With voting underway for the Oscars in just under two weeks' time, American Beauty has had its chances of Academy success bolstered by its winning two more awards this weekend. Sam Mendes picked up the award for Outstanding Directorial Achievement in a Feature Film from the prestigious Directors Guild of America on Saturday, while last night Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening were given top acting honours from the Screen Actors Guild for their portrayal of the black comedy's dysfunctional suburban couple. The film also won the guild's award for best ensemble acting, and now leads all contenders with eight Oscar nominations.

 A resident near Burketsville, Maryland, where The Blair Witch project was filmed, has said that the film crew making the sequel left behind a load of production notes which has dutifully put on his site. It all smacks of another publicity scam by those tricksy witches famous for their spoof sites but it does appear to give a sniff of the project. Check for yourself at this guy's site

 Living Hollywood legend Elizabeth Taylor is to become immortalized in a doll, modelled on the actress's most famous role in Joseph Mankiewicz's 1963 epic, Cleopatra. Resplendent in gold costume, towering feathered headress, sparkly eyeshadow and the famous heavy kohl eyeliner, the doll will be the first in a series commemorating Taylor's career.

 British star Helen Baxendale, who found fame as Ross's girlfriend in American sitcom Friends, is to play a suicidal widow who plans to throw herself into the Niagara Falls in David Cronenburg's next film, Dead by Monday. Fellow Brit Timothy Dutton will star as the complete stranger with whom Baxendale's character enters a suicide pact. Sixth Sense actress, Toni Collette, is also slated to star.

 Johnny Depp is reportedly in advanced negotiations to star in From Hell, a Jack the Ripper movie that has bounced around the studios for nearly six years. Depp is said to be interested in playing the part of Scotland Yard detective Frederick Abberline who investigated the macabre killings of East London prostitutes during the 1880s. The period crime horror, based on a 10-part series of graphic novels, will be directed by the Hughes brothers, famous for their slightly less grotesque innner-city dramas Menace II Society and Dead Presidents.

 Paramount Pictures is in negotiations to acquire North American distribution rights to Kevin and Perry, the feature film version of Harry Enfield's sketch starring himself and Kathy Burke as a couple of stereotypical teenage boys desperate to lose their virginity. Directed by tv comedy director and husband of Ruby Wax Ed Bye, the film sees the spotty duo leave Britain for Ibiza in the hope of easy sex and fame as hip-hop DJs. They meet the cool Jim Jam, played by Rhys Ifans, on the island and seem destined for success but Jim Jam is not all that he seems.

 The production designer, Bo Welch, who created the look for Batman and Men in Black, will make his directorial debut with Mike Myers' new film Sprockets, a comedy about an avant-garde German talkshow host called Dieter who travels to America after his pet monkey is kidnapped. Myers had considered directing the film himself, but decided on Welch because of his unique visual style. Based on a German waiter Myers knew in Canada and performed as a sketch on Saturday Night Live, the 36-year-old comedian has been working on Dieter's catchphrase "Your conversation has become tiresome" since he was 18, far longer than his Wayne's World and Austin Powers creations.

webTitle: M&S attacks sales slump with rebranding

fields.headline: M&S attacks sales slump with rebranding
fields.standfirst: Store eliminates name confusion
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer will formally unveil a rebranding of its entire product range early next month in an attempt to halt a precipitous fall in sales, the stores chain confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer will formally unveil a rebranding of its entire product range early next month in an attempt to halt a precipitous fall in sales, the stores chain confirmed yesterday.

Its famous St Michael brand will be transformed into a "promise of satisfaction" for customers, but will be relegated to garment care labels and price tags, with the Marks & Spencer name being promoted as the primary brand across all goods.

On food, the St Michael promise - which the company believes still carries strong associations of "integrity" and "trust" - will appear alongside the ingredients panel.

"We are not dropping St Michael, but we will use it in a different way - similar to the kitemark for British wool," a spokesman said.

The move comes as Verdict, the retailing analyst, warned that "time is running out" for the troubled group, whose share of high street spending on clothes slumped from 13% to 11% last year.

In a three-part study of the clothing market published today Verdict identifies M&S as the worst hit by vicious price competition on the high street but also warns that the entire sector is facing crisis.

"Too many retailers are offering uninspired and bland ranges and consumers are shopping less for clothes as a consequence," said Verdict, adding that the main victims have been specialist retailers who are still losing market share to supermarkets such as Asda and Tesco.

While both Next and discount stores chain Matalan managed to push their share of the clothing market higher last year, Verdict points to the success of Asda's George brand, which pushed its market share up from 2.2% to 2.4% during 1999.

Its experience is contrasted with Bhs, whose parent Storehouse has been besieged by takeover offers. Bhs is "no longer viable in its current form", according to Verdict.

There was further evidence during the weekend that Stephen Tucker, the Monaco-based entrepreneur, is close to tabling a plan to inject new management into the company, having recruited the former boss of Texas Homecare, Ron Tenter, to a team which already includes former Kingfisher executives Nigel Whittaker and Tom Wyatt.

Mr Tucker wants to break up more of the Storehouse group, selling the best assets, such as Mothercare, and then return surplus cash to shareholders.

At M&S, teams of image and marketing specialists led by the design agency Interbrand Newell & Sorrell have been working on a relaunch of the entire chain for six months.

The new look - which will include a new M&S facia on the high street, redesigned shop fronts and new shopping bags - will be rolled out during the autumn after trials at a small number of pilot stores this summer.

The St Michael label has been used on all clothing for more than 70 years, but work with consultants indicated that its existence alongside the Marks & Spencers name created confusion among shoppers.

webTitle: Straw will not set date for release of Bulger killers

fields.headline: Straw will not set date for release of Bulger killers
fields.standfirst: Home secretary pledges to abide by Lord Chief Justice's future ruling
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw said today that he would not set a date for the release of Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the two boys who murdered the Merseyside toddler James Bulger in 1993.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw said today that he would not set a date for the release of Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the two boys who murdered the Merseyside toddler James Bulger in 1993.

In a Commons statement, Mr Straw said that the Lord Chief Justice would decide how long Venables and Thompson, who were 10 at the time of the murder, would remain in prison and that he would be bound by this decision.

The two boys were sentenced to eight years' detention at the time of the trial in 1993 but that figure was raised to 10 years by the previous Lord Chief Justice. The then home secretary, Michael Howard, increased the minimum sentence to 15 years, which was reversed by the European court of human rights in December 1999 on the ground that a politician could not make impartial judicial decisions.

Mr Straw acknowledged that the "continuing uncertainty" would be distressing to James Bulger's family but said he hoped that the process could be concluded quickly.

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe said she accepted that Mr Straw had no alternative but to observe the ruling of the European court but said she saw it as a "most unwarranted interference" and believed that 15 years was an "appropriate" tariff for the killers.

Miss Widdecombe said Thompson and Venables should not be allowed to see themselves "as victims of the system rather than perpetrators of an unthinkable crime".

fields.headline: Me and my motor
fields.standfirst: John Shuttleworth
fields.trailText: What are you driving?
fields.body:
What are you driving?

An Austin Ambassador - Y reg, beige exterior, maroon interior.

What does that say about you?

I have immaculate taste and a keen sense of colour coordination.

What do you like about it/not like about it?

Roomy glove compartment - but the catch is broken, preventing access to the glove compartment.

Why did you buy it?

I have asked myself that occasionally.

What kind of driver are you?

Cautious, yet swift to react in moments of danger.

Any bad habits?

I make soft clucking noises when measuring a piece of timber prior to sawing. Why do you ask?

Any driving-test tales?

Of course not. I passed first time without incident.

What was your first car?

A 1958 Ford Anglia. It was brown, which helped disguise the rust.

Have you ever crashed/got a speeding ticket/got any points?

I was involved in a collision with an articulated lorry in the above vehicle. The car was a mess, but it spawned one of my finest songs to date, Incident on the Snake Pass. Fortunately, my injuries were superficial. Having said that, to me they were very real.

What do you use your car for?

A shop at Netto, and daily runs to the reservoir to check the water level.

Have you ever experienced road rage?

In Netto's car park I once saw a woman nutting the steering-wheel. I thought, Oh dear, she's forgotten a major item off her list. Then I realised she was just trying to pull her seat forward.

What sort of state is your car in?

Frankly, it's beginning to niff a bit. I left a slice of gala pie in the glove compartment two weeks ago.

What else is in the glove compartment?

A road atlas, spare batteries for my organ and a pair of wellies, just in case the reservoir requires a closer look.

Have you ever had any romantic encounters in a car?

Once my wife Mary came with me to check the reservoir level. It was abnormally low, and we became concerned for our children's futures. I put my arm round Mary and gave her a reassuring squeeze.

What music do you listen to on the road?

That's easy: Chris Rea. And, for high-speed motorway journeys, the Lighthouse Family.

What would be your dream car?

A camper van like Doreen Melody's (She's a good friend of Mary's; they go to Bums, Tums and Thighs together on Thursdays) with a sturdy chrome ladder for immediate access to the roof, and a stove for brewing up during longer visits to the reservoir.

Who would be your dream passenger?

Chris Rea. I'd like to drive him home for Christmas.

Graham Fellows, aka John Shuttleworth, tours his new show, 2000 & John, from Friday.

fields.headline: The habit of a lifetime
fields.standfirst: Morgan is a little family business in the Malvern hills that lovingly turns out 11 cars a week. Its new model - the first in 64 years - will still be built by hand, yet it was the star of this year's Geneva motor show.
fields.trailText: Hammers tap softly; drills whine no louder than a dentist's. The soundtrack in the factory where they've been making those spiffing little Morgan sports cars for decades is odd; the smells are even odder - seasoned ash rather than scorched metal - and the sights are positively bizarre.
fields.body:
Hammers tap softly; drills whine no louder than a dentist's. The soundtrack in the factory where they've been making those spiffing little Morgan sports cars for decades is odd; the smells are even odder - seasoned ash rather than scorched metal - and the sights are positively bizarre.

Automated assembly line? Gantry cranes overhead? Oh no. Here, chassis and bodyshells are cradled on wooden trestles or trundled round on little trollies. And as soon as an embryo Morgan sprouts wheels, it's pushed from tin shop to wood shop to paint shop, presumably to get it used to using them.

Morgans are made in the Malvern hills, a location far outside the harsh, doomed motor manufacturing triangle of Cowley, Dagenham and Longbridge. It's a magic domain in mellow, Elgar country, and you might think time has stopped still at the plant, which was producing more cars after the 1914-18 war than it does today (50 a week then; 11 now).

It has taken Morgan 64 years to come up with a wholly new model, the Aero 8; a sibling of the 4/4 and the Plus 8, the two models currently on the market. When the Aero 8 was unveiled in Geneva two weeks ago, motoring hacks must have pinched themselves to be sure they weren't dreaming, for so much of the Morgan mystique is wreathed in myth and mist.

But no, there was the reassuring presence of Charles Morgan, grandson of the founder of the family firm, HFS Morgan - fabled inventor of the sliding pillar front suspension (marvellous road grip, but a great denture-rattler), to vouch that a new babe had been born and was legitimate Morgan stock.

The Aero 8 is a zappy, aerodynamic design with advanced aluminium chassis, top speed of 160 mph from a 4.4 BMW V8 engine, and a price tag of almost £50,000 - which should test your braking distance. Will so advanced a car really emerge from the low-built, laid-back collection of buildings in Malvern Link, redolent with nostalgia for the first Morgan three-wheelers and the racing circuit?

Charles, a former ITN cameraman with a degree in business management who heads the company now that his father, Peter, is taking it easier at 80, is a little hurt by the question. Morgan's a lot more modern than you think, he says (we'll come back to that) and slightly stung by criticism from the Daily Telegraph at the launch.

The DT's motoring writer opined: "My initial reaction was to ask if customers would be able to specify their Aero 8s without the body." Morgan staff looked slightly pained. Most of all, the DT man didn't like the headlamps, and reckoned they gave the car a cross-eyed look.

Charles is understandably defensive. These headlamps are "probably the most beautiful in production" - and the most expensive Bosch make, he adds. The Aero 8 is "a modern concept of what a 1930s sports car should look like". Sure, there are more creature comforts - electrically heated windows and air conditioning for the first time - but then, to be a Morgan owner, you don't have to be a stoic in leather helmet and goggles .

From July, two Aero 8s a week will be produced. But why, given that the waiting list for the 4/4 and the Plus 8 is about four years, bother to update? Surely they could go on for ever, turning out 500 or 600 cars a year for avid buyers, who prize them more than shares in a hot dot.com company? And with gross company profits of £3m, the family, like their motors, are doing very well without changing gear.

Partly it's that Charles wants to revive the grand racing days of Morgan and make his mark; partly it's because the length of the waiting list - it once stretched to 11 years - can be so frustrating that some would-be purchasers drop-out - or die, presumably of melancholy.

Charles hints that there could even be an expansion of production - they've got spare land "as big a football pitch" on their present site. Expansion! Surely that's enough to tremble the stiff upper lips of vintage Morgan owners, such as those stalwarts who'll turn out in August for the "Mog 2000 Gymkhana", a weekend fest of sprints, races, and reminiscences.

But don't get Charles wrong: expansion would be a million miles from mass production: "Even if we were to make 1,500 cars a year, Morgans would still be a limited edition. 50% of them go abroad."

The works staff show no signs of being fazed by the advent of the Aero 8. In the last few years, they've got to used to new developments. Well, relatively accustomed. When Sir John Harvey-Jones first came to the factory a decade ago for his TV series, Troubleshooter, he remarked to a foreman who'd been there for 31 years that he must have seen a lot of changes. The foreman famously replied "No, not a great deal at all, no."

Maybe not then, but all staff have by now. Time is on the move. For decades, customers could never get through on the phone in the middle of the day because most of the staff lived close enough to go home for lunch and no one stayed to take the calls. At last, someone does.

It is true, too, that at one stage in their production, the half-built carts were actually pushed uphill, by employees, between the different shops. Marketing manager Matthew Parkin smiles indulgently, but insists it doesn't happen any more: now they're pushed down the gradient. There is still a series of separate workshops, but the chaos that used to reign has been ironed out. "We used to start 10 cars together here on a Monday." says Parkin. "Often , there was no space to do anything. Now we start two cars a day, Monday to Friday, and it's all smoother."

Morgan has forgiven Harvey-Jones his original blistering comments, and he's been back there for a more mutually-forgiving visit (the programme was shown last Thursday).

They've cut the time it takes a car to progress from chassis building, panelling, engine and electrical fitting, painting, upholstery to the final sparkling finish from four weeks to about 17 days

And they've done it while keeping intact the air of a coachworks, where many of the stages are still hand-crafted. Sure, there's laser technology for precision cutting aluminum panels, but you can still see workmen with metal clippers. And though the wings are now pressed out of single metal sheets, rather than a skilled, deft patchwork of pieces, the body frame is still made of ash.

"That's kiln-dried ash," explains Parkin, like a manager in a posh restaurant describing the construction of the house special. Except that, on the Morgan menu, many of the ingredients are still traditional. Connolly leather seats in all cars; and, in the Aero 8, a removable Mulberry leather case for your personal computer.

As Morgan is the ultimate name to drop in certain (but not all) circles, they have to be careful, in these days of pushy lifestyle products, who they keep company with by way of accessories. Happily, that's a caveat that doesn't extend to their customers: Morgan don't mind who buys their cars, so long as the customer has the cash - and a life expectancy of at least four years in order to be around on the delivery date.

fields.headline: Welcome to Clockwork Orange country
fields.standfirst: When Stanley Kubrick wanted a setting for a tale of alienation and ultraviolence, he knew just where to go.  Jonathan Glancey follows him to Thamesmead, London SE28
fields.trailText: A Clockwork Orange opens with Alex and his Nadsat-speaking droogs sipping drug-laced pintas in the wonderfully over-the-top interior of the Korova Milk Bar. It is real "horrowshow", as Alex would say approvingly. A pop-art, 70s-kitsch S&M dungeon with pools of excessively bright light amid dense shadows, the Korova was designed by John Barry (not the composer) and was one of the few sets built for Kubrick's notorious film, re-released on Friday after an absence of 26 years.
fields.body:
A Clockwork Orange opens with Alex and his Nadsat-speaking droogs sipping drug-laced pintas in the wonderfully over-the-top interior of the Korova Milk Bar. It is real "horrowshow", as Alex would say approvingly. A pop-art, 70s-kitsch S&M dungeon with pools of excessively bright light amid dense shadows, the Korova was designed by John Barry (not the composer) and was one of the few sets built for Kubrick's notorious film, re-released on Friday after an absence of 26 years.

Apart from two other interior sets, A Clockwork Orange was filmed on location in and around London. The immediate reason was cost: the film's budget was $2m, chicken-feed in Kubrick's terms, even in 1971. Yet, at the time, the locations that would best express the dystopian world Alex and his droogs inhabited had just been built by architects, most of them employed by local authorities. If the Korova had existed it would have been somewhere in the Tavy Bridge shopping centre, Thamesmead, London SE28.

The postcode is real, London's most extreme in numerical terms. This is where Alex lives in one of the concrete "neighbourhood" blocks linked by elevated walkways. It was underneath one of these, by the shopping centre, that Kubrick filmed the droogs attacking an old tramp. Later, when Alex (played by Malcolm McDowell) becomes the subject of medical research at the "Ludovico Institute", he is really in Brunel university, Uxbridge, another brand-new concrete megastructure.

Kubrick and his designers found the sets by trawling through the latest architectural magazines. These were mostly in love with Thamesmead. Naturally the mini-new town, planned from 1961 by the London County Council and built from 1965 by the architects department of the Greater London Council, won awards.

Thamesmead, a name chosen by readers of the now defunct London Evening News, was designed as a brave new home for 60,000 lucky Londoners, who were to live in a cluster of ostensibly rational, pre-fabricated concrete "neighbourhoods". Each neighbourhood would offer between 1,500 and 1,700 "dwelling units" for between 8,000 and 9,000 residents. Neighbourhoods would be connected, South Bank style, by elevated walkways, and meet in a large civic piazza with a shopping centre. The site, east of Woolwich and Plumstead marshes, is on wet ground, squeezed up beside the old Crosswell sewage treatment plant where the fine Victorian steam compound rotative beam engine that pumped London's effluence from its centres of population is now being lovingly restored.

More than 30 years on, Thamesmead itself would benefit from a little tender loving. In parts it looks like a film set, so strange is the town-planning premise on which it is founded. Concrete towers, flanked by two artificial lakes, rise around a set-piece square facing the Thames. This original core is then wrapped around with the sort of tweedy, bricky, neo-nothing family houses many of us fear will swamp the banks of the Thames as John Prescott's London overspill housing policy is translated into action. The strangest views of the area are those you can get from a boat heading towards Southend and the Channel, or those framed by the ruins of the abbey built from 1191 by Sir Richard de Lucy as a penance for the murder of St Thomas à Beckett.

What is striking about the locations chosen for A Clockwork Orange and other films documenting alienation is that they were meant to enhance human life. Today only the herons, swans and geese that haunt the lakes and riverside at Thamesmead seem serene. These and the carp and tench that idle through the dark waters of the lakes created by the GLC's landscape gardeners. And maybe those families in search of a four-bedroom detached home with 30ft lounge, double garage and front and back gardens for under £120,000 (there are plenty of them). The price they pay, if they commute (and most do) is a long bus ride, or an uncertain journey by train to London Bridge. This and a catalogue of worries to do with crime, schooling, the usual things. And a very specific sense of isolation.

One of the criticisms of Thamesmead and towns like it is that they are fundamentally middle-class constructs imposed on what were, at the time of their first building, working-class families. Those who first came here had given up life in inner-city streets. True, these were classified as slums, yet they were "home" in the sense that Thamesmead has never been.

Well-intentioned GLC architects and planners (several of those who worked on the design of Thamesmead had previously helped to develop London's South Bank) were genuinely surprised when residents said there was nowhere for children to play. What about the 300 acres of parks the GLC had generously provided? That wasn't the point. Previously children had been able to kick balls around local streets and alleys. The idea was that the middle classes would come here too, but they never really did. Thamesmead remains solidly Old Labour, despite being a new town. In the May 1997 election, the turnout was 66%. Labour held the seat with 62% of the vote. The extreme right-wing vote was low, with the British National Party wooing just 1.7%.

The working-class nature of Thamesmead was sympathetically depicted in the 1996 film of Jonathan Harvey's play Beautiful Thing - though it stressed the lack of privacy so many people felt growing up in the world Alex and the droogs knew. In that future everything was exposed, up-front and violent. No secrets. How different, how very different from life lived behind the screen of privets in middle-class suburbs.

One could not say that Thamesmead was in any way cynical, a form of middle-class or local-government manipulation of the lives of those way down the pecking order. It wasn't. Nor was it cheap. A fortune was spent in the first five years (1965-70). Local government was a costly business in the 60s because there was a consensus that new housing, schools, hospitals, parks and other amenities were needed and that these could not, should not, be left in the hands of the private sector. Certainly the private sector would never attempt to build a housing development as complex and costly as Thamesmead. It was true, though, that the concrete flats leaked and were prone to condensation, and the smell of the sewage works on summer days was "strong enough to peel paint at 50 paces", according to one local. By 1974 just 12,000 people lived there. Today the population is 30,000 and the mini-new town is considered to be no more than half-complete. After the abolition of the GLC in 1986, it was handed over to Thamesmead Town Limited. Rents are high, residents say, and services are poor.

But at least Thamesmead was built with some sense of vision - however misguided. Nowadays, business parks, distribution depots and Prescott memorial housing threaten the marshlands that give this odd stretch of far-flung London its strangely haunting character and its glorious birds and other wildlife. Maybe it's still a tough and isolated place to live, but it has its "horrorshow" side.

A Clockword Orange opens on Friday.

Today only the herons, swans and geese that haunt the lakes and riverside at Thamesmead seem serene. These and the carp and tench that idle through the dark waters of the lakes created by the GLC's landscape gardeners. And maybe those families in search of a four-bedroom detached home with 30ft lounge, double garage and front and back gardens for under £120,000 (there are plenty of them). The price they pay, if they commute (and most do) is a long bus ride, or an uncertain journey by train to London Bridge. This and a catalogue of worries to do with crime, schooling, the usual things. And a very specific sense of isolation. One of the criticisms of Thamesmead and towns like it is that they are fundamentally middle-class constructs imposed on what were, at the time of their first building, working-class families. Those who first came here had given up life in inner-city streets. True, these were classified as slums, yet they were "home" in the sense that Thamesmead has never been. Well-intentioned GLC architects and planners (several of those who worked on the design of Thamesmead had previously helped to develop London's South Bank) were genuinely surprised when residents said there was nowhere for children to play. What about the 300 acres of parks the GLC had generously provided? That wasn't the point. Previously children had been able to kick balls around local streets and alleys. The idea was that the middle classes would come here too, but they never really did. Thamesmead remains solidly Old Labour, despite being a new town. In the May 1997 election, the turnout was 66%. Labour held the seat with 62% of the vote. The extreme right-wing vote was low, with the British National Party wooing just 1.7%. The working-class nature of Thamesmead was sympathetically depicted in the 1996 film of Jonathan Harvey's play Beautiful Thing - though it stressed the lack of privacy so many people felt growing up in the world Alex and the droogs knew. In that future everything was exposed, up-front and violent. No secrets. How different, how very different from life lived behind the screen of privets in middle-class suburbs. One could not say that Thamesmead was in any way cynical, a form of middle-class or local-government manipulation of the lives of those way down the pecking order. It wasn't. Nor was it cheap. A fortune was spent in the first five years (1965-70). Local government was a costly business in the 60s because there was a consensus that new housing, schools, hospitals, parks and other amenities were needed and that these could not, should not, be left in the hands of the private sector. Certainly the private sector would never attempt to build a housing development as complex and costly as Thamesmead. It was true, though, that the concrete flats leaked and were prone to condensation, and the smell of the sewage works on summer days was "strong enough to peel paint at 50 paces", according to one local. By 1974 just 12,000 people lived there. Today the population is 30,000 and the mini-new town is considered to be no more than half-complete. After the abolition of the GLC in 1986, it was handed over to Thamesmead Town Limited. Rents are high, residents say, and services are poor. But at least Thamesmead was built with some sense of vision - however misguided. Nowadays, business parks, distribution depots and Prescott memorial housing threaten the marshlands that give this odd stretch of far-flung London its strangely haunting character and its glorious birds and other wildlife. Maybe it's still a tough and isolated place to live, but it has its "horrorshow" side. A Clockword Orange opens on Friday.

webTitle: 'No need' for buy now, pay later PFI

fields.headline: 'No need' for buy now, pay later PFI
fields.standfirst: Hailed by the previous government as a buy now, pay later way of renewing the fabric of the public sector, the PFI has proved to be "small beer," says a think tank report.
fields.trailText: The government could have paid for all the new schools and hospitals funded under the controversial private finance initiative without straining the treasury's golden rules for controlling the public finances, a report claims.
fields.body:
The government could have paid for all the new schools and hospitals funded under the controversial private finance initiative without straining the treasury's golden rules for controlling the public finances, a report claims today.

Hailed by the previous government as a buy now, pay later way of renewing the fabric of the public sector, the PFI has proved to be "small beer," according to the left-leaning think tank, the Institute for Public Policy Research.

The IPPR's chief economist, Peter Robinson, estimates the PFI will provide around £11bn of investment from 1999 to 2001 - some 14% of investment in the public sector. Had the taxpayer paid upfront, Mr Robinson says the government would still have met its fiscal rules of borrowing only to invest and keeping government debt below 40% of national outcome.

"The Treasury's new fiscal framework is entirely compatible with not having the PFI at all - the initiative is not necessary to secure prudent public finances," said Mr Robinson. "The macro fiscal argument for the PFI was always weak."

The IPPR report suggests the only reason to keep the PFI is if it delivers value for money. Independent reports suggest that on average PFI deals are around 10% to 20% cheaper than conventional public procurement deals. With the government set to spend £3.6bn in 2004-2005 on servicing PFI contracts, the initiative may be saving taxpayers around £360m to £720m a year - small beer, says the IPPR.

However, Mr Robinson warns even the small cost savings that the deal has achieved so far could be eroded because most public sector managers believe the PFI is their only hope of getting a new school or hospital.

"When they construct the public sector comparator to demonstrate value for money, they must be doing so half-heartedly because they believe that the public financing option is not open to them," said Mr Robinson.

"And the private sector bidders must be in a more powerful position because they too know the PSC is a mere formality and the project will go ahead under the PFI."

fields.headline: Owning up
fields.standfirst: Forget content. The latest ABCs show the value of a good proprietor, says  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: Who is the most important person on a newspaper? The editor? The star columnist? The football writer? No, the most important individual is the owner.
fields.body:
Who is the most important person on a newspaper? The editor? The star columnist? The football writer? No, the most important individual is the owner. There has never been a successful newspaper without a good proprietor. These men (and this has been a man's world for most of the past century) may do the job differently, but they all share an understanding that newspapers are not like other consumer products.

Some have been noticeably hands-off, like the late, lamented Lord Thomson, who delegated to brilliant editors and took little interest in current affairs. Some have been heavy-handed political mischief-makers, such as Lord Beaverbrook. Some have prospered through instinctive, sometimes maverick behaviour, like the late Lord Rothermere III.

Their success has nothing to do with morality, with the quality and value of the editorial content. It is a statement of fact: these men owned and ran newspapers which, in their markets, outsold their rivals' titles and, by that virtue, were able to exercise enormous influence. Looking at the chart below, it is impossible not to realise who is the greatest press owner of this generation.

Rupert Murdoch's four national titles have set sales records for the past couple of decades, defying market trends. The Sun, in spite of being about 700,000 down from its 1988 high point, still dominates among the red-top dailies. In February, the gap between it and the Mirror was a daunting 1,322,726 copies, while the Daily Star is dropping out of sight.

The Times, though it has yet to realise Murdoch's ambition of over taking the Daily Telegraph, has more than doubled its sales since he bought it in 1981. Then it was selling barely 280,000. Last month it recorded 729,140, below its 760,000 peak and certainly due to aggressive pricing tactics, but a remarkable transformation all the same.

On Sundays, Murdoch bestrides the quality broadsheet and the red-top markets. His News of the World, though well below its best figures, has eclipsed the opposition. Together the Sunday Mirror and the People sold 3,514,893 in February to the NoW's 4,154,972. The Sunday Times is, as rivals grudgingly admit, unassailable. Its regular 1.3m circulation almost equals the joint sale of its three rivals.

Ah yes, you may say, but quantity isn't everything, and that's undeniable. But sales have a weight of their own, squashing quality and ethical purity. Might may not be right, though it is usually rightwing.

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: Martin Bell is launching a quixotic campaign to win veteran correspondent Kate Adie a seat in the Lords. He surprised trainee officers at Sandhurst during a lecture with a paean of praise for his ex-colleague. "She visited my constituency to address the British Legion, and it struck me then what a wonderful role model she is, especially for the young. She could sit as an independent. Lady Adie has a wonderful ring to it."
fields.body:
 Martin Bell is launching a quixotic campaign to win veteran correspondent Kate Adie a seat in the Lords. He surprised trainee officers at Sandhurst during a lecture with a paean of praise for his ex-colleague. "She visited my constituency to address the British Legion, and it struck me then what a wonderful role model she is, especially for the young. She could sit as an independent. Lady Adie has a wonderful ring to it."

*National Magazines appear to have landed the perfect aspirational Cosmo woman in new Cosmopolitan editor Lorraine Butler. After leaving Liskeard Comprehensive at 16 for her local paper, the Cornish Times, she worked her way through the Sun, Today, Marie Claire and B Magazine, before landing at the Times last summer as features editor. In the best tradition of Cosmo founder Helen Gurley Brown, Butler, 31, also has the right address - Ladbroke Grove - and a fiance, in the City.

*More problems for Conrad Black, big-hearted proprietor of the Telegraph. About 100 employees of his newspaper, the Calgary Herald, are on strike over pay and job descriptions. Asked why he was ridding himself of so many staff, Black said kindly: "We're amputating gangrenous limbs."

*Roy Thompson, head of BBC Children's television, gave away an interesting nugget at a seminar on children and the media last week. Some delegates (media studies teachers) pressed for children to be given control of their own chunk of TV time or website, without adults bossing them around.

Thompson said the problem was the number of racist emails sent to BBC children's websites. Every message is read before being posted on BBC sites, with those judged unsuitable sent back, with a "silly sausage" reprimand. That should scare them senseless.

*The Independent Television Commission is to start a "teddy bear" research project, placing mini-cameras in wired-up homes, to see how families bicker and resolve conflicts over electronic programme guides, and who chooses what to watch from 200 channels. The ITC may come to regret this intrusion - previous research shows that "bickering" comes way down the list of things people do in front of their sets. Eating, falling asleep and having sex is much more prevalent.

*"I believe in Channel 4, multi-cultural programming, serious news in prime time and bottoms in washing machine doors!" Don't laugh. The channel is drawing up its first mission statement to which all staff will sign up. The reason, apart from adopting the latest trendy management theories, is that the broadcaster is changing from a single network to a multi-media company, with internet services and betting online coming soon, and the EN channel due to launch in November. So,the reasoning goes, if everyone signs up, their decisions will comply with the central purpose. Isn't life easy!

*Thanks for the emails about bringing back Medium Wave to Radio 4. Producers from Radio 5 Live's Papertalk are working on a proposal and think they are pushing at an open door. One thing: base it in London, not Manchester (home of Medium Wave). It's where the media is concentrated.

You can contact Maggie Brown on maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com
