webTitle: Sound and fury signifying, well, not much

fields.headline: Sound and fury signifying, well, not much
fields.standfirst: Over the past three weeks the Spectator has reported on a 'Republican cell' at the heart of this newspaper. The editor of the Guardian,  Alan Rusbridger, responds to the increasingly bizarre allegations
fields.trailText: Running a small weekly journal of opinion presents its editor with the recurring problem: visibility. How, with a limited marketing budget, do you create enough noise to get your opinions noticed?
fields.body:
Running a small weekly journal of opinion presents its editor with the recurring problem: visibility. How, with a limited marketing budget, do you create enough noise to get your opinions noticed?

The answer successive editors of the Spectator have come up with is to stir up controversy. Typically, this involves throwing a stone through someone's front window and then waiting behind the hedge for the red-faced resident to appear.

This is not a risk-free enterprise, but there is also risk for the red-faced resident. Chasing giggling schoolboys down the street is at best undignified and, at worst, may invite another stone the moment the front door is closed. Often it is best simply to stay put on the sofa and call the glazier the next day. So it is with a slightly heavy heart - and only after three stones - that I stir myself.

The missiles that have been lobbed through the Guardian's window recently concern our coverage of Ireland. Something that may have long been apparent to alert Guardian readers has come to the attention of the Spectator's media columnist: that we have, in our editorials, shown a considerable degree of understanding towards the leaders of Sinn Fein as they have attempted the near-impossible task of persuading a movement devoted to violence that democratic politics is a more worthwhile and effective way of resolving the nightmare of conflict in Northern Ireland. We have also been careful to note how the problems the Sinn Fein leaders have with their hardliners are mirrored by the difficulties David Trimble has with his instinctive rejectionists.

This is not, you might think, a terribly extreme position. It is, give or take the odd nuance, the position of the British, American and Irish governments. Senior British intelligence sources, policemen and politicians on both sides of the Atlantic have shown an engaged interest in our editorials. As a stance on Northern Ireland it might be thought at least as mainstream as, say, the Spectator's sister paper, the Daily Telegraph, which has been resolutely hostile to the peace process from the start.

As on most newspapers, our editorial line is settled upon by the leader writers of the day - in our case, generally between four and six in number. Three or four of us have written on Ireland in recent months. The two main writers arrived at broadly the same conclusion about Ireland after years of discussions with different sources on all sides of the political, religious and international divides.

At the same time as the leaders have appeared we have run a variety of op-ed pieces on Ireland, many of them notably unsympathetic to Sinn Fein. In the past year we have run pieces by Hugo Young, Roy Hattersley, David Trimble (three times), John Taylor and Seumas Mallon. We have run one piece by Gerry Adams.

In addition to this I personally signed up serialisation of Eamonn Collins's account of being in the IRA - a work so detested by the Provos that Collins paid for it with his life. We are now being sued for our coverage of this book by his cousin Micky, accused in the book of being in the IRA.

So far, so unremarkable. You may not agree with the editorial line. It may turn out to be wise, we may be made to look foolish. But we have been straight down the middle in our reporting and have deliberately allowed plenty of space to different views. Our editorial line has been honestly arrived at after considerable thought, soul-searching and open discussion.

The media commentator of the Spectator, Stephen Glover, thinks otherwise. He made the startling discovery - known, I guess, to all Guardian employees and numerous others in Fleet Street and the worlds of publishing and television - that the deputy editor of the Guardian, Georgina Henry, lives with the author Ronan Bennett, who is open about his support for a united Ireland. After considerable research, Mr Glover chanced upon the singular fact that Georgina was pregnant.

Sleuthing further, he found out that Bennett had once been in Long Kesh and had been convicted of the murder of an RUC policeman - though he was just cute enough to concede that Bennett had also subsequently been acquitted.

He also told his readers that a serial Bennett had made about the Easter 1916 rising had been rejected by the Irish TV station, RTE, for being "too sectarian".

All this was almost too exciting to be true, especially when Glover subsequently thought he had discovered that Georgina wrote leaders on Northern Ireland and was in the habit of slagging off our sister paper, the Observer, for being "dangerously sympathetic to the Unionists".

Bingo! Bennett had not only impregnated Georgina with his baby, he had also succeeded in impregnating her with his sectarian views and - through her - had turned the Guardian into "an alarmingly pro-IRA" paper. You doubt that a "media commentator" could pen so crude a sub-Freudian analysis of a newspaper? Oh but he did - right down to stating: "she is pregnant with his child" [emphasis added].

Moreover, Glover had found out, all this had been done behind the editor's back - though he dangled the theory that I enjoyed the "chic idea of drinking with Provos". And all this without us ever telling Guardian readers who Bennett was! The little boys must have hugged themselves with glee as they penned the headline: "The Republican cell at the heart of the Guardian."

The problem was that virtually none of it was true. Bennett's serial has not been rejected by RTE. Georgina has never written a leader on Northern Ireland and does not hold the view of the Observer ascribed to her. She had a baby last December (do try to keep up, Mr Glover!), was on maternity leave at the time of the recent editorials that have most offended the Spectator and played absolutely no part in their formulation.

The development of the Guardian leader line was emphatically not done behind my back. Bennett's time in Long Kesh was hardly a secret from Guardian readers: he wrote a 2,000-word G2 cover story on the subject in September 1998 (since then he has written precisely one piece for the Guardian - a book review). And no leader writer on the Guardian - myself excepted - has ever discussed Irish politics with Bennett.

This was a fairly spectacular list of errors and might be thought to torpedo the entire basis of the piece. It is, as I have discovered, a mistake to try to discuss matters such as this with Glover himself, since he has only a hazy notion of respecting private conversations. So I wrote a long, careful - and private - letter to the magazine's editor, Boris Johnson, asking if he would consider correcting the five main errors.

There was a long silence from the Spectator's offices at Doughty Street, so I rang Johnson. He exploded into a string of apologies and conceded they'd got all the "personal stuff" wrong. But, pressed for a correction, he got distinctly ratty and described the errors as trivial and "hair-splitting". He muttered something about our leaders immediately after the Docklands bomb and promised to write me a letter.

No letter arrived. I faxed him our leaders on the Docklands bomb, which unequivocally condemned the IRA. As his deadline neared I rang Johnson again. I could, he said, write a letter but there would be no correction. It transpired during these exchanges that anyone who felt any admiration for anything Adams and McGuinness had done during these past five years was regarded by the Spectator as being "pro-IRA".

No letter came. The magazine appeared with no correction. Johnson is reputed to have a sense of humour, so I penned a jokey 200-word leader about the matter in which one in every two facts was wrong, and invited readers to guess which was true and which was garbage.

Johnson said he loved it and asked if he could repeat some of Glover's accusations in a letter to the Guardian. I said that would be just fine once they corrected all the mistakes in his own magazine. I settled back on the sofa. End of the affair.

Wrong. There was still giggling from behind the hedge. Johnson briefed a number of journalists about the "controversy" and gained his quota of helpful publicity. Several papers wrote about the "row" until Guardian readers were the only ones left out of the loop. Hence this article.

He returned to the theme last week, more elegantly than Glover, but still maintaining that the original article was substantially correct ("if we got anything significantly wrong (and I don't think we did), then I apologise unreservedly"). It was a more moderate rehearsal of the cell thesis, and we all presumed that was truly the end of the affair.

Far from it. This week Glover returned to his sombre duty. Same theme, same headline. The notion that something might be corrected (something the Guardian itself does as a matter of routine and policy four or five times a day) had by now become a sinister inhibition on free speech. Even to ask showed that the Guardian - supposedly a champion of open debate - was "worse than the Downing Street heavies". Glover bravely announced that he would not be silenced by these "threats".

Glover then did what is known in Fleet Street as "doing a Glover". He glancingly accepted that he had got some things wrong, while claiming that the real truth was even more significant. For the record, he now accepts that RTE did not, as he originally claimed, reject Bennett's series. He has replaced this with a new claim ("possibly more illuminating") - that RTE demanded changes to the script. This, illuminatingly enough, is also untrue.

Glover is also happy to accept that Georgina has never written a leader on Northern Ireland. He thinks this a "minor point", adding: "It scarcely matters that her fingers never make contact with the keyboard."

There is a also an interesting (if unacknowledged) shift in language. Glover has quietly retreated from his deliberate and repeated charges that the Guardian is "alarming pro-IRA" to the charge that the Guardian is now "pro-Sinn Fein/IRA", or even just plain pro-Sinn Fein. All this is a start.

But his dogged researches have turned up fresh outrages. Last year, he reports, Bennett introduced me to Gerry Adams. Bennett did make a call on my behalf - though it was three years ago. I wanted to meet Adams, who at this time was talking freely to the British, American and Irish governments. This is hardly shocking - or new - stuff. The great CP Scott met Michael Collins twice at the time of the October 1921 "peace process". He even persuaded him to write for the paper. Imagine the frothy excitement of the media commentators of the day: "Scott chic: dining with killers!"

I arranged the meeting with Adams through Bennett because I knew he knew Adams and because our then Irish correspondent, David Sharrock, was writing a biography of Adams which he had told me was going to be unsympathetic. But I did ask Sharrock (now the Telegraph's Belfast correspondent) if he could arrange dinner with two leading unionist politicians for the following evening. This he did. It is odd that Glover cannot find room for this detail.

Next Glover finds that Jonathan Freedland, this paper's policy editor, and I conducted a "Pravda"-like interview with McGuinnesss and "put him under no pressure about punishment beatings".

This is what McGuinness said on the record about punishment beatings in that interview: "I think punishment beatings are brutal, and I think they should stop. No matter who's involved. That is my view and it has been my view for some considerable time. Now, I can't make a clearer statement than that. I think they are wrong and I think they should stop." Glover could not find room for this quote.

And so on. In a sense, this is all missing the point. The Spectator is there as a journal of opinion. It has lots of opinions - many of them irritating, some of them interesting, some barking mad. What it has had trouble with is facts. It often can't get them right and its response when challenged is always to feel persecuted and shout its opinions even louder.

If other journalists could learn to realise this is the game they might be slower to rush in with the "controversy" stories that the Spectator so badly needs to oxygenate its little band of readers. As for the Guardian's views on Ireland, what you see is what you get. There are no secret cells, no hidden strings. (Before Glover makes an exciting new "discovery": Bennett is a friend of mine and we are writing a script together. Not about Ireland which, he may believe it or not, we seldom discuss.)

Anyone who doesn't like our views on Ireland is free to damn them. Glover's arrogant mistake is to believe that those who hold different views from his own cannot have arrived at them openly and honestly.

I happen to disagree passionately with the Telegraph's views on Ireland. I sometimes think it odd that Charles Moore, its editor, should stand on a political platform in Belfast to denounce the proposed Patten Reforms of the RUC. But I believe he holds his opinions sincerely and honestly and I respect both them and him. And it wouldn't occur to me to ask what his wife thinks about Northern Ireland or whether she has shaped his views.

One of Moore's regular contributors and sources on Ireland is the former IRA killer, Sean O'Callaghan, who in 1990 was given a 539-year sentence for two murders and more than 40 other terrorist offences. Unlike Bennett, his convictions were never overturned. Within eight years Moore was paying him a lucrative serialisation fee for his memoirs. He is, I note, a welcome contributor to the pages of the Spectator.

In 1993 - long before the current peace process - O'Callaghan was visited in prison by Andrew Neil, then editor of the Sunday Times. In 1994/5 Moore also made the journey to Maghaberry prison to listen to him. The two men got on well. I would be surprised if Glover has not also been seeking his counsel.

Bennett's commitment to the peace process is every bit as solid as O'Callaghan's, and Glover can produce no evidence to the contrary. Why, then, is Bennett demonised three weeks running by the Spectator and not O'Callaghan? Is this anything to do with Glover's supposed subject - "Media Studies" - or is it simple political prejudice laced with personal venom?

But you have to admit, they got me off my sofa. Now, boys, why not find another window?
fields.bodyText: Running a small weekly journal of opinion presents its editor with the recurring problem: visibility. How, with a limited marketing budget, do you create enough noise to get your opinions noticed? The answer successive editors of the Spectator have come up with is to stir up controversy. Typically, this involves throwing a stone through someone's front window and then waiting behind the hedge for the red-faced resident to appear. This is not a risk-free enterprise, but there is also risk for the red-faced resident. Chasing giggling schoolboys down the street is at best undignified and, at worst, may invite another stone the moment the front door is closed. Often it is best simply to stay put on the sofa and call the glazier the next day. So it is with a slightly heavy heart - and only after three stones - that I stir myself. The missiles that have been lobbed through the Guardian's window recently concern our coverage of Ireland. Something that may have long been apparent to alert Guardian readers has come to the attention of the Spectator's media columnist: that we have, in our editorials, shown a considerable degree of understanding towards the leaders of Sinn Fein as they have attempted the near-impossible task of persuading a movement devoted to violence that democratic politics is a more worthwhile and effective way of resolving the nightmare of conflict in Northern Ireland. We have also been careful to note how the problems the Sinn Fein leaders have with their hardliners are mirrored by the difficulties David Trimble has with his instinctive rejectionists. This is not, you might think, a terribly extreme position. It is, give or take the odd nuance, the position of the British, American and Irish governments. Senior British intelligence sources, policemen and politicians on both sides of the Atlantic have shown an engaged interest in our editorials. As a stance on Northern Ireland it might be thought at least as mainstream as, say, the Spectator's sister paper, the Daily Telegraph, which has been resolutely hostile to the peace process from the start. As on most newspapers, our editorial line is settled upon by the leader writers of the day - in our case, generally between four and six in number. Three or four of us have written on Ireland in recent months. The two main writers arrived at broadly the same conclusion about Ireland after years of discussions with different sources on all sides of the political, religious and international divides. At the same time as the leaders have appeared we have run a variety of op-ed pieces on Ireland, many of them notably unsympathetic to Sinn Fein. In the past year we have run pieces by Hugo Young, Roy Hattersley, David Trimble (three times), John Taylor and Seumas Mallon. We have run one piece by Gerry Adams. In addition to this I personally signed up serialisation of Eamonn Collins's account of being in the IRA - a work so detested by the Provos that Collins paid for it with his life. We are now being sued for our coverage of this book by his cousin Micky, accused in the book of being in the IRA. So far, so unremarkable. You may not agree with the editorial line. It may turn out to be wise, we may be made to look foolish. But we have been straight down the middle in our reporting and have deliberately allowed plenty of space to different views. Our editorial line has been honestly arrived at after considerable thought, soul-searching and open discussion. The media commentator of the Spectator, Stephen Glover, thinks otherwise. He made the startling discovery - known, I guess, to all Guardian employees and numerous others in Fleet Street and the worlds of publishing and television - that the deputy editor of the Guardian, Georgina Henry, lives with the author Ronan Bennett, who is open about his support for a united Ireland. After considerable research, Mr Glover chanced upon the singular fact that Georgina was pregnant. Sleuthing further, he found out that Bennett had once been in Long Kesh and had been convicted of the murder of an RUC policeman - though he was just cute enough to concede that Bennett had also subsequently been acquitted. He also told his readers that a serial Bennett had made about the Easter 1916 rising had been rejected by the Irish TV station, RTE, for being "too sectarian". All this was almost too exciting to be true, especially when Glover subsequently thought he had discovered that Georgina wrote leaders on Northern Ireland and was in the habit of slagging off our sister paper, the Observer, for being "dangerously sympathetic to the Unionists". Bingo! Bennett had not only impregnated Georgina with his baby, he had also succeeded in impregnating her with his sectarian views and - through her - had turned the Guardian into "an alarmingly pro-IRA" paper. You doubt that a "media commentator" could pen so crude a sub-Freudian analysis of a newspaper? Oh but he did - right down to stating: "she is pregnant with his child" [emphasis added]. Moreover, Glover had found out, all this had been done behind the editor's back - though he dangled the theory that I enjoyed the "chic idea of drinking with Provos". And all this without us ever telling Guardian readers who Bennett was! The little boys must have hugged themselves with glee as they penned the headline: "The Republican cell at the heart of the Guardian." The problem was that virtually none of it was true. Bennett's serial has not been rejected by RTE. Georgina has never written a leader on Northern Ireland and does not hold the view of the Observer ascribed to her. She had a baby last December (do try to keep up, Mr Glover!), was on maternity leave at the time of the recent editorials that have most offended the Spectator and played absolutely no part in their formulation. The development of the Guardian leader line was emphatically not done behind my back. Bennett's time in Long Kesh was hardly a secret from Guardian readers: he wrote a 2,000-word G2 cover story on the subject in September 1998 (since then he has written precisely one piece for the Guardian - a book review). And no leader writer on the Guardian - myself excepted - has ever discussed Irish politics with Bennett. This was a fairly spectacular list of errors and might be thought to torpedo the entire basis of the piece. It is, as I have discovered, a mistake to try to discuss matters such as this with Glover himself, since he has only a hazy notion of respecting private conversations. So I wrote a long, careful - and private - letter to the magazine's editor, Boris Johnson, asking if he would consider correcting the five main errors. There was a long silence from the Spectator's offices at Doughty Street, so I rang Johnson. He exploded into a string of apologies and conceded they'd got all the "personal stuff" wrong. But, pressed for a correction, he got distinctly ratty and described the errors as trivial and "hair-splitting". He muttered something about our leaders immediately after the Docklands bomb and promised to write me a letter. No letter arrived. I faxed him our leaders on the Docklands bomb, which unequivocally condemned the IRA. As his deadline neared I rang Johnson again. I could, he said, write a letter but there would be no correction. It transpired during these exchanges that anyone who felt any admiration for anything Adams and McGuinness had done during these past five years was regarded by the Spectator as being "pro-IRA". No letter came. The magazine appeared with no correction. Johnson is reputed to have a sense of humour, so I penned a jokey 200-word leader about the matter in which one in every two facts was wrong, and invited readers to guess which was true and which was garbage. Johnson said he loved it and asked if he could repeat some of Glover's accusations in a letter to the Guardian. I said that would be just fine once they corrected all the mistakes in his own magazine. I settled back on the sofa. End of the affair. Wrong. There was still giggling from behind the hedge. Johnson briefed a number of journalists about the "controversy" and gained his quota of helpful publicity. Several papers wrote about the "row" until Guardian readers were the only ones left out of the loop. Hence this article. He returned to the theme last week, more elegantly than Glover, but still maintaining that the original article was substantially correct ("if we got anything significantly wrong (and I don't think we did), then I apologise unreservedly"). It was a more moderate rehearsal of the cell thesis, and we all presumed that was truly the end of the affair. Far from it. This week Glover returned to his sombre duty. Same theme, same headline. The notion that something might be corrected (something the Guardian itself does as a matter of routine and policy four or five times a day) had by now become a sinister inhibition on free speech. Even to ask showed that the Guardian - supposedly a champion of open debate - was "worse than the Downing Street heavies". Glover bravely announced that he would not be silenced by these "threats". Glover then did what is known in Fleet Street as "doing a Glover". He glancingly accepted that he had got some things wrong, while claiming that the real truth was even more significant. For the record, he now accepts that RTE did not, as he originally claimed, reject Bennett's series. He has replaced this with a new claim ("possibly more illuminating") - that RTE demanded changes to the script. This, illuminatingly enough, is also untrue. Glover is also happy to accept that Georgina has never written a leader on Northern Ireland. He thinks this a "minor point", adding: "It scarcely matters that her fingers never make contact with the keyboard." There is a also an interesting (if unacknowledged) shift in language. Glover has quietly retreated from his deliberate and repeated charges that the Guardian is "alarming pro-IRA" to the charge that the Guardian is now "pro-Sinn Fein/IRA", or even just plain pro-Sinn Fein. All this is a start. But his dogged researches have turned up fresh outrages. Last year, he reports, Bennett introduced me to Gerry Adams. Bennett did make a call on my behalf - though it was three years ago. I wanted to meet Adams, who at this time was talking freely to the British, American and Irish governments. This is hardly shocking - or new - stuff. The great CP Scott met Michael Collins twice at the time of the October 1921 "peace process". He even persuaded him to write for the paper. Imagine the frothy excitement of the media commentators of the day: "Scott chic: dining with killers!" I arranged the meeting with Adams through Bennett because I knew he knew Adams and because our then Irish correspondent, David Sharrock, was writing a biography of Adams which he had told me was going to be unsympathetic. But I did ask Sharrock (now the Telegraph's Belfast correspondent) if he could arrange dinner with two leading unionist politicians for the following evening. This he did. It is odd that Glover cannot find room for this detail. Next Glover finds that Jonathan Freedland, this paper's policy editor, and I conducted a "Pravda"-like interview with McGuinnesss and "put him under no pressure about punishment beatings". This is what McGuinness said on the record about punishment beatings in that interview: "I think punishment beatings are brutal, and I think they should stop. No matter who's involved. That is my view and it has been my view for some considerable time. Now, I can't make a clearer statement than that. I think they are wrong and I think they should stop." Glover could not find room for this quote. And so on. In a sense, this is all missing the point. The Spectator is there as a journal of opinion. It has lots of opinions - many of them irritating, some of them interesting, some barking mad. What it has had trouble with is facts. It often can't get them right and its response when challenged is always to feel persecuted and shout its opinions even louder. If other journalists could learn to realise this is the game they might be slower to rush in with the "controversy" stories that the Spectator so badly needs to oxygenate its little band of readers. As for the Guardian's views on Ireland, what you see is what you get. There are no secret cells, no hidden strings. (Before Glover makes an exciting new "discovery": Bennett is a friend of mine and we are writing a script together. Not about Ireland which, he may believe it or not, we seldom discuss.) Anyone who doesn't like our views on Ireland is free to damn them. Glover's arrogant mistake is to believe that those who hold different views from his own cannot have arrived at them openly and honestly. I happen to disagree passionately with the Telegraph's views on Ireland. I sometimes think it odd that Charles Moore, its editor, should stand on a political platform in Belfast to denounce the proposed Patten Reforms of the RUC. But I believe he holds his opinions sincerely and honestly and I respect both them and him. And it wouldn't occur to me to ask what his wife thinks about Northern Ireland or whether she has shaped his views. One of Moore's regular contributors and sources on Ireland is the former IRA killer, Sean O'Callaghan, who in 1990 was given a 539-year sentence for two murders and more than 40 other terrorist offences. Unlike Bennett, his convictions were never overturned. Within eight years Moore was paying him a lucrative serialisation fee for his memoirs. He is, I note, a welcome contributor to the pages of the Spectator. In 1993 - long before the current peace process - O'Callaghan was visited in prison by Andrew Neil, then editor of the Sunday Times. In 1994/5 Moore also made the journey to Maghaberry prison to listen to him. The two men got on well. I would be surprised if Glover has not also been seeking his counsel. Bennett's commitment to the peace process is every bit as solid as O'Callaghan's, and Glover can produce no evidence to the contrary. Why, then, is Bennett demonised three weeks running by the Spectator and not O'Callaghan? Is this anything to do with Glover's supposed subject - "Media Studies" - or is it simple political prejudice laced with personal venom? But you have to admit, they got me off my sofa. Now, boys, why not find another window?

fields.headline: A play for fresh talent
fields.standfirst: Wanted: young person, 18-25, with passionate interest in music, good prospects.  Andy Parfait  on Radio 1's scheme to attract six of the best
fields.trailText: Radio 1 is on a mission. We are looking for six creative and talented young people to come and work with us. We aim to bring the best new music to the widest possible young audience and we have an important role to play in introducing new talent to our listeners.
fields.body:
Radio 1 is on a mission. We are looking for six creative and talented young people to come and work with us. We aim to bring the best new music to the widest possible young audience and we have an important role to play in introducing new talent to our listeners.

The most important ingredient needed to achieve this is a young, energised and skilled group of people, which includes producers, broadcast assistants, music programmers and, of course, DJs. It's not an easy job because our audiences demand a service from Radio 1 that is in touch, credible and knows what it is talking about. The best way to achieve that is to ensure that there is always fresh, young talent in the team.

Since I've been controller, I've wanted to start a Radio 1 trainee scheme that attracts a range of talented young people. The idea is to immerse trainees in the channel's culture and train them in all aspects of the station, whether it be marketing, production or being a DJ.

These days so many of the roles have become interchangeable. Zoë Ball was a researcher on the Big Breakfast, Jo Whiley a journalist and Mark Radcliffe a radio producer. Many of our specialist DJs work in the music industry some way or another, so I did not want to be prescriptive and pigeonhole people from the beginning.

This is the sort of scheme that I would have given everything for when I was 20. I was passionate about working in radio from a ludicrously early age (eight, actually). It was not until I was in my 20s that I got a traineeship as a studio manager. The BBC's trainee schemes at the time seemed completely impenetrable.

Hopefully, not any more. I feel this new trainee scheme, supported by the Guardian, can provide a point of access for young people and has an important role that can be systematic in its training and talent development. That way, we won't leave the next generation at Radio 1 to chance.

The scheme is open to anyone aged 18-25, and each traineeship will last 12 months. In the first six months, each person will spend a short period working in each of the major departments in Radio 1, as well as undergoing formal training in all the digital technologies, editing, music-making and the internet. In the second part of the scheme, each candidate will be placed within a single department or programme.

I would like a group of people from really varied backgrounds and their selection will be based solely on their potential, not on any previous radio experience. It will benefit Radio 1 in that it will bring a new perspective and fresh ideas into the station.

We took the decision to put the application process on the Radio 1 website. This came about when we were asking current staff and DJs what skills they felt were important to their job. A quick look around the Radio 1 building is enough to show that being computer literate and internet-friendly are very much a part of working life here. The second stage of the application will be designed to draw on each candidate's creative talents and his/her ability, both to generate new and exciting ideas and communicate them effectively.

If I were giving advice to people thinking about applying for the scheme, I would tell them to trust their instincts and to be honest when filling in the questionnaire. No two people who work at Radio 1 at the moment share exactly the same talents and experience, and we are looking for the same variety of strengths in the successful trainees.

The only unchangeable criteria is that anyone who works here must have an active passion for music, which is why this has become one of the key phrases of the Radio 1 talent campaign. Also, the more they know about the station's output, both in terms of the shows and the music that we play, the more likely they are to be the kind of person we are looking for. I would encourage them not to be put off by the high number of applicants that we are expecting. There are enough different stages to the selection process to ensure their strengths will shine through.

To enter the Radio 1 talent scheme, go to www.bbc.co.uk/radio1 or call 0906 5550000. Brochures with details of the scheme are available from sponsors Top Shop, Top Man and Odeon cinemas. They are also available at WH Smith

webTitle: Edinburgh Festival: Dyke to give MacTaggart

fields.headline: Edinburgh Festival: Dyke to give MacTaggart
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, director-general of the BBC, will be delivering the keynote MacTaggart Lecture at this year's Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival (GEITF 2000), celebrating its 25th year.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, director-general of the BBC, will be delivering the keynote MacTaggart Lecture at this year's Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival (GEITF 2000), celebrating its 25th year.

It will be Greg Dyke's second MacTaggart lecture - the first time this has happened. He last took the platform six years ago with a strong and much lauded attack on the politicisation of broadcasting.

"It's a real honour to be invited back," he said. "As ever, the Edinburgh Television Festival falls at a crucial time; this autumn, the industry will be preparing for the forthcoming communications bill and I welcome the opportunity to try to set the agenda for the debate to come.

"I thought the MacTaggart was something you get to do only once in a lifetime - until I became director-general of the BBC."

The MacTaggart Lecture is one of the key events of the broadcasting year, the scene of some priceless moments and ground-setting debates. It was during the MacTaggart that Janet Street-Porter gave her three Ms theory on broadcast management in 1995: "male, middle class and mediocre"; the next year, John Birt argued for an increased licence fee; 1997 saw screenwriters, Marks and Gran, accuse the BBC of stifling creative talent. Former speakers include Peter Bazalgette, Rupert Murdoch, Dennis Potter, Michael Grade and Richard Eyre.

"Greg Dyke is the man of the moment, the perfect person to deliver this agenda setting lecture," said Dawn Airey, GEITF 2000's advisory chairwoman and C5's director of programmes.

Edinburgh International Television Festival 2000 The MacTaggart Lecture takes place on Friday 25 August at 6pm in the McEwan Hall, Edinburgh. GEITF 2000, the most important television event of the year, runs from the 25-28 August; For more details call 0207 379 4519; Fax: 0207 836 0702 or go to www.geitf.co.uk.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst:
Frank S Dobson

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Newspapers: I have read the Times for many years, and suspect I'm one of the few readers who read the Sunday Times almost from cover to cover. But, having said that, I'm an avid reader of any other paper I come across: the Sun, Mirror, even the Guardian.
fields.body:
Newspapers: I have read the Times for many years, and suspect I'm one of the few readers who read the Sunday Times almost from cover to cover. But, having said that, I'm an avid reader of any other paper I come across: the Sun, Mirror, even the Guardian.

Magazines: I read a large range of computer magazines. Also, as I'm still into environmental education, publications like the RSPB magazine and in particular British Wildlife.

Books: I'm one of those people who likes to have four books on the go at once. I'm keen on sailing, so CS Forester and the Hornblower books are great favourites. I like Robert Graves, and am reading Goodbye to All That at the moment. Most impressed.

Film: My life is very hectic and I just don't get time to see films. My favourite is Das Boot - I must have seen that about 14 times. I reckon that if you put me in a U-boat I could take command. I nearly saw Shakespeare in Love by mistake, instead of archive films on British waterways - went into the wrong bit of the cinema.

Television: I'm very keen on wildlife documentaries. I very much enjoy sitting in warmth and comfort watching some documentary on people in great discomfort in faraway lands. Lunchtime, I have something to eat and a cup of coffee and watch the BBC news at 1pm.

Radio: I'm an avid listener of Radio 4: listen to almost anything. I like a lot of the plays, in particular the classic serial on a Sunday afternoon. I hear the Archers about once a month and that's enough to keep in touch with the various plots.

Ads: A favourite is the Milka chocolate advert, which has a little boy who has lost his chocolate rabbit and the police get it back for him. It appears on Vox, a German channel, every Easter. My all-time favourite is the Anchor Butter dancing cows.

Multimedia: I've just learned to fly, so I've got a flight simulator on the computer. The Encyclopaedia Britannica can make me seem brilliant to my grandchildren.

Much to Frank Dobson's annoyance, Frank S Dobson is running as an independent candidate in the race to become London's mayor.

fields.headline: The great pretenders
fields.standfirst:
Triple counting, repeat messaging, pre-buttals - tonight's Panorama will reveal the inside workings of Labour's spin machine. Programme editor, Peter Horrocks , reveals life in the glare of the government's media manipulators

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The government often accuses the media of being obsessed with covering spin and government presentation, to the exclusion of issues of substance. But it's a criticism that's strange from this government, which believes in the crucial importance of presentation.
fields.body:
The government often accuses the media of being obsessed with covering spin and government presentation, to the exclusion of issues of substance. But it's a criticism that's strange from this government, which believes in the crucial importance of presentation.

In tonight's Panorama, Spin Doctors, we examine the use of spin in the NHS. John Ware reports how the use of PR has become not just an issue of media manipulation, but of direct relevance to the formation of policy. He concludes that the inflation of spending claims by the government has increased expectations of what Labour has done for the NHS since it came to office.

That meant that when the January NHS crisis hit the prime minster had to dip into his war chest to convince the public that he was serious about changing the NHS. Now, that pledge has been downgraded to an aspiration, and the spin doctors are in a fierce debate trying to massage expectations of what Blair's promises on the David Frost programme meant.

Labour's concentration on presentation is vividly captured in Panorama's interview with Romola Christopherson, the former head of communications at the department of health. She says: "I think they have devoted an enormous amount of energy to that communications drive." She reveals that she warned against the notorious triple counting involved in the government's announcement of a three year, £21bn spending plan on the NHS.

Christopherson says: "I certainly had reservations about it . . . The accusations of triple counting and the use of mirrors were accusations that I could anticipate." She says she alerted ministers to the potential criticism, but in the end they decided to go ahead.

Like the Clinton team, Campbell and company are advocates of the "permanent campaign". Blair has even described the war in Kosovo as having elements of a political campaign and he believes that an essential part of a campaign is good presentation.

In last night's BBC2 retrospective on Kosovo, Moral Combat, he told Allan Little: "It wasn't just a military campaign, it was also a propaganda campaign and we had to take our public opinions with us . . . I felt a bit like, you know, at the beginning of a big political campaign."

If the Kosovo war was like a political campaign, Christopherson goes further. She says that for New Labour everything is like an election campaign: "I think they really have been in a campaigning mode, interestingly enough from virtually day one of getting into power."

One of the tenets of that philosophy is that most voters pay almost no attention to political news, so to get messages through, they have to be repeated ad nauseam. Christopherson reveals the thinking: "I remember Alastair Campbell saying: 'By the time you and me have got absolutely fed up to the back teeth with repetition, that's probably when it's beginning to get through to the wider constituency.'"

Spin Doctors details how £20m for the new instant booking system for NHS patients has been announced on four separate occasions: in September 1998, November 1998, April 1999 and September 1999. On each occasion, the announcements talked of the service being "boosted" or "an extra £20m" or "a £20m boost". None of the press notices at the time of the three repeated announcements made clear that this money had previously been made available. It is, of course, reasonable for the government to reiterate its message, but is it right when those announcements do not make clear that they are being repeated?

Whitehall civil servants have told Panorama that such statements are always cleared directly by ministers, who are keen that the words "modernised", "beacon", "extra" and "boost" are frequently used.

Clearly, the media techniques the government employs were used, although probably to a lesser extent, by the Tories in the past. There are also reasonable arguments to make for the professional implementation of information and you might expect to hear the health secretary making that case on tonight's programme. But, as we say in the trade, "he declined to appear".

The battle over interviews is a vital one for broadcasters. Print can get away with not having on-the-record quotes, but TV and radio need interviewees. It is of particular importance for current affairs programmes to call the powerful to account. But ministers are increasingly careful about when to appear. It is no use researchers and producers arguing with government press officers that the public interest would be served by them coming on. They invariably ask: "What's in it for us?"

Of course, the Conservatives played this game very hard too. When I edited Newsnight from 1994 to 1997, predominantly in the Conservative era, government press officers would insist that ministers would not discuss directly with their Labour shadows. They wanted to be "lone and last".

Labour, naturally, complained bitterly to us about the injustice of this, but the moment they were in power they immediately instituted a similar system. Just count the number of times that a minister discusses directly with his or her opposite number on Today or Newsnight. It's very much the exception.

For a pre-recorded programme, such as Panorama, the interviewing game is played at least as toughly. Cabinet ministers make a calculation about whether they want to appear. If they feel that a particular programme has little in it for them they may well put up a junior minister or decide that no one will appear.

As well as considering the merits of each case, the departments also take into account the track record of each programme. In some cases, New Labour can be very open. For instance, Downing Street has just announced that they will be granting access to Michael Cockerell to make a film about Number Ten's media operation. But Panorama is now very much out of favour (and this article won't help, but there you are).

Panorama's main offence has been three programmes we have done in the past year looking at devolution and Labour selection procedures in Wales, Scotland and London. The programme broadcast in December, The Blair Mayor Project, examined how the Labour party's London membership lists came to make their way from Millbank to Frank Dobson's campaign.

Margaret McDonagh, Labour's general secretary, complained about the programme repeatedly both in advance and after transmission. However, despite being responsible for the implementation of the rules for Labour's selection contests, she has always refused to be interviewed on this subject (or indeed on any other).

That does not prevent her complaining of bias. Of course, it might be that the perceived bias could be ameliorated by her appearing and making her case, but she decides not to. The BBC is then left in the Kafkaesque situation of responding to a complaint of bias, to which we cannot reply: "Well, why didn't you just come on the programme and explain yourself?" Our duty is to be fair, irrespective of whether interviewees appear.

This history of complaints against the programme certainly impedes us in our dealings with the highly co-ordinated government information machine. When BBC current affairs was making the Kosovo programme Moral Combat, we requested an interview with Blair, an interview which, given the outcome of the war, would probably be relatively benign for the government.

After many weeks, we had heard nothing from Downing Street. We then spoke to a press officer who explained the hold up. "We thought you were something to do with Panorama." We explained that the programme was on BBC2 and was not therefore a Panorama. "Oh, that's all right then" said the press officer and the interview went ahead.

It no longer shocks me that the government machine plays such a blatant "favourites game". But it may surprise viewers who believe that decisions about the presentation of information and the appearance of ministers on programmes is part of a compact with the public about their right to have information presented fairly and defended openly. That is increasingly not the case.

Peter Horrocks is editor of Panorama and was executive editor of Moral Combat: Nato at War on BBC2. Panorama, the Spin Doctors, is on BBC1 tonight at 10pm.

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown - the Guardian's Northern Ireland correspondent in  the early 1970s - looks again at the shocking events of the day known as  Bloody Sunday
fields.trailText: Monday, 3pm: Derek Brown - the Guardian's Northern Ireland correspondent in the early 1970s - looks again at the shocking events of the day known as Bloody Sunday
fields.body:
Why is Bloody Sunday in the news again?

This morning's Guardian reveals that three weeks before the shootings, a senior British army commander wrote in a secret memo that anti-riot measures like rubber bullets and CS gas no longer deterred rioters. He recommended that "the minimum force necessary to achieve a restoration of law and order is to shoot selected ringleaders..." The memo also recommended that soldiers use smaller-calibre ammunition than usual when dealing with rioters - a suggestion that may throw light on the mysterious destruction, two months ago, of three army rifles used on Bloody Sunday.

How has the secret memo come to light?

Veteran Northern Ireland reporters Peter Pringle and Phil Jacobsen unearthed the document while researching their forthcoming book on Bloody Sunday. It had been declassified by Lord Saville, the law lord leading the latest inquiry into the shootings.

Will it help Saville to establish the truth at last?

The army has always stoutly denied that it ever issued shoot-to-kill orders in Northern Ireland, especially against unarmed civilians. The memo does not amount to such an order, but it does indicate that the top brass at least considered a new and lethal policy to deal with civil unrest. The destruction of the Bloody Sunday rifles is a setback to the inquiry, which could have had them examined to see whether they had been adapted to fire smaller rounds of ammunition.

Why does the size of the bullets matter?

The standard 7.62mm rounds used by the then-standard issue Self Loading Rifle had deadly penetrative power. As the secret memo points out, they could easily pass through a target body and go on to kill another, innocent, person. (This actually happened at least once in Derry in the early 1970s, when two IRA men were killed by a single army round). If the army wanted to use lethal force to quell a riot, they could not use the standard SLR rounds without significant risk of 'collateral damage', but would instead have to adapt the weapon to take different ammunition.

Why were the weapons destroyed?

According to defence secretary, it was the result of a bureaucratic cock-up.

Has the Saville inquiry made much progress?

It is due to begin taking evidence in public on March 27 at Derry's Guildhall. In two years it has amassed 60,000 pages of written submissions and has been dogged by lengthy legal delays. The inquiry tried to ensure that soldiers giving evidence would be identified in court, but the House of Lords ruled that they were entitled to anonymity. Now lawers for the families of the 14 people killed - one was fatally wounded and died some months after Bloody Sunday - are asking the High Court in Belfast for a postponement of the main hearing, to allow them to digest the vast mass of material involved in the inquiry, which has so far cost £13m.

Wasn't there a major inquiry after the shootings?

It was headed by Lord Widgery who, to the unbridled contempt of the victims' families, said that the army's conduct on Bloody Sunday "bordered on the reckless". He also said in his report that "Civilian, as well as Army, evidence made it clear that there was a substantial number of civilians in the area who were armed with firearms" - a claim hotly denied by many witnesses. The Saville inquiry has already raised strong doubts about another feature of the forensic evidence given to Widgery, suggesting that some of the victims had handled firearms. The tests made at the time, it has said, were not reliable.

Why was the new inquiry set up?

It was announced by Tony Blair in January 1998, at a time when the recently elected Labour government was desperate to restore momentum to the faltering Northern Ireland peace process. He was also responding to the persistent demands of the Irish government - closely involved in the peace negotiations - for a fresh investigation. Several months before the announcement, Dublin gave the British government a detailed submission, setting out its case for a definitive inquiry.

 Bloody Sunday: Those are real bullets aren't they? by Peter Pringle and Philip Jacobsen, to be published by Fourth Estate on March 27.

fields.headline: Frying times
fields.trailText:
Sweet farewell in last battering
Gastronomes the world over are in mourning for the legendary Haven Chip Shop in Stonehaven, near Aberdeen, which turned off its friers for the last time this week.
fields.body:
Sweet farewell in last battering
Gastronomes the world over are in mourning for the legendary Haven Chip Shop in Stonehaven, near Aberdeen, which turned off its friers for the last time this week.

Quite aside from serving an excellent plate of cod and chips, the Haven was renowned as the birthplace of that supreme culinary masterpiece, the deep-fried Mars bar.

The Haven's owners first began experimenting with the idea of battered chocolate in the early 1990s. "I'll never forget the first time I tried one," said one convert. "As soon as I tasted that unique fusion of melted chocolate and pure fat I was completely hooked. In many ways it was better than sex."

The trend soon caught on, and before long chip shops throughout Scotland, and then Britain, began serving up an artery-clogging selection of deep-fried confectionery. Only last month a Paris chip shop, Le Chippier, included the delicacy on its menu.

Sadly, despite its finest creation living on, the Haven itself has succumbed to competition from two rival shops, and this week battered and fried its final chocolate snack. "They helped me work, rest and play," sighed one disappointed customer, "Although after the heart attack I did have to cut down to three a week."
The Aberdeen Independent

Robust scoring
There has been concern lately about the on-field behaviour of Britain's professional footballers. Compared with recent events in Sedgefield, however, the antics of even your most seasoned Premiership hard-nut appear no more threatening than a night out at the Royal Ballet.

Trouble started during the annual Shrove Tuesday football game on Sedgefield's village green. A tradition supposedly dating back almost 900 years, the game has little to do with modern football, involving instead a small metal ball which is chased by several dozen players who try to kick it through a green hoop.

"There aren't really any rules as such," said one player. "Which is just as well because even if there were, we're all far too pissed-up to take any notice of them."

There is always an element of rugged competitiveness to the game. But this year things got somewhat out of hand, with an argument between players leading to a full-scale riot in which several police officers were injured and a police vehicle overturned.

Order was eventually restored and the game completed, although who actually won, and by what score, no one seems to know. "It's not the winning that counts," opined one player. "It's the taking part - and kicking someone's head in."
The Hartlepool Mail

High-tech beams down
Since one of its residents first picked up a football and ran with it, thus creating an entirely new sport, not a great deal of interest has happened in Rugby. But all that changed this week with a spate of UFO sightings over the Warwickshire town.

The sightings began in February and have continued on a regular basis. "I was driving along the A45, when I saw these large triangular orange lights in the mirror, which was strange because there was no other traffic on the road," said Mike Harris, a local resident. "I watched them for a while, and then they disappeared. I'm very sceptical about UFOs, but I really do have no other explanation for what I saw."

There have been numerous reports of the mysterious object, described as either triangular or diamond-shaped, and travelling at high speed. UFO enthusiasts are now flocking into the area in the hope of more sightings.

"I'm keeping an open mind," said Geoffrey Brownlow, a UFO investigator. "But considering the speed and the abrupt change of course, it's clear that whatever they are they're extremely advanced pieces of machinery."

"Obviously not made in Britain then," commented one local man.
The Rugby Advertiser

Pig in crimplene
We all experience the odd pig of a day, but few of us, perhaps so literally as pensioner June Merrin.

Ms Merrin, 70, of St Agnes, Cornwall, was enjoying a quiet afternoon stroll in the countryside, when she was accosted by Banjo - a runaway pig.

The playful porker, an Oxfordshire Black, had escaped from a farm with his sister Peggity. But while Peggity stayed in the farm garden eating daffodils, Banjo decided to try his luck further afield, setting off down a nearby lane where, having chased the doctor's wife Jane Henderson into a hedge, he came across Ms Merrin. He found himself irresistibly attracted her crimplene anorak.

While the panting pensioner tried to fend him off with her walking stick, Banjo butted her to the ground and began tugging at the anorak, trying to remove it. Ms Merrin was only saved when a passing motorist pulled over and chased the pig away.

"The farmer sent her a lovely box of pork sausages," said one neighbour, "Although whether or not it was Banjo inside them he didn't say."
Cornwall Online

Letter of the Week
I know this might not be a nice subject, but every day I walk my children home from school and we have to tip-toe our way through countless piles of dogs' mess.

I love Clevedon, and wouldn't want to move, but this mess is absolutely disgusting. I am not a dog hater, I have one of my own, and I always pick up after her. Nonetheless, the route that I walk is always full of piles of crap, and children have to walk that way too. Are people just too bloody lazy, or dirty, or is it simply that they don't care?

I think they should re-name Clevedon, with its lovely Victorian seafront and its piles of dog crap. If anyone can think of a new title please post it.
Fed Up Bristol Evening Post

Response:
How does Crapton-on-Sea sound?
Alf Barker
Bristol Evening Post

fields.headline: Too good to be true
fields.standfirst:
Tomorrow the internet goldrush will reach a new pitch of excitement with the flotation of Lastminute.com. But amid the euphoria and free spending, there are alarming echoes of past bubbles. Larry Elliot asks if this one is about to burst

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Tomorrow the internet goldrush will reach a new pitch of excitement with the flotation of Lastminute.com. But amid the euphoria and free spending, there are alarming echoes of past bubbles.
fields.body:
It's bonanza time.Lastminute. com is coming to the stock market tomorrow and the world is going share crazy. Everybody, it seems, wants a piece of a company that at the 11th hour can get you a flight to Spain or two tickets for the theatre. So much so that by tomorrow night Lastminute.com will be worth - on paper at least - as much as Manchester United, the world's richest football club.

The dizzying price tag attached to a company that has been in business for all of 19 months seems a perfect symbol for the giddy mood of affluence that has gripped much of Britain since the words dot com became synonymous with easy money. With a pressure cooker stockmarket fuelling a frenzy of spending, the signs of an 80s-style boom are all around: soaring house prices, roaring sales of the most preposterous luxury goods, and the surest indicator of all, figures for the consumption of champagne that suggest some people are confusing it with sparkling water.

But as punters sit and dream of the untold riches that Lastminute.com will bring them, they would do well to ponder four little words - the four most dangerous words in finance. This time it's different. Of course, speculators caught up in the frenzy are not doing any pondering at all. They're sticking to the dreaming. We've had stock market bubbles before, so their argument goes, but they were based on uncontrollable greed and hysteria. This time it's different. We've had stock market bubbles before, but back then there was no Alan Greenspan, the head of America's central bank, to steer us to safety. This time it's different. We've had stock market bubbles before, but that was when companies were run by charlatans and deadbeats rather than dynamic, young entrepreneurs. This time it's different.

But what if it isn't? What if this bubble - this wild speculation in companies unheard of six months ago - is about to go the way of all the others, from tulip mania in 17th-century Holland to the Japanese stock market in the late 80s - and end in a spectacular crash?

If - or rather when - it happens, it will happen suddenly. And the impact will be savage. Two weeks before the crash of 1929, the New York Times carried a headline: "Stocks will stay at high level for years to come." A week later, when the first signs of a problem were emerging, the eminent Yale economist Irving Fisher, had some soothing words. "Fisher says prices of stocks are low," declared the stately New York daily. In subheadings it added: "Quotations have not caught up with real values as yet, he declares. Sees no cause for slump."

A week later came Black Tuesday, when the floor of the New York Stock Exchange descended into pandemonium and dealers tried to offload shares at any price. Stocks that had been previously been the most fashionable - such as Radio Corporation of America - were among the biggest losers. The pages of the Times took on a more sombre tone.

Slowly, perhaps too slowly, today's policy makers are starting to wake up to the idea that it could all happen again, that the laws of economics have not been rewritten by Bill Gates et al, and that unless investors tread warily, Lastminute.com could turn into Lastgasp.com. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, last week urged investors to exercise caution, suggesting "people will want to look at the performance of each of these individual (high-tech) companies."

Howard Davies, head of the Financial Services Authority, the City's watchdog, was even more blunt, saying: "When a company is valued more on hope than on expectation, then you can expect it to be a volatile stock. We know from previous experience that many of the companies around at the moment will not be around in three to five years."

A similar attempt to let the air gently out of the stock market bubble is underway on the other side of the Atlantic, where Greenspan has been nudging up interest rates to slow down America's booming economy. He believes that there has been a renaissance in the US economy, and he's right, but not one that justifies the extraordinary rise in high-tech stocks on Wall Street. A year ago, the Nasdaq index of new technology companies stood at around 2,000; it hit 3,000 in November, 4,000 in December and 5,000 last week. Tim Congdon, one of the City's leading economists calls the valuations on the Nasdaq index "insane". Greenspan now has the unenviable task on his hand: how to deflate the bubble without bursting it.

Will he be successful? In all honesty, nobody knows. In financial markets everybody is blessed with 20:20 hindsight, but anyone who says they can say precisely when there will be a crash is lying. It could be this year, next year, sometime, never. What can be stated with some justification is that the warnings are justified by historical precedent and that the longer the high-tech frenzy goes on, the shorter the odds on an eventual day of reckoning.

Some of the valuations of the high-tech companies look - how shall we put it - somewhat optimistic. Lastminute.com, for example, is expected to have a notional value of £1bn when its shares go on sale today. Its revenues in the last quarter, which included the peak Christmas buying season, totalled £409,000. So far, what the company has going for it is a bright idea and a good brand, but not that many customers. It is losing money, lots of money.

Those who argue - as did Irving Fisher in 1929 - that the market is not over-valued would say that there is nothing wrong with that. Plenty of companies lose money when they are getting the business established, when building up a customer base takes precedence over profitability. Capital investment is expensive and so is advertising.

In the end, however, companies that succeed in a market economy are those that make profits. That may sound brutal, but it's a fact of life. A company's share price reflects the profits that investors expect it to make in the future, and eventually they will want to see some signs that those profits are going to be delivered. And here's the rub: not only have the vast majority of the dot.com companies never made a profit, but they are unlikely ever to do so. Why? Because there are too many companies chasing business at a time when profit margins are being squeezed by intense competition.

The online market for books is a case in point. Amazon is the market leader in this field, although it, too, has never made a profit. Yet anybody keen to buy a book over the net can log on to a website called Bookbrain.co.uk, which will search all the online booksellers and give a rundown of price, delivery times and the cost of packaging and postage. Take Delia's second How to Cook book, for example. This is available for £16.99 from the BBC but much more cheaply online. According to Bookbrain, Amazon has it at £10.94 including p&p, but two other outlets - Alphabetstreet and Country Bookstore are churning it out at £8.49. All this is wonderful news for the consumer, but doesn't do much for the bottom line of Amazon, or any of the other online bookstores.

The cannier investors are starting to latch on to this inescapable truth. Last month's stock market darling, Freeserve, saw a third wiped off its share price last week when it became clear that a price war among internet service providers was bound to cut revenues and profits.

While all eyes have been on the go-go stocks in the high-tech sector, shares in so-called old economy companies have been in the doldrums. Brewers, banks, supermarkets, retailers, power companies have been churning out healthy profits, but no one has been even remotely interested in fuddy-duddy companies run by men in suits. For those who believe in happy endings, the hope is that when the bubble bursts for the high-tech sector, the money will simply rotate into the old economy stocks again and the technological revolution - which is for real - will embed itself into the economy without any of the accompanying hype. If that happens, there will be a short period of turbulence, but nothing worse.

But there are pessimists who argue that this ignores the factor that has characterised all post-bubble periods - panic. When sentiment turns, it can turn so quickly that policy makers cannot respond quickly enough and by the time remedial measures kick in it is too late. One favourite scenario for the Cassandras is that the determination of America to live beyond its means forces Greenspan to continue ratcheting up interest rates. At some point, companies start reporting that their profits are being affected, leading to a crash in share prices. Foreign investors - up to their necks in Wall Street - suffer big losses, leading to knock-on effects on stock markets around the world. The fall in the stock market then undermines the hitherto strong dollar, affecting exports from Europe and Asia by making them more expensive. In these circumstances, there would be a very nasty global recession, with the strong possibility of falling house prices and the certainty of sharply rising unemployment.

The worst-case scenario, of course, would be a full-scale 30s-style slump. Graham Turner, economist at GFC economics, said: "This is not going to be pleasant. He added that the likeliest outcome was that the men in suits at the old economy companies would have the last laugh. "A lot of internet companies will be swallowed up by traditional firms, who will be able to cherry pick the best brand names at the bottom of the market. Let's be honest: there are some good brands out there but they won't be able to keep going when there is a big correction."

For the rest, the future looks less bright. One of the internet's most entertaining sites is iTulip.com, which brilliantly lampoons the whole high-tech bubble. "Now you, too, can enjoy the thrill of owning an uneconomical internet company's stock certificate without fear of losing all your money," it says. "Buy an iTulip.com Stock Certificate. Not only does iTulip.com not have any assets, revenues or profits, it doesn't even exist. Of course, some internet companies won't exist either after the internet stock speculative mania ends."

For the super rich, a new age of conspicuous consumption offers retail therapy the rest of us can only dream of. The timepiece of choice for those with real money is the Patek Phillippe Calibre 89 - yours for a mere £1.7m.

fields.headline: What's the big idea?
fields.standfirst:
At the start of a weekly e-diary describing the birth of a dot.com our two heroes ditch their day jobs

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Have you ever felt you were missing out on something? The internet seemed to be racing past, carrying with it the promise of excitement and opportunity.
fields.body:
Have you ever felt you were missing out on something? The internet seemed to be racing past, carrying with it the promise of excitement and opportunity.

The two of us knew we wanted to be on the internet bullet train but were not sure how to climb aboard. We knew that our then employer, a leading UK growth consultancy, was keen to back an internet start up. All we needed was to come up with an idea and make it happen.

We spent a great deal of time thinking about what we could possibly do.

It might seem strange to decide to be in business without knowing what that business would be. However, we now know of at least half a dozen successful internet companies that started in exactly the same way.

What could we do that had not been done already? The answer came in a suitably glamorous place, the kitchen. In a cavalcade of thought on e-commerce, online retailing, financial services, the internet population, it finally popped out.

We would empower an entire generation of young people to shop online. There appeared to be a real need and therefore a genuine opportunity. Although teenagers are more comfortable with the technology and use the net more than any other age group - teenagers in the UK are more than one and a half times more likely to be online as adults - they buy very little online because of age-related restrictions on the use of credit cards.

We were particularly excited because the service would be unusual, not just another online retailer or content provider, so it should be easier to be heard above the cacophony of existing dotcom crosstown traffic.

We wanted to pull our idea apart. It seemed good to us, but did it stand a more objective test? Our enthusiasm was infectious and allowed us to get some free time with some of the best commercial brains we knew.

We got most input from work colleagues with similar backgrounds to ourselves but we were also able to test the idea with friends and relatives who had broader but relevant experience, including an ex-university friend who had recently secured a sizeable amount of funding for another start-up business. Two days worth of formal brainstorming and conversations over the kitchen table resulted in almost 100 decent alternative ideas for an online business, but none of them generated the same excitement and enthusiasm as our transaction facility.

The simplicity of the idea did not transfer across to the reality of making it happen. However, we did have a couple of things on our side. First, our former employer agreed to provide us with office space, resources and a small amount of working capital to help kick-start the business. Secondly, our own experience as consultants meant we had some pretty good contacts with retailers, banks, venture capitalists and in new media. Getting what later came to be known as Rools going was going to be really tough, but not as tough as it might have been.

Both of us have been lucky to have always had interesting jobs. However, we have always had the nagging urge to break out on our own, and nothing has compared to the thrill and sense of exhilaration we have felt in creating something completely new. Our excitement is heightened by the fact that we are constantly racing against the clock.

We are prepared for the hard work that lies ahead and have not been fooled by the overnight internet millionaire stories. The internet has created a wealth of business opportunities, it just so happens that it is the entrepreneurs rather than the large corporations that have been the first to rush into the space. As the big guns start rolling in and the industry becomes more populated it is going to take even more innovative ideas, better technology and excellent execution to make a successful internet business. All that and great timing.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com

webTitle: Bosnian Serb general goes on trial for Srebrenica massacre

fields.headline: Bosnian Serb general goes on trial for Srebrenica massacre
fields.trailText: UN prosecutors today opened their genocide case against General Radislav Krstic, who stands accused of leading the slaughter of Muslim civilians at Srebrenica in the worst atrocities committed in Europe since the second world war.
fields.body:
UN prosecutors today opened their genocide case against General Radislav Krstic, who stands accused of leading the slaughter of Muslim civilians at Srebrenica in the worst atrocities committed in Europe since the second world war.

Gen Krstic, 51, a professional soldier who lost his right foot to a land mine, is charged with genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity in the systematic massacre of at least 7,000 Muslim men and boys in the UN-designated "safe haven" of Srebrenica. The highest-ranked Bosnian Serb in UN custody, Gen Krstic is said to be a close associate of former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and his wartime military leader, Gen Ratko Mladic, who have also been indicted by the tribunal and remain at large.

"This is not a case, like others, where you have thugs, soldiers or paramilitaries who got out of hand and did something unlawful," said Heather Ryan, a US lawyer in the Hague working with the Coalition for International Justice, an organisation that assists the war crimes tribunal. "Here, there was a very deliberate, blatant, organised decision by the military to execute people."

According to the charges against him, Gen Krstic was in command of the mass killings, or at the very least did not use his authority to stop them. He was arrested by US troops in Bosnia in a road ambush on December 2, 1998, and sent to the Hague. He has pleaded not guilty.

The trial is the most important yet at the international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, created by the UN to prosecute those responsible for mass murder, "ethnic cleansing" of civilians and other crimes against international law during the1992-95 war in Bosnia-Hercegovina. Unless Mr Karadzic and Gen Mladic are captured, Gen Krstic will be the most senior Bosnian Serb official called to account.

On July 11, 1995, the 15,000 soldiers of the Serb Drina corps overran the UN-declared safe area of Srebrenica in eastern Bosnia, which was packed with Muslim refugees. Tens of thousands of women and children were expelled. Then, over a five-day period, Muslim men and boys were slaughtered after surrendering, or hunted down and killed as they fled to Tuzla, a Muslim town 40 miles away. Once in the hands of Bosnian Serb soldiers, the males were massed together and killed methodically by machine-gun fire or hand grenades.

"Thousands of civilians who had laid down their arms were systematically murdered by the Bosnian Serb army and the accused," said the US prosecutor, Mark Harmon. "The crimes that were committed were of a type and scale not seen since world war II. The Bosnian Serb army, organised, planned and willingly participated in genocide."

The fall of Srebrenica after it was declared a UN safe haven and the ensuing atrocities badly tarnished the UN's reputation. "The tragedy of Srebrenica will haunt our history forever," UN secretary-general Kofi Annan said last November in a self-critical report of the UN's handling of Srebrenica. When Serbian soldiers attacked, there were only 110 lightly armed Dutch peacekeepers in the town and senior UN officials turned down repeated requests by troops on the ground for air strikes against the encircling Bosnian Serb forces.

Prosecutors in the Hague had access to photographs of mass graves taken by US spy satellites - the first time such sensitive intelligence material has been given to the tribunal. In addition, forensic investigators have been searching for and digging up mass graves, some miles from Srebrenica, for the past four years.

According to prosecutors, the Bosnian Serb forces made a concerted attempt to conceal their actions, digging dozens of new trenches and moving corpses from old graves to outwit international investigators. At last report, only about 2,000 bodies had been recovered.

Survivors claim the Dutch helped the Serbs round up Muslims and have demanded that their commanders, along with UN civilian and military leaders, be indicted for complicity. The present trial will be a significant test for the Hague-based tribunal, which has yet to secure a genocide conviction. One accused killed himself while awaiting judgment and a second was acquitted of genocide but found guilty of murder.
