The highest-ranked Bosnian Serb in UN custody, Gen Krstic is said to be a close associate of former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and his wartime military leader, Gen Ratko Mladic, who have also been indicted by the tribunal and remain at large. "This is not a case, like others, where you have thugs, soldiers or paramilitaries who got out of hand and did something unlawful," said Heather Ryan, a US lawyer in the Hague working with the Coalition for International Justice, an organisation that assists the war crimes tribunal. "Here, there was a very deliberate, blatant, organised decision by the military to execute people." According to the charges against him, Gen Krstic was in command of the mass killings, or at the very least did not use his authority to stop them. He was arrested by US troops in Bosnia in a road ambush on December 2, 1998, and sent to the Hague. He has pleaded not guilty. The trial is the most important yet at the international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, created by the UN to prosecute those responsible for mass murder, "ethnic cleansing" of civilians and other crimes against international law during the1992-95 war in Bosnia-Hercegovina. Unless Mr Karadzic and Gen Mladic are captured, Gen Krstic will be the most senior Bosnian Serb official called to account. On July 11, 1995, the 15,000 soldiers of the Serb Drina corps overran the UN-declared safe area of Srebrenica in eastern Bosnia, which was packed with Muslim refugees. Tens of thousands of women and children were expelled. Then, over a five-day period, Muslim men and boys were slaughtered after surrendering, or hunted down and killed as they fled to Tuzla, a Muslim town 40 miles away. Once in the hands of Bosnian Serb soldiers, the males were massed together and killed methodically by machine-gun fire or hand grenades. "Thousands of civilians who had laid down their arms were systematically murdered by the Bosnian Serb army and the accused," said the US prosecutor, Mark Harmon. "The crimes that were committed were of a type and scale not seen since world war II. The Bosnian Serb army, organised, planned and willingly participated in genocide." The fall of Srebrenica after it was declared a UN safe haven and the ensuing atrocities badly tarnished the UN's reputation. "The tragedy of Srebrenica will haunt our history forever," UN secretary-general Kofi Annan said last November in a self-critical report of the UN's handling of Srebrenica. When Serbian soldiers attacked, there were only 110 lightly armed Dutch peacekeepers in the town and senior UN officials turned down repeated requests by troops on the ground for air strikes against the encircling Bosnian Serb forces. Prosecutors in the Hague had access to photographs of mass graves taken by US spy satellites - the first time such sensitive intelligence material has been given to the tribunal. In addition, forensic investigators have been searching for and digging up mass graves, some miles from Srebrenica, for the past four years. According to prosecutors, the Bosnian Serb forces made a concerted attempt to conceal their actions, digging dozens of new trenches and moving corpses from old graves to outwit international investigators. At last report, only about 2,000 bodies had been recovered. Survivors claim the Dutch helped the Serbs round up Muslims and have demanded that their commanders, along with UN civilian and military leaders, be indicted for complicity. The present trial will be a significant test for the Hague-based tribunal, which has yet to secure a genocide conviction. One accused killed himself while awaiting judgment and a second was acquitted of genocide but found guilty of murder. webTitle: Spanish PM wins historic second term by a landslide

fields.headline: Spanish PM wins historic second term by a landslide
fields.standfirst: Listen to election analysis from Adela Gooch
fields.trailText: Spain's conservative prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, won a historic victory for the right in yesterday's general election as voters heeded his call for an absolute majority in his second term.
fields.body:
Spain's conservative prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, won a historic victory for the right in yesterday's general election as voters heeded his call for an absolute majority in his second term.

With 95% of votes counted, his Popular party was expected to obtain 183 seats in the 350-seat parliament while the main Socialist opposition dropped to 125, their worst showing since the early 1980s.

Conceding defeat, the Socialist leader, Joaquin Almunia, announced his resignation.

"We have not been able to convince Spaniards with our project for the future; we have not been able to connect with their hopes and aspirations," he said.

The results were a resounding endorsement for Mr Aznar's softly-softly approach to economic reform that has led to high growth and a job creation rate three times that of any other European country.

The prime minister has also dispelled doubts that his party was a reincarnation of the old, autocratic right rather than a modernising centralist force.

It is the first time that the conservative party has obtained a majority since Spain became a democracy following the death of the fascist dictator General Francisco Franco in 1975.

Mr Almunia's attempts to rally the left through an electoral alliance with the Communist-led United Left appeared to have failed miserably. "We have not been able to motivate leftwing voters, even though they are the majority in society," he said. "That project remains for the future."

Mr Almunia's claim that the government had practised "crony capitalism", enriching a few personal friends of the prime minister at the expense of the population as a whole, fell on deaf ears.

Instead, voters heeded Mr Aznar's warning that the Socialist-Communist pact, modelled on France's government led by Lionel Jospin, would jeopardise Spain's economic success and reduce the country's chances of becoming a top European power.

The polls had given Mr Aznar a slim lead of 4-5 percentage points and his supporters gathered outside the Popular party's headquarters in Madrid overjoyed that he would not have to rely on regional nationalists to form a government. "Torero! Torero!" they shouted when he appeared on the balcony.

Mr Aznar insisted that even with a majority he would continue to seek consensus on the major issues facing Spain.

"I want to insist that the attitude of the next government will be as open to dialogue with other political parties and social groups as this one has been - because they're all necessary for the progress of Spain.

"Dialogue, agreement, consensus - those are the foundations of an open country which will enable us to reach our objectives in the next few years."

A roar of approval greeted his words and the ultimate accolade: "Macho! Macho!"

Voter turnout was down nearly 10% compared to the last election in 1996. Mr Almunia said that this accounted in part for his defeat. But Popular party leaders described it as a normalisation of the electoral process in Spain, which brought turnout figures closer to those of other countries.

"Seventy per cent is still very healthy indeed, but it also shows that people aren't as worried about the future of the democratic system as they used to be," said Federico Trillo, the parliamentary speaker.

Mr Aznar's greatest challenge remains the relationship between the regions and Madrid. The threat of Basque terrorist violence had overshadowed the campaign.

fields.headline: Lords to examine members' interests
fields.standfirst: Committee on Standards in Public Life
fields.trailText: The government's standards watchdog is today examining whether peers should be forced to declare their interests in a public register.
fields.body:
The government's standards watchdog is today examining whether peers should be forced to declare their interests in a public register.

Lord Neill, chairman of the committee on standards in public life, will look at whether the Lords should face the same scrutiny as elected MPs, including a strict code of conduct and a commissioner for standards who would investigate breaches. It is the latest proposal to modernise the Lords, which has already undergone a major shake-up to end hereditary peerages.

"The committee has had a long-standing commitment to considering these issues in relation to the House of Lords. At a time when the House has undergone such a radical change in its composition, it is now particularly appropriate that we should fulfil that commitment," Lord Neill said. He is also expected to look at the use of the House of Lords and its members by lobbying companies, and at peers' earnings from parliamentary consultancies.

Leader of the Lords Baroness Jay sought to score some political points from the latest development. "We very much welcome this inquiry," the Labour peer said. "Labour Ministers in the Lords already declare their interests to the same standard as is required in the Commons. Many Labour peers have followed suit. Any resistance to such an inquiry in the past has come from parties in opposition and not from the Labour party."

A spokesman for the committee said it would publish a consultative report in a few weeks and open its ideas to the public. A decision could be made within six months. The Neill committee first published a report in 1995 on the House of Commons and called for tighter disciplinary procedures including a code of conduct and parliamentary commissioner for standards.

So far, the Lords has been against the idea of stricter rules and currently operates a voluntary system to register interests. Tougher scrutiny of the Commons came after former Conservative minister Neil Hamilton was found guilty of taking envelopes stuffed with cash in return for asking questions in parliament.

An internal parliamentary inquiry said Mr Hamilton was guilty in the cash-for-questions scandal which tainted the Tories with sleaze, a factor that contributed to their loss in the 1997 general election. Earlier this month, MPs suspended the Conservative member Teresa Gorman for a month after the Neill report said she had failed to properly register her property interests.

The rules in the Commons are particularly tight where lobbying and financial consultancies are concerned. All MPs involved in such work must deposit a contract of employment with the commissioner for standards and that contract is available to the public for inspection. MPs are also required to register all paid outside employment. They are required to register shareholdings that amount to more than £25,000 or 1% of the company, substantial property holdings and any sponsorship or other financial support.

Among the peers who could be forced to register interests is Lord Lamont of Lerwick, the former Tory chancellor, who was criticised for taking trips to Chile funded by a group supporting General Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator. Lord Lamont was not required to list the trips in the register.

Liberal Democrat party treasurer Lord Razzall said "This is long overdue. In the light of the reform of the House of Lords the same standards must apply to peers as are in place in the House of Commons. The recent events regarding Lord Lamont's support for General Pinochet clearly demonstrate the need for urgent reform of the upper house."

fields.headline: Beards
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about men's facial furniture on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about men's facial furniture on the net
fields.body:
1. Frank Dobson's aides want to give him the chop. They say the beard has to go.

2. Apparently a little barefaced chic may go a long way to woo the capital's voters.

3. But Mr Dobson's not impressed. He thinks beards are great and told his party's image-makers to "get stuffed".

4. The London mayor candidate is one of a growing number of hairy men who feel that beards don't always get the respect and appreciation they deserve.

5. It wasn't always like this. Many great men, including Leonardo da Vinci, the ancient Greek philosophers as well as Karl Marx and Jesus Christ (maybe), wore quite spectacular beards.

6 Labour joins an increasing number of organisations, including delivery company UPS and furniture chain IKEA, who believe facial hair of any style has no place in today's world.

7. An article in the latest issue of the Journal of Mundane Behaviour suggests that beards are a signifier of masculinity that shifts its meaning with the times.

8. Gay men, says author Michael John Pinfold, have radically politicised facial hair: for example, the hairy bear movement encourages beards and so crosses the gay/straight dichotomy. "Men with hair on their faces are seen as men with hair on their faces," he says.

9. If he fails to win London, maybe Mr Dobson should run for office in Kabul, Afghanistan.

10. There the ruling Talibans punish beard trimmers and jail any man who wears their beard too short.

webTitle: New 'super-jumbo' to create up to 22,000 jobs

fields.headline: New 'super-jumbo' to create up to 22,000 jobs
fields.standfirst:
Larry Elliott's latest comment
Picture: see the new jet
fields.trailText: Thousands of new jobs are set to be created after the Government today unveiled a £530 million investment package for a new "super jumbo" aircraft.
fields.body:
Thousands of new jobs are set to be created after the Government today unveiled a £530 million investment package for a new "super jumbo" aircraft.

The aid will allow the European aircraft manufacturing consortium Airbus Industrie to begin work on a newly-developed, twin deck plane which will become the world's first rival to the mighty Boeing 747.

The project will create 8,000 new jobs at BAe Systems, formerly British Aerospace, which already makes wings for aircraft produced by the four-nation Airbus consortium. The jobs boost will benefit Broughton in Flintshire, North Wales, and Filton, near Bristol, where the wings will be manufactured.

But it will also bring new work to other BAe Systems plants, including Prestwick in Ayrshire.

Ken Jackson, leader of the AEEU engineering union with many members at BAE, told BBC radio the A3XX would create 22,000 jobs within the aerospace industry overall and safeguard an exisitng 62,000.

"This is a real boost for British industry," he said on BBC radio. BAE makes wings for existing Airbus planes.

A further 20,000 jobs will be safeguarded and hundreds of suppliers across the UK will win new work.

webTitle: Shoot to kill - army general's plan before Bloody Sunday

fields.headline: Shoot to kill - army general's plan before Bloody Sunday
fields.standfirst:
Secret memo weeks before killings called for targeting

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The officer in day-to-day command of troops in Northern Ireland recommended to his superior that the army adopt a policy of shooting rioters three weeks before Bloody Sunday, it can be revealed today.
fields.body:
The officer in day-to-day command of troops in Northern Ireland recommended to his superior that the army adopt a policy of shooting rioters three weeks before Bloody Sunday, it can be revealed today.

Major General Robert Ford wrote in a secret memo that rubber bullets and CS gas no longer deterred rioters in no-go Catholic enclaves such as the Bogside. The army dubbed them Derry's Young Hooligans.

Major General Ford recommended: "The minimum force necessary to achieve a restoration of law and order is to shoot selected ringleaders among the DYH, after clear warnings have been given."

His secret report to his boss in Northern Ireland, Lieutenant General Harry Tuzo, includes recommendations on what bullets to use. It also may throw light on the mysterious destruction two months ago of three army rifles used at Bloody Sunday.

The memo's contents are certain to spark renewed controversy ahead of the much-delayed start of Lord Saville of Newdigate's inquiry, which has so far cost £13m. It is scheduled to begin taking evidence in Derry's Guildhall on March 27.

Peter Pringle and Philip Jacobsen, authors of the forthcoming Bloody Sunday chronicle "Those are real bullets, aren't they?", reveal Major General Ford's memo in The Guardian today.

The Parachute Regiment shot dead 13 unarmed Catholics at an illegal civil rights demonstration in Derry in disputed circumstances on January 30 1972. A man who was wounded died five months later.

Tony Blair announced Lord Saville's probe in January 1998, much to the dismay of prominent figures in the armed forces. They had supported the findings of Lord Chief Justice Lord Widgery's 1972 tribunal, which effectively exonerated the army.

Lord Widgery's report enraged relatives of the deceased, sparking an enduring campaign to re-examine the evidence. They believed they have had to suffer a Ministry of Defence-inspired whispering campaign against those who died for almost 30 years.

Lord Saville's inquiry has been dogged by controversy throughout, particularly when it tried and failed to ensure soldiers were named when they appeared to give evi dence. The House of Lords ruled they should be entitled to anonymity.

Lawyers for the 14 people killed are due to return to the High Court in Belfast today. They are seeking a judicial re view of Lord Saville's decision to deny them a postponement.

They have each so far received 60,000 pages of evidence. But there is still significant material outstanding, and they doubt whether they could digest it in time if it were passed to them immediately.

As well as providing an insight into military attitudes towards rioters 30 years ago, lawyers for the victims hope that it may resolve the mystery of two missing rifles. The Ministry of Defence admitted last month three had been destroyed three months after it gave an undertaking to Lord Saville to preserve them.

There were 29 rifles available to Lord Widgery's tribunal. But 14 were later destroyed and 10 sold to private companies. There were five left when Lord Saville demanded they be kept safe.

In his memo Major General Ford said they were entitled to use the high-velocity, large-calibre bullets that their rifles took to deal with rioters. But he was worried about possible collateral damage, with the bullets able to kill one person and pass through into another.

He suggested modifying some of the rifles to take smaller bullets "to enable ringleaders to be engaged with less lethal ammunition". Just before Bloody Sunday Major General Ford had sent 30 of the altered weapons to Derry for training purposes.

Lawyers confirmed they were determined to probe Major General Ford's memo. Pringle and Jacobsen suggest one victim, Kevin McElhinney, 17, may have been shot with one of the smaller bullets.

Peter Madden, whose firm Madden and Finucane represents nine of the 14 bereaved families, said: "We need to know if the modified rifles were used. This is a very serious area, and you can rest assured it is a key issue. We are all determined fully to explore it."

Michael McKinney, 49, whose elder brother Willie, then 27, was killed, said: "They were all innocent victims. My brother was not in the IRA; he was not a gunman; he did not throw nail-bombs. We are determined that the full truth comes out this time."

A statement published yesterday suggested soldiers started shooting believing they were under fire after a sergeant was apparently shot. He had instead been hit by the empty cartridge from one of his men's rifles after he accidentally shot himself in the foot.

A retired colonel, then a captain in the Parachute Regiment, said in his statement to the inquiry some soldiers were "animals". They could not be controlled and later gloated over their actions.

fields.headline: Goodbye to all this
fields.standfirst: Everybody's talking about it - the mobile phone which will give us all our information. But what does that mean for your large-screen news plans? Bob Eggington on the fear of  obsolescence
fields.trailText: The unsettling thing about new media is that there is always, well, something new. It's not just a set of content and services that will steadily mature and be absorbed into the established order. It is always changing, always being enlarged, always coming up with new challenges. That is also the satisfying thing about it, of course. The latest challenge for the news media is mobile internet.
fields.body:
The unsettling thing about new media is that there is always, well, something new. It's not just a set of content and services that will steadily mature and be absorbed into the established order. It is always changing, always being enlarged, always coming up with new challenges. That is also the satisfying thing about it, of course. The latest challenge for the news media is mobile internet.

Just when the newspapers, agencies and broadcasters were getting used to the internet, along comes internet-on-the-move. The downside from the media's point of view is yet another set of protocols, delivery mechanisms, interfaces and business models to be understood and developed. The upside is that it could make the economics of the whole industry upwardly mobile.

And the glint of riches-to-come is leading media companies into the middle of the seething activity that characterises the entire mobile phone industry. The BBC is currently sending Ceefax stories, in Wap format, to Vodafone as the basis of an experimental news service. These meet the key criteria of form, timeliness and comprehensiveness. People on the move have less time to read, it will almost certainly cost more to do it, and there will be much less screen space to look at. This seems to many in the business to lend itself more to up-to-the-minute or "breaking" news than to longer-form, considered coverage.

"Breaking" news is not their strong point and to succeed in the mobile internet space they will probably need to continue further down the route that the Guardian and others have taken, of expanding their web publishing activities beyond the content that is prepared for the printed page.

Wireless industry analyst Andrew Seybold, author of the respected Andrew Seybold's Outlook, says general web surfing is unlikely to be satisfying for a mobile-phone user. "I believe that many people's first experience with the internet will be wireless and that might be an OK thing. But when phone display screens get bigger, and as audio and video are progressively added to the service, the offering will become much richer and more complex. Making the coverage coherent in the mobile interface will be a significant task in the months ahead for all news companies. Re-versioning existing content might continue to work, and that would suit the marketing and finance people in the news business who love the efficiency suggested by phrases such as "write once, use often".

The rewards for getting it right could be fundamental to the future of web news. Like almost every other type of web business, commercial news sites have struggled to make money. Mobile internet could be their salvation.

There are several reasons for this, but the main one is the simple fact that access from mobile devices is certain to make the internet market bigger. CNN Interactive is already a good example of this factor at work.

Surprisingly, for a big web company, CNN is fairly candid about its financial position. Last year, for the first time since its launch, the CNN web arm covered its operating costs. The figures are not publicly available, but CNN has a staff of 450 and a big technical infrastructure, so the revenues must have been considerable. By comparison, the BBC site, with a third of the staff and a much smaller infrastructure, costs about £8m a year.

One of the ways CNN "hit the black" was by selling on their content to mobile phone networks. Scott Woelfel, editor-in-chief, says: "It was only one contributory factor but mobile services give you the ability to leverage content over a wider range of distribution, thereby increasing the margin."

What type of content is likely to "sell" over mobile internet? CNN has found that general content like news summaries is popular, but so is the more granular information that can be highly personalised, for example sports results and stock prices.

This coincides with the view of Psion, the UK company whose future is bound up in the success of mobile internet access. Psion is not only a leading manufacturer of PDAs but also has a big stake in Epoc, the most popular operating system for mobiles.

"Our aim is to put the internet in your pocket," says David Levin, Psion chief executive. "Three things are converging [through the next generations of mobile phones]: the internet, broadband services and computing power, and that will create a rich environment in which to innovate services for personal and corporate users.

"We think three factors are crucial to the future of mobile services: location of the user, so that services that are available there can be accessed; time sensitivity - people want things right now; and personalised information - the stuff that matters to me."

Although there is no shortage of "vision" within the industry, it is an exceptionally difficult environment in which to work because of the scramble for "first-mover-advantage".

"There are two words, wireless and internet, that make rich and smart people very dumb," says Seybold. "There are some real good deals being put together and some real good stuff happening here . . . but we have to go through all the hype and bullshit before we get there." And Bob Egan, wireless specialist with the Gartner Research Group, warns media and other companies not to expect too much too soon:

"The wireless web access market for cell phones is likely to die a thousand deaths before any internet portal or m[mobile]-commerce company makes money in this market. Ninety-nine per cent of consumers will reject existing offerings because they are too expensive, incomplete or out-and-out frustrating to use. As someone once said, 'Consumers don't want choice, they want exactly what they want' and nowhere is this going to be more true than in wireless internet."

fields.headline: Destroyed rifles set back inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Defence minister says destruction of weapons used in Bloody Sunday killing of 13 marchers was a bungle but truth could be more sinister

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Defence minister says destruction of weapons used in Bloody Sunday killing of 13 marchers was a bungle but truth could be more sinister
fields.body:
The ministry of defence's unauthorised destruction of rifles fired by paratroopers in Londonderry on Bloody Sunday was a bureaucratic bungle, according to the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, but the action could have been more sinister.

The loss of the rifles appears to be a set- back for Lord Saville's new tribunal of inquiry into the deaths of 13 unarmed Catholics and the wounding of 14 others in the Bogside on January 30, 1972.

As Saville's expensive investigation prepares to open public hearings, the missing rifles have emerged as a key factor in the central question: Did the paratroopers lose control and shoot recklessly into a crowd of civil rights marchers, or were the killings part of a plan to shoot troublemakers that went terribly wrong?

Among ministry of defence documents declassified by Saville is a secret memo by Major General Robert Ford, then in day-to-day command of the army in Northern Ireland. Writing to his superior in Ulster, Lieutenant General Harry Tuzo, Ford observed that the Bogside's stone-throwing rioters -dubbed "Derry Young Hooligans" (DYH) by the army-were no longer deterred by conventional crowd control weapons such as rubber bullets and CS gas.

An alternative had to be found because the regular rioting, which included petrol bombs and nail bombs, prevented the army from patrolling the "no go" area of the Bogside and the Creggan and often formed a cover for IRA snipers, turning foot patrols into high-risk operations.

Brutal conclusion

At the time of Ford's memo - three weeks before Bloody Sunday - the army was under pressure from Stormont and Westminster to restore law in the Catholic enclaves. Ford had to weigh up whether to sit things out in the hope that the rioting would taper off, invade the enclaves with his limited resources, or develop more effective methods of deterring the hooligans.

His brutally frank conclusion was that: "The minimum force necessary to achieve a restoration of law and order is to shoot selected ring leaders among the DYH, after clear warnings have been given." Ford considered that soldiers would be justified in opening fire with their 7.62mm self-loading rifles (SLRs), then the army's main infantry weapon, but he was understandably worried about the risk of collateral casualties.

The high-velocity rounds could penetrate an iron railway line at short range and had been known to travel for three miles; a bullet could tear straight through one person's body and retain sufficient force to kill another. Ford proposed adapting some SLRs to take a smaller .22in high-velocity round " to enable ring leaders to be engaged with less lethal ammunition".

In early January, Ford sent 30 of the modified rifles to Derry for training purposes, though he emphasised they would not be deployed without authorisation. The question facing Saville is whether any of the adapted rifles were ever used - particularly on Bloody Sunday.

After Saville had formally opened the new inquiry in 1998, he asked the MoD to provide all the SLRs fired by the paratroopers. For the 1972 official inquiry into the killings - carried out by Lord Widgery, then lord chief justice - 29 rifles were produced but they were no longer in service.

In 1986, the SLR was replaced by a lighter rifle, the SA80, which fired a smaller 5.56 mm round (coincidentally, the equivalent of a .22in). The SLRs were progressively scrapped. The MoD reported to Saville that 14 of the 29 rifles had been destroyed and another 10 sold to private companies.

The inquiry received an assurance that the remaining five rifles would be preserved as evidence, but last January, in defiance of an internal MoD order, two more of the SLRs were destroyed, leaving only three. Saville was livid. In a written answer in the Commons, Geoff Hoon expressed "deep regret" and ordered an investigation by the head of the MoD police, with officers from the West Mercia constabulary also involved. Saville was invited to nominate an observer.

But what could the paratroopers' rifles have told the new inquiry after so many years?

Forensic evidence produced for the Widgery tribunal established that two bullets, said to be 7.62mm rounds, lodged in two of the dead were matched to rifles of paratroopers identified as Soldier F, a lance corporal, and Soldier G, a private. Soldier F shot 17-year-old Michael Kelly and Soldier G shot Gerald Donaghy, also 17, both in the stomach. They bled to death.

According to army statements for Widgery, all the ammunition issued that day was either 7.62mm rounds for the SLRs, or 9mm for Browning pistols, mostly carried by the officers. And post-mortem examinations established that all but one of the entry wounds on the 13 dead measured between 6-8mm, corresponding to the 7.62 round. But the bullet that killed Kevin McElhinney, 17, who was shot from behind, left a significantly smaller entry wound that measured only 3mm. It entered his left buttock and sliced through his bladder, colon and severed an artery. He died almost immediately.

Could the pathologists have made a mistake or was the bullet of a different calibre - a .22in perhaps?

The Widgery tribunal heard that the soldier who shot McElhinney could not be identified; it might have been either Seargent K, or Privates L or M. Soldier L's evidence did not mention what type of rifle he had; Soldier M said he had a 7.62mm SLR; Sgt K had a sniper's rifle, an SLR with a telescopic sight, but he did not mention the calibre.

Forensic pathologists acknowledge that the size of entry wounds does not tell the whole story. The same bullet can produce a hole of different dimensions depending on how it flies through the air, whether it is deflected on the way to its target (a ricochet), and the type of body tissue it enters.

Soft target

When a rifle bullet leaves the barrel it wobbles initially, then stabilises and spins like a top and, in theory, travels nose first. But in practice bullets always yaw slightly and never hit the target nose on. The greater the yaw the larger the surface area of the bullet presented to the target, and, therefore, the larger the entry wound. If a bullet hits something on its way to the target, it might start to tumble, causing an even larger entry wound. For example, the bullet, said to have been a 7.62 round, that killed Gerald Donaghy, 17, made a gaping 3 x 2cm hole and Saville's experts have concluded that it was a ricochet.

If the bullet strikes a soft target, such as the tissue of a buttock, as in McElhinney's case, the entry may appear smaller because the tissue can close round the wound. The only way to check is from photographs taken of the corpse but Saville's experts say too few were taken and many were taken at too great a distance.

At the time of the Widgery inquiry, General Ford's memo about the .22in rifles was still secret, so the question of whether any of the soldiers had rifles of a different calibre was never asked. Now, with only three of the original rifles now available, it may never be answered.

The missing rifles could also make it much harder for Saville to unravel the mystery of what happened to the 19 rounds fired by the paratrooper identified as Soldier H. He said he was shooting at a gunman behind a bathroom window in a flat in the Bogside, but it was established that this was not the case. So what were his 19 bullets really aimed at if, indeed, it was he who fired them? Saville may wish to consider whether Soldier H was the fall guy for comrades who had fired more rounds than they wanted to admit.

Another way of matching a bullet to a rifle is by its casing. Each time a bullet is fired the ejected casing has a mark made by the hammer in the firing mechanism. The spoils of war among citizens in the Bogside included spent bullet casings.

If all, or even most of the rifles, used by the paratroopers were still available, cas ings collected by civilians on Bloody Sunday - and some spent bullets were handed in to Widgery - could have been tested to see if they matched.

Finally, with only three of the rifles left, Saville may be handicapped in finding out the distance from which the paratroopers fired. Some witnesses say the paratroopers fired repeatedly at close range.

As the witnesses employed by Saville have explained, when a bullet emerges from the muzzle it is accompanied by a discharge which contains burned and partially-burned explosive charge, plus particles of lead from the bullet and the primer.

By comparing the pattern of the deposit with the pattern of deposits from tests shots fired from various distances it is possible to estimate the distance from which the shot was fired. If the gun was fired from less than a metre away, there is usually a visible deposit, and when it is not visible it can be detected by chemical means, the results recorded on a filter paper. Tests were made for the Widgery inquiry, but no records have been made available to Saville.

When his own experts come to check those tests for accuracy, they will need to test fire the weapons. Are the remaining rifles sufficient for such a crucial process? Only 21 paratroopers fired their rifles so it is possible that the three SLRs now being offered by the MoD may never have been used on Bloody Sunday.

 Bloody Sunday, "Those are real bullets aren't they?" by Peter Pringle and Philip Jacobson will be published by Fourth Estate on March 27

So what were his 19 bullets really aimed at if, indeed, it was he who fired them? Saville may wish to consider whether Soldier H was the fall guy for comrades who had fired more rounds than they wanted to admit. Another way of matching a bullet to a rifle is by its casing. Each time a bullet is fired the ejected casing has a mark made by the hammer in the firing mechanism. The spoils of war among citizens in the Bogside included spent bullet casings. If all, or even most of the rifles, used by the paratroopers were still available, cas ings collected by civilians on Bloody Sunday - and some spent bullets were handed in to Widgery - could have been tested to see if they matched. Finally, with only three of the rifles left, Saville may be handicapped in finding out the distance from which the paratroopers fired. Some witnesses say the paratroopers fired repeatedly at close range. As the witnesses employed by Saville have explained, when a bullet emerges from the muzzle it is accompanied by a discharge which contains burned and partially-burned explosive charge, plus particles of lead from the bullet and the primer. By comparing the pattern of the deposit with the pattern of deposits from tests shots fired from various distances it is possible to estimate the distance from which the shot was fired. If the gun was fired from less than a metre away, there is usually a visible deposit, and when it is not visible it can be detected by chemical means, the results recorded on a filter paper. Tests were made for the Widgery inquiry, but no records have been made available to Saville. When his own experts come to check those tests for accuracy, they will need to test fire the weapons. Are the remaining rifles sufficient for such a crucial process? Only 21 paratroopers fired their rifles so it is possible that the three SLRs now being offered by the MoD may never have been used on Bloody Sunday.  Bloody Sunday, "Those are real bullets aren't they?" by Peter Pringle and Philip Jacobson will be published by Fourth Estate on March 27

webTitle: Dome chief may seek extra time

fields.headline: Dome chief may seek extra time
fields.trailText: Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the head of the Millennium Dome, yesterday left open the possibility that he might want the showpiece to stay open for another year.
fields.body:
Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the head of the Millennium Dome, yesterday left open the possibility that he might want the showpiece to stay open for another year.

The £750m dome in Greenwich, south-east London, is due to close at the end of this year. A government competition has been launched to find a buyer who will find a new use for the site.

But Mr Gerbeau declined to rule out that he might want the show to go on. When he was asked whether it might be an idea to extend the dome for another year, the chief executive of the New Millennium Experience Company told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost that he had to make sure the dome was a success.

He added: "I think we have got enough focus right now, and then, you know, as soon as we have proved that it is better, it is working and it is a popular success, then we can look at different things."

Mr Gerbeau has shaken up the troubled venue, extending opening hours and cutting queuing times, after taking over from Jennie Page.

Of his new lower visitor target of 10m, he said: "We hope we are going to do better. We are just going to go pretty big, and now with new opening hours, we have a bigger capacity and a better overall experience."

He said the dome would target the tourist market "very aggressively" this summer in the hope of hitting its day capacity of 45,000.

webTitle: Pope says sorry for sins of church

fields.headline: Pope says sorry for sins of church
fields.standfirst: Sweeping apology for attacks on Jews, women and minorities defies theologians' warnings
fields.trailText: Saving one of his most audacious initiatives for the twilight of his papacy, John Paul II yesterday attempted to purify the soul of the Roman Catholic church by making a sweeping apology for 2,000 years of violence, persecution and blunders.
fields.body:
Saving one of his most audacious initiatives for the twilight of his papacy, John Paul II yesterday attempted to purify the soul of the Roman Catholic church by making a sweeping apology for 2,000 years of violence, persecution and blunders.

From the altar of St Peter's Basilica in Rome he led Catholicism into unchartered territory by seeking forgiveness for sins committed against Jews, heretics, women, Gypsies and native peoples.

Fighting through trembles and slurrings caused by Parkinson's disease, the Pope electrified ranks of cardinals and bishops by pleading for a future that would not repeat the mistakes. "Never again," he said.

Centuries of hate and rivalry could not recur in the third millennium. "We forgive and we ask forgiveness. We are asking pardon for the divisions among Christians, for the use of violence that some have committed in the service of truth, and for attitudes of mistrust and hostility assumed towards followers of other religions."

Plea for brotherhood

Defying warnings from some theologians that the unprecedented apology would undermine the church's authority, the 79-year-old pontiff asked God to forgive the persecution of the Jews. "We are deeply saddened by the behaviour of those who in the course of history have caused these children of yours to suffer, and asking your forgiveness we wish to commit ourselves to genuine brotherhood."

Wearing the purple vestments of lenten mourning, the Pope sought pardon for seven categories of sin: general sins; sins in the service of truth; sins against Christian unity; against the Jews; against respect for love, peace and cultures; against the dignity of women and minorities; and against human rights.

Ethnic groups had endured "contempt for their cultures and religious traditions". Women were "all too often humiliated and marginalised". Trust in wealth and power had obscured the church's responsibility to the poor and oppressed.

There was no reference to homosexuals, who had asked to be included for suffering theocratic violence. The Pope did not identify guilty individuals or name the crusades, the Inquisition or the Holocaust, but the references were clear.

Five Vatican cardinals and two bishops confessed sins on behalf of the church during the ceremony. Cardinal Edward Cassidy recalled the "sufferings of the people of Israel" asked divine pardon for the "sins committed by not a few [Catholics] against the people of the covenant".

'Warped' view

Several Jewish leaders praised the sermon as historic and significant but Israel's chief rabbi said he was deeply frustrated by the Pope's failure to mention the Holocaust, and described the service as "a severely warped view of history".

Rabbi Israel Meir Lau joined other Israelis in expressing hope that the pope had omitted acknowledging the church's passivity during the Holocaust only because he was planning a specific apology during next week's pilgrimage to the holy land.

Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, head of the congregation of the doctrine of the faith, confessed to the sins of the congregation's predecessor, the Inquisition. "Even men of the church, in the name of faith and morals, have sometimes used methods not in keeping with the Gospel," he said.

Applause from the congregation greeted the Pope's arrival in the basilica. He kneeled before the Pieta, Michelangelo's statue of the dead Christ in the arms of his mother, before being wheeled to the altar. He leaned on his silver staff and it took several attempts for him to get out of his chair to kiss a crucifix. The Vatican no longer denies the Pope has Parkinson's disease. An operation to remove a tumour, several falls and an assassination attempt have left him hunched and stiff.

Seeking forgiveness has been a leitmotif of his papacy since his election in 1978. He has apologised for the crusades, the massacre of French Protestants, the trial of Galileo and anti-semitism.

Yesterday's apology was by far the most sweeping and an unprecedented act for the leader of a major religion. One of the highlights of this year's jubilee, or holy year, it was the result of four years' research by a panel of 28 theologians and scholars.

Disquiet that the apology was a beautiful gesture but a theological mistake bubbled to the surface last week.

Echoing widespread concern from liberal as well as conservative theologians, the Bishop of Como, Alessandro Maggiolini, said: "In whose name, exactly, is the holy father asking pardon? He is relying on a group of experts, but tomorrow another group of experts might come up with different examples."

Other churchmen said the gesture would be seen by Muslims as a sign of weakness and by secular enemies as a cue to launch further attacks.

The Pope's persistence in ramming through the initiative, despite resistance inside the Vatican, has doused claims that he has effectively retired and abandoned policy-making.

The document that provides the theological framework emphasises a distinction between the sins committed by the church's sons and daughters and the church itself, which remains holy and immaculate.

Speaking after the ceremony to the crowd in St Peter's Square, the Pope stressed he was seeking forgiveness not from those who had been wronged, but from God. "Only he can do that."

2,000 years of violence and persecution

The Crusades

Pope Urban II, anxious to assert Rome's authority in the east, sent a military expedition in 1095 to reconquer the holy land. The crusaders ravaged the countries they passed through and massacred the Muslim, Jewish and even Christian population of Jerusalem after capturing it in 1099. After 200 years of conflict Muslim armies drove them out for good, but the crusaders' symbol of the red cross remains provocative.

The Inquisition

The attempt to combat suspected apostates, Jews and Muslims at the time of the Reformation spawned tribunals in Europe and the new world that tortured and executed thousands. Ecclesiastical queasiness about flowing blood led to the use of racks, thumbscrews and red-hot metal instead of blades; 2,000 people were burned at the stake during the tenure of Spain's first grand inquisitor, Tomas de Torquemada.

The Holocaust

Pope Pius XII never publicly condemned the Nazis' persecution of Jews, even when they were being rounded up and deported from Rome. His silence is partly blamed for the failure of Germany's Catholics to resist Hitler. Anti-Jewish Catholic doctrines such as the claim that the Jews murdered Christ were said to have ideologically underpinned nazism. Vatican officials allegedly helped Nazis escape Europe after the war.

fields.headline: The Pope's hypocrisy
fields.trailText: Yesterday Pope John Paul issued an unprecedented public apology for past wrongs committed in the Catholic Church's name. At a special ceremony in St Peter's Square he asked forgiveness for sins of intolerance and violence against dissidents, wars of religion, and the Inquisition. He also begged pardon for excommunications, persecutions and sins against the Jews; the church's failure to speak out against injustice; sins against peace and the rights of peoples; and sins against women.
fields.body:
Yesterday Pope John Paul issued an unprecedented public apology for past wrongs committed in the Catholic Church's name. At a special ceremony in St Peter's Square he asked forgiveness for sins of intolerance and violence against dissidents, wars of religion, and the Inquisition. He also begged pardon for excommunications, persecutions and sins against the Jews; the church's failure to speak out against injustice; sins against peace and the rights of peoples; and sins against women.

John Paul pressed ahead with the initiative in the teeth of opposition from many cardinals; and his apology to the Jews, especially, echoes numerous condemnations of anti-Semitism he has made over the past two decades. Few doubt his sincerity. Unlike Pius XII, the wartime pope whose ambivalent attitude towards the Third Reich has drawn charges of cowardice and upset plans to declare him a saint, John Paul suffered at first hand in a Nazi labour camp.

Why then has his statement prompted sharp criticism, as well as admiration? Many Catholics - let alone those outside the church - naturally feel that the apology has been issued scandalously late. But it also comes hard on the heels of a Vatican declaration that Pius IX, a notoriously anti-Semitic 19th century pontiff, is to be beatified on September 3. The move will place him in line to be declared a saint soon afterwards; but as Professor Owen Chadwick, Britain's foremost church historian, comments: "Pius IX's [record] verges on the criminal."

Pius IX (born Giovanni Maria Mastai-Ferretti), a symbol of unbending resistance to the modern world, reigned for a record period between 1846 and 1878. He is chiefly remembered for proclamations on the immaculate conception (1854) and infallibility (1870), and for his condemnation in The Syllabus of Errors of anyone who held that "the Roman Pontiff can and should reconcile himself with progress, liberalism and modern civilisation".

His anti-Semitism, though not untypical of the period, caused dismay even to many contemporary Catholics. As the world has now been reminded, in 1858 the papal police in Bologna entered the home of a Jewish couple and abducted their six-year-old son. Their pretext was that the boy, Edgardo Mortara, had been baptised while dan gerously ill by a housemaid several years earlier. Edgardo was detained and subsequently adopted by Pope Pius, who refused to give him back to his distraught parents unless they converted to Catholicism.

Even when seen in the most sympathetic light (Pius clearly believed he was saving Edgardo from damnation), this record is hardly synonymous with sainthood. Why should the present Pope - an intellectual who says he welcomes dialogue between theology and other disciplines, and a staunch advocate of human rights - now be giving his blessing to a figure as ignominious as Mastai-Ferretti?

The decision is a mark of the deep contrasts and contradictions in John Paul's character. Though a lifelong critic of the right and leftwing dictatorships he lived under before his election, this Pope has been happy to accept or extend an authoritarian style of church government. His approach to saint-making - avid, controversial and unchallengeable - is as clear a mark of his conservative agenda as the Vatican's regular silencing of independently minded theologians has been.

Normally, a prime requirement of beatification is that a cult should have arisen around the candidate in question. Though an icon of resistance to the Risorgimento during his lifetime, Pius has signally failed to satisfy this test. He will be beatified on the same day as Pope John XXIII, a figure of genuine stature who opened the Catholic church to the modern world through the Second Vatican Council of 1962-65.

The joint ceremony will form a coded warning that liberalism can only operate within strict limits, and take place soon before an equally contentious service to beatify several hundred "martyrs" from the Spanish civil war.

"The irony of infallibility," says Owen Chadwick, "is that it places limitations on popes because they can't contradict their predecessors." (The doctrine was first invoked during the Renaissance by Franciscans who told the then pope that he could not contradict an earlier pontiff's declaration that Christ had lived in poverty.) A Catholic historian who wishes not to be named goes further. "Not being able to condemn a predecessor is one thing. But affirming a former pope so explicitly is quite another. John Paul II's action is a disgraceful abuse of his authority."

 Rupert Shortt was formerly assistant editor of the Tablet

webTitle: Hannibal producer bullish over loss of Foster

fields.headline: Hannibal producer bullish over loss of Foster
fields.trailText: Fans of Silence of the Lambs who believed Jodie Foster was irreplaceable have nothing to fear according to the sequel's producer Dino De Laurentiis
fields.body:
Fans of Silence of the Lambs who believed Jodie Foster was irreplaceable have nothing to fear according to the sequel's producer Dino De Laurentiis.

The 80-year-old who has been producing movies for over 30 years, including Barbarella and Conan The Barbarian,among his credits, says in interview with American magazine Entertainment Weekly that Foster's performance as the driven FBI agent was not a key element in the success of the cannibal thriller. "The only thing that matters is a good director and a good story. With those two things, I could play [Clarice] Starling. Within two minutes the audience will forget all about Jodie Foster - I promise you," De Laurentiis tells the magazine. But according to a source close to the producer, also speaking to EW, his reaction was less circumspect than that: "Dino's attitude was, 'Fuck it, move on,' adding that after Anna and the King [Foster's controversial retelling of the King and I which upset the Thai royal family and grossed only $39m], the thinking was, 'Good. What did Jodie Foster really bring anyway?'"

Foster's legacy may have been brushed away but the pressure is still on her successor Julianne Moore to see how she measures up to Foster's Oscar-winning performance. She already has the blessing of writer Thomas Harris. The reclusive author has apparently said that he "couldn't be more pleased" with the decision to cast the actress, who is up for Best Actress at this year's Oscars for her performance as the rejected adulteress in The End of the Affair. But Moore, who was put up for the part by her agent, says that she is determined to make her own mark "I'm not going to do what Jodie did," says Moore in the same interview. "She's a great actor, it was a magnificent performance, there's no way I'm going to duplicate it. There's no sense in even thinking about it - I have to look at Lambs as a separate entity. It's a great film, an untouchable thing, but it was its own deal and Hannibal is another movie altogether. It's my movie."

fields.headline: Nicolas Walter
fields.standfirst: Journalist and philosopher devoted to the unflinching pursuit of atheism and anarchism
fields.trailText: Journalist and philosopher devoted to the unflinching pursuit of atheism and anarchism
fields.body:
The last document from the hand of Nicolas Walter is headed "Curriculum Vitae (Mortisque)" [course of life (and death)] - a bare but accurate summary of his existence. Walter, who has died aged 65, was a writer and lecturer of deep secular humanist and anarchist convictions - his book About Anarchism is known round the world - and factual accuracy was one of his passions.

His insistence on getting the facts right, together with his skill in rhetoric and ready wit, made him a wonderfully entertaining controversialist, either in a set-piece debate or in questions after a lecture, especially when his opponent was clever and pompous. Sometimes, Walter anticipated points that would be raised, and came prepared with copies of historical documents showing that the opponent had got the facts wrong.

Accused in a published letter of supposing that history consisted of nothing more than getting the facts right, he replied: "Getting the facts right is not history, but it is a necessary preliminary." He went on to list the factual errors in the letter he was answering.

By profession a journalist, Walter was deputy editor of Which? (1963-65), press officer for the British Standards Institution (1965-67), chief sub-editor of the Times Literary Supplement (1968-74), and editor of New Humanist, followed by various director ial posts for the Rationalist Press Association (1975-99). Many of his letters putting the rationalist point of view were published in the Guardian and elsewhere, over his own name and a variety of pseudonyms including "A Freeman" and "Mary Lewis". He continued writing after retirement: his last published article appeared in the anarchist paper Freedom, on February 26.

For various publishers, he compiled and edited texts on atheism and anarchism by figures both political and literary, including Michael Bakunin, Edward Carpenter, Denis Diderot, EM Forster, Peter Kropotkin, George Bernard Shaw, Percy Bysshe Shelley and Oscar Wilde. His book about Charlotte Wilson, a leading late 19th-century anarchist writer and and founder of Freedom, is to be published later this year.

Among his own books, About Anarchism (1969) has been translated into many languages, including Chinese, Japanese, Russian, Greek and Serbo-Croat. Other books include Nonviolent Resistance: Men Against War (1963); Blasphemy Ancient and Modern (1990) and Humanism: What's in the Word (1997).

Walter was a founding member of the anti-nuclear Committee of 100 and of Spies for Peace, the group which exposed the notorious "regional seats of government" (underground bunkers designed to give government members a chance of surviving nuclear war), and an energetic demonstrator for peace and freedom until crippled by the side effects of radiotherapy in the 1980s. In 1966, he was imprisoned for two months for interrupting a Labour Party church service in Brighton.

Born in south London, Walter studied at Rendcomb College, Cirencester, and read modern history at Exeter College, Oxford. One of his grandfathers was SK Radcliffe, a radical atheist who wrote a history of the South Place Ethical Society, London: Walter was the soci ety's chairman during its bicentenary celebration in 1993. His other grandfather was Karl Walter, an anarchist who reported the international anarchist conference of 1897 for the Times. His father was W Grey Walter, the neurophysiologist famous for the robot "tortoises" at the Festival of Britain exhibition in 1951, and now on show again in the millennium dome.

In a letter to the Guardian, replying to an article about dying without the comfort of religion, he wrote: "Raging against the dying of the light may be good art, but it is bad advice. 'Why me?' may be a natural question, but it prompts a natural answer, 'Why not?'. Religion may promise life everlasting, but we should grow up, and accept that life has an end as welI as a beginning ... Mortality is inevitable, but morbidity is not."

The last line of his final CV reads "Recreation: Living". Nicolas Walter was a warm and enthusiastic family man. He is survived by his first wife Ruth, their two daughters, two grandsons and a granddaughter; and by his second wife Christine and their two stepsons and stepdaughter.

 Nicolas Walter, writer and lecturer, born November 22 1934; died March 7 2000

webTitle: Mission to Mars blasts into US box office

fields.headline: Mission to Mars blasts into US box office
fields.trailText: Brian DePalma's sci-fi epic Mission to Mars blasted into the number one spot at the American box office this weekend grossing an estimated $23m, the second biggest opening of the year - behind Scream 3 - and the third biggest opening after 1997's Liar, Liar and 1990's Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles
fields.body:
Brian DePalma's sci-fi epic Mission to Mars blasted into the number one spot at the American box office this weekend grossing an estimated $23m, the second biggest opening of the year - behind Scream 3 - and the third biggest opening after 1997's Liar, Liar and 1990's Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.

Reviews of the sci-fi extravaganza, which stars Tim Robbins as an astronaut stranded on the Red Planet, were distinctly lacklustre - Jami Bernard in the New York Daily News Still sums up the view of many: "The dialogue and some story elements are disappointing, a molten mass of cliches spouted by characters who barely develop and never grab you" - but the American public was sufficiently intrigued, proving that big budget sci-fi films will always pull in the crowds. Deep Impact, Independence Day and Apollo 13, which also all relied heavily on special effects rather than a strong narrative and good script, did well at the box office.

Mission to Mars earned more than the next four films combined, and accounted for about 38 percent of the total top 10 gross. The only other new entry in the top 10 was director Roman Polanski's The Ninth Gate. The supernatural thriller, which stars Johnny Depp as an antiquarian book seller who has to track down two books with satanic powers, opened at number two. The Whole Nine Yards relinquished its top spot, which it has held for three weeks, whilst the only movie to increase its taking was family flick My Dog Skip which rose to number three.

webTitle: Sri Lanka make history in Pakistan

fields.headline: Sri Lanka make history in Pakistan
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka's victory in the second Test at Peshawar makes them the first team ever to win consecutive Test series in Pakistan, following their 2-1 triumph in 1995-96. Sri Lanka did lose to Pakistan in the final of the Asian Test Championship, but it was played in Dhaka, Bangladesh (despite counting as part of a Pakistan home series for the purposes of the Wisden World Championship - the preceding match between the two sides, in Lahore, was drawn).
fields.body:
Sri Lanka's victory in the second Test at Peshawar makes them the first team ever to win consecutive Test series in Pakistan, following their 2-1 triumph in 1995-96. Sri Lanka did lose to Pakistan in the final of the Asian Test Championship, but it was played in Dhaka, Bangladesh (despite counting as part of a Pakistan home series for the purposes of the Wisden World Championship - the preceding match between the two sides, in Lahore, was drawn).

In fact Sri Lanka are only the second side to win two series in Pakistan. The first was Australia, who won 2-0 in 1959-60 but then had to wait 39 years for their next triumph, a 1-0 victory 18 months ago inspired by Mark Taylor's unbeaten 334 at Peshawar.

Pakistan, who lost just four Test series at home in the first 43 years of their existence as a Test-playing nation, have now lost five in the last four years: the two defeats by Sri Lanka, plus South Africa (0-1 in 1997-98), Zimbabwe (0-1 in 1998-99) and Australia (0-1 in 1998-99). This also includes their last three home series.

India have just been beaten at home, by South Africa, for the first time in 13 years: could it be that the subcontinent is now becoming the place every side actually wants to tour?

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: 'I wanted to throw myself into the sea'

fields.headline: 'I wanted to throw myself into the sea'
fields.standfirst:
Aitken book claims 'fear and arrogance' led him to lie and that love for his son saved him from throwing himself off 200ft cliff

The Aitken affair: special report
fields.trailText: Aitken book claims 'fear and arrogance' led him to lie and that love for his son saved him from throwing himself off 200ft cliff
fields.body:
Jonathan Aitken embarked on the long road of salvaging his tattered reputation yesterday when he made his first public pronouncements since being jailed for perjury and perverting the course of justice.

With a three page interview and extract from his forthcoming book Pride and Perjury in the Sunday Times, the former cabinet minister painted a picture of himself as a contrite man, who was saved from suicide by the love of his 14-year-old son and his faith in God.

But Aitken, who was released from prison in January after serving 6 months of an 18-month sentence, was pitched into further controversy, this time over the estimated £150,000 the newspaper has paid for exclusive rights to the book.

Labour MPs yesterday accused the Sunday Times of breaching the press complaints commission guidelines which forbid payments to convicted criminals and their associates. The newspaper released a statement saying a fee for the serialisation rights was being paid to Mr Aitken's bankruptcy trustees, and no money was going to him or his family. But Peter Bradley, Labour MP for the Wrekin, said he had drafted a letter to the PCC complaining that the contract between the newspaper and Mr Aitken's publishers HarperCollins was a clear breach of the guidelines because the money was being used to pay off his bankruptcy debts. "Mr Aitken is still getting a benefit from marketing sleaze and I don't think that is acceptable."

In the book, which charts his fall from grace as a minister in John Major's government to his sentencing at the Old Bailey last June, Mr Aitken said "fear and arrogance" led him to lie about his infamous stay at the Paris Ritz in 1993.

"The fear came from not wanting to be embarrassed about a possible breach of questions of procedure for ministers at a time when I was in the frame for promotion to the cabinet," Aitken said. "Instead of sorting the matter out with a little penitence ... I toughed it out with a lot of arrogance."

When his libel case against the Guardian and Granada Television collapsed after it emerged he had lied in the witness box and persuaded his wife and daughter to support his false story, he suffered the "blackest descent into misery I have ever known".

"All that lay ahead was an unending vista of media tortures, legal nightmares, money crises, family upheavals and jail," he said.

After fleeing to California with his son, William, to escape the media attention Aitken said he climbed to the top of a 200ft cliff and felt tempted to "throw myself in to the swirling seas".

He asked his son whether he would have better prospects without the burden of a disgraced father hovering in the background, but William told him not to be a chump and that he needed him.

Weeks later, he wrote, he had a supernatural experience as he walked along Sandwich Bay in Kent. Aitken, who plans to spend the next two years studying Theology at Wycliffe College, Oxford, said a voice inside his head promised help and guidance and afterwards he discovered his normally reliable Rolex watch had stopped.

"I was not mad. Yet on the beach I had heard something, felt something and my watch had unaccountably stopped."

Mr Aitken also spoke about his experiences as an inmate at Belmarsh prison in south-east London and the gentler regime at Standford Hill in Kent.

Aitken, whom other inmates nicknamed "Joino" because he could do joined up writing, found "a lot of warmth and kindness, a lot of laughter" in jail, revealing that armed robbers and other criminals he met inside had been calling at his house in Lord North Street, Westminster, since his release.

But there was also a darker side, with two thirds of prisoners regular heroin users ...

In an extract from Pride and Perjury Aitken recounted the hours leading up his "sword of truth" speech, in which he promised to cut out the cancer of "bent and twisted journalism". He said he drafted the speech after a sleepless night and tried it out on a group of treasury lawyers and civil servants and his family at home. The treasury group apparently burst into applause while his wife and daughter begged to be allowed to accompany him to the press conference.

Despite his "bombastic" performance from the platform at Tory central office, inside he was feeling nervous. "I knew there were vulnerabilities on my side," he explained.

Despite well documented evidence that his divorce from his wife, Lolicia, was one of convenience in an attempt to stop his creditors from seizing his assets, Aitken claimed their separation was the saddest part of the whole affair. "A strong part of me would love to get back together, but she is not interested in that," he said. Asked if a man branded a liar can ever be trusted by the public again, Aitken responds that it us up to the public to make up their own minds. "Some will, some won't."

webTitle: Reformers could make a world of difference

fields.headline: Reformers could make a world of difference
fields.trailText: After much unseemly horse-trading, Horst Köhler is favourite for the top job at the International Monetary Fund. One wonders why he is bothering, because the reputation of multilateral organisations has rarely been lower. The World Trade Organisation? Creature of multinational capitalism and source of all global evil. The IMF? A battering ram for Wall Street, an arm of American foreign policy. The World Bank? Redundant in an age of large private sector financial flows. The United Nations? Inefficient, little more than an expensive talking shop.
fields.body:
After much unseemly horse-trading, Horst Köhler is favourite for the top job at the International Monetary Fund. One wonders why he is bothering, because the reputation of multilateral organisations has rarely been lower. The World Trade Organisation? Creature of multinational capitalism and source of all global evil. The IMF? A battering ram for Wall Street, an arm of American foreign policy. The World Bank? Redundant in an age of large private sector financial flows. The United Nations? Inefficient, little more than an expensive talking shop.

Even more worrying is that the attacks on the global institutions have come from left and right. The right has always been suspicious of any form of governance and sees the Bank and the Fund as relics of a discredited age interventionism. For a variety of reasons - debt, structural adjustment, dams, bananas - a section of the left has lost its faith in multilateralism.

It is not difficult to see why these views are held. In the immediate post-war period, the Fund was the custodian of the fixed exchange rate system set up at Bretton Woods and helped countries through short-term balance of payments crises. But since the Bretton Woods system collapsed in the early 1970s the Fund has had its fingers in every economic pie, with little success.

Even so, it would be mistake to give up on multilaterism. It is tempting to believe that a world without a WTO or an IMF would return to a state of pre-globalisation nirvana, but it would not. All that would happen is that there would a state of global anarchy in which the strongest would use their muscle to extract concessions from the weak. The result of dismantling the Fund, for example, would not be that poor countries cease to have inappropriate policies foisted on them: it would simply mean the inappropriate policies would be imposed by the rich countries of the G7 rather than by the IMF.

So let's not kid ourselves. A retreat from multilaterism would not be a victory for the forces of progressivism, it would leave the field open for the forces of conservatism. The solution is to reshape the way multilateral institutions work and create new ones to address issues such as environmental protection.

Although they are often caricatured as being unaccountable, the multilateral organisations reflect the policies of the countries that make up their membership. Should the IMF wish to promulgate expansionary macro-economic policies, with domestic autonomy protected by controls on capital, there is no reason why it could not do so, provided that is what its main shareholders want.

Indeed, this was what was enshrined in the first article of agreement of the Fund in 1944. Maynard Keynes and Harry Dexter White, the US negotiator, faced down protests from Wall Street and committed the IMF to "the promotion and maintenance of high levels of employment and real income, and the development of the productive resources of all members as primary objectives of economic policy". Nothing there about deflation, budget cuts, structural adjustment, privatisation and the rest of the neo-liberal catechism. That came later, when the west turned its back on the economic policies of the golden age. While it is tempting for countries to blame the Fund for unpopular and painful policies, the truth is that countries - especially the G7 countries - dictate to the Fund rather than the other way round.

Now is a good time to attempt progressive reform of the Fund. The financial instability of recent years has dented faith in the main tenets of neo-liberalism and created space to redefine the role of the multilateral institutions. If the left does not engage in this debate it will leave the field open to those on the right who would prefer minimal global governance or none at all.

A contribution to the debate came last week from the Meltzer report on future US policy towards the Fund, the Bank, the regional development banks, the Bank for International Settlements and the WTO. One of the main recommendations - that the Fund and the Bank should write off their claims against all highly indebted poor countries - was welcome; the other, that the Fund restrict its lending to the provision of short-term liquidity and withdraw from the arena of poverty reduction altogether, was far more questionable.

Certainly, the Fund's track record in developing policies that will combine macro-economic success with poverty reduction has been abysmal. It has been arrogant and wrong. But it would be naive to assume that the absence of the Fund would mean that poor countries would be left to their own devices, because they assuredly would not. The same policies would be imposed by the G7 and, more particularly, the US treasury. Those on the left who want to see the demise of the Fund have to ask themselves whether that would be a better or worse outcome.

Let us start from a different perspective: that the Fund is intrinsically a good thing. Let us also assume that it has good and honourable people working for it whose intention is to improve global welfare. Can it be harnessed to make the world a better place?

The answer is yes. First, there is a question of democratic control. As the shenanigans over who is to succeed Michel Camdessus as managing director have shown, the IMF is essentially a plaything of the G7, which with only 14% of global population controls 57% of the vote. It is much less democratic than the WTO, where all carry equal weight. Such a system is impossible in the Fund, because members expect to call the tune. But restricting the vote of any country to 10% while increasing the voting power of developing countries would be a step in the right direction. As Oxfam says: "It is unacceptable that people in Africa, whose lives are arguably most affected by IMF programmes, account for only 2% of voting rights. It is outrageous that loan conditions are used to promote policy reforms in poor countries - such as agricultural market liberalisation, rapid trade liberalisation, financial market deregulation - which would be rejected in G7 countries."

Lender of last resort

Second, the IMF and other multilateral institutions need to remember that one of the principles upon which they were established was that the burden of adjustment in times of difficulty should fall on creditors as well as debtors. In the case of the Fund, countries running balance of payments surpluses should operate expansionary demand policies to help those in deficit. This principle has been turned on its head: the presumption is that deficit countries must resolve their own problems by deflating.

Third, the Fund should operate as a proper lender of last resort, but this is something that it cannot do unless it is also prepared to tame global capital markets. Naturally, this is something that the US, the Fund's biggest shareholder, is not prepared to countenance, but the reality is that a lender of last resort can only work if there are effective national and global policies to restrict volatility. The object of the Fund should be to foster liquidity and output, not create Wall Street buying opportunities.

It would be wrong to say this will be easy. It won't be, given that even at a time when so-called social democratic governments are in power across most of the west, the G7 seems unable to state the obvious: that the neo-liberal emperor has no clothes. What will change that? As Harold Macmillan once said: "Events, dear boy, events."
