Should the IMF wish to promulgate expansionary macro-economic policies, with domestic autonomy protected by controls on capital, there is no reason why it could not do so, provided that is what its main shareholders want. Indeed, this was what was enshrined in the first article of agreement of the Fund in 1944. Maynard Keynes and Harry Dexter White, the US negotiator, faced down protests from Wall Street and committed the IMF to "the promotion and maintenance of high levels of employment and real income, and the development of the productive resources of all members as primary objectives of economic policy". Nothing there about deflation, budget cuts, structural adjustment, privatisation and the rest of the neo-liberal catechism. That came later, when the west turned its back on the economic policies of the golden age. While it is tempting for countries to blame the Fund for unpopular and painful policies, the truth is that countries - especially the G7 countries - dictate to the Fund rather than the other way round. Now is a good time to attempt progressive reform of the Fund. The financial instability of recent years has dented faith in the main tenets of neo-liberalism and created space to redefine the role of the multilateral institutions. If the left does not engage in this debate it will leave the field open to those on the right who would prefer minimal global governance or none at all. A contribution to the debate came last week from the Meltzer report on future US policy towards the Fund, the Bank, the regional development banks, the Bank for International Settlements and the WTO. One of the main recommendations - that the Fund and the Bank should write off their claims against all highly indebted poor countries - was welcome; the other, that the Fund restrict its lending to the provision of short-term liquidity and withdraw from the arena of poverty reduction altogether, was far more questionable. Certainly, the Fund's track record in developing policies that will combine macro-economic success with poverty reduction has been abysmal. It has been arrogant and wrong. But it would be naive to assume that the absence of the Fund would mean that poor countries would be left to their own devices, because they assuredly would not. The same policies would be imposed by the G7 and, more particularly, the US treasury. Those on the left who want to see the demise of the Fund have to ask themselves whether that would be a better or worse outcome. Let us start from a different perspective: that the Fund is intrinsically a good thing. Let us also assume that it has good and honourable people working for it whose intention is to improve global welfare. Can it be harnessed to make the world a better place? The answer is yes. First, there is a question of democratic control. As the shenanigans over who is to succeed Michel Camdessus as managing director have shown, the IMF is essentially a plaything of the G7, which with only 14% of global population controls 57% of the vote. It is much less democratic than the WTO, where all carry equal weight. Such a system is impossible in the Fund, because members expect to call the tune. But restricting the vote of any country to 10% while increasing the voting power of developing countries would be a step in the right direction. As Oxfam says: "It is unacceptable that people in Africa, whose lives are arguably most affected by IMF programmes, account for only 2% of voting rights. It is outrageous that loan conditions are used to promote policy reforms in poor countries - such as agricultural market liberalisation, rapid trade liberalisation, financial market deregulation - which would be rejected in G7 countries." Lender of last resort Second, the IMF and other multilateral institutions need to remember that one of the principles upon which they were established was that the burden of adjustment in times of difficulty should fall on creditors as well as debtors. In the case of the Fund, countries running balance of payments surpluses should operate expansionary demand policies to help those in deficit. This principle has been turned on its head: the presumption is that deficit countries must resolve their own problems by deflating. Third, the Fund should operate as a proper lender of last resort, but this is something that it cannot do unless it is also prepared to tame global capital markets. Naturally, this is something that the US, the Fund's biggest shareholder, is not prepared to countenance, but the reality is that a lender of last resort can only work if there are effective national and global policies to restrict volatility. The object of the Fund should be to foster liquidity and output, not create Wall Street buying opportunities. It would be wrong to say this will be easy. It won't be, given that even at a time when so-called social democratic governments are in power across most of the west, the G7 seems unable to state the obvious: that the neo-liberal emperor has no clothes. What will change that? As Harold Macmillan once said: "Events, dear boy, events." larry.elliott@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Tories on the move
fields.standfirst:
A win in Ayr may revitalise Hague, but it won't last unless he can find some big ideas and ways to fund them
Devolution in Scotland: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: A win in Ayr may revitalise Hague, but it won't last unless he can find some big ideas and ways to fund them
fields.body:
A Scottish morning dawns in Troon, a blustery South Ayrshire town of old folk and tea shops, and Malcolm Rifkind, ex-conservative cabinet minister and unseated MP, takes to the streets with a plum in his mouth, leaflets in his hand and a spring in his step.

In his Barbour jacket and tartan tie he strides around, canvassing for the local candidate in this Thursday's byelection for the Scottish parliament, with the confidence of man apparently oblivious to the oblivion which has been inflicted on his own party in recent elections north of the border. "We haven't seen a favourable reaction like this for a Tory candidate for some years," he says. "You can sense that the mood is changing."

The voters look set to oust Labour and return a Tory to the Scottish parliament. According to the polls their lead is narrow but consistent - although a huge number remain undecided. A victory would make John Scott, a local farmer, the first Conservative MSP to be elected on the first-past-the-post basis. The prospect has put Tories in jubilant mood, with supporters pouring in from all over Scotland.

The ramifications of a Tory victory here go beyond the Tweed to the nation at large. Its importance is reflected in the big guns that have been sent to the area from Westminster. The Conservative leader, William Hague, arrives today. The cabinet enforcer, Mo Mowlam, was here on Thursday. It is also illustrated by a high-level snub last week from the prime minister. Despite a visit to Scotland Tony Blair declined to come to the constituency, claiming pressure of work. Many here accuse him of running scared of association with almost certain defeat.

It is easy to grasp the significance of such a defeat for Conservatives. Most commentators have either written them out of the current political narrative as an irrelevance or written them in as a joke. When shadow spokesmen and women are wheeled in front of the cameras one presumes that (with the possible exception of Anne Widdecombe) they have been invited either out of sympathy or in a desperate search for balance - not because they might have something to contribute, however nefarious, to any particular debate. Hague is regarded as a man holding the fort and clearing up the mess until a grown-up steps in - not as the possible leader of the next government.

Victory in Ayr, Tories hope, followed by gains in council elections in May, might signal the green shoots of a general recovery. "I very much hope that this election is seen as the turning point in Tory party fortunes throughout the country," says Scott. "It will show that we have learnt our lesson from the last election and that the voters can trust us."

If he wins this, many far more extravagant claims will be made by the right which should be treated with extreme caution rather than dismissive ridicule. Defeat in Ayr will not send Millbank into a tailspin. This is not like Dudley West, which went from a 5,789 Conservative majority to a 20,694 Labour win in 1994, presaging the 1997 landslide. Labour won by only 25 votes in Ayr last year. If the Conservatives cannot overturn that slender margin almost three years into Labour's term then there is little hope for them.

But the result should serve as a timely reminder that, unlike Monty Python's infamous parrot, the Tory party is not dead, but merely sleeping.

The shock Conservative victory in last year's Euro elections shows just what a mistake it is to write them off. The sense of drift, introspection and lack of unity they display may evoke Labour during the early 80s. But electorally their share of the popular vote in 1997 is almost identical to Labour's in 1987.

And come the next election there will be many more slender margins out there for them to whittle away at - more than a third of Labour's majority comes from constituencies won by less than 5,000 votes; add to this almost half the Liberal Democrat seats which are held by the same margin and it becomes clear that in 18 months the Tories could be in a position to mount a credible opposition.

Yet they do not seem ready for the role. There is more to opposition than arithmetic. They will owe a victory in Ayr only to disillusionment with the government both in Westminster and Holyrood. If Labour crash to third position behind the SNP, as one poll suggested they might, it will be because three-quarters of those those who currently don't know how to vote on Thursday voted Labour last time.

Turning disaffected Labour supporters into active Tories will not be easy - especially so long as the economy is strong. But it might not be impossible. Many of those who backed Labour at the last election did so for the first time and, given the right incentive, could be attracted back without too much concern about loyalty. This is Blair's worst nightmare - the Tories galvanising their core support while Labour voters sit on their hands.

Paradoxically, given that it was the issue which tore them apart before the last election, the most popular policy the Conservatives have is on Europe. Their stance of leaving Britain inside the EU but outside the euro chimes with the views of most voters. Since no other party agrees, it has the added benefit of being distinctive.

And a glimmer of what else is possible emerges from the few who genuinely do seem to have begun ideologically to regroup after 1997. Last week the Tory party in Brighton selected its first openly gay parliamentary candidate. When the party's London mayoral candidate, Steve Norris, says he would have sacked the Met commissioner Paul Condon after the Macpherson report, and that he expects police to turn a blind eye to gay people having sex in public places, he turns heads among people who would never have dreamed of voting Tory before.

But that will not be enough. Even if Labour does not have a monopoly on socially progressive assertions, it is a terrain with which they are far more familiar than the Tories. For Conservatives to be taken seriously they are going to have to update their economic policies too.

Canvassers in the Ayr byelection repeat that the key issues are jobs, health and education - not areas where Tories are well trusted. At a Conservative party meeting in the village hall in the small Ayrshire village of Loans on Friday night, the handful of members present criticised rail privatisation and the paltry increase in pensions. They questioned why Gordon Brown's 1p cut in income tax was not going to the NHS.

This is William Hague's greatest challenge. He must face down not only the race-haters and gay-baiters within his own party, but the privatisers and tax slashers too - to find a creative, big idea and a creative way to fund it too. Like George W Bush and Tony Blair, if he is ever going to make himself popular with the voters he must first learn how to make himself unpopular with his own party. It might wipe the smile off Malcolm Rifkind's face; but it might put his frown back in Westminster too.

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: All your questions on EMU answered
fields.body:
Could the UK be left as the only European Union state not to be part of the single currency?

While Britain has been dithering about whether to join the euro, the three other countries left on the sidelines when the single currency was launched a year ago - Denmark, Sweden and Greece - are all inching towards membership.

Greece announced last week that it was formally applying to join and on the same day Denmark set a date in late September for a referendum on the subject. The ruling Social Democrat party in Sweden held a special congress this weekend which backed the government's cautious pro-economic and monetary union (EMU) line, but demanded that the issue be put to the electorate in a referendum.

Why didn't the others join at the beginning?

Greece missed out because in 1998, when the first entrants were being decided, it did not meet the economic tests for joining set out in the Maastricht treaty.

Denmark, Sweden and the UK chose not to enter because of domestic political hostility to the project. Denmark and Britain had formally negotiated the right to opt out out of the launch of the eurozone.

Will the Greeks be allowed to join this time?

Greece is very keen to join and has managed to conquer its inflationary problem and get government borrowing under control. Strictly speaking it still violates one of the Maastricht rules - national debt is more than 60% of its annual income.

But the judges turned a blind eye to this rule in 1998, with six out of the 11 founding members violating it, so that probably will not be a showstopper. Greece could potentially join the eurozone in January 2001.

Who will be next?

Denmark, about a year later, if the pro-EMU camp wins September's referendum. The pros are currently leading the antis by a nose, but one in five voters has yet to make up their mind, so there is a lot still to play for. The Danes have voted against EMU before.

What about Sweden and Britain?

The Swedish position on EMU seems to be "yes, but later". The government will have a tough job to convince a largely eurosceptic electorate of the virtues of the single currency.

In fact the position is remarkably similar to Britain's stance, right down to the reluctance to spell out a timetable for joining. The race to be last to join could be a close-run thing.

fields.headline: Dangerous liaisons
fields.standfirst: It was a story that went to the very heart of the privacy debate - the nanny who decided to break her silence on the Blairs. But after a week of injunctions, threats to sue and late-night court hearings, has anyone won the latest media war? Roy Greenslade reveals the mistakes made by all sides
fields.trailText: It was a story that went to the very heart of the privacy debate - the nanny who decided to break her silence on the Blairs. But after a week of injunctions, threats to sue and late-night court hearings, has anyone won the latest media war? Roy Greenslade reveals the mistakes made by all sides
fields.body:
When Simon Walters, the Mail on Sunday's political editor, telephoned Alastair Campbell nine days ago he knew what to expect. He was about to tell the prime minister's formidable press secretary that his paper knew all about a supposedly secret book written by the Blair family's former nanny, Ros Mark. But this tape-recorded call, received by Campbell after he had watched his beloved Burnley lose a match, did not go as Walters, or his editor Peter Wright, anticipated.

It was the beginning of a story that was still rumbling over the weekend, a row that was still producing many column inches in yesterday's Sunday papers. The case of the nanny, the Blairs and the MoS has raised a myriad of important issues concerning press ethics.

Walters thought Campbell would be amazed when he revealed to him that Mark had written a book and would probably explode when he explained that the MoS was planning to write a story about it.

Instead, Campbell was unsurprised. He had had a conversation hours earlier with Mark in which she had told him that she had been approached by the MoS. She told him she had written "a manuscript" which she had passed on to an agent, whom she had since dismissed. She didn't know what to do, she said. Mark assured Campbell that there was no question of her publishing anything without obtaining the full permission of the Blairs. It was, she explained, a sort of social history. The agent had told her he couldn't sell the manuscript because it was an affectionate portrait of the Blair household and not a kiss-and-tell story.

Campbell suggested that Mark write to the paper to ensure that nothing in the least bit controversial might be published. She then sent Wright an email message asking what the paper intended to publish and asking whether it might be possible to delay any story for a couple of weeks until she had finished her teacher-training course.

Believing he had taken sensible precautions, Campbell was relaxed throughout his call from Walters. He wanted to avoid any headline critical of Blair.

On his side, Walters wanted to conceal the fact that the paper knew exactly what was in the manuscript. So the conversation was like a surreal bout of shadow boxing.

My belief is that Walters was trying to provoke Campbell into launching some kind of legal action, or at least a fearsome threat of one, enabling the paper to publish a story headlined along the lines of "Blair gags nanny". Aware of this tactic, Campbell assumed an air of nonchalance, a reaction which probably upset Wright's plans. Walters asked Campbell if he had "a problem" with the paper saying that Mark was seeking a publisher for her book.

Given the assurances from Mark, Campbell was noncommital. It was going to be a routine story, he thought, so he even told Walters: "If you want a quote say 'Tony and Cherie think Ros Mark is a 100% good person. They would trust her not to say anything that would harm or embarrass the family'."

That single conversation was to prove crucial to the storm that was to break hours later. It is possible, with hindsight, to see how important it was. For some reason, mainly due to Campbell's high regard for Mark, neither of the calls - from Mark and Walters - rang alarm bells. The woman had had an exemplary record while working for the Blairs, was loved by the children and had kept in regular touch with the family since leaving her job in August 1998.

According to people close to the Blairs, she was capable, conscientious and clever. Whatever the problems and strains, she was "a rock", coping calmly whatever the crisis. Soon after Mark joined the household in January 1994, Cherie Blair realised her good fortune in having found her. Though sad when the nanny left, she understood: Mark wanted to put her intelligence and skills to better use by becoming a teacher.

Aware of all this, Campbell's antennae were not tuned in. In an unusual example of naivety, he accepted that there was not a completed book.

According to Mark, the MoS had virtually tricked their way into her house and she appears not to have informed Campbell of the extent of the "manuscript". He was left feeling it was an "outline" for a book and not the 451-page, 180,000-word document she had typed over the previous year. Mark had first been visited at her home in Galgate, near Lancaster, by the MoS's writer, Fiona Barton, on Friday afternoon.

Barton wasn't invited in but Mark did confirm during a doorstep conversation that she had written a book. They parted - on friendly terms, according to the MoS, though not according to Mark - and Barton returned, with a photographer, the next day. Barton made two more visits on Saturday morning and this time she was allowed into the house, also meeting Mark's mother, Margaret, known as Mig. During the course of these visits, Mark talked much more fully about the book's content. She also posed happily for pictures and even handed over pictures of herself with the Blair family.

Mark was later to claim that she posed reluctantly when told that pictures of her taken at a distance made her look "tired". Wouldn't she prefer to see herself looking groomed? Whether true or not, most journalists know of this ruse.

During those talks, Barton came to believe that Mark did want the book published and was also hoping for a newspaper serialisation. Surely though, asked Barton, there was some kind of confidentiality agreement between her and the Blairs? Yes, replied Mark, there was. In fact, she had raised it with Cherie a couple of years into her tenure, but a friend had convinced her that it wasn't binding.

At this point, the MoS's editor and lawyers knew they had to be careful. No paper has a better first-hand knowledge of the Blairs' desire to protect their children. The MoS was censured by the Press Complaints Commission last year for running a story about the schooling of Kathryn Blair, and no matter how much the adjudication rankled with Wright, he was unlikely to stray into a legal confrontation with the Blairs without taking great care. What tipped the balance was their interpretation of the Walters-Campbell call. Since Campbell knew they had been talking to the nanny and offered them a quote, it must be OK to go ahead.

A splash was written with a prediction which soon turned out to be spot on: a "sensational" account by their nanny "would spark a major controversy with the Blairs". She had written it, she explained to the paper, because "I had been part of a moment in history and I wanted to write about it for historical reasons".

The next mystery is how the paper came by Mark's manuscript in the first place. By her account, she handed a disk of her would-be book to an agent selected at random, Jonathan Harris, asking him to find a publisher.

The MoS is coy about how it came to know of the book, claiming it came from "sources in the publishing industry". Harris has stated unequivocally that he "played absolutely no part whatsoever" in the MoS story, which he told me yesterday remains the case. If he did approach publishers with the manuscript, a lot of people could have tipped off the paper. What we do know is that no publisher made an offer and Mark, frustrated with Harris's failure, dispensed with his services.

It wasn't until 9.40pm last Saturday that Campbell realised the full import of the MoS story. It wasn't just a case of reporting the fact of the book's existence after all. It also included anecdotes and incidents from the manuscript. In a hastily convened conference call with Cherie, in London, Tony Blair in Durham and Lord Falconer, it was decided that, if those details were not to gain further currency once in the public domain, they must go for an injunction. The key was the confidentiality agreement signed by Mark. She had, in Cherie's view, broken both the spirit and the letter of it. The injunction was granted, leading to the paper recalling copies and publishing a new front page.

Though the Blairs were to issue supportive statements about Mark, stressing how much they liked her, some aides have since pointed out that she is entirely to blame for all that has happened. "They've been over-generous really, which does them credit,"said one. "But you can't help feeling that Ros, or perhaps her mother, saw a chance to make a lot from their 15 minutes of fame."

Mark is certainly guilty, at the very least, of naivety in thinking that - to use her own phrase - she could "get round" her agreement with Cherie. Having worked so closely with the Blairs, it seems remarkable, given her undoubted intelligence, that she thought publishing even an affectionate book would be possible, especially while Blair is in office.

The Blairs have a right to feel let down. They offered the hand of friendship to Mark's family. At one time, her mother acted as a home help while her brother, Tom, also helped out. There is some incredulity at Number 10 at suggestions in the press that Tom was Blair's "butler-cum-valet" or even his "personal dresser".

The arrangement appears to have been less a case of hired domestic service than a job creation scheme by the Blairs, an act of kindness to people who were, at the time, virtually homeless.

The sense of personal betrayal was heightened by the fact that although Mark kept in touch regularly after leaving she never mentioned writing about the family. She even called Blair on his daughter's birthday, just three days before the MoS publication, telling the paper: "I didn't tell him about the book."

With the legal clamp still in place, the contents of the MoS story cannot be repeated or even touched upon. But it is fair to say that it contained material which was intrusive and could have been used to satirise and undermine the Blairs. Far from being an anodyne story, it was potentially harmful. It can also be seen as the thin end of the wedge. If this was allowed to pass then other revelations were bound to surface.

That was certainly the view adopted by the judge last Friday who upheld the injunction, ruling against the MoS, a fact the MoS failed to report in its lengthy justification of its actions yesterday.

This episode does reveal a great deal about the nature of our present society, where privacy is at a premium, human relationships have become a commodity and the prime minister is beginning to attract the kind of press hostility that is clouding editorial judgment.

But my canvass of other editors suggests that they don't agree with the MoS, in spite of odd columnists claiming the injunction threatens press freedom. Most journalists agree, for once, with the Sun, which last week stated: "Nobody should have the spotlight shone on everything they do in their own home. This kitchen table tittle-tattle had no public interest justification."

Quite so.

He was about to tell the prime minister's formidable press secretary that his paper knew all about a supposedly secret book written by the Blair family's former nanny, Ros Mark. But this tape-recorded call, received by Campbell after he had watched his beloved Burnley lose a match, did not go as Walters, or his editor Peter Wright, anticipated. It was the beginning of a story that was still rumbling over the weekend, a row that was still producing many column inches in yesterday's Sunday papers. The case of the nanny, the Blairs and the MoS has raised a myriad of important issues concerning press ethics. Walters thought Campbell would be amazed when he revealed to him that Mark had written a book and would probably explode when he explained that the MoS was planning to write a story about it. Instead, Campbell was unsurprised. He had had a conversation hours earlier with Mark in which she had told him that she had been approached by the MoS. She told him she had written "a manuscript" which she had passed on to an agent, whom she had since dismissed. She didn't know what to do, she said. Mark assured Campbell that there was no question of her publishing anything without obtaining the full permission of the Blairs. It was, she explained, a sort of social history. The agent had told her he couldn't sell the manuscript because it was an affectionate portrait of the Blair household and not a kiss-and-tell story. Campbell suggested that Mark write to the paper to ensure that nothing in the least bit controversial might be published. She then sent Wright an email message asking what the paper intended to publish and asking whether it might be possible to delay any story for a couple of weeks until she had finished her teacher-training course. Believing he had taken sensible precautions, Campbell was relaxed throughout his call from Walters. He wanted to avoid any headline critical of Blair. On his side, Walters wanted to conceal the fact that the paper knew exactly what was in the manuscript. So the conversation was like a surreal bout of shadow boxing. My belief is that Walters was trying to provoke Campbell into launching some kind of legal action, or at least a fearsome threat of one, enabling the paper to publish a story headlined along the lines of "Blair gags nanny". Aware of this tactic, Campbell assumed an air of nonchalance, a reaction which probably upset Wright's plans. Walters asked Campbell if he had "a problem" with the paper saying that Mark was seeking a publisher for her book. Given the assurances from Mark, Campbell was noncommital. It was going to be a routine story, he thought, so he even told Walters: "If you want a quote say 'Tony and Cherie think Ros Mark is a 100% good person. They would trust her not to say anything that would harm or embarrass the family'." That single conversation was to prove crucial to the storm that was to break hours later. It is possible, with hindsight, to see how important it was. For some reason, mainly due to Campbell's high regard for Mark, neither of the calls - from Mark and Walters - rang alarm bells. The woman had had an exemplary record while working for the Blairs, was loved by the children and had kept in regular touch with the family since leaving her job in August 1998. According to people close to the Blairs, she was capable, conscientious and clever. Whatever the problems and strains, she was "a rock", coping calmly whatever the crisis. Soon after Mark joined the household in January 1994, Cherie Blair realised her good fortune in having found her. Though sad when the nanny left, she understood: Mark wanted to put her intelligence and skills to better use by becoming a teacher. Aware of all this, Campbell's antennae were not tuned in. In an unusual example of naivety, he accepted that there was not a completed book. According to Mark, the MoS had virtually tricked their way into her house and she appears not to have informed Campbell of the extent of the "manuscript". He was left feeling it was an "outline" for a book and not the 451-page, 180,000-word document she had typed over the previous year. Mark had first been visited at her home in Galgate, near Lancaster, by the MoS's writer, Fiona Barton, on Friday afternoon. Barton wasn't invited in but Mark did confirm during a doorstep conversation that she had written a book. They parted - on friendly terms, according to the MoS, though not according to Mark - and Barton returned, with a photographer, the next day. Barton made two more visits on Saturday morning and this time she was allowed into the house, also meeting Mark's mother, Margaret, known as Mig. During the course of these visits, Mark talked much more fully about the book's content. She also posed happily for pictures and even handed over pictures of herself with the Blair family. Mark was later to claim that she posed reluctantly when told that pictures of her taken at a distance made her look "tired". Wouldn't she prefer to see herself looking groomed? Whether true or not, most journalists know of this ruse. During those talks, Barton came to believe that Mark did want the book published and was also hoping for a newspaper serialisation. Surely though, asked Barton, there was some kind of confidentiality agreement between her and the Blairs? Yes, replied Mark, there was. In fact, she had raised it with Cherie a couple of years into her tenure, but a friend had convinced her that it wasn't binding. At this point, the MoS's editor and lawyers knew they had to be careful. No paper has a better first-hand knowledge of the Blairs' desire to protect their children. The MoS was censured by the Press Complaints Commission last year for running a story about the schooling of Kathryn Blair, and no matter how much the adjudication rankled with Wright, he was unlikely to stray into a legal confrontation with the Blairs without taking great care. What tipped the balance was their interpretation of the Walters-Campbell call. Since Campbell knew they had been talking to the nanny and offered them a quote, it must be OK to go ahead. A splash was written with a prediction which soon turned out to be spot on: a "sensational" account by their nanny "would spark a major controversy with the Blairs". She had written it, she explained to the paper, because "I had been part of a moment in history and I wanted to write about it for historical reasons". The next mystery is how the paper came by Mark's manuscript in the first place. By her account, she handed a disk of her would-be book to an agent selected at random, Jonathan Harris, asking him to find a publisher. The MoS is coy about how it came to know of the book, claiming it came from "sources in the publishing industry". Harris has stated unequivocally that he "played absolutely no part whatsoever" in the MoS story, which he told me yesterday remains the case. If he did approach publishers with the manuscript, a lot of people could have tipped off the paper. What we do know is that no publisher made an offer and Mark, frustrated with Harris's failure, dispensed with his services. It wasn't until 9.40pm last Saturday that Campbell realised the full import of the MoS story. It wasn't just a case of reporting the fact of the book's existence after all. It also included anecdotes and incidents from the manuscript. In a hastily convened conference call with Cherie, in London, Tony Blair in Durham and Lord Falconer, it was decided that, if those details were not to gain further currency once in the public domain, they must go for an injunction. The key was the confidentiality agreement signed by Mark. She had, in Cherie's view, broken both the spirit and the letter of it. The injunction was granted, leading to the paper recalling copies and publishing a new front page. Though the Blairs were to issue supportive statements about Mark, stressing how much they liked her, some aides have since pointed out that she is entirely to blame for all that has happened. "They've been over-generous really, which does them credit,"said one. "But you can't help feeling that Ros, or perhaps her mother, saw a chance to make a lot from their 15 minutes of fame." Mark is certainly guilty, at the very least, of naivety in thinking that - to use her own phrase - she could "get round" her agreement with Cherie. Having worked so closely with the Blairs, it seems remarkable, given her undoubted intelligence, that she thought publishing even an affectionate book would be possible, especially while Blair is in office. The Blairs have a right to feel let down. They offered the hand of friendship to Mark's family. At one time, her mother acted as a home help while her brother, Tom, also helped out. There is some incredulity at Number 10 at suggestions in the press that Tom was Blair's "butler-cum-valet" or even his "personal dresser". The arrangement appears to have been less a case of hired domestic service than a job creation scheme by the Blairs, an act of kindness to people who were, at the time, virtually homeless. The sense of personal betrayal was heightened by the fact that although Mark kept in touch regularly after leaving she never mentioned writing about the family. She even called Blair on his daughter's birthday, just three days before the MoS publication, telling the paper: "I didn't tell him about the book." With the legal clamp still in place, the contents of the MoS story cannot be repeated or even touched upon. But it is fair to say that it contained material which was intrusive and could have been used to satirise and undermine the Blairs. Far from being an anodyne story, it was potentially harmful. It can also be seen as the thin end of the wedge. If this was allowed to pass then other revelations were bound to surface. That was certainly the view adopted by the judge last Friday who upheld the injunction, ruling against the MoS, a fact the MoS failed to report in its lengthy justification of its actions yesterday. This episode does reveal a great deal about the nature of our present society, where privacy is at a premium, human relationships have become a commodity and the prime minister is beginning to attract the kind of press hostility that is clouding editorial judgment. But my canvass of other editors suggests that they don't agree with the MoS, in spite of odd columnists claiming the injunction threatens press freedom. Most journalists agree, for once, with the Sun, which last week stated: "Nobody should have the spotlight shone on everything they do in their own home. This kitchen table tittle-tattle had no public interest justification." Quite so.

webTitle: The best behind the scenes scene: Three kings

fields.headline: The best behind the scenes scene: Three kings
fields.trailText: Kuwait. In a US Army Media Relations trailer, TV reporter Cathy Daitch (Judy Greer) and Major Archie Gates (George Clooney) pull on their clothes.
fields.body:
Kuwait. In a US Army Media Relations trailer, TV reporter Cathy Daitch (Judy Greer) and Major Archie Gates (George Clooney) pull on their clothes.

"I still have my gold story, right?" enquires Daitch. "Returning the gold to Kuwait?"

"What do you know about that?"

"You know. They think it's in some bunker somewhere."

The door of the trailer swings open. Outside are Colonel Horn (Mykelti Williamson) and Daitch's arch-rival, Adriana Cruz (Nora Dunn). Struggling to his feet, trousers still around his knees, Gates attempts to maintain his composure.

"What's going on, Colonel?"

"I was just about to ask you the same thing, Major."

Cruz turns to Horn, her eyes ablaze.

"You said he would take great care of me! What a bunch of bullshit!"

"Would you please_"

"Doesn't she have her own escort?"

"Of course she does. She's right here."

Horn gestures toward a glum woman beside the trailer.

Cruz glares at Horn.

"Well, why don't you find her some stud so she'll leave my escort alone?"

Daitch, still half-dressed, has had enough.

"That is really unnecessary."

"I don't want him going to other reporters and giving away my stories."

"Look at you, Adriana," Daitch sneers. "Look at what's become of you."

"Yes, look at me," Cruz spits back. "I've got my clothes on. I'm dressed ."

See also: Network, Living In Oblivion, This Is Spinal Tap

Don't see also: Pret à Porter

Pointless trivia: On 4 September 1998, Mykelti Williamson was acquitted of manslaughter, having been accused of stabbing his ex-wife's lover.

fields.headline: Lion heart
fields.standfirst:
Thomas Mapfumo, the 'Lion of Zimbabwe', has been imprisoned, used as a propaganda tool and transformed into a national hero - all because of his music. And now, finds Jane Cornwell, he is speaking out against the Mugabe regime
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Thomas Mapfumo, the 'Lion of Zimbabwe', has been imprisoned, used as a propaganda tool and transformed into a national hero - all because of his music. And now, finds Jane Cornwell, he is speaking out against the Mugabe regime
fields.body:
The 'Lion of Zimbabwe' isn't exactly roaring, but he's pretty furious. Twenty years of misrule by Robert Mugabe's government has seen his country's economy collapse. Crime, unemployment and food prices are soaring. Corruption is rife; human rights abuses abound. The Zimbabwean dollar is virtually worthless; foreign exchange reserves are at an all-time low.

"So there is no diesel or petrol," growls Thomas Mapfumo, down a crackling phone line from his home in Harare. "I have cars parked in my yard, but I can't drive any of them. When I play with my band we have to take the bus. These are not good circumstances Zimbabweans are experiencing." What makes things worse is that this is a government 55-year-old Mapfumo helped to bring about.

The politicisation of TM, as he is known, began in the mid-70s, in what was then Rhodesia. With the traditions and customs of his culture subjugated by the ruling white minority, he had begun his career playing covers of American hits (Elvis's A Mess of Blues was a favourite). But as the country struggled to throw off colonial rule and lurched toward civil war, Mapfumo began to adopt a more revolutionary stance.

As a boy growing up in the countryside he had learned Shona music from his grandparents, members - like 70% of the population - of an old culture with its own language and traditions. The Shona's signature instrument was the mbira, or thumb piano. Mapfumo began to arrange the splattering rhythms of mbira songs for the guitars in his group the Acid Band, who became the renowned Blacks Unlimited. "As a young man I was aware that we were oppressed people in our own land," he says. "When civil war came I found a focus for who I was and what I should be doing. I composed a lot of militant songs." He called the music chimurenga, which is Shona for struggle.

While often overtly political, the songs' traditional subject matter - unjust chiefs, or snakes in the forest - assumed new connotations. The irresistible beats and revolutionary messages of chimurenga soon blared from cassettes and radios up and down the country; Mapfumo and co played from township to township, often lining up in the convoys of the guerrilla fighters they were singing for. The white population were unable to understand the Shona language, but there could be no ignoring Mapfumo's popularity in the wake of his hit album, Hokoyo (Watch Out). The Ian Smith regime banned his music from the airwaves; Mapfumo was arrested and detained without trial for 90 days.

"They thought my music was encouraging youngsters to leave the country to train and come back fighting the government," he says proudly. "These policemen brought in a whole lot of singles they said were mine, but they actually belonged to other kids who were trying to follow in my footsteps. I kept telling them it was the traditional music of the people of Zimbabwe. There was no way I wasn't going to sing it."

He was released under armed guard, on the condition that he and Blacks Unlimited play at a rally for the supporters of a government puppet, Bishop Abel Muzorewa. They did, but they played their revolutionary songs about freedom, justice, peace and unity. "I told them afterwards that I'd been in detention and didn't have time to compose any for the occasion."

The Smith regime peddled photographs of Mapfumo with Muzorewa as proof TM had crossed over; it even broadcast his songs from army helicopters hovering above war zones. It took him years to recover his reputation. "Some people thought we had sold out," says Mapfumo, who cites Malcolm X and Martin Luther King as inspirations. "They didn't realise the music had never changed."

He remained prolific after Zimbabwean independence in 1980, introducing the mbira to the Blacks Unlimited line-up, releasing album after socially aware album and influencing other home-grown stars such as Oliver "Tuku" Mtukudzi. After 30 years of touring, his Blacks Unlimited pungwes - dance marathons featuring songs decrying Aids, alcoholism and domestic violence - are the stuff of legend. Such is his popularity that he has been unofficially been bestowed with Zimbabwe's national symbol, the lion, as an alias.

For a long time, he says, he didn't want to admit that Mugabe and his cronies were failing to deliver. "We supported them when they were fighting in the bush. When they came into power they promised us many things, but the people are still suffering and the country is a mess. So what did we fight for?" Corruption is now so widespread that Mapfumo believes Zimbabwe would crumble without it. It's a subject he addressed in his 1990 album Chamunorwa (Corruption), which was duly banned from the state-owned media.

Though heartened by last month's No vote on a new constitution to enhance presidential powers and allow for the seizure of white-owned land without compensation (a vote Mugabe has chosen to ignore, triggering the invasion of white-owned farms by former guerrillas), Mapfumo expects the worst for the parliamentary elections in April. (Or at least, they are due in April; no date has yet been scheduled.) While he intends to vote for the opposing Movement for Democratic Change and their 47-year-old leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, he has refused the MDC permission to play his songs at rallies. "I don't belong to any political party. I am a messenger."

He won't be surprised if the Mugabe government rig the polls. If they do, he continues, the currently simmering violence is likely to erupt. If they don't, and victory goes to the MDC, 76-year-old Mugabe could instruct his army to take over anyway. "If Mugabe had his way he'd be in power for another 10 years," says Mapfumo. But he won't be, he adds ominously. "The people have had enough."

"The newspapers say bad things but they are afraid/Those who read about me know the damage I can do/You plan to kill me but I know you fear me," Mapfumo sings on Chamunorwa. He laughs wryly when asked if he has been personally threatened this time around. "I have no fear," he says. "I see myself as a freedom fighter. A representative. If anyone points a finger at me, then they're pointing it at the people."

Thomas Mapfumo and Blacks Unlimited play the Barbican, London EC2 (0171-638 8891), on Wednesday. For more about Mapfumo, go to www.anonymousweb.com

fields.headline: Tension in Berlin
fields.standfirst:
Anti-Nazi protest counters pro-Haider march

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Riot police yesterday clashed with demonstrators protesting against a march through central Berlin by German neo-Nazis to show solidarity with the Austrian far-right leader Jörg Haider.
fields.body:
Riot police yesterday clashed with demonstrators protesting against a march through central Berlin by German neo-Nazis to show solidarity with the Austrian far-right leader Jörg Haider.

Police said they arrested more than 18 anti-Nazi protesters throwing stones and bottles at some 500 members of the National Democratic party (NPD) as they marched towards the Brandenburg Gate.

Attempts by the city government to ban the NPD march were rejected by the courts on Saturday. Judges ruled that the rally, held to mark the anniversary of Nazi Germany's 1938 annexation of Austria, did not pose a significant threat to public order.

More than 1,500 riot police with water cannons and tear gas were on hand to stop serious clashes.

The anti-Nazi demonstration was attended by the parliamentary president, Wolfgang Thierse. "It is encouraging that so many people have turned out to demonstrate," he said. "Right-wing extremism must not be given any chances in Europe."

fields.headline: Past . . . present . . . future . . .
fields.standfirst: Welcome to personal television and smart programme guides. But is it the end for the Radio Times?  Patrick Barkham  reports on an armchair revolution
fields.trailText: Ten years ago it was easy. You got home after work, thought about the evening ahead and flicked through a relatively slim magazine which told you, in detail, what was on television that night. How about now? With more than 100 digital channels already cabled in or beamed down to British homes, there is enough listings information out there to transform your weekly copy of TV Quick into the Encyclopaedia Britannica.
fields.body:
Ten years ago it was easy. You got home after work, thought about the evening ahead and flicked through a relatively slim magazine which told you, in detail, what was on television that night. How about now? With more than 100 digital channels already cabled in or beamed down to British homes, there is enough listings information out there to transform your weekly copy of TV Quick into the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

So what do we do to stop having to leaf through 1,000 tightly-typed pages just to find out what time Friends is on? The answer could come from the latest television technology. Onscreen electronic programme guides (EPGs) are already here. Other smart machines, able to tell you what you want to watch and when you want to watch it, are not far behind. Do they herald the end of the dear old weekly TV listings magazine lying on top of your set?

EPGs are the beginning of what OnDigital's Andrew Marre calls "personal television". Digital TV providers, such as Sky and Cable & Wireless, all currently offer broadly similar EPG services, where part of the TV screen shows viewers what they are watching now, what they might watch on other channels and what they could be watching tomorrow. But what sounds like a souped-up Teletext is actually far more sophisticated.

At the flick of a button on the remote, viewers can arrange channels so their favourites are first on the channel list. EPGs can also be used to order films on demand through Sky and C&W, while the latter provide a search facility by programme title or genre and onscreen reminders shortly before a searched-for programme starts.

Like forgetting your favourite programme, the days of wrestling with the video will also fade from view. US company Replay Networks have developed hardware to enable viewers to pause a "live" broadcast, make a cup of tea and then carry on watching. Sky have just signed a deal with Replay Networks' Silicon Valley neighbour, TiVo, to sell their personal video recorders in the UK, which will provide a beefed-up EPG of 14-days' listings plus programme recording at the touch of a "thumbs up" button.

"The next major step of our EPG is when it becomes web-based," says Bill Goodland, head of content production at Cable & Wireless. Making EPGs part of the fast-developing TV internet firmament, Goodland argues, will provide enormous potential to link from programme descriptions to reviews. It will also provide opportunities for live chat, debate and email.

Web-based EPGs coming through your interactive TV are mere months away and digital companies are already counting the cash flows these lucrative TV portals will bring in. Forrester Research calculate that EPGs will generate $3.2bn of advertising in the US within five years.

"The power of TV brands is absolutely enormous. EastEnders engages the loyalty of millions, but is almost unexploited outside the broadcast arena," says Goodland.

The mobile phone will also have a crucial say in how we get our TV information. Despite signing deals with BT Cellnet and Vodaphone, Sky, like C&W, remain undecided about whether to use Wap (wireless application protocol) phones for TV listings.

Whatever they decide, a six-strong internet start-up team operating from a shed in Devon has already beaten them to it. Russ Freeman calls his DigiGuide a "proactive agent to look out for good stuff on TV". 75,000 users have already downloaded DigiGuide's free software, which seeks out TV choices, stores favourites, and alerts you to all programmes featuring John Wayne if you have registered such an interest.

In a couple of weeks their new web service will be transferable on to palm pilots and Wap phones. When your Wap phone rings on the train it could be to remind you not to miss Tomorrow's World on the TV that night.

But for the bewildered viewer who does not like the sound of the future TV world, will there still be a battered copy of a weekly listings magazine near the TV to guide them through the jungle of channels?

The resounding verdict of almost all in digital and dog-eared media is yes. "People are still going to flick through magazines and read columns by Alan Titchmarsh and Polly Toynbee," says Sky spokesman Andrew Sholl.

"Our customers do not just want an EPG which is like a railway timetable. They want gossip and background," adds Goodland. C&W are currently in discussions with several potential content partners and Goodland sees the arrival of EPGs as "a great opportunity for some of those well-known brands in the TV magazine space, like the Radio Times, to extend their presence into online and e-commerce territory".

Ashley Munday, the Radio Times's publisher, agrees. "It's the first time since the deregulation of TV listings in 1990 that we are able to go on the offensive. Rather than threatening our position, the new technology is allowing us to develop."

Munday wants the Radio Times to "become the dominant broadcast publishing brand". His strategy is to get the venerable 76-year-old TV listings magazine on to as many platforms as possible. Its 70-strong editorial team has been augmented by a digital publishing division to repackage its content for the new interactive technology, for which partners are now being courted.

"You can split listings into two major functions: navigation and guidance," says Munday. "Navigation is what's on. Guidance is what to watch." He believes EPGs will do the basic "what's on now what's on next" in the future, while TV listings magazines will guide, although he denies "you'll ever take listings out of the Radio Times".

The Radio Times's website is the first prong of its digital assault. One of the most popular parts of Beeb.com, it attracts 1.5m hits a month with a mix of search facilities, chat and expanded features.

But it has its critics. "It's pitiful," says DigiGuide's Russ Freeman. "The site is so slow you sometimes think it is dead. Of course, if they came to us and said 'help us out guys' then they would have a top system."

"The mantra of the digital age is no longer the broadcaster telling you what you want to watch and when you want to watch it," says Sky's Andrew Sholl. webTitle: Don't burn the dead trees yet

fields.headline: Don't burn the dead trees yet
fields.trailText: Every new medium is predicted to kill whatever existed before. When Caxton first cranked his printing press, I expect people thought that folk songs were finished. Television was predicted to destroy radio; radio has never been more popular. Television was predicted to eliminate cinema; cinema has never had healthier attendances and advertising revenues.
fields.body:
Every new medium is predicted to kill whatever existed before. When Caxton first cranked his printing press, I expect people thought that folk songs were finished. Television was predicted to destroy radio; radio has never been more popular. Television was predicted to eliminate cinema; cinema has never had healthier attendances and advertising revenues.

Not long ago the experts were predicting that the internet would sound the death knell for conventional media. It would begin to exterminate the printed word, they said. Rubbish. Crystal-ball gazing is hazardous, but let me offer some predictions for media in the post-internet era.

I predict that TV channels will continue to proliferate. When Sky Digital launched, it said that it would offer 200 channels. "Who the hell wants 200 channels?" was the response. No, what people want is to be able to make up their viewing choice from a repertoire of 200 options, minute by minute, hour by hour, day by day, instead of being at the mercy of the scheduler.

In that world, it will be all too easy to avoid advertising. But because TV is such a powerful medium, we'll find ways to persuade people that it's worth watching the ads, even if we have to pay them to do so.

I predict that posters will enjoy continuing success as the last truly mass medium. As long as the environmentalists don't stop us putting them up.

I predict that cinema will thrive as the only real-time, collective-experience medium. People don't sit around watching TV together (unless it's the Manchester United game showing at the pub). But, in the cinema, advertisers know that they have a captive audience.

I predict that radio will continue to prosper. It's the only medium that you can consume while you're doing something else which, as we all get busier, is useful. And, despite the efforts of some politicians, we remain in love with our cars, which is where so many of us listen to the radio. Also radio is the preferred accompaniment of the net surfer.

This leaves the press. The medium the doom-merchants thought would be the first to be destroyed by the internet. On the contrary, there is no evidence that the internet is reducing the popularity of the printed word. I predict that magazines will continue to proliferate. While many of their information needs are serviced by the net, people love the tactile process of turning glossy pages, and appreciate the skills of the editor and art director. As long as there isn't political interference in the freedom of our national press, I'm sure it, too, will continue to prosper. Although there is an overall decline in newspaper reading, quality newspapers are doing fine - and by "quality" I don't just mean the broadsheets, but all newspapers which know their audiences and deliver what their readers want.

Finally, the regional press. The internet is thought to be especially threatening to local and regional media, particularly as they rely so heavily on classified advertising. I disagree. The regional press is a strong medium. It has powerful links with its local community, good geographical targeting capabilities, and is trustworthy. While there's scepticism about the contents of the nationals, people seem to believe what's in their local papers.

Advertisers have been reluctant to use the regional press as a national medium, partly because it can be expensive and partly because it's like embarking on an obstacle course to run a national campaign that way. But the regional press has launched a new initiative - Creating New Perspectives - to position themselves as a national media alternative. It will make it easier to buy regional press advertising on a national basis, to supply artwork, and to improve reproduction across the myriad of titles.

This reminds me of how radio got its act together and transformed itself into a coherent industry with a national offering. Most ad agencies used to see radio as a disparate collection of stations, dominated by the power house of Capital Radio, not worth taking seriously as part of any national advertising campaign.

But helped by new licences and new national stations such as Virgin and Classic, the radio industry started to act collectively. It listened to the advertising community, and worked out what we needed. Now the regional press is doing the same, which will help ad agencies to integrate the regional press into national campaigns.

The internet will unquestionably add to the robust media landscape in this country. The more choice we have, the more stimulating it is for advertisers and the more challenging for advertising agencies. But the greater that challenge, the cleverer the media strategy and planning people have to be with their creative messages, and the more important it will be to integrate as closely as possible with our clients.

So, another prediction: the separation of creative and media agencies will begin to reverse as we start working more closely together again.

Rupert Howell is president of the IPA and chairman of HHCL and Partners

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: * Katharine Mieszkowski www.salon.com
fields.body:
* Katharine Mieszkowski www.salon.com

The Social Life of Information dives into the muck of failed predictions to show why the future isn't likely to let go of the past. In a series of eight essays, authors John Seely Brown, Xerox's chief scientist, and Paul Duguid, a historian and social theorist at the University of California, gently deflate the more extreme claims of "the blinkered euphoria of the infoenthusiasts".

The authors make the case that reducing libraries to "information warehouses", universities to "information providers" and office work to "information handling" makes it easy to vastly overstate the impact that digital technology will have on society.

At the centre of their argument is the observation that popular thinking about technology today is ruled by a kind of relentless "endism" which forecasts the death of everything from mass media to the nation state, government to politics, universities to regions, even distance itself. It's the end of the world as we know it, and the technopundits feel fine.

The mistake that the seers at Business Week made while predicting the future was to consider paper as simply a medium for delivering information. Their excitement about technology replacing paper made them forget that people would still need paper - more readable printed pages, official documents bearing signatures, even sticky notes used to get a colleague's attention.

* Ben Hammer <A HREF="http://www.thestandard.com"

" TARGET="_NEW">www.thestandard.com

Drawing from the outside forces threatening its empire, internet advertising giant DoubleClick has hired a New York City government consumer advocate and a former New York state attorney general to fill two new privacy posts.

New York City consumer affairs commissioner Jules Polonetsky will begin as DoubleClick's chief privacy officer in two weeks. He will work with the company's clients to monitor their privacy policies and will act as the firm's spokesman on privacy.

DoubleClick also said it has retained lawyer Bob Abrams, a former New York attorney general, to chair its new privacy advisory board. Abrams will help select the committee's members and direct its presentation of online privacy issues to DoubleClick executives.

DoubleClick announced the new positions in mid-February as part of an effort to deal with a rush of law suits over its plans to merge information about internet users' online activities with their offline buying habits. Chief executive Kevin O'Connor said his company will not move forward with those plans until government and industry have agreed common privacy standards.

webTitle: Bulger killers may be free by 2003

fields.headline: Bulger killers may be free by 2003
fields.standfirst:
Victim's family appalled as Straw expected to announce earliest release date for boy murderers

Bulger case: special report
fields.trailText: Victim's family appalled as Straw expected to announce earliest release date for boy murderers
fields.body:
The two boys who murdered James Bulger could be released in three years after serving the minimum sentence set by a former lord chief justice, it emerged yesterday.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, is expected to announce in the Commons this week the earliest release date for Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, who were aged 10 at the time of the killings and are now 17.

The pair were convicted in 1993 for the brutal torture and murder of the two-year-old Liverpool boy they abducted while he was with his mother at the city's Strand shopping centre. They took James - who would have been 10 this week - to a railway line where they poured paint over him, abused and battered him and left him for dead. His body was run over by a goods train.

The murder, and the fact that the brutality was inflicted by young children, shocked the world. When the boys were tried at Preston crown court they ran a daily gauntlet of crowds shouting abuse and hurling stones at the prison vans.

At the end of the trial in Preston crown court, Mr Justice Morland ordered that the two be detained at Her Majesty's pleasure but recommended that they serve eight years. The then lord chief justice suggested they serve 10 years but this was overruled by the then home secretary, Michael Howard, who set the boys' tariff - the minimum time that they must serve behind bars - at 15 years.

Later this week Mr Straw is expected to tell the Commons that he has fixed the tariff at 10 years, which means the pair could both be released in 2003 when they are 20. The statement will follow a European court of human rights ruling in December that Mr Howard acted illegally when he fixed the 15-year term.

The European court ruled that Mr Howard had been wrong to take into consideration coupons clipped from the Sun to petition him when he was acting in a quasi-judicial capacity. The court also ruled that the two boys should not have been tried in an adult court.

Mr Straw, who faces a passionate campaign to reinstate the 15-year tariff by the parents of James Bulger, which is backed by the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, is expected to announce that he will follow the recommendation of the lord chief justice and impose a minimum 10- year sentence. This would not necessarily mean that Venables and Thompson would be released in 2003. The parole board would review their cases and only set a final release date if it were convinced there remained no risk to the public.

James Bulger's mother Denise Fergus, 32, said she was appalled at the timing of the announcement. "I am disgusted with Jack Straw. I had relied on him. I put my faith in him and he has let me down," she said.

"What makes it worse is that they always manage to pick a date for these announcements that causes more upset. Last time it was the European court ruling which came just before Christmas. It would have been James's 10th birthday on Thursday and that is all I am thinking about now.

"I am sick of all this attention being devoted to James's killers. A 10-year minimum means they are getting something like six months in jail for murder. The rest of the time they have only been in children's homes."

Miss Widdecombe said: "I believe that the 15-year tariff was actually appropriate given the severity of the crime. An adult who had done something similar would have got about 25 years, so there was a very substantial reduction to take into account, quite properly, the youth of the perpetrators. It's very much of a letdown for the Bulgers."

The home secretary is also expected to announce changes to the way children facing serious charges are tried in English courts. The lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, has already abolished the wearing of wigs and gowns in such cases. Accused children no longer have to sit in the dock but can stay near their families during their trials.

fields.bylineHtml: Alan Travis and Audrey Gillan

fields.headline: The secret socialist at Number 11
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor has been doing good by stealth, or so I'm told

Chancellor's pre-budget speech: special report
fields.trailText: The chancellor has been doing good by stealth, or so I'm told
fields.body:
A couple of weeks ago I was accosted by one of Gordon Brown's most influential friends who told me - more in anger than in sorrow - that he deeply resented my "incredibly harsh" criticisms of government social policy.

Before I had time to thank him for what I regarded as a compliment, he refined his complaint to a point where it barely existed - or at least applied only to what he regarded as my less than generous attitude towards the chancellor of the exchequer. Indeed he seemed to share my reservations about the rest of the New Labour leadership.

Gordon Brown, he said, was prevented from taking all sorts of progressive initiatives by "the man next door" whose naturally conservative inclinations were always supported by the "second-rate sycophants" who compose his cabinet. What the chancellor's confidant resented was not my occasional expression of dissent but my failure to explain that, bad as some of the government policies are, the chancellor had done his best to improve them.

My suggestion that the Downing Street neighbours were mutually dependent upon each other was greeted with the bitter qualification that "Number 10 controls the publicity machine". And my conclusion that (since they sink or swim together) Gordon Brown must be able to insist that the prime minister keeps his chosen economic policies afloat, was dismissed with the resentful assertion "the boss is always the boss".

I was just beginning to worry about the tone of the conversations which are held across the Whitehall garden wall when my assailant opened up a second front. Did I not realise how much good Gordon Brown is doing by stealth? Billions of pounds - the actual number increased as the conversation grew more heated - had been redistributed from rich to poor. It was a disgrace that Labour activists did not recognise Gordon Brown as a secret socialist.

The chancellor's champion was an economist. So there was no point in starting a discussion on the joys of paradox. Instead, I simply pointed out that Gordon Brown spends so much time and effort pretending to be the Right Honourable Thomas Gradgrind, that he can hardly complain when people believe him.

The intention to deceive is carefully targeted. But I had doubts about the identity of the people who are expected to be less perceptive than the party rank and file. Clearly "the man next door" is not one of them. When Margaret Thatcher claimed that Nigel Lawson's policy of "shadowing the Deutschmark" was put in place behind her back, nobody believed her. Prime ministers know, or at least are told, what is going on. Surely, I suggested, "international confidence" - that ethereal advantage in whose name so many crimes are committed - is equally well informed.

My inquiry was answered in a tone of undisguised contempt. The impression of parsimony - prudence, like Nurse Cavell's patriotism, not being enough - had to be created in order to retain the support of the still volatile, but apparently unperceptive, suburbs. The implication was clear. If ever it became public knowledge that Labour still felt sympathy for the poor, the government would be doomed. The panic provoked by the prospect of admitting an inclination to help those who need help most was, in one sense, reassuring. Despite New Labour's infatuation with the middle classes, its opinion of their moral character is far lower than mine. I do not assume that their pursuit of self interest has destroyed every generous impulse.

We argued for half an hour. I gladly conceded that the government has been more egalitarian than it is prepared to admit. And I expressed my pleasure that some of the poor had received surreptitious help. But - for reasons which have nothing to do with honesty or open government - I do not believe the double talk to be sustainable. Good intentions will be eaten away, step by step. Fear of the language will evolve into terror of the idea that the words convey. Then it will seem too dangerous to turn principle into practice.

If you doubt the inevitability of that gloomy process, consider both the prospect of Britain joining the single European currency and the hope of Labour raising sufficient revenue to provide the health service with the investment that it so desperately needs. By fearing to advocate either policy, the government actually makes each idea more unpopular. Silence converts nobody. Unless politicians are brave enough to say what they believe, they stop believing in the things they dare not say.

webTitle: Brown's chance to take credit for reviving family life

fields.headline: Brown's chance to take credit for reviving family life
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has an unprecedented opportunity to show that Labour is the party of the family in the budget next week.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has an unprecedented opportunity to show that Labour is the party of the family in the budget next week.

He has already committed himself to a shake-up of the tax credit system, with a fundamental shift of resources from wallet to purse, when he was setting out ideas last autumn for an integrated child credit to be paid directly to the main carer in the family.

He could go much further. Tax credits, the most radical anti-poverty initiative introduced by this government, boost the incomes of poor working families by, on average, £24 a week.

They can also, however, as experience in the United States has shown - have perverse and unintended effects on families, removing fathers from mainstream family life.

Let us take a look at how the tax credit system works and the proposed reforms.

The working families tax credit is a major weapon in the government's armoury, making work pay and tackling child poverty. The government has committed itself to halving child poverty by 2010 and abolishing it by 2020.

The figures are startling. The number of children living in poverty has soared over the past 30 years and today over 4m live below the poverty line.

The rise has been closely linked to two factors: the growth in the number of children with no working parent; and the rise in the number of lone parent households.

But the WFTC only helps tackle child poverty in those families with someone in work, restricting its impact to a fraction of those who really need financial support.

According to the treasury the new child credit would be complemented by an employment tax credit paid through the wage packet to working households - be they with or without children.

That will allow the chancellor to extend the ambition of his anti-poverty measures, using the integrated child credit to reach every household, in or out of work.

The new child credit should also please critics of the WFTC, such as the women's budget group, who say that the replacement of family credit by a tax credit paid to the main earner tends to take money out of the purse and put it into the wallet

They argue that women are more likely than men are to spend the income they receive directly on the family, while men use theirs as personal spending money.

The new child credit is likely to be paid to the main carer, alongside child benefit, overcoming this problem.

However, there is another, less discussed, effect of the tax credit system - that is the effect on family life and particularly on fathers.

Almost half of tax credit recipients at the moment are lone parents in low-paid jobs. But the design of the WFTC penalises single parents who wish to take a long-term partner or declare if they are living with the father of their child.

Take, for instance, a mother with two children working full time and earning the minimum wage. After the WFTC is calculated she receives £199.53 a week.

If she marries another minimum wage worker their income would be £256.80 with the tax credit. But if she does not declare that she has a partner their joint income would be much higher - £317.26. In other words, she is penalised by more than £60 a week for declaring her partner.

One solution is to move towards what has been called "income splitting" - that is, adding both partners' incomes together, splitting the total in half, and calculating the credit on each half. With no change in behaviour, the treasury has estimated that the cost of such a policy, combined with a reduction in the income at which credits start to be withdrawn, from £90 to £45 a week, could be up to £5bn.

But that could be lowered by phasing in the reforms, or lowering the level at which the taper cuts in. It is also likely that behaviour would change if the system were reformed, reducing the number of claims.

Reforming the system may be expensive. But it is a small price to pay if the result is that fathers resurface in low-income communities, reinvigorating family life.

 Reforming the Working Families Tax Credit - How an Integrated Child Credit Could Work for Families and Children, by Ruth Kelly, MP for Bolton West, is published this week by the Fawcett Society

fields.headline: Cigarette smugglers to lose assets
fields.standfirst:
Smoking: special report
Chancellor's pre-budget speech: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will announce a huge clampdown on cigarette and tobacco smuggling in his budget next week, including the use of the same penalties to seize the assets of the criminal gangs behind the trade as of those handling heroin.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will announce a huge clampdown on cigarette and tobacco smuggling in his budget next week, including the use of the same penalties to seize the assets of the criminal gangs behind the trade as of those handling heroin.

The tough new stance follows growing panic in the treasury that it is losing large amounts of revenue from tobacco smuggling as people turn to illegal suppliers for cigarettes and hand-rolled tobacco.

Last month the Guardian revealed how the UK-based British American Tobacco is implicated in the smuggling of billions of cigarettes world-wide. Latest figures show that £2.4bn a year is lost to the exchequer from tobacco smuggling - enough cash to fund entire government departments or pay for almost a fifth of the NHS hospital budget.

The sale of hand-rolled tobacco is almost entirely transacted on the black market, costing the treasury £800m a year. This is up by 30% since the 1997 election.

Some 80% of all sales take place illegally in pubs, clubs, hotdog stalls and through illegally supplied tobacconists. Punters are saving £4 a time on supermarket prices for a standard pouch and regular "trade routes" have been set up between Belgium and Britain. In Belgium the tax on hand-rolled tobacco is a quarter of the level in the UK.

Whitehall is alarmed that the trade in smuggled cigarettes has more than doubled since 1997, from 10% to nearly 25% this year. This means that one in four packets of cigarettes are now bought illegally. If this trade reached the levels of that in hand-rolled tobacco the treasury stands to lose £8bn a year.

Customs intelligence operations have revealed that crim inal gangs used to dealing in heroin and cocaine are switching to tobacco because they can expect lighter jail terms and do not suffer the same penalties, such as the seizure of all assets.

The result is that ministers have been steadily ratcheting up the penalties over the past year - including taking away lottery licences from tobacconists caught receiving smuggled cigarettes and destroying vehicles caught with smuggled goods. This is because gangs were found to be attending customs auctions of seized goods and buying back their vehicles at knockdown prices.

The latest pre-budget move will be announced tomorrow when Dawn Primarolo, the paymaster general, visits Dover to announce high-profile measures to deter tobacco smugglers, including new warning signs at ports of entry. Seized vehicles will be put on view.

Mr Brown wants to go further and is said to be determined not to give in to criminals by lowering taxes - even though a report commissioned by the treasury has recommended that this should be done. He also has pledged that any increase in tobacco duties will go directly to the NHS. Customs regards revenue on hand-rolled tobacco as a lost cause unless the Belgians put up taxes, which they are not keen to do.

This leaves Mr Brown with no alternative but to get Jack Straw, the home secretary, to toughen penalties. Under misuse of drugs legislation, smugglers and dealers face life imprisonment and those smuggling cannabis face 14 years in prison. Smuggling tobacco carries seven years in jail.

The treasury wants to force convicted smugglers to prove that all their assets are not from smuggling or face confiscation of everything.
