fields.headline: 'Labour cronies' in NHS jobs row
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The government will face fresh charges of political cronyism this week over the way it appointed Labour councillors and activists to senior posts on NHS trusts and health authorities without proper vetting after its 1997 election landslide.
fields.body:
The government will face fresh charges of political cronyism this week over the way it appointed Labour councillors and activists to senior posts on NHS trusts and health authorities without proper vetting after its 1997 election landslide.

An investigation by the public appointments commission will spell fresh embarrassment for Labour's candidate for mayor of London, Frank Dobson, and his successor as health secretary, Alan Milburn, over the way sitting members of health boards were replaced.

Tory MPs, have been complaining about the replacement of some highly-experienced chairs of hospital trusts and health authorities with Labour councillors.

"In some areas it has been described as a Stalinist purge," said one Conservative MP. "Labour have been behaving unspeakably badly for the past two years," said one ex-minister.

This week's report produced by Dame Rennie Fitchie, the recently-appointed public appointments commissioner, will be far tougher than that issued last summer by her predecessor, Sir Len Peach. He warned that it was unacceptable for health ministers to be sent lists of names without independent vetting.

Sir Len's report revealed that 288 out of 374 councillors and local people appointed - including 37 chairs - to trusts and authorities were Labour supporters.

Only 49 Tories, two nationalists and 28 Lib Dems were appointed. Claims that Labour was simply "re-balancing" the committees are hotly contested.

Ministers stress that, since Lord Nolan's report on standards in public life, procedures have been tightened to ensure there is better independent vetting in the most sensitive of public services, the NHS. Trust members can be held legally liable. But stories of last-minute imposition of ministerial allies persisted and prompted Dame Rennie's renewed interest. Her report was intitially expected before Christmas, but was delayed so that all the evidence could be published.

"I understand It is a pretty thorough job," said Graham Brady, Conservative MP for Altrincham and Sale, who complained about the speedy replacement of key members of both his local Trafford NHS trust and the Salford and Trafford authority which purchases NHS services.

The Fitchie investigation has focused on the north-west, the north and Yorkshire where most complaints were made. Dame Rennie, a 57-year-old veteran of public bodies, is a former health authority chair in Gloucester and chaired the south-west region of the NHS from 1992-94.

She knows the system better than Sir Len. "She's a very good woman, very straight and very wise, she's a heroine," said one senior Tory.

NHS boards have always been more politicised than most. Tory ministers were accused of purges, including putting backbenchers wives on trust boards, and they admit that boards must be broadly sysmpathetic to ministerial aims but say that Mr Dobson and Mr Milburn have gone too far.

In a separate attack tonight the Conservatives will claim that Labour has "cherry-picked" proposals to clean up party political funding - made by Lord Neill who succeeded Lord Nolan as chairman of the commission on standards in public life.

Tory spokesman, Sir George Young, complained last night that the anti-euro campaign in any future referendum would only be able to spend half what the pro-euro side would spend under Labour's bill, due to receive its third reading in the Commons tonight.

fields.headline: Justify night flights, court orders
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Night flights at Heathrow may infringe the right to a decent home life of families that live in the flight path, according to the court of human rights in Strasbourg.
fields.body:
Night flights at Heathrow may infringe the right to a decent home life of families that live in the flight path, according to the court of human rights in Strasbourg.

In a test case on aircraft noise the court has ordered the government to justify subjecting 1m people in London to unacceptable night time noise.

Eight residents near Heathrow have spent seven years fighting the decision of the government to allow 16 night flights between 4am and 6am and unrestricted flights between 6am and 7am.

Judges at Strasbourg have accepted the case and called on the government to account for itself. So far the government has failed to put up a defence - partly because the only one that appears to be open to it in law is that night flights are vital to the national economy.

Lawyer Susan Ring, who with her partner Richard Buxton, is representing the residents, said the human rights court had accepted that under article 8 of the European convention night flights might infringe the right to enjoyment of your home. The case had already gone through judicial reviews in England and to the House of Lords.

One high court judge has described the government's case as "devious and deeply unattractive".

Ms Ring added: "That was even before the government's conduct was shown by evidence to have been dishonest: saying one thing to residents and to the courts, and another thing to the terminal 5 public inquiry."

The government had introduced night flights in 1993 to further the commercial interests of the airlines having earlier claimed it was going to reduce noise.

Under English law "night" is from 11.30pm to 7am but the government lopped an hour off to allow unrestricted flights after 6am.

Philippa Edmunds lives less than a mile from the end of the runway and is one of eight people who have given statements to the Strasbourg judges. She has two children Lucy, eight and Eve, six, who are woken up by jets. "Sleep deprevation is used as a form of torture. That is what happens when these jumbo jets start arriving at 4am and keep on coming. It is a human rights issue, the right to a decent night's sleep. We have had the house double glazed, which helps but it is not enough. We wear earplugs, and cannot open the windows. It affects our moods and our productivity at work."

John Cavalla, a retired research scientist lived for 42 years close to Heathrow under the flightpath at Osterley, west London, but moved because he could no longer stand the night flights.

"To start with there were none, and then it just got worse and worse. They started about 4am and got more and more frequent. Between 6am and 7am they came every 90 seconds. In the end it just drives you crazy. We just had to get out."

Ms Ring said that because of the night flights the area close to Heathrow has become a ghetto of poor housing. "Anyone with enough money or a decent job moves out leaving those in low paid jobs behind. Only people who cannot afford to go anywhere else live under the night time flight path."

fields.headline: Taxpayers to meet tube sale shortfall
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A rescue package of £2.5bn will have to be thrown at the part-privatisation of the London Underground by the government to ensure that the project does not collapse before the possible election of Ken Livingstone as the capital's new mayor.
fields.body:
A rescue package of £2.5bn will have to be thrown at the part-privatisation of the London Underground by the government to ensure that the project does not collapse before the possible election of Ken Livingstone as the capital's new mayor.

The prime minister has been told by the treasury that a shortfall on the project will have to be met by the injection of taxpayers' money. The plan's initial investment costs of £7bn have now risen to around £12bn.

The project's architect, John Prescott, had hoped that sufficient funds would be found from the private sector over the 30-year period of the contract. But bidders for the contract, due to be finalised in April 2001, say that they are not prepared to bear the shortfall in the escalating costs.

The government also has to bear in mind that the fares on the underground will have to be kept to reasonable limits. Ministers are unlikely to accept independent forecasts that fares on the tube would have to rise by at least 30% to offset the cost of the huge project.

Fierce opposition to the public-private partnership (PPP) by Mr Livingstone in the mayoral election has raised fears among some bidders that the project to upgrade the tube could fold.

Peter Mason, chief executive of the construction group Amec, which is bidding for two of the three contracts, said: "We have long been concerned about the political impact of the PPP on the mayoral election."

Ministers are convinced that some bidders are using the threat of Mr Livingstone's election as a bargaining tool to cut the price. But treasury officials admit that the shortfall is real and that taxpayers will have to support the project.

Some bidders have offered to reduce their price by up to 33% if London Underground allows them to shut down large sections of the system for several months at a time to speed up building work, and to contain costs. But LU has rejected this plan as politically unacceptable.

Bidding for two of the tube contracts must be submitted to Mr Prescott by the end of the month. These are for the deep tube lines.

The remaining bid for the sub-surface lines, including the Metropolitan and Circle lines, has been delayed because Mr Prescott decided to withhold the contract from Railtrack after the Paddington train disaster last October. Contractors have until August to bid for this contract.

The PPP does not fall into the mayor's jurisdiction until the contract is signed, although the mayor will be responsible for transport in the capital, including the operation of services and the setting of fares.

But the mayor must be consulted over the forms of the contract and must enforce it once it is signed.

As a last resort, Mr Prescott can pull back from signing the PPP if he feels that the bids do not offer value for money. This would be regarded by Mr Livingstone as a vindication of his opposition to the PPP.

Treasury estimates put the shortfall on the project at £200m a year for the duration of the 30-year contract. The terms of the deal allow the private sector to invest and take the profits before handing the operation back to the government.

The government's subsidy of £600m for the running of the underground is due to expire next year.

But industry sources believe that the gap between the original £7bn cost of the project - the most expensive in Europe - could even double over the next few years.

webTitle: Good jokes and straight talk are what count in politics

fields.headline: Good jokes and straight talk are what count in politics
fields.standfirst:
There's a lot in common between John McCain and Ken Livingstone

The London mayor: special report
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: There's a lot in common between John McCain and Ken Livingstone
fields.body:
John McCain bowed out on the phoniest note possible. "I love my party," he said. "It is my home." Some home, some hearth! The Munsters in the parlour; Lizzie Borden chopping wood in the back garden; and Harold Shipman coming up the front path for his morning call. What on earth (as Ken Livingstone might add) is there to love about this malign monstrosity?

The chosen son of the grand old party spent $50m or so attacking a flaky, heartless, closet liberal son of a bitch called McCain: and it ground the senator down in the end. The chosen party of Citizen Ken throws in a double dose of its own acid adjectives just for luck. Where, pray, does "love" come into this?

And yet, when push comes to shove, the victims take their punishment hard. The senator from Arizona still professes a mystic attachment to the gang of street fighters who've cut him up. The MP from Brent East agonises for two long weeks before turning his back - "the hardest thing I've ever done" - on the Millbank mob. Both choke with curious emotion. The friends, the ties, the loyalties ... It's worse than Roy Hattersley deciding to support Sheffield United.

Those of us on the outside, however, the great non- joiners of politics, can afford to disregard all such sentiment - just as those on the inside forget it when the glycerine bottle is stowed away and the cameras switched off. A caring band of brothers and colleagues? See how they kicked away Harold Wilson like a useless old boot. See how John Major, in perceived failure, fades quietly now into unpersonhood. Who can bother to raise a cheer for Bob Dole or Mike Dukakis? Yesterday's men; yesterday's canned affection.

Thus, when we talk of the party machine, the word is exact. You can't get soppy about a machine. You buy it to do a mechanical job. And the fascination of what McCain almost achieved and what Ken Livingstone may yet achieve is watching that machine puff and clank under strain. A spectacle devoid of sentiment.

The first two insurgencies of 2000 have a lot in common. Both insurgents are loners with a vestigial track record for getting things done. But the senator wowed the press and, for a while, ran rings round a wooden Bush because he answered questions, admitted errors and cracked good jokes. Amazing post-Mandelson discovery: a politician who connects is politician who can seem like a human being. Which, of course, is also Livingstone's stock in trade; the soft smile and witty answer that turn away wrath.

Charm, from scions of a largely charmless profession, can work wonders. It didn't help McCain with the machine in closed primaries, but it rolled up votes and approval amongst the millions of floaters who will decide the presidency next November. The first polls for Indy Ken show him the overwhelming choice of voters from all parties who don't put party first.

The only essential difference between the pair is that the system managed, at the last, to fix McCain (just as it was designed to do) whilst the system that was supposed to fix Livingstone was such a hoot, such a lousy, obvious contrivance, that all it signalled to the voters was Millbank's contempt for them. Great going! The Republicans have shot their prospects in the foot. New Labour would appear to have shot itself in the head. Blah about loyalty and broken promises turns to ashes in the mouth.

And see how inevitably re-adjustment follows imbecility. McCain has gone, but he doesn't intend to be forgotten. He will have to be placated - and already the GOP's spin doctors peddle the thought that, after Bush's inevitable defeat, a chastened party might turn to a 67-year-old war hero in 2004. Hang in there boy; they're serving jam tomorrow.

Meanwhile Mr Livingstone is beginning to wallow in jam today. Will Labour party members who give him a hand be disciplined or expelled? Er, no: there are too many of them. Will Downing Street decline to work with a Livingstone London administration? Er, no: what government heading into a general election wants to penalise 5m voters for being wrong? Will Millbank, all adjectives blazing, go down with the Titanic called Dobbo? Apparently not: the bilges have dried up already and only bizarre leaks about Irish "distress" at his mayoralty swill below decks.

The machine's minders, in short, would appear to be edging towards a bizarre neutrality. They can't unleash a TV fortune's worth of negative advertising against Livingstone. (And, even if they could, the bullying would rebound). They can't shut him out of the publicity race, because most of his publicity comes free. They can't rely on the foot soldiers of doorstep canvassing, who mostly voted for Ken in the first place. They can't resuscitate Frank Dobson by feeding him Clint Eastwood's leftover lines. Nobody can remake his day.

W hy keep banging your head against a wall? The prudent recourse in adversity (an American way) would be to withdraw the "official" candidate, issue no further "advice" to Labour voters and sit the weeks till May 4 out. That way you don't have to keep eating humble pie round the clock. But party machines - like supertankers - have an interminable turning circle.

There are two schools of received wisdom about this fiasco. One is that, in a while, it won't matter because peo ple forget and winning general elections is a different game. The other is that the sheer incompetence of the past few months has wiped away the sheen of Blair hegemony for ever. Actually, both of those verdicts may be right. The polls of popularity set on Blair, but the Hague never rises.

There is, though, a deeper and more durable lesson. Simply: that in a largely non-ideological age, the voters have grown cynical, too. They think that machine fixes insult their intelligence. They can't relate to nouveau apparatchiks like Paul Boateng spouting pre-rehearsed texts like George W Bush on speed. Loyalty? Where is compassion as poor, loyal Dobbo is cut adrift? Moral disgust at Ken's "broken word"? It is a signal (and little-mentioned) fact that Bill Clinton's approval rating today - on the last Opinion Dynamics poll - stands at 66%: better than Reagan, better by far than the president's election- winning score in '96, the age before Monica.

What counts in this new age of politics is prosperity delivered, good jokes, straight talk and a semblance of humanity. The levers of schmaltz on the fabled machines are broken, hanging loose. And those of us who don't want to vote Livingstone will have to find a damned good reason not to. Ah! Simon Heffer in the Mail has just called Steve Norris an "absolute plonker", an "unprincipled, bloated libertine" and a "disgrace to the party in whose name he stands". Now we're talking.

fields.headline: Selective memory
fields.standfirst: Grammar schools are a side issue
fields.trailText: Grammar schools are a side issue
fields.body:
In the wake of the Ripon result, David Blunkett's cheeks were ablaze yesterday over what he did or did not say on the future of 11-plus selection at Labour's 1995 conference. The embarrassment will pass and may even do him some good; he tends to adopt a holier-than-thou style and a reminder that he is a fully paid up member of the Blairite concert party - no golden oldies, please - may be salutary. Besides, Mr Blunkett needs to remind his critics to the left that an assault on grammar schools would have been a gross distraction. Getting teachers and money into failing schools; raising attainment across the board - these have to be the government's objectives. The device of a parental ballot was a way of cooling out local agitation. The Venetian complexity of the rules on who can vote once a ballot has been triggered by parental petition will postpone action, even in Barnet and places where a contest seemed inevitable. But parents everywhere need to keep a vigilant eye on the government's bid to raise standards in all schools, so that no parent, however aspirational, need again fear sending their child to the local school.

Of course that is a cop out. The ecology of education affects the capacity of schools, however well resourced. If able children are segregated, either in grammar or private schools, comprehensives may lose much-needed leaven. Still, David Blunkett cannot waste precious time and energy in fighting unwinnable battles. He does need to be warned, however, that toying with vouchers - said to be an in idea among drafters of Labour's next manifesto - makes the inequities of 11-plus separation all too transparent.

Ripon, some will say, merely reflects the bias of the electoral scheme. It may also speak to the indifference of many parents whose children do not go to grammar schools to precise secondary arrangements - though they care deeply about resources and achievement in the system at large. The result reminds us, yet again, of the incoherence of government, parents and teachers about the "local" dimension in education. Had questions of school structure been left to elected local authorities, many more grammar schools would have been kept. Yet how much easier would it now be for Whitehall to leave vexing decisions to the one local body with its own legitimacy, its own blameworthiness and its own ballot box disciplines - the council?

webTitle: Ilisu is a dam too far

fields.headline: Ilisu is a dam too far
fields.standfirst: Environmental policy needs joining up
fields.trailText: Environmental policy needs joining up
fields.body:
The green lobby has had much to celebrate lately. First, the wildlife bill delivered almost everything the environmentalists had wanted on protecting wild animals as well as, after 65 years of campaigning, the right to roam.

Last week the government came up trumps on climate change; fears that New Labour would renege on its manifesto commitment to a 20% cut in carbon dioxide by 2010 proved groundless. The United Kingdom can now rightly claim to be a world leader in cutting carbon emissions, and John Prescott will play a key role in the Hague in November in developing the international architecture needed to implement the targets agreed at Kyoto. What is more, environment minister Michael Meacher made it clear that this is just an instalment towards the target of 60-70% cuts by 2050.

Of course, environmentalists still have gripes. They complain the government has failed to grasp the nettle on transport; traffic figures continue rising. They want changes in the planning system to match a Danish-style push for the adoption of wind power. But in the big picture, after a long wait, New Labour has finally begun to deliver on the environment. What lies behind this shift has been increasing awareness on the part of business of the environment's importance. Industry has begun to spot the silver lining to the clouds around Gordon Brown's climate change levy: the opportunity to save money on energy conservation and eventually even make money by trading carbon emissions quotas.

Set against these advances, the official position on the Ilisu dam project in southern Turkey looks even more indefensible - as the trade and industry select committee argued strongly last week. The government has double standards: a green agenda at home that seems irrelevant to British companies when they operate abroad. Preventing this kind of policy incoherence was the rationale behind the government's bid to "join up". Nowhere is consistency more needed now than in Stephen Byers' decision whether the export credit guarantee department (ECGD) should offer Balfour Beatty £200m to underwrite the massively controversial scheme; in December the trade secretary had said he was minded to back it. The select committee said that lack of consultation and displacement of thousands of Kurds were big concerns, but it was also alarmed at the lack of international consultation with Syria and Iraq, countries down river of Ilisu. What particularly irked the MPs was the "deplorable and counter-productive lack of transparency" around the project.

Their report is crucial evidence in the case against the ECGD. It portrays a department which operates on principles which bear no relation to the objectives of the rest of the government, whether on the environment or for the sake of an ethical foreign policy. The MPs warn the department of trade and industry to take seriously its responsibilities to promote human rights and sustainable development rather than leaving them to other departments. It must not always give priority to commercial considerations.

This would amount to a significant change in the culture of the two Whitehall departments which under the Tories became standard bearers for uncritically pro-business Thatcherism. Mr Byers has to make sure his civil servants get the message. The government's credibility on the environment does not rest on the department of that name alone. Ilisu is fast becoming the litmus test of New Labour's ability to put principles before its promotion of business interests.

fields.headline: Apologising for the past
fields.standfirst: Only survivors have a case to answer
fields.trailText: Only survivors have a case to answer
fields.body:
The Roman pontiff is to make apology for how, in the past, the standard bearers of the Catholic version of Christian witness massacred, slashed and burned in the name of the Lord - Muslims, heathens, Jews and a variety of other Christians included. Yet the church is, in a sense, the victim of its historical success. Few other institutions possess its memory, let alone its titular continuity. Islam is not without a few blots on its escutcheon yet there is no central repository of Muslim faith or government to take responsibility for the past. By contrast, the papal archives go back 1,500 years. Despite Avignon, there is no significant rupture in its history.

Pope succeeded pope in generally good order - and clerks kept the paperwork up to date. Had the Vatican been levelled, say by the Germans in 1944, things might look different. As it is, with its unbroken longevity grows potential culpability. The older the institution the more likely it has apologies to offer.

That is why the scope of John Paul's exculpation needs watching by other ancient institutions with a chequered past, monarchies for example. Jacques Chirac can safely say, of massacres of natives in 18th-century Canada or the murder of Huguenots: not me, squire, that is down to the Bourbons. Revolution washes the slate clean. And suicide. The Communist party of the Soviet Union imploded and with it the possibility of repentance. Ethiopians, so barbarously treated by Mussolini, cannot expect the modern Italian state to offer condolence. What about the UK? The list of claimants at royal palaces is likely to be long. Like the Vatican, the "Crown" rejoices in its long-term existence. Elizabeth Windsor is only there because she is the legitimate heir to Victoria of Saxe-Coburg and all her predecessors, right back to Guillaume le Btard - whose father, lest we forget, was a bloody crusader. The pope is not the only one with contemporary apologies to offer.

Pope succeeded pope in generally good order - and clerks kept the paperwork up to date. Had the Vatican been levelled, say by the Germans in 1944, things might look different. As it is, with its unbroken longevity grows potential culpability. The older the institution the more likely it has apologies to offer. That is why the scope of John Paul's exculpation needs watching by other ancient institutions with a chequered past, monarchies for example. Jacques Chirac can safely say, of massacres of natives in 18th-century Canada or the murder of Huguenots: not me, squire, that is down to the Bourbons. Revolution washes the slate clean. And suicide. The Communist party of the Soviet Union imploded and with it the possibility of repentance. Ethiopians, so barbarously treated by Mussolini, cannot expect the modern Italian state to offer condolence. What about the UK? The list of claimants at royal palaces is likely to be long. Like the Vatican, the "Crown" rejoices in its long-term existence. Elizabeth Windsor is only there because she is the legitimate heir to Victoria of Saxe-Coburg and all her predecessors, right back to Guillaume le Btard - whose father, lest we forget, was a bloody crusader. The pope is not the only one with contemporary apologies to offer.

fields.headline: Why Cherie Booth is right
fields.trailText: So many commentators have missed the point of the Blair nanny affair, or at least appear to have been taken in by one of Ros Mark's pained attempts at self-exculpation. She claims, and I don't dispute it, that she hasn't written anything nasty about any of the Blairs; she loves them all and would only say good things about them.
fields.body:
So many commentators have missed the point of the Blair nanny affair, or at least appear to have been taken in by one of Ros Mark's pained attempts at self-exculpation. She claims, and I don't dispute it, that she hasn't written anything nasty about any of the Blairs; she loves them all and would only say good things about them.

Certainly the extract that appeared briefly in the Mail on Sunday before being banned was bland, and had very little about the Blair children. But that's totally irrelevant. The whole point about breaching a confidential relationship is the act of betrayal. The result of that betrayal, the factual content of what is revealed, is immaterial. It is just as culpable to disclose something nice as something awful.

The Blairs have the right - moral as well as legal - to their nanny's silence. That she breaches that right by telling the world the banal trivialities of home life, rather than any tittle-tattle to their discredit, does not lessen the seriousness of the trust destroyed, let alone excuse the breach.

The court case against the nanny is based on her having broken a confidentiality agreement; but she would have been just as legally blameworthy without such an agreement. The law imputes a duty of confidentiality on certain relationships: between spouses, for instance; and where employees are in close personal contact with their employers, and can learn intimate facts about them. It is right that the law stops them from disclosing that information.

If it were not so, human intercourse over a range of relationships would become impossible. That is why Cherie Booth is not over-reacting and why the nanny has behaved wrongly.

Here's another puzzling thing. A couple of weeks ago I wrote a piece on lawyers having sex with their clients. To ban or not to ban? I ended it with a couple of jokes, one of them told to me by the well-known matrimonial solicitor Ray Tooth. According to his uncle, the difference between a doctor and a lawyer, as to allowable conduct, was that "a doctor can lay his hands on his patient's body but not her money; a lawyer can lay his hands on the client's money, but not her body." No great side-splitter, but mildly amusing in the context. Mr Tooth has now written to me, amiably pointing out that I'd got it the wrong way round. His uncle had in fact jested that "a doctor can touch the patient's money but not her body; a lawyer can touch the client's body but not her money." I'm now totally confused, and no longer know which of the versions is a) funnier b) closer to the professional reality. It's driving me mad.

This is the moment faithful readers await all year. It is the week of the Cheltenham Racing Festival; and therefore the occasion on which Writ Large recommends a horse with a legal name to support - in the sense of indulging in a substantial judicious investment. This is not, I emphasise, gambling, just as putting money on the sun rising in the east is not gambling. The horse this year is the French Hors la Loi III, (Outside the Law) running in the Champion Hurdle tomorrow. The odds will not be good, but remember my mother's wise words: "Better a 5-4 favourite that wins than a 33-1 outsider that comes nowhere."

fields.headline: Case of the week
fields.standfirst: Chocs away
fields.trailText: The people who make chocolate penises have a lot to answer for. There is mounting evidence to support a ban on these dangerous products for their tendency to spark off expensive and embarrassing litigation. Last week the Sun had to pay out substantial damages to a primary school head teacher, Joan Morris, over articles alleging she had bullied and humiliated her deputy into giving up teaching. One of the most damning allegations was that she had tricked the poor fellow into presenting the offending object to a retired lady colleague.
fields.body:
The people who make chocolate penises have a lot to answer for. There is mounting evidence to support a ban on these dangerous products for their tendency to spark off expensive and embarrassing litigation. Last week the Sun had to pay out substantial damages to a primary school head teacher, Joan Morris, over articles alleging she had bullied and humiliated her deputy into giving up teaching. One of the most damning allegations was that she had tricked the poor fellow into presenting the offending object to a retired lady colleague.

In 1996 two women working in computer sales accepted undisclosed damages in an out-of-court settlement after claiming "environmental sexual harassment" over dirty jokes and simulated sexual acts at a black-tie office dinner. One woman was presented with a chocolate penis and another was forced to sit next to a blow-up sex doll.

In another case the same year, a £60,000-a-year woman executive claimed she suffered post-traumatic stress disorder after a colleague wearing only an elephant trunk G-string handcuffed her in front of laughing workmates. A fellow director countered her claim by telling the tribunal she had once come back from a trip to New York and given him a chocolate penis and chocolate nipples.

Even law firms are not immune. In 1992 a legal secretary was awarded £4,700 in compensation and damages for injured feelings after bringing a sex discrimination case against a leading firm, Nabarro Nathanson, and her former boss, Anthony Hamnett, after she was sacked. She claimed a staff Christmas party had degenerated into a "bunfight" during which Mr Hamnett had eaten a seven-inch long chocolate penis covered with cream.

The dangerous delicacies can even lead to criminal charges, according to a story in a Beirut newspaper last year. The paper reported that a young Lebanese woman, her hen-party guests and a Beirut baker all faced possible jail sentences after magazine pictures appeared of her hen-night cake, topped with a chocolate penis. The police chief asked the investigating magistrate to start proceedings under Lebanon's morality laws after seeing the magazine.

The baker told the magistrate that the cake had been commissioned by the woman's guests as a hen night surprise.

webTitle: 'I have a duty to a client, just as a surgeon does to a patient'

fields.headline: 'I have a duty to a client, just as a surgeon does to a patient'
fields.standfirst:
Michael Caplan, the man who represented Pinochet, talks about the case for the first time to Clare Dyer

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Caplan, the man who represented Pinochet, talks about the case for the first time to  Clare Dyer
fields.body:
"It would be enormously helpful, Senator Pinochet, if you claimed you were a member of the IRA", the pinstripe-suited man with a briefcase labelled LAWYER tells the glum Chilean ex-dictator. The lawyer in the cartoon looks nothing like Pinochet's solicitor, Michael Caplan, but then Caplan's features are hardly well known. Throughout his client's 16-month sojourn as a hostage to Spanish and British justice, he eschewed the TV interviews and newspaper soundbites. He decided not to fight the issues in the media, but to keep the arguments for court. Only now, his client safely back in Santiago, has he agreed to an interview.

The walls of Caplan's tiny, functional office in London's Clerkenwell are hung with cartoons, most of them marking the highlights of the case of a lifetime. Above his desk, the room's only touch of colour is a court artist's drawing of the historic scene in the House of Lords when the law lords pronounced their final judgment removing the legal obstacles to Pinochet's extradition to Spain to face torture charges. Caplan appears as an anonymous figure in a far corner, belying his central role in the saga.

After 16 months on the unrelenting rollercoaster the case turned out to be, he admits he breathed a sigh of relief when the Chilean air force 707 taxied down the runway 10 days ago, within hours of Jack Straw's decision that the general was unfit to stand trial and would not be extradited to Spain. As the plane started to move, "there was a great sense with all the officials there, of witnessing a bit of history".

He almost ended up as an extra to the jubilant entourage when he boarded the plane to hand the general the plate Lady Thatcher had entrusted to him. She had left strict instructions that Caplan, who travelled to Waddington airbase as part of the convoy, should hand over the plate, inscribed "Margaret Thatcher", only when his client was safely on the plane. But his getaway wasn't as swift as he'd planned. "A lot of people wanted to say goodbye to me and express their thanks, which I found rather embarrassing - embarrassing in the sense that I have a role to play and my role was to deal with the legal issues. It was only when I got off that I was told they had closed the doors and taken the steps away. They had had to put the steps back up."

Only when the plane took off could Caplan be sure that his client was safely on his way home to Chile at last. Up to that point, a last-ditch legal challenge by human rights groups or one of the four countries seeking his extradition could have blocked his departure.

Tension was high as the convoy headed down the motorway. "I realised that even though we'd received the decision from the home office at eight o'clock that morning, the case was far from over. I had set up direct links with my office so I would be informed on a separate line whilst we were moving up the A1. I had to take along a separate mobile because the press had got hold of my mobile number. There were lawyers and police officers in the car and every time the phone rang, everyone looked anxiously at it."

The case had taken over much of Caplan's life since the Friday in October 1998 when Pinochet was arrested. He needed a lawyer fast. Kingsley Napley, Caplan's firm, was recommended for its international law reputation - one of his partners, Stephen Pollard, had represented rogue trader Nick Leeson - and Caplan, with previous experience in extradition cases, met the Pinochet family on the Sunday.

Kingsley Napley supports Amnesty International, the human rights group that worked hard to deliver Pinochet to his Spanish accusers, but there was never any question of turning the ex-dictator down. Unlike barristers, solicitors are not obliged to take on any client who seeks their help, but criminal lawyers are not in the business of turning away unpopular clients.

If they were, hate figures like Myra Hindley, Ian Brady, Harold Shipman and Fred and Rosemary West would go unrepresented. Caplan, who sits as a part-time judge for four weeks a year, sees himself as fulfilling a professional role, like a doctor, who would never refuse to treat a patient just because he he was accused of heinous crimes.

He will not divulge where his own political sympathies lie but most criminal lawyers, who tend to have an anti-establishment streak, are more likely to be leftish than rightish in their views. He faced abuse from human rights campaigners and was even assaulted coming out of court, but he makes no complaint. "I'm a great believer in free speech. I hope people will understand that I'm carrying out my duty to a client, in the same way as a surgeon would to a patient."

At first the issues seemed simple: could one country try another country's former head of state for crimes against humanity? When the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Bingham, heard the case with two other judges in the High Court, the judges had only two lever-arch files of documents, and they quickly decided that Pinochet was immune from prosecution under the State Immunity Act.

But the case was to go to the House of Lords three times, getting more and more complex, till by the end each judge had 20 lever-arch files. On the first appeal, the law lords overturned the High Court judgment by a three to two margin, opening the way for extradition. Then Kingsley Napley was tipped off by an anonymous phone call that Lord Hoffmann, whose decision tipped the balance, was an unpaid director of the fundraising charity arm of Amnesty International, the human rights group which had argued for Pinochet's extradition during the appeal. It later emerged that Kingsley Napley had contributed £1,000 in response to a fund-raising letter from Amnesty that mentioned Hoffmann as a director. Caplan says he has no recollection of the letter, if he ever saw it, and was unaware of Hoffmann's role.

But what could be done? The law lords are the final court of appeal and they had never overturned one of their own judgments. "We had to feel our way, to work out whether we could create what was to be legal history." A different panel of law lords decided that Hoffmann was disqualified by his interest in Amnesty from hearing the case and set the judgment aside. A new panel of seven law lords ruled by six to one that Pinochet could be prosecuted, but only on charges of torture and conspiracy to torture, and only for offences committed after December 8 1988, cutting the number of charges from 31 to three. Spain promptly came up with new charges. Whether it had power to do so or jurisdiction to try Pinochet for crimes that did not involve Spanish nationals would have been argued at the habeas corpus hearing, listed to start a week today. But Jack Straw intervened.

The proposal that Pinochet should undergo a medical examination came from the home secretary, Caplan confirms. "There was an approach to me asking if the senator would undergo a medical examination by clinicians appointed by the home secretary on the basis that any report would be confidential to him and to us."

He has always refused to comment on Pinochet's health and was "saddened" when the details of the medical report leaked out through a Spanish newspaper. On the one occasion when he had to speak publicly on his client's medical problems - to excuse his inability to appear at the magistrates' court - he was careful to be "extremely circumspect".

Pinochet has escaped prosecution in Europe but back in Chile new travails are in store. The prosecuting authorities have decided to pursue charges against him. His son, Marco Antonio, said: "I'm sure this will go on and on until my father is dead."

The case has sent a message to tyrants everywhere that international conventions against torture and hostage-taking have real effect in law. "The fundamental point is clearly that the law evolves, it doesn't stand still," says Caplan. But he believes the national courts of unconnected countries are not the right places to decide such issues. "It does show the need for an international forum supported by every country."

webTitle: Kosovo drug mafia supply heroin to Europe

fields.headline: Kosovo drug mafia supply heroin to Europe
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: International agencies fighting the drug trade are warning that Kosovo has become a "smugglers' paradise" supplying up to 40% of the heroin sold in Europe and North America.
fields.body:
International agencies fighting the drug trade are warning that Kosovo has become a "smugglers' paradise" supplying up to 40% of the heroin sold in Europe and North America.

Nato-led forces, struggling to keep peace in the province a year after the war, have no mandate to fight drug traffickers; and - with the expulsion from Kosovo of the Serb police, including the "4th unit" narcotics squad - the smugglers are running the "Balkan route" with complete freedom.

The peacekeepers of K-For "may as well be coming from another planet when it comes to tackling these guys," said Marko Nicovic, a lawyer and vice-president of the international narcotics enforcement officers association, based in New York.

"It's the hardest narcotics ring to crack because it is all run by families and they even have their own language. Kosovo is set to become the cancer centre of Europe, as western Europe will soon discover," he said.

He estimates that the province's traffickers are now handling between 4.5 and five tonnes of heroin a month and growing fast, compared to the two tonnes they were shifting before the Kosovo war of March-June last year, when Nato bombing forced Serbia's regime to pull out of the largely ethnic-Albanian province.

"It's coming through easier and cheaper - and there's much more of it. The price is going down and if this goes on we are predicting a heroin boom in western Europe as there was in the early 80s."

A heroin trafficker in Belgrade confirmed to the Guardian that since the war the Kosovo heroin dealers, most of them from four main families, are concentrating on the western Europe and US markets.

A kilo of heroin that is worth £10,000 in Kosovo or £20,000 in Belgrade can make £40,000 on the British, Italian or Swiss markets, said that 24-year-old heroin middleman. He expected the Kosovo route to grow: "There's nobody to stop them."

Only half the promised 5,000 policemen have arrived to join the peace operation in the province, which is now the main route for heroin flowing through some of the world's most troubled countries, Afghanisatan, northern Iran, the southern states of the Russian Federation, Azerbaijan, Turkey, Kosovo and into western Europe and the US

"It is the Colombia of Europe," said Mr Nikovic, who was the chief of the Yugoslav narcotics force until 1996. "When Serb police were burning houses in Kosovo they were finding it [heroin] stuffed in the roof. As far as I know there has not been a single report in the last year of K-For seizing heroin. They are soldiers not criminal investigators."

Echoing this, an official at Nato in Brussels said: "Generals do not want to turn their troops into cops ... They don't want their troops to get shot pursuing black marketeers."

There is no evidence that the ethnic Albanians' Kosovo Liberation Army is involved directly in drug smuggling, but according to the British-based International Police Review published by Jane's they may be dependent on the drug families who, the Review says, partly funded the KLA's operations in Kosovo last year.

When drug squad chiefs from northern and eastern Europe met in Sweden 10 days ago, the Balkan route was the main issue, according to the head of the Czech narcotics agency, Jiri Komorous: "There are four paths of drug trafficking through the Balkans to western Europe and we have to improve our attempts to control the Kosovo Albanians."

The Kosovo mafia has been smuggling heroin since the mid-80s - but since the Kosovo war they have come into their own, according to Mr Nicovic: "You have an entire country without a police force that knows what is going on."

The Kosovo Albanian mafia is almost untouchable. "Everything is worked out on the basis of the family or clan structure, the Fic (brotherhood), so it is impossible to plant informers," said Mr Nicovic.

"Their diaspora have been in Turkey and Germany since Tito's communist purges so the whole route is set up. Now they have found the one country between Asia and Europe which is not a member of Interpol."

To Britain, he said, there are two routes: "By truck through Germany, Belgium and France and then via Dover - and also through Budapest, Poland, the Netherlands, then to Britain."

Responsibility for organising police work in Kosovo "is a grey area", said the Nato official, but "if organised crime goes on thriving it will have intenational ramifications".

Kosovo is set to become the cancer centre of Europe, as western Europe will soon discover," he said. He estimates that the province's traffickers are now handling between 4.5 and five tonnes of heroin a month and growing fast, compared to the two tonnes they were shifting before the Kosovo war of March-June last year, when Nato bombing forced Serbia's regime to pull out of the largely ethnic-Albanian province. "It's coming through easier and cheaper - and there's much more of it. The price is going down and if this goes on we are predicting a heroin boom in western Europe as there was in the early 80s." A heroin trafficker in Belgrade confirmed to the Guardian that since the war the Kosovo heroin dealers, most of them from four main families, are concentrating on the western Europe and US markets. A kilo of heroin that is worth £10,000 in Kosovo or £20,000 in Belgrade can make £40,000 on the British, Italian or Swiss markets, said that 24-year-old heroin middleman. He expected the Kosovo route to grow: "There's nobody to stop them." Only half the promised 5,000 policemen have arrived to join the peace operation in the province, which is now the main route for heroin flowing through some of the world's most troubled countries, Afghanisatan, northern Iran, the southern states of the Russian Federation, Azerbaijan, Turkey, Kosovo and into western Europe and the US "It is the Colombia of Europe," said Mr Nikovic, who was the chief of the Yugoslav narcotics force until 1996. "When Serb police were burning houses in Kosovo they were finding it [heroin] stuffed in the roof. As far as I know there has not been a single report in the last year of K-For seizing heroin. They are soldiers not criminal investigators." Echoing this, an official at Nato in Brussels said: "Generals do not want to turn their troops into cops ... They don't want their troops to get shot pursuing black marketeers." There is no evidence that the ethnic Albanians' Kosovo Liberation Army is involved directly in drug smuggling, but according to the British-based International Police Review published by Jane's they may be dependent on the drug families who, the Review says, partly funded the KLA's operations in Kosovo last year. When drug squad chiefs from northern and eastern Europe met in Sweden 10 days ago, the Balkan route was the main issue, according to the head of the Czech narcotics agency, Jiri Komorous: "There are four paths of drug trafficking through the Balkans to western Europe and we have to improve our attempts to control the Kosovo Albanians." The Kosovo mafia has been smuggling heroin since the mid-80s - but since the Kosovo war they have come into their own, according to Mr Nicovic: "You have an entire country without a police force that knows what is going on." The Kosovo Albanian mafia is almost untouchable. "Everything is worked out on the basis of the family or clan structure, the Fic (brotherhood), so it is impossible to plant informers," said Mr Nicovic. "Their diaspora have been in Turkey and Germany since Tito's communist purges so the whole route is set up. Now they have found the one country between Asia and Europe which is not a member of Interpol." To Britain, he said, there are two routes: "By truck through Germany, Belgium and France and then via Dover - and also through Budapest, Poland, the Netherlands, then to Britain." Responsibility for organising police work in Kosovo "is a grey area", said the Nato official, but "if organised crime goes on thriving it will have intenational ramifications".

fields.headline: Allies count cost of unity
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: It was meant to last for only a few days - a few cruise missiles, attacks on Yugoslavia's air defence system, and Slobodan Milosevic would buckle.
fields.body:
It was meant to last for only a few days - a few cruise missiles, attacks on Yugoslavia's air defence system, and Slobodan Milosevic would buckle.

On the first night of air strikes that were to go on for 78 days, Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state and Washington's chief hawk, told the media: "I don't see this as a long-term operation. I think this is something that is achievable within a relatively short space of time."

Nato's military chiefs were given the same misplaced advice. General Mike Short, commander of allied air forces, said last night: "I was being told, 'Mike, you're only going to bomb for two or three nights, that's all the alliance can stand, that's all Washington can stand'."

It was what President Milosevic also believed; he ordered his troops to stay put, assuming the alliance would crack.

The alliance remained united, but at a price that military commanders found hard to stomach; in the first joint military action of its 50-year history, Nato had to fight a war by committee.

The allies ignored one of the basic principles of warfare - keep the enemy guessing - when they made it abundantly clear they would not invade Kosovo. "It was a coercive air campaign for essentially political aims," a senior western defence source said. "The objective was not to defeat the Serb army."

Military commanders had wanted to go in hard and heavy from the start. But they were prevented from doing so because member governments, looking over their shoulder at public opinion, insisted on keeping tight control of what targets could be hit.

Contingency bombing plans had not been agreed in advance. As Nato aircraft pounded Serbian military targets with "smart" and not so smart bombs, its member governments were under pressure to get results. That meant attacking those who were carrying out the atrocities against ethnic Albanians on the ground in Kosovo, whether or not it was strategically advantageous to do so.

"There was a moral imperative to be seen to attack the Third Army in Kosovo," Gen Short said on BBC2's Moral Combat programme last night. "I don't wish to be impertinent, but I don't think most of our civilian leadership generally understands air power and how it should be employed. Their exposure to it has been films of the Gulf war, which looked very much like a video game."

When Nato commanders turned to targets inside Kosovo, they were frustrated by bad weather, a shortage of smart bombs that could be guided through cloud, and the Serbs' ability to hide their equipment.

Meanwhile, the allies - in particular the US contingent, whose pilots were responsible for more than 80% of the bombing missions - were determined to protect their aircraft from attack, which meant that, for the most part, they bombed from above 4,600 metres (15,000ft).

President Bill Clinton's refusal to allow Apache helicopters to attack Serb positions did nothing to improve the prickly relationship between General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme allied commander who complained he was having to fight a war with one hand tied behind his back, and the Pentagon.

And when Nato later turned on a wide range of economic and industrial targets across Serbia, the bombing almost inevitably led to the deaths of more innocent civilians. British ministers were forced to defend the attack on the Serbian television headquarters in Belgrade, which led to several civilian deaths, describing it as a "legitimate military target".

webTitle: Rebuilding the Balkans: Too soon to forgive

fields.headline: Rebuilding the Balkans: Too soon to forgive
fields.standfirst:
In a week-long series Guardian writers examine how Nato won the war but may now be losing the peace

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The Zabeli family sits in their barn, warming themselves by a woodstove. Their makeshift home is comfortable compared with the tent where all 10 of them - grandparents, two grown-up children, one spouse and several toddlers - huddled through the winter.
fields.body:
The Zabeli family sits in their barn, warming themselves by a woodstove. Their makeshift home is comfortable compared with the tent where all 10 of them - grandparents, two grown-up children, one spouse and several toddlers - huddled through the winter.

"It was not until January, seven months after the end of the war, that we got timbers from a foreign charity and enough tiles to roof the damaged barn," says Sandik Zabeli, 63, the family's hardy patriarch. His handshake feels as though it could crush one of those timbers like a matchstick.

In the hierarchy of suffering around the Kosovan capital, Pristina, the Zabelis are above the bottom rung. "We're all healthy. No one in our family was killed," Mr Zabeli says.

Even tent life was better than the three months they spent in the woods last year after Serb forces burnt their home three weeks before Nato's air strikes began. "At least we don't have to run into the woods with the children any more," he says.

As the March 24 anniversary of the air strikes approaches, peacetime reconstruction remains pitifully slow. When international aid agencies poured into Kosovo with the tide of returning refugees, they found 50,000 houses totally destroyed, leaving close to half a million people without shelter. But after the billions of pounds spent on bombing, the tough message was that no one could expect rapid help for rebuilding. Families would get aid to make ready for winter only one room.

So all over Kosovo residents put transparent plastic across the windows of their barns and cow sheds, and blue tarpaulin on the concrete floors to keep out the damp. Kosovo's Albanians would be freezing but free.

Twenty miles away, a death notice with the faces of 14 Serb victims hangs on the kitchen wall like an icon, a perpetual reminder of loss. No postwar atrocity in Kosovo caused as much outrage as the slaughter of this group of Serb farmers heading for their fields near the village of Gracko last July. It exposed the weakness of K-For, the international peacekeeping force that entered Kosovo with the goal of providing security for all ethnic groups.

No one was hit harder by the massacre than Lyubica Zivic, who lost her two sons, leaving her daughters-in-law widows and their seven children fatherless. Dressed in black every day, the three Zivic women are prisoners in their village, like almost every other Serb in Kosovo. Once in total control, the Serbs have been reduced to a few dozen enclaves which they leave at their peril. Two-thirds of the 150,000 who lived in Kosovo a year ago have gone.

Gracko's horizons have shrunk. It is too dangerous for secondary school children to go to the nearest big town any more. Instead, they have their classes in the village primary school. A doctor makes a weekly visit, and those taken ill in an emergency have to be escorted in ambulances by K-For.

"We have only left here once since the tragedy," says a tearful Vesna Zivic. "To mark the half-year since they died, we went to the cathedral in Gracanica to light a candle."

Yet isolation and bereavement have brought no sense of reflection. They refuse to accept any wrongdoing to Albanians during the offensives by the Serbian president, Slobodan Milosevic, and with their new fear has come hatred.

"I hate now. I didn't hate before," says Ms Zivic. "I hate every single Albanian thing; everyone, even a little Albanian child." Like a symbol of almost every group of Serbs still in Kosovo, the Zivic women are trapped but unrepentant.

A year after the Nato intervention, the question that recurs in almost every conversation is whether Nato won the war but is losing the peace.

"We will be facing two sets of critics," Nato's spokesman, Jamie Shea, told a conference in Pristina recently. "There are the revisionists who say that because Nato was unable to avoid causing some civilian casualties, and because only 2,000 Albanian bodies have been discovered in mass graves so far, the Nato campaign was not justified. The second group are the perfectionists, who complain that we haven't produced a multi-ethnic, democratic Kosovo."

His argument, of course, ignores the larger group of people who supported intervention but feel Nato governments' postwar efforts should have been more generous and efficient, just as the military campaign should have been conducted differently.

In the bluntest terms, the intervention achieved its goal of ending President Milosevic's ethnic cleansing and securing a Yugoslav military withdrawal.

"For the first time in their history Kosovars see soldiers who do not threaten them," says Veton Surroi, the publisher of the newspaper Koha Ditore. Like most Albanians, he is angry that the international community has failed to do more to improve their physical conditions.

As hundreds of thousands struggled through winter in the countryside in tents and cowsheds, others moved to Pristina to find shelter. But even there they shivered through repeated cuts in power and water, which had never affected the city under Serb rule.

At the mercy of criminals

Foreign governments have supplied fewer than half the 4,500 police they promised, leaving both Albanians and Serbs at the mercy of criminals. Even if UN police or K-For troops manage to arrest suspects, they tend to be released within hours.

"There are only 50 detention places in Pristina," complains a British officer. "If we find someone with illegal weapons, he's usually let out the next day. All we keep is the name and photo."

Of the 4,000 people arrested by K-For since June 3, 750 have been released. In hundreds of cases defendants are freed because Albanian prosecutors and judges are bribed or intimidated. Although the UN appointed some Serbs as prosecutors, none dared to take up the post. The obvious solution of appointing foreign judges was delayed for months.

The Albanians are in no mood to forgive the Serbs. Before the war, the two communities walked the same streets and used the same shops, although they went to different schools. Now the apartheid is total. Serbs and Albanians are split into separate areas and rarely see each other - few want to.

"The oppression is too recent. Hatred is much worse than a year ago," said a young translator. His father stayed in Pristina when half the city's population was expelled by Serb forces. What shocked him was the way one of their Serb neighbours changed overnight after Nato started its air strikes - he put on paramilitary fatigues and shot at their house.

Few Serbs admit that more Albanians suffered injustice or lost family members before K-For arrived than the Serbs have done since. "An equivalent number of people died on each side," says Aca Nikolic, a headmaster in Vrbovac. "We need someone to calm things down for us. I trust the international community to do it, but there will be a lot more casualties on both sides. It is the good people who will suffer."

 Police used force to shut down a radio and television station in south-eastern Serbia yesterday in what an opposition politician said was part of the authorities' heavy-handed preparations for elections.

About 30 officers raided the station in Pozega, 110 miles from Belgrade. "Every television, every radio station and every newspaper must be protected," the politician, Vladan Batic, said. "If we do not do so, tomorrow it will be too late."

 Tomorrow: Maggie O'Kane in Belgrade on a country spiralling towards civil war. Plus, they promised to rejuvenate the Balkans. So why has so little been done?

fields.headline: MP takes medicines to Iraq
fields.standfirst: Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour MP George Galloway flew into Jordan last night on the first stage of a journey to deliver medical supplies to Iraq to highlight the damaging impact of UN sanctions.
fields.body:
The Labour MP George Galloway flew into Jordan last night on the first stage of a journey to deliver medical supplies to Iraq to highlight the damaging impact of UN sanctions.

He is to lead a convoy, including a refrigerated truck carrying £115,000 worth of medical supplies, 1,000 miles across the desert to Baghdad.

The main hurdle will be at the Iraqi border on Wednesday, when the convoy will have to undergo a search by UN representatives.

An Iraqi government representative expressed concern that the medicine, which has to be kept refrigerated, might perish if taken out of storage for too long at the border.

Mr Galloway and two others travelled to Amman on a scheduled flight, the team drastically scaled down from the 207 people who had originally planned to make the journey.

A special flight, which would have been the first direct civilian flight from London to Baghdad since the Gulf war, was vetoed last week by the UN sanctions committee.

fields.headline: Boys out ...
fields.standfirst: Last week, a women-only college won its fight to stay that way. Good news or bad, asks  Terri Apter
fields.trailText: Last week, a women-only college won its fight to stay that way. Good news or bad, asks  Terri Apter
fields.body:
"The last thing I wanted when I came up to university was to go to an all-women's college," Emily Agg-Manning says. But what was originally a disappointing placement at St Mary's, Durham University's unique single-sex college, soon became a love affair and now she is celebrating an important step towards maintaining her college's women-only status.

Ask fellow student Sally Cheesman what is so special about an all-women college and she begins by describing a boarding school atmosphere, where they all go to breakfast in their pyjamas. But her focus intensifies as she speaks of a support system like no other. "When someone's ill, we look after her. When someone's stuck on an essay, we encourage her and give her advice if we can."

Why would that necessarily be different if there were men here? "I don't know, but it would change things. It's not like we don't interact with the mixed student body - we do, every day. But here, where we live, we have our own space."

A space of her own has undergone many different meanings in the past 150 years. The first women's college in Cambridge had to be built two miles from the city limits, lest the mingling of the sexes distract one and deprave the other. But to have their own space meant being able to have an education (albeit not, until 1948, a degree) and many women were grateful for that.

Long after mixed schooling became commonplace, the perks of separate spaces emerged in surprising ways. If school space is shared, the boisterous boys take teachers' attention from the quieter girls. Girls can lose their footing among more confident boys. Any unease they have with science and maths is compounded by assumptions that "these aren't girls' subjects anyway". If the class is girls-only, the teacher inevitably fosters girls' abilities. There are strong educational arguments for separate schools.

Recent trends in grades, with girls showing more gains than boys (in mixed and single-sex schools), show teachers have become skilled in overcoming prejudice. We hear about the "Can Do Girls": confident, motivated, optimistic. But these forward-looking young women have a history and we should take lessons from that history before we conclude that the value of a special women's space is obsolete.

In the 60s and 70s, the women's movement was a bid for women to get out of what was defined as their space - the kitchen or the home - into the world abroad. They did this by joining other women, in a very different kind of women-only space. This was the space indicated on the cover of Marilyn French's cult consciousness-raising novel, in which "Ladies" on a lavatory door is crossed out and replaced with "Women". In a ladies' room, there's female-only space, but the label implies social control. In the women's room, they break with ladylike conventions and become self-aware people who fight for their rights. From the networks formed in the women's room, they stepped into male cultures of work and politics.

Finding space here was a slow and uncomfortable process. They kept guard, careful not to be too feminine. They dressed soberly, lowered their voices, preened themselves to be tough and competitive. Some social critics have argued that this was the time when the skinny female figure became an ideal. Thinness shaved away womanly features and minimised the space she took up.

The expectation was that once enough women entered the workplace, they wouldn't have to conform to a male model. Management expert Rosabeth Moss Kanter estimated that when women form 15% of employees, they have a comfortable presence. Less than that and they suffer a strange combination of invisibility (too few to be noticed) and exposure (so odd as to be a freak).

Now there are more women in the workplace, there's a lot of talk about its feminisation. This means the styles and values associated with women (caring, nurturing) are marketable. No longer do managers issue orders. Instead they listen and collaborate. In principle, being macho (except over working hours) is frowned upon and sensitivity rewarded.

Well, maybe. Many organisations are high on feminine-value vocabulary but not on real value for what's feminine. A 1998 survey of 5,000 enterprises in the EU showed the average profile of the British female manager has changed little since the 80s. She is less likely to be married and twice as likely to be divorced as her male counterpart. She also earns less, even at director level. The workplace may have changed style but to call it "feminised" is stretching the term. A feminised place is one in which women's needs meet with a direct, intuitive response. These places tend to be populated by women.

Nevertheless, a strong argument against women-only spaces is that they are a throwback to earlier times when women were kept in "their proper place". Some years ago, I was in a mixed college that wanted to have a women's meeting place. The bursar couldn't understand us. Having fought so hard to enter a man's world, we now seemed to be engaging in a voluntary retreat.

Retreat? That has two meanings: losing ground in a war and a safe haven. A woman's space is not a retreat in the slow march towards equality, but it is a retreat where one can gain strength and regroup. Sometimes it is no more than a girls' night out, sometimes it is three years in a women-only college.

As with all retreats, reality is waiting. "Life is about getting out and mixing with other people," Sally Cheesman reflects. "I love being at St Mary's now and I'll always appreciate a women's environment, but I won't always have one."

Emily Agg-Manning believes, however, that she can take this special place with her. "I have gained an inner confidence here. Nothing and no one could make me feel that women aren't equal to anything." Wherever that knowledge is provided is a good educational space.

* St Mary's is not the only all-female college: three at Cambridge (Newham, New Hall, Lucy Cavendish) and one at Oxford (St Hilda's) are men-free.

* Legislation originally designed to increase opportunities for women often present a threat to women's institutions. For example, Oxford University is prevented by law from funding academic posts advertised for women only, so St Hilda's has to fund them itself and is said to be running out of money. Thanks to a different administrative structure, Cambridge can sidestep sex discrimination law.

* The University Women's Club in Mayfair was founded in 1886 by 300 women campaigning to get women accepted into university. Its 1,200 members include Betty Boothroyd, Barbara Mills, Judi Dench and PD James. Unlike many gentlemen's clubs, the average age of members is falling, thanks to an influx of women in their 20s.
fields.bodyText: "The last thing I wanted when I came up to university was to go to an all-women's college," Emily Agg-Manning says. But what was originally a disappointing placement at St Mary's, Durham University's unique single-sex college, soon became a love affair and now she is celebrating an important step towards maintaining her college's women-only status. Ask fellow student Sally Cheesman what is so special about an all-women college and she begins by describing a boarding school atmosphere, where they all go to breakfast in their pyjamas. But her focus intensifies as she speaks of a support system like no other. "When someone's ill, we look after her. When someone's stuck on an essay, we encourage her and give her advice if we can." Why would that necessarily be different if there were men here? "I don't know, but it would change things. It's not like we don't interact with the mixed student body - we do, every day. But here, where we live, we have our own space." A space of her own has undergone many different meanings in the past 150 years. The first women's college in Cambridge had to be built two miles from the city limits, lest the mingling of the sexes distract one and deprave the other. But to have their own space meant being able to have an education (albeit not, until 1948, a degree) and many women were grateful for that. Long after mixed schooling became commonplace, the perks of separate spaces emerged in surprising ways. If school space is shared, the boisterous boys take teachers' attention from the quieter girls. Girls can lose their footing among more confident boys. Any unease they have with science and maths is compounded by assumptions that "these aren't girls' subjects anyway". If the class is girls-only, the teacher inevitably fosters girls' abilities. There are strong educational arguments for separate schools. Recent trends in grades, with girls showing more gains than boys (in mixed and single-sex schools), show teachers have become skilled in overcoming prejudice. We hear about the "Can Do Girls": confident, motivated, optimistic. But these forward-looking young women have a history and we should take lessons from that history before we conclude that the value of a special women's space is obsolete. In the 60s and 70s, the women's movement was a bid for women to get out of what was defined as their space - the kitchen or the home - into the world abroad. They did this by joining other women, in a very different kind of women-only space. This was the space indicated on the cover of Marilyn French's cult consciousness-raising novel, in which "Ladies" on a lavatory door is crossed out and replaced with "Women". In a ladies' room, there's female-only space, but the label implies social control. In the women's room, they break with ladylike conventions and become self-aware people who fight for their rights. From the networks formed in the women's room, they stepped into male cultures of work and politics. Finding space here was a slow and uncomfortable process. They kept guard, careful not to be too feminine. They dressed soberly, lowered their voices, preened themselves to be tough and competitive. Some social critics have argued that this was the time when the skinny female figure became an ideal. Thinness shaved away womanly features and minimised the space she took up. The expectation was that once enough women entered the workplace, they wouldn't have to conform to a male model. Management expert Rosabeth Moss Kanter estimated that when women form 15% of employees, they have a comfortable presence. Less than that and they suffer a strange combination of invisibility (too few to be noticed) and exposure (so odd as to be a freak). Now there are more women in the workplace, there's a lot of talk about its feminisation. This means the styles and values associated with women (caring, nurturing) are marketable. No longer do managers issue orders. Instead they listen and collaborate. In principle, being macho (except over working hours) is frowned upon and sensitivity rewarded. Well, maybe. Many organisations are high on feminine-value vocabulary but not on real value for what's feminine. A 1998 survey of 5,000 enterprises in the EU showed the average profile of the British female manager has changed little since the 80s. She is less likely to be married and twice as likely to be divorced as her male counterpart. She also earns less, even at director level. The workplace may have changed style but to call it "feminised" is stretching the term. A feminised place is one in which women's needs meet with a direct, intuitive response. These places tend to be populated by women. Nevertheless, a strong argument against women-only spaces is that they are a throwback to earlier times when women were kept in "their proper place". Some years ago, I was in a mixed college that wanted to have a women's meeting place. The bursar couldn't understand us. Having fought so hard to enter a man's world, we now seemed to be engaging in a voluntary retreat. Retreat? That has two meanings: losing ground in a war and a safe haven. A woman's space is not a retreat in the slow march towards equality, but it is a retreat where one can gain strength and regroup. Sometimes it is no more than a girls' night out, sometimes it is three years in a women-only college. As with all retreats, reality is waiting. "Life is about getting out and mixing with other people," Sally Cheesman reflects. "I love being at St Mary's now and I'll always appreciate a women's environment, but I won't always have one." Emily Agg-Manning believes, however, that she can take this special place with her. "I have gained an inner confidence here. Nothing and no one could make me feel that women aren't equal to anything." Wherever that knowledge is provided is a good educational space. * St Mary's is not the only all-female college: three at Cambridge (Newham, New Hall, Lucy Cavendish) and one at Oxford (St Hilda's) are men-free. * Legislation originally designed to increase opportunities for women often present a threat to women's institutions. For example, Oxford University is prevented by law from funding academic posts advertised for women only, so St Hilda's has to fund them itself and is said to be running out of money.
