fields.headline: The bitch is back
fields.standfirst: If it's feuding Labour females, then it must be a catfight:  Yvonne Roberts sees red at the way rows between women are billed
fields.trailText: Two men embroil themselves in battle and it's a gladiatorial feud: Blair and Brown, Fayed and Rowlands. Take two high-profile females at loggerheads and something much more subversive for the sisterhood apparently emerges: a catfight between bitches.
fields.body:
Two men embroil themselves in battle and it's a gladiatorial feud: Blair and Brown, Fayed and Rowlands. Take two high-profile females at loggerheads and something much more subversive for the sisterhood apparently emerges: a catfight between bitches.

Last week, it emerged that a truce had been announced between Margaret McDonagh, New Labour's general secretary, and Sally Morgan, Blair's political secretary, who between them control his political empire. True to the catfight scenario, they had been at war over a man - namely Ken Livingstone. Any number of struggles must have taken place over the months among New Labour minions but it is the female Furies who attract attention. "When a man gives his opinion, he's a man," as Bette Davis said. "But when a woman gives her opinion, she's a bitch."

The idea that men argue, compete, comment, complain, dispute and debate while women simply bitch is one that has stood the test of even these allegedly post-feminist times. The reason, of course, is that the single word manages to embrace so much of the confusion and contradiction, prejudice and impotence, that continues to hover around the business of us bad girls trying to make good in a manmade game.

In Fay Weldon's novel Praxis, written in the 70s, the heroine says of her gender: "We betray each other. We manipulate, through sex; we fight each other for possession of the male - snap, catch, swallow, gone! Where's the next? We prefer the company of men to women. We will quite deliberately make our sisters jealous and wretched ... And all in pursuit of our self-esteem and so as not to end up old and alone."

Earlier still, in the 40s, Simone de Beauvoir in The Second Sex wrote: "Man's true victory, whether he is liberator or conqueror, lies in just this: that the woman freely recognise him as her destiny."

Destiny is not what it once was. Some women, nowadays, also have their eyes on fat salaries, corporate success, gay lovers or, for that matter, all three plus a husband in tow. But still, at the heart of bitchery, lies the premise that a woman's job is to find a man. And to fight off her sisters in the process. If masculinity is in crisis, as we're so often told, all the more reason why some men cling fast to the idea that all any woman wants is him. So he exploits every opportunity he can to prove that a woman's worst enemy is her sister.

The bitch, for instance, is now in the boardroom, too. She is the one who persists in employing traditional ploys that bother female colleagues and bewilder men. She sleeps with the boss, flirts with middle management and treats female solidarity as an antisocial disease. She is also the senior manager who refuses to consider job-shares, term-time contracts; paid parental leave or flexible hours. Unless, of course, it's a man who is asking. You'll know her because she's the one who says, without any sense of irony: "Women are their own worst enemies."

In short, in these modern times, the bitch as man-hunter has adapted into the bitch as man. More precisely, the bitch as selfish man. Hence Naomi Campbell's triumphant cry when she was sacked by the modelling agency Elite for allegedly being, well, Naomi: "I'm a hard-working bitch. I do what I do. Life is too short, you have to go for it."

It's the "And sod the rest of you" left hanging that makes the bitch the backlash's favourite broad. She single-handedly sabotages the sisterhood as she proves that women, far from being morally superior, are even nastier than men. After all, what male would say of a brother, as Dorothy Parker said of Katharine Hepburn: "She runs the whole gamut of emotions from A to B"? (Plenty, of course, but that's why mythology and misogyny are so warmly wedded.)

In Bittersweet, Love Envy and Competition in Women's Friendships, Susie Orbach and Luise Eichenbaum describe the differences in male and female competition. Girls are reared to put others first; boys, in Campbell's words, to go for it. "Whereas women search for self through connection with others, men search for self through distinguishing themselves from others."

A bitch rejects connectedness and says, in more ways than one: "I'm not like other, inferior women." It's she who provides the perfect opportunity for the malevolent man to divide and rule. She's Judas and Jezebel. And what really is a bitch is that, while the sisterhood has helped, conditioning ensures there's a bit of her in all of us

Michele Hanson returns next week.

fields.headline: Abortion guidelines hailed by campaigners
fields.standfirst: Royal college calls for operation within three weeks of referral
fields.trailText: Royal college calls for operation within three weeks of referral
fields.body:
New guidelines on abortion were last night hailed by campaigners as a turning point in a service that has had to fight for legitimacy and is still often subject to stigma.

Ann Furedi of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service said the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists document setting new standards for the NHS and private clinics was a clear sign that the medical profession, policy makers and society at large were beginning to accept abortion as part of essential reproductive health care.

She added: "Abortion may have been legal in Britain for 30 years but it has yet to be recognised as entirely legitimate and is often the subject of controversial debate. If the RCOG succeeds in establishing these principles of care nationally it will represent the 'coming of age' of abortion services."

The anti-abortion lobby is incensed by the suggestion that abortion could become respectable, and will shortly be even further angered by a booklet for children which the Family Planning Association plans to publish and distribute in schools. The booklet is in cartoon style and aimed at those in their early to middle teens. It describes what abortion is and the reasons why a girl might seek one.

Today's royal college guidelines, compiled by a group funded by the department of health, says abortion services should "provide high quality, efficient, effective and comprehensive care that respects the dignity, individuality and rights of women to exercise personal choice over their treatment."

Abortion is far more common than most people realise. Because of the stigma and shame attached, few women will talk about it, but the college points out that at least a third of women experience an abortion before the age of 45. Studies have shown that the majority are not young girls, but women in their twenties, and that a substantial number are older women who already have children. Organisations like the pregnancy advisory service - and the FPA with its booklet for children - think it is time for the normalisation of abortion which, they insist, nobody ever embarks upon lightly.

They are delighted that the college's guidelines emphasise the safety of the procedure. It is safer, the document states, than carrying a pregnancy to term, and complications are uncommon. But there is unequal access to abortion around the country and many women have to endure lengthy and distressing delays under the NHS. This, and the disapproval of some GPs, are the main reasons why many women resort to private clinics.

The guidelines state that no woman should have to wait longer than three weeks from her initial referral by the GP. Ideally, she should be offered an appointment for assessment within five days of referral and she should have the termination within seven days of her request being approved.

The document recommends that day care services should be provided because they are cost-effective and can minimise disruption to the lives of women and their families. Some clinics have begun a lunch-hour service, which has been castigated by critics. The royal college suggests no more than 10% will need an overnight stay.

Wherever possible, women who are admitted for an abortion should be treated separately from those who are pregnant and want their baby - particularly if they are having an ultrasound scan. Putting them together can be distressing for both. Health authorities should provide more information to let women know how to obtain an abortion and what options are available to them.

The document, The Care of Women requesting Induced Abortion, suggests that psychological trauma is more common in women who have been denied an abortion than in those who have had one. "Only a small minority of women experience any long term adverse psychological sequelae after abortion," it says. "Early distress, although common, is usually a continuation of symptoms present before the abortion. Conversely, long-lasting, negative effects on both mothers and their children are reported where abortion has been denied."

webTitle: Colour coordinated: Radical redecoration for Kenwood

fields.headline: Colour coordinated: Radical redecoration for Kenwood
fields.trailText: Jaws dropped when the first visitors saw the radical redecoration of rooms at Kenwood, the mansion housing some of the country's most famous paintings.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
Jaws dropped when the first visitors saw the radical redecoration of rooms at Kenwood, the mansion housing some of the country's most famous paintings.

The interiors had been icy blue, grey and white since the 1920s, when Lord Iveagh left the nation his palatial house on Hampstead Heath in north London, and his astounding art collection - the richest ever art bequest.

Rembrandt's majestic self portrait, recently voted Britain's favourite picture, and the priceless Vermeer, The Guitar Player, are now on crimson French stamped velvet in a dining room redecorated so that its palest shade, the off white ceiling, is fractionally darker than the painter's white cap.

"We have made a rich, dark, sombre setting for these pictures," said Alec Cobbe, consultant to English Heritage on the redecoration of four rooms. "It was a unique project. I had a free hand, my only requirement was to make the pictures look fabulous."

The stormy grey of the music room, seen left with Mr Cobbe, was inspired by the thundery cloud behind Mary, Countess Howe, the most ravishing of Gainsborough's 18th century beauties. Other dazzling women's portraits have been assembled with it in the room. "What a relief!" said Julius Bryant, head of collections at English Heritage, contemplating the new decor. "It used to be so embarassing that I hated bringing people here; now it's another world, a true harem."

The other rooms also smoulder with colour. Rich carpets cover bare boards, the windows are draped with opulent curtains. White woodwork is now dark woodgrain. The Green Room, which lost its colour almost a century ago, is green again.

The work, costing £800,000, goes against all recent restorations. "We could have recreated the original appearance," said Mr Bryant. "There would have been just one problem: the paintings would have looked disgusting."

When Lord Iveagh died in 1927, he had not begun redecorating Kenwood - so English Heritage and Mr Cobbe took their lead from his homes in Ireland. The dining room curtains are a direct copy of those made in Dublin in 1828 for another Irish mansion, Mr Cobbe's family home.

webTitle: Grieving couple in test case to choose sex of next child

fields.headline: Grieving couple in test case to choose sex of next child
fields.trailText: A couple whose only daughter died in a bonfire accident have launched a test case to be allowed to choose the sex of their next child.
fields.body:
A couple whose only daughter died in a bonfire accident have launched a test case to be allowed to choose the sex of their next child.

Louise and Alan Masterton, from Monifieth in Tayside, have asked the human fertilisation and embryology authority to allow Mrs Masterton to be implanted with female embryos to ensure they have a baby girl.

The Mastertons' only daughter, Nicole, died last summer at the age of three after a balloon containing flammable gas fell on to a bonfire at their home and exploded. Nicole suffered 90% burns and died two months later. Mrs Masterton, who already has four sons, was sterilised after Nicole's birth.

Embryo sex screening is cur rently only available for prospective parents who are carriers of medical conditions related to a particular gender.

A spokesman for the authority said it had been contacted by the Mastertons some time ago and had advised them to go to one of the five clinics in the UK which offer the procedure, and have an official application forwarded by the clinic.

An authority spokesman, James Yeandal, said it had not yet had an application on behalf of the Mastertons but would consider one when it was put to it.

"In 1993 we asked the public how they felt about sex selection," he said. "The overwhelming view was that it should not be allowed for what were called 'social reasons.' However, through clinics, peo ple are always welcome to make applications to us. I'm not saying there are any plans to change our policy but we have the power to grant applications which might not sit alongside the policy. This is the first time we have had a case like this."

Observers say the authority is increasingly aware of pressure to allow sex selection in these sorts of circumstances.

In an interview with the Scottish Sunday Mail, the Mastertons, both 42, said they could never replace Nicole but were desperate to have another little girl.

"We love our boys but we have lost our daughter," Mrs Masterton said. "I want the chance again to be a mum to a little girl and enjoy all the different experiences that brings."

webTitle: Straw plans new tags for stalkers and sex offenders

fields.headline: Straw plans new tags for stalkers and sex offenders
fields.trailText: A new generation of electronic tags to prevent criminals such as stalkers or sex offenders visiting the homes of their victims will be part of a criminal justice bill to be published by the home secretary, Jack Straw, on Thursday.
fields.body:
A new generation of electronic tags to prevent criminals such as stalkers or sex offenders visiting the homes of their victims will be part of a criminal justice bill to be published by the home secretary, Jack Straw, on Thursday.

The legislation will also contain police powers to carry out mandatory drug tests on any suspected heroin or other hard drug abuser, whatever offence they have been arrested for. Although limited resources mean the powers are unlikely to be used to detect cannabis smokers, thousands of suspects will be tested in police stations in an attempt to break the link between crime, particulary property offences such as burglary and shoplifting, and drug abuse.

The criminal justice and court services bill also includes an overhaul of the pro bation service, but during the bill's passage Mr Straw is expected to drop his plan to rename the probation service as the community punishment and rehabilitation service.

More than 100 MPs had criticised the new name, which also came under fire in the House of Lords. Mr Straw is expected to put forward a compromise under which the term probation, dating back to the early 1900s, is retained. It is thought the service will be called, Probation - the community punishment and rehabilitation service, so that the public gets a clearer message that its purpose is to protect them.

It is believed Mr Straw has also decided to drop the suggestion that probation officers should be renamed as community punishment and rehabilitation officers; critics suggested the criminals would quickly dub the officers "crapos".

The second generation of electronic tags follows their successful use in enforcing home detention curfews in the past two years. webTitle: Australian gets plum Royal Ballet job

fields.headline: Australian gets plum Royal Ballet job
fields.trailText: The Royal Ballet has offered the job of artistic director to Ross Stretton, director of the Australian Ballet, after a worldwide search.
fields.body:
The Royal Ballet has offered the job of artistic director to Ross Stretton, director of the Australian Ballet, after a worldwide search.

As soon as the current director, Anthony Dowell, announced that he would be leaving in 2001, the dance world went into speculative overdrive as to his successor. Stars such as Mikhail Baryshnikov, Twyla Tharp and Sylvie Guillem were touted - with varying degrees of credibility - but few had Stretton down as frontrunner, let alone the winner.

Stretton, 48, in fact has a solid career behind him. Born in Canberra in 1952, he studied at the Australian Ballet school and became one of the company's leading dancers.

In 1979 he moved to the US, and after two years dancing with the Joffrey Ballet he joined the American Ballet Theatre, where he was appointed assistant director in 1992. In 1996 he moved back to direct the Australian Ballet.

It was Kevin McKenzie, Stretton's boss at ABT, who was most widely tipped to become the Royal's new director - with Michael Kaiser, execu tive director of the Royal Opera House and past executive director at ABT one of his keenest backers.

McKenzie finally chose to remain at ABT, but Stretton, with his US links, will undoubtedly be seen as an ally for Kaiser, who is still feeling embattled by criticisms of the revamped ROH.

It is much too soon to predict Stretton's impact on the Royal Ballet; his tenure in Australia has not exactly made international dance news. But his nationality will certainly cause controversy. With an American, Kaiser, already running the ROH and another, Antonio Pappano, soon to take over the 0pera, there has been strong pressure for a British born, or at least a British based, director at the ballet.

The Royal Ballet has always prided itself on its British style of dancing and its British choreographers, and it was assumed that a director with first-hand knowledge of these traditions would be a priority.

But an obvious candidate did not materialise among the UK applicants. Experienced ballet directors are a rare breed, and the most natural contender, David Bintley, who runs Birmingham Royal Ballet, wanted to stay put.

Numerous dancers and choreographers also applied, including Ashley Page, Deborah Bull and Irek Mukhamedov. But as Dowell discovered 14 years ago, it is hard for working artists to turn from employee to boss, and while Bull, for instance, is considered to have directing potential she is still too closely in volved with the company. Sylvie Guillem, another possibility for the future, has made it clear that her immediate concern is her dancing career.

A UK candidate was runner-up. Ross MacGibbon, once principal dancer with the Royal, is now on the ROH board and a successful television director and producer.

He was one of the more radical contenders, with strong views on rooting out inefficient working practices and on forging links between the ballet and the wider artistic com munity. He wanted to update the company's aesthetic while retaining its British profile. But he had no experience of running a ballet company.

For Stretton, though, running the Royal will hardly be cosy. He will bear the symbolic burden of becoming the first director to begin his tenure at the rebuilt opera house, and his appointment comes at a time when the ballet is desperately seeking to position itself in the 21st century.

 Judith Mackrell is the Guardian's dance critic.

Following in Madam's dance steps

Ninette de Valois (1931- 63)

Still alive at 101 and universally known as Madam, the Royal Ballet's founder remains its presiding genius. De Valois had adroit political skills as well as dedication to her art; from the beginning her vision of a national ballet and school set the scale of the Royal's

ambitions. She nurtured the talents of several generations of artists, most famously choreographer Frederick Ashton and prima ballerina Margot Fonteyn, but was herself a choreographer of considerable wit and dramatic invention.

Frederick Ashton (1963-70)

Founding choreographer of the Royal Ballet, whose works helped to define the company's distinctive English style (detailed, elegant, sensuous and musical). His direction of the company is still remembered as a golden age during which a generation of dancers (Antoinette Sibley, Anthony Dowell and Lynn Seymour) flourished, standards of dancing rose throughout the ranks, and the repertory expanded to absorb early 20th century classics and new works such as MacMillan's Romeo and Juliet.

Kenneth MacMillan (1970-77)

Ashton's successor was also one of the giants of British choreography, and like Ashton MacMillan suffered from the fact that running a company was not entirely compatible with his creativity. Aspects of his regime were controversial but he was a figurehead and, by acquiring ballets from outside choreographers such as Glen Tetley and Hans van Manen, as well as creating new works (notably Manon), he is credited with updating the image at a crucial time.

Norman Morrice (1977-86)

Came from Ballet Rambert, the small classical company which he transformed into a modern ensemble. His direction was controversial (including his ban on guest stars) but gave opportunities to dancers like Fiona Chadwick and Briony Brind and to choreographers like Ashley Page.

Anthony Dowell (1986-2001)

Considered the greatest male dancer of his generation, Dowell was still performing when he took over. His achievement was to raise technical standards but he oversaw the final flowering of MacMillan's career and its impact on dancers like Darcey Bussell and Irek Mukhamedov. But he was criticised for not keeping step with modern fashion.

webTitle: Ahern seeks pull-out of troops in Armagh

fields.headline: Ahern seeks pull-out of troops in Armagh
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, said yesterday that the continued presence of British security forces in border areas of Northern ireland such as South Armagh remained a source of "harassment and annoyance" to the local nationalist community.
fields.body:
The Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, said yesterday that the continued presence of British security forces in border areas of Northern ireland such as South Armagh remained a source of "harassment and annoyance" to the local nationalist community.

Addressing members of the Australia-Ireland Fund in Melbourne, he said: "It would make an immense contribution to confidence-building if the public could feel assured that every organisation that was involved in the Northern Ireland conflict accepts that a return to an armed campaign is not an option.

"But all of us, not least the two governments, have an absolute obligation to ensure that all aspects of the [Good Friday] agreement are implemented in full.

"This includes the de-escalation of military dispositions by the security forces as provided for in the agreement, especially in certain border areas such as South Armagh, where they are still a source of harassment and annoyance."

His call came four days after the Irish foreign minister, Brian Cowen, said the nationalist communities needed to see politics were working: "If there is a reality for people in nationalist areas [it is] that the security presence, far from decreasing since the ceasefire has, if anything, increased in some instances."

The Stormont assembly was suspended last month due to an impasse over decommisioning. Since then, intense discussions have been taking place. Yesterday Mr Ahern also said that the best way to resolve the crisis would be to first reinstate the assembly. Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, made a similar plea yesterday at a Belfast rally.

Little progress is expected before Northern Ireland politicians arrive in Washington later this week for St Patrick's Day celebrations, where president Bill Clinton will host informal talks.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Blair nanny's trip defended
fields.body:
Blair nanny's trip defended

Downing Street denied yesterday that Tony Blair should have registered a trip by his former nanny, Ros Mark, and her family to the Cannes apartment of former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson. A No 10 spokesman said: "Hospitality from a friend does not need to be declared.

Bomb murder case release

Detectives have released one of the two people questioned over the murder of human rights lawyer Rosemary Nelson who was killed by a loyalist car bomb near her home last March.

Whiplash risk from headrests

Four in five motorists are risking neck injuries by driving with poorly-positioned headrests, according to the Association of British Insurers which says whiplash and back-related injuries cost more than £1bn a year. It said women drivers were twice as likely to suffer injury as they had to sit further forward.

Raquel tells of breakdown

Former Coronation Street actress Sarah Lancashire has revealed how she suffered a 14-month nervous breakdown at the height of her fame as barmaid Raquel. "The breakdown was a time-bomb waiting to go off," she told TV Times.

Simone selects top influences

Singer Nina Simone is to present a six-week series from April 6 for Radio 2, it was announced yesterday. Simone, 67, a jazz, gospel, folk and blues artist over a half-century career, will select material which has meant the most to her from such artists as Frank Sinatra, Michael Jackson, Duke Ellington, Al Green, soprano Maria Callas and Stevie Wonder.

Jackpot rollover

The National Lottery jackpot will roll over to Wednesday as no-one picked the winning numbers of 7, 12, 37, 42, 46 and 49, and the bonus 9. Sixteen tickets matched five balls and the bonus number, picking up £147,083 each. One person won the Thunderball £250,000 prizewith numbers 4, 11, 14, 27 and 33. The Thunderball was 6.

webTitle: Girl dies after jump from a bus

fields.headline: Girl dies after jump from a bus
fields.trailText: A 16-year-old girl died after jumping from a moving double-decker bus which was being towed to a depot, a police spokesman said yesterday.
fields.body:
A 16-year-old girl died after jumping from a moving double-decker bus which was being towed to a depot, a police spokesman said yesterday.

The girl fell under the wheels of the bus as she and her friend jumped off on the ring road in Farnley, Leeds on Saturday night, West Yorkshire police said.

The bus had been picked up by a recovery vehicle and was being towed back to depot, the spokesman said.

The driver was unaware that the girls, both teenagers, had stayed on board.

The girl's friend jumped safely from the bus first, but when she followed she was pulled under the wheels, the spokesman said.

The girl, who is from Leeds, died in Leeds general infirmary. Her identity has not been released.

fields.headline: 'Zero tolerance' for beggars
fields.trailText: The government yesterday gave the Metropolitan police the go-ahead to pursue its promised policy of "zero tolerance" towards organised beggars operating on London's streets.
fields.body:
The government yesterday gave the Metropolitan police the go-ahead to pursue its promised policy of "zero tolerance" towards organised beggars operating on London's streets.

As Sir John Stevens, the Met's new commissioner, signalled his determination to tackle "quality of life" issues on the street, the home office minister, Paul Boateng, said that persistent, aggressive and even passive begging "can't be accepted".

"What we have got to do is back the police and the courts 100% when they make it clear this sort of conduct simply isn't tolerable," Mr Boateng told BBC TV's On the Record.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, backed that approach.

The Tory tabloids have become preoccupied with the number of east European beggars - especially, it is claimed, Romanian gypsies - who are operating in organised begging teams in London and other cities.

Last week the threatened imprisonment of one persistent woman beggar by a London magistrate was deftly woven into Gordon Brown's latest attempt to clamp down on the black economy - the "hidden" economy as Labour sensitively prefers to call it.

Yesterday Miss Widdecombe sought to distinguish economic migrants from genuine asylum seekers. She complained that in 1997 there were 29,000 asylum seekers compared to 71,000 plus a huge backlog today - because Mr Straw had sent out a '"soft touch" message.

fields.headline: Parents back gene therapy
fields.trailText: Most parents would let their children undergo gene therapy, even though they were unclear about the technique involved, according to a Mori poll commissioned by medical charity Action Research.
fields.body:
Most parents would let their children undergo gene therapy, even though they were unclear about the technique involved, according to a Mori poll commissioned by medical charity Action Research.

It showed 65% of adults were unclear about what gene cloning meant. But after the process was explained, 74% agreed gene therapy was acceptable if it was tightly controlled.

Gene cloning is the process of producing copies of a single gene. Gene therapy involves introducing the healthy gene into a patient to combat a genetic disease, such as cystic fibrosis.

In Scotland, 85% would let their child undergo gene therapy, compared with 74% in England, 73% in Wales and 62% in London. While 35% of adults understood gene cloning, 32% thought it referred to producing cloned animals such as Dolly the sheep.

Action Research's director of communications and marketing, John Grounds, said: "The results of our Mori poll are very encouraging.

"The lack of clear understanding was not really a surprise. There has been so much about GM foods and Dolly the sheep that people have got at best an incomplete understanding of what it is."

webTitle: Young rich owe wealth to internet

fields.headline: Young rich owe wealth to internet
fields.trailText: Internet tycoons dominate the lists of Britain's richest young millionaires, according to newspapers yesterday.
fields.body:
Internet tycoons dominate the lists of Britain's richest young millionaires, according to newspapers yesterday.

On the Observer's list, 19 of the richest 20 aged 30 and under are in e-commerce. On top is Jason Drummond, 30, with a £123m fortune from Virtual Internet, which registers domain names on the internet for companies to protect copyright and brand names.

Next is Robert Bonnier, 30, head of the freephone service Scoot.com, with £72m, then Jonathan Rowland, founder of the internet investment vehicle Jellyworks, on £40m.

Topping the Sunday Times list is the Earl of Iveagh, 30, head of the Guinness family, whose inheritance is put at £600m. Charles Nasser, 30, found of the internet provider ClaraNET, has £300m.

The richest woman on the list is Avneet Sahni, 29, worth £50m, who runs the VIP computer centre with her husband, Jatti. The youngest millionaire is the Welsh singer Charlotte Church, 14, worth £10m.

webTitle: Police check drug link in 'punishment killing'

fields.headline: Police check drug link in 'punishment killing'
fields.trailText: Police were last night investigating a possible drugs link with the murder of a man found bound and naked in an apparent punishment beating or interrogation.
fields.body:
Police were last night investigating a possible drugs link with the murder of a man found bound and naked in an apparent punishment beating or interrogation.

Michael Crago, 32, unemployed, was beaten to death in the lounge of his ransacked house in Bridgwater in Somerset. Earlier a neighbour had heard screams.

Yesterday Avon and Somerset police told a press conference a single piece of rope had been used to tie together Mr Crago's legs and bind his hands behind his neck. He died from a series of blows to the head, after being struck heavily about the body.

Detective chief inspector Ken Smout said it had all the signs of a punishment beating. "The attack was very vicious and it would not have been done like that without [people] targeting someone."

Police searching the house found a substance which was being tested last night by drugs officers. Mr Crago, was convicted last year for possessing cannabis and amphetamines and fined £100.

Mr Crago's brother and girlfriend, who did not live in the house, are helping inquiries.

Mr Smout said that his last known contact was with a friend by phone on Thursday night, when he had not seemed unduly concerned.

On Friday morning, a neighbour had said, sounds of shouting and screaming had come from the house. On Friday night the body was found by a friend. There was no sign of forced entry.

fields.headline: Nurses get power to prescribe
fields.trailText: New powers allowing nurses to prescribe drugs without a doctor's consent begin today to help speed up the treatment of chronic illnesses like asthma and diabetes, and minor injuries.
fields.body:
New powers allowing nurses to prescribe drugs without a doctor's consent begin today to help speed up the treatment of chronic illnesses like asthma and diabetes, and minor injuries.

The health minister, Lord Hunt, said the move marked a break down of barriers between health professionals, and would free doctors from writing prescriptions when specialist nurses were on hand.

Lord Hunt said: "For example, an asthma nurse treating a boy with asthma can give him a lung check-up and advise on his exercise and diet, but at present cannot write a prescription for an inhaler.

"Nurse prescribing is currently limited to district nurses and health visitors, working from a limited list of medicines including laxatives and pain killers. Extending the scope will free up doctors' time"

fields.headline: Pupils to face a 9-to-5 day
fields.standfirst:
Blunkett plans a more rigorous school regime

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Primary school pupils are to be given more rigorous preparation for their move to secondary school, and a nine-to-five school day when they get there, the government will announce this week.
fields.body:
Primary school pupils are to be given more rigorous preparation for their move to secondary school, and a nine-to-five school day when they get there, the government will announce this week.

The measures are among a package of controversial initiatives to raise standards in secondary schools, many through much closer collaboration with the primaries.

Ministers have been increasingly concerned about evidence that children's academic progress falls behind on transfer to secondary school, and want teachers from both sectors to work together to build on progress already made.

The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, is likely to fuel the debate about the growing emphasis on testing on Wednesday by saying that pupils who have done well in the key stage two national tests at 11 - in the final year of primary school - should immediately start preparing for the key stage three tests for 14-year-olds.

He wants the May to July period of year six (the final year at primary school) - after the tests in May - to be better used. He wants a more rigorous academic regime with a strong emphasis on literacy and numeracy. In addition, from this autumn, pupils who fail the key stage two tests will be given the chance of "catch-up" lessons.

In a speech to a conference organised by the Social Market Foundation thinktank, Mr Blunkett will announce that challenging literacy and numeracy frameworks for the first year of secondary school will be published shortly. Teaching packs will be sent to secondary schools next term, initially covering just maths.

Mr Blunkett also believes there is a strong case for a much longer secondary school day. Echoing the message delivered by the prime minister in a lecture at Oxford university late last year, Mr Blunkett will say that it is no longer acceptable for children to be sent home halfway through the afternoon. Instead, he wants them to stay until 5pm, taking part in music and sports activities and supervised homework and revision lessons.

The move would bring pupils at state schools into line with independent schools, which already have a much longer school day. Yesterday Mr Blunkett said the new approach involved a "learning day" rather than a traditional school day.

Pupils will be encouraged to take part in the government's summer school programme, which is being massively expanded this week. The idea is to encourage new secondary school pupils to spend time in their new school during the summer before starting in the autumn term. Mr Blunkett will announce that the number of summer schools is to be increased to 2,300, of which 500 will be devoted to "gifted and talented" children. Around 1,800 of the schools will concentrate on literacy and numeracy.

Mr Blunkett's speech will cause controversy because of the emphasis on children spending more time at school, and with a more rigorous programme for younger children. The teaching unions are unlikely to be happy, given their complaints that they already have a gruelling teaching workload. But Mr Blunkett also wants the new partnership to include a greater exchange of staff between primary and secondary schools.

A spokesman for the department for education and employment said yesterday: "David Blunkett is concerned that pupils fall back when they start at secondary school. Very often this is because secondary and primary schools in some cases don't talk to each other enough."

webTitle: Labour puts election plan on hold to win back faithful

fields.headline: Labour puts election plan on hold to win back faithful
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's plans to stage the next general election in May or June 2001 may have to be postponed until October because voters in Labour heartlands may need more time - and more spending on key public services - before their dwindling loyalty is rekindled.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's plans to stage the next general election in May or June 2001 may have to be postponed until October because voters in Labour heartlands may need more time - and more spending on key public services - before their dwindling loyalty is rekindled.

Though one minister has publicly claimed that Mr Blair has pencilled in May 3 next year for his bid to clinch an historic second term, others are starting to fear that Gordon Brown's spending timetable is too tight for voters to feel the full benefit by then.

New City figures today will offend both the tax-cutting right and the high-spending left. They say that taxes taxes as a whole - direct and indirect - are now £10.4bn a year higher - equal to 4p on basic income tax; and they confirm that health spending by 2002 will, as a share of GDP, be up only 0.4% on 1997.

Mr Brown has cancelled a visit to Merseyside today to concentrate on his fourth budget, barely a week away. But senior spending ministers are resigned to the fact that most of the extra public spending the chancellor has in mind will not surface until his second comprehensive spending review (CSR) in July.

That means it will not start flowing into the health, education, transport and housing budgets - all crucial to the way Labour voters view their government's record - until the financial year that starts in April 2001, weeks before the May 3 election date privately floated as Mr Blair's choice by one of the foreign office ministers, Keith Vaz.

This weekend a series of senior ministers, MPs and officials - including David Blunkett and Robin Cook - have signalled unhappiness with what Mr Vaz's foreign office colleague, Peter Hain, called "a bad fist at communicating" Labour's achievements.

That is a device politicians use for tactfully blaming the presentation instead of the source - in this case Mr Brown's fiscal austerity.

With the Conservative press demanding more tax cuts and Labour MPs urging more spending, the City accountants, PricewaterhouseCoopers, stirred the pot last night. It revealed that Mr Brown has increased the total tax burden as a proportion of GDP by 2.4%, which by 2001-2002 will amount to around £23bn. Only about half of this - or 1.1%- is by deliberate action, mostly on indirect taxes; the rest is thanks to a strong economy.

The treasury secretary, Andrew Smith, insisted that taxes would fall slightly overall, to 36.8%, not 37.7% as PWC claims. Either way the ambitious and politically sensitive Mr Brown is under pressure to ease his foot off the brake.

Amid growing concern about falling membership and low party morale in the party's heartlands, Mr Prescott - backed by colleagues in other big spending departments - is pinning his hopes on Mr Brown providing a big cash injection for job creation programmes in the March 21 budget.

Blairite loyalists like Fraser Kemp also also urging greater recognition for devolution in England, while at the close of Labour's Scottish conference yesterday, Jack McConnell, the Scottish Finance Minister, warned that Labour faces a decline in membership - down 3,000 in a year to 27,000 - and a severe cash shortage north of the border.

fields.headline: Soft focus
fields.trailText: The celebrity profile has always been a difficult form for television. This is because profiles depend for their balancing hostility on off-the-record quotes about the subject.
fields.body:
The celebrity profile has always been a difficult form for television. This is because profiles depend for their balancing hostility on off-the-record quotes about the subject.

Television has no way of accommodating non-attributable witnesses. But enemies are more willing to go on camera with their views and so TV profile series - such as BBC2's Reputations and Channel 4's Secret History - have tended to be retrospective.

The Unforgettable (Wednesday/Friday, 10.15pm, ITV) swings the camera round to look at figures from the medium's own history: beginning with the Richard Beckinsale and Larry Grayson.

Reputations and Secret Lives treated politicians, kings, writers and sporting heroes in a manner which could only be described as even-handed in the sense that both hands were bunched into fists. So it's rather surprising to discover that these showbusiness biographies find only talent and niceness.

Typical of the tone of these shows is the revelation from Don Warrington, who acted with Beckinsale and Leonard Rossiter in Rising Damp, that "Len really loved Richard". Beckinsale's widow, Judy Loe, reminisces about the difficulty of filming Rising Damp and Porridge simultaneously because one required long hair and the other short. The one sharp remark comes from director Stephen Frears, who had to remove Beckinsale from a film when he died before completing it, but knows when he watches that the actor is standing behind a door or is in a car.

In the Grayson film, it's as if a memo has been sent, forbidding reference to the comedian's sexuality. There is no attempt to establish if the campness of Grayson's act was a feint or a steer. It is possible that Grayson was essentially sexless and, even it he wasn't, it might be thought kindly in other circumstances to apply to the closet the comedian's famous catch-phrase: shut that door! But the relatives of some of those brutally exposed in other posthumous profile series must find themselves wishing that their loved ones had gone into showbusiness.

fields.headline: Oh, what a lovely war
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV
fields.trailText: Moral Combat - Nato At War (Sunday) unfolded with calm authority the ugly story of the Nato campaign in Kosovo, from its beginnings as a local guerrilla war through the stupendous bunglings of the diplomatic process to a bloody conclusion.
fields.body:
All too often, documentaries consist of little else than men with nasty ponytails riding around in the back of jeeps claiming that something interesting once happened on a drab piece of Turkish roadside. Either that, or the special effects team get so carried away with a new piece of software that we're left squinting through the hi-tech equivalent of Vaseline on the lens. So it's a surprise and a delight to find an unashamedly old-fashioned doc on BBC2 - one that lets the story speak for itself.

And what a story. Moral Combat - Nato At War (Sunday) unfolded with calm authority the ugly story of the Nato campaign in Kosovo, from its beginnings as a local guerrilla war through the stupendous bunglings of the diplomatic process to a bloody conclusion. Two hours is a long time in TV, particularly when there's no sex and precious few laughs, but Allan Little's film never flagged, never dipped into sentimentality and kept even the worst-informed viewer up to speed with a narrative of Byzantine complexity. To no one's surprise, the politicians emerged with egg all over their faces, confessing that they had no control over a situation that they pretended was a masterpiece of international co-operation. The Americans, among them Madeleine Albright, were politely evasive, stressing tactics over casualties; Tony Blair at least had the grace to admit that war is a messy business and that people will get hurt.

What seemed like a nightmare at the time appears as a monumental balls-up with the benefit of hindsight. Nightly bombing schedules were leaked by Nato officers to the Yugoslavian government; General Nebojsa Pavkovic, commander of the Yugoslav army in Kosovo, actually winked to an off-camera crony when describing his success in avoiding air strikes. At the end of the conflict, peace was brokered by a shady Swedish financier. It was all very Jack Higgins.

The most effective moments - deployed sparingly - came from footage captured by cameras in the nose-cones of Nato missiles as they showered over Kosovo. There can be no image more acute of the role of communications technology in modern warfare.

ITV's Sunday night drama Hero Of The Hour deployed a much cruder special effect in the looming form of Ross Kemp, fresh out of EastEnders, with a lot to prove. Dramas featuring ex-EastEnders are ten a penny these days - some of us are still hoping that Punk Mary will get the break she deserves, by the way - but even so, Kemp seemed more than most a big fish in a small pond. Would he have what it takes to break out of soap?

We needn't have worried, for he deftly sidestepped the issue by playing, basically, Grant in a funny hat. Richie Liddle was a security guard, and thus Kemp joins the ranks of ex-EastEnders who have gone straight into uniform (Nick Berry and Paul Nicholls as policemen, Michael French as a surgeon). He bravely foiled a warehouse burglary, got himself shot in the leg and then, in a moment of aberration, decided to nick the money himself. This lapse haunted him for the rest of the show, which lasted for another two hours, during which time Kemp looked alternately cross and confused. Range isn't something that you'd expect from a man who looked cross and confused for nearly ten years in Albert Square, but at least Kemp has a certain physical charisma. The rest of the cast, notably Maggie O'Neill as his justifiably fed-up wife, acted rings around the star as he groped towards some kind of personal peace. Sadly, this came at least half an hour too late, by which time audiences must surely have dropped off and thus missed the edifying sight of Kemp cuddling a baby that looked exactly like him - bald, wide-eyed and a bit dazed.

That child may have a glittering future with Derrick's Doubles, featured in ITV's The Lookalikes Agency (Saturday). This furnished the biggest laugh of the weekend as a procession of alleged dead ringers gave us their versions of the rich and famous. Elton John (a carpenter from Essex) was good enough to fool the denizens of Soho, but far more entertaining were the hopeless Leonardo DiCaprio and Richard Gere, who resembled their subjects only insofar as they were both male. A young man of the vampire type auditioned as the star of Saturday Night Fever and Pulp Fiction. "Hellooo-" he drawled in what might have been a Transylvanian accent. "Ah'm not the real Jawn Dravolda-" Day jobs never looked so attractive.

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Russell Crowe in Hammers Over The Anvil
fields.body:
Russell Crowe in Hammers Over The Anvil

Who? New Zealand-born actor, who made his name in slightly-dubious skinhead flick Romper Stomper before heading for Hollywood. He continued playing hardnuts - including a virtual reality serial killer in Virtuosity - until he landed the role of Bud White in LA Confidential. While still a hard case, Bud allowed Crowe to show his sensitive side, and he hasn't looked back since. Except off-screen, that is, where he's still playing the tough guy, getting involved in bar-room brawls in both Canada and Australia. Crowe plays a middle-aged scientist blowing the whistle on big, bad tobacco firms in his latest film, The Insider; away from the camera, however, he still smokes.

The role: East Driscoll, the manliest man in a small outback town in the1910s. He takes pleasure in all manner of butch Antipodean pursuits, like bare-back riding, taming wild horses and, um, chasing ostriches.

Best Line: When lady of the manor Grace McAlister (Charlotte Rampling) tries to come over all Lady Chatterley, she rides to East's place on a mare she wants impregnating. He look at the horse - and more specifically, the rider.

"Too old?" Grace enquires. "Not at all," East replies. "Not at all."

Cringe factor: Low. He really has no reason whatsoever to be embarrassed by the opening scenes of him skinny dipping with horses and then riding them naked in the river.

Other wannabes: None, but a lot of the other actors involved have never worked again. Draw your own conclusions.

Also not starring in: An episode of Australian TV comedy The Late Show, as Shirty, the Slightly Aggressive Bear, in 1991.

Hammers Over The Anvil (Ann Turner, 1991) Wednesday 15 March, 9.15pm, Carlton Cinema

fields.body:

Joseph Mitchell's account of Joe Gould's Secret (9.45am, Radio 4) is a memorable study of a well-born eccentric who lived on the city's streets, supposedly compiling an Oral History of Our Times. One gifted bird can carry out simple mental arithmetic and identify 100 separate objects.

fields.trailText: Vic Reeves and Bob Mortimer are best known for sending up existing television genres. Their new series, Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased), is closer to straight drama. Will they cope?
fields.body:
The comedians Hale & Pace once dreamed up a scheme to star in a TV series based on Reginald Hill's Dalziel and Pascoe novels. But they met authorial disapproval and the stories were eventually performed by the more conventional acting duo of Warren Clarke and Colin Buchanan.

Little in the history of comedy led a television critic to expect to make a comparison between Hale & Pace and another comedy double-act - Reeves and Mortimer - but the latter now make the kind of switch from comedy to drama at which the former failed. Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased) (Saturday, 8.55pm, BBC1) is a remake of the 1970 series about a supernatural sleuth, with Vic Reeves and Bob Mortimer in the roles originally played by Mike Pratt and Kenneth Cope.

The two main questions arising from this enterprise might be summarised as Subversion and Submersion. Reeves and Mortimer are celebrated for sending up formats - most notably the game show in their career-making hit Shooting Stars - so will this be a spoof Saturday night crime show or a real one? And - given that the main difference between comic acts and acting is the extent to which the performer changes role - to what extent will Reeves and Mortimer bother to disguise their lucrative and popular personalities?

On the first test, Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased) is a parody in the sense that it plays with existing images which will be in the minds of older viewers at least but is far closer to a conventional detective series than Shooting Stars is to a game-show. Genuine clues lead to a proper plot, however ludicrous. But it's not as if Reeves and Mortimer have decided to cast themselves as Morse and Lewis. Based on an impossible proposition - life after death in a white suit in which only your old business partner can see you - this series was never a straight police procedural anyway.

Producer-writer Charlie Higson has notionally updated the dramas to the present - there's a script line about the Oprah Winfrey show and Hopkirk's ghost first shows up by ambushing a PlayStation game - but there's still a very 60s feel to Randall and Hopkirk's detective agency, with its name painted on a glass door and jobs which involve taking pictures of adulterers with a camera rather than the electronic surveillance and cyber-hacking which sleuthing more probably involves today. The smart karate skills of Emilia Fox as the duo's sidekick Jeannie also feel very Avengers.

The special effects - the apparitions and vanishings of Hopkirk when he becomes the agency's spectral consultant - would probably also have worked better with viewers just getting used to television than it will for eyes long widened by computer graphics.

The most modern aspect of the opening episode is its satire on contemporary art. The leading suspect in Randall and Hopkirk's first case is a poseur installationist called Gordon Stylus, whose expensively sold works include a sculpture of his own skull moulded from frozen urine and a cast of his own face in gold which he narcissistically kisses. The main clue to how a murder occurred is seen during a Stylus installation. The episode ends with a visual joke which depends on a knowledge of Damien Hirst's bifurcated taxidermy.

It's in these elements that the series seems most to show the influence of Reeves, a former art student who has published a book of his own images. And the art-scene sequences show that Reeves and Mortimer are making few concessions in their attempt to move from BBC2 cult status to BBC 1 peak-time.

Although run by the same organisation, the BBC's television channels are often artistically North and South Korea. Very few talents have lived successfully on both sides. In attempting to cross the border, performers make a crucial decision about whether to change their regime. Reeves and Mortimer have not obviously altered their ideology and this must make the series a gamble. The kind of following which makes you a hero on BBC2 alarms the contract department on the other side.

Guilty of only mild Subversion, do the comedians achieve Submersion? Although comics in straight roles is now the default option for producers, other examples - Alan Davies in Jonathan Creek, Dylan Moran in How Do You Want Me? - were relative unknowns without an existing profile to overcome. Reeves and Mortimer have - in both senses - more to lose.

Where the pairing works best is the weight of affinity they bring. Unlike actors playing buddies who might meet for the first time at the read-through, they feel on screen like two people who have worked together for years, because they have. There is an emotional force to the scenes of Hopkirk's funeral which comes from the same source and may also be helped by the fact that (according to newspaper reports) Emilia Fox and Reeves were an item during filming. And in one exchange of dialogue - as Hopkirk points out the bad rhymes in an ancient verse about ghosts - Reeves and Mortimer begin to riff and improvise as they might on other shows.

Elsewhere - like a cavalier county batsman who feels pressured to defend at Test level - they perhaps play it too straight. Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased) has not quite enough subversion and a little too much submersion. Jonathan Creek did comedy-drama better and it was entirely original, not a 70s retread.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Hound Of The Baskervilles
fields.body:
The Hound Of The Baskervilles

(Sidney Lanfield, 1939)

5.30pm, Sky Cinema

Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce make their first appearances in this best-known of Conan Doyle's adventures. The pair are off to the Cornish moors to collar the ghastly hound that's been eating the unfortunate Baskerville clan. Suspenseful to the end, this is the one that ends with addict Holmes calling for his needle.

Killer's Kiss

(Stanley Kubrick, 1955)

6pm, FilmFour

The late Kubrick's second feature is a modest but poignant melodrama, shot on location in New York with $75,000 provided by friends and family. Jamie Smith is a recently KO'd boxer rescuing dance hostess Irene Kane from her vicious boyfriend-come-boss Frank Silvera: a good deed that lands them both in trouble. A familiar thriller plot, atmospherically shot in monochrome, but with little to hint at the grand visions to come.

Reach The Rock

(John Hughes, 1998)

8pm, Sky MovieMax

An interesting experiment from former teen obsessive Hughes, albeit one that fails comprehensively. Smalltown drifter smashes window. Local cop, who blames drifter for death of nephew, hauls him to station. While making phonecall, drifter spots keys to cell in open drawer... Set during one night and with a cast of five, this is a curious mish-mash of Ferris Bueller, Fargo and The Sermon On The Mount, and no one is safe from Hughes' proselytising: small-minded police, posh girlfriends, the system. Refreshingly, most of the wrath is directed at the loser hero.

Wag The Dog

(Barry Levinson, 1998)

10.10pm, Sky Premier

When the president's election campaign is about to collapse due to some hanky-panky, a shady consultant, Robert De Niro's Conrad Brean, is called in. He calls on Hollywood producer Stanley Motss to fake a war against Albania, distracting media attention till polling day. It's too shambolic but it's performed with vaudevillian glee

fields.headline: Dobson beards image makers
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The crumpled corduroy suit may not be ideal, but a smooth chin, trimmed sideburns and perhaps a whiff of cologne represent the image the Labour party would prefer its candidate for London mayor to present.
fields.body:
The crumpled corduroy suit may not be ideal, but a smooth chin, trimmed sideburns and perhaps a whiff of cologne represent the image the Labour party would prefer its candidate for London mayor to present.

Frank Dobson yesterday said he told the party's image makers to "get stuffed" when they asked him to revert to the barefaced chic of his younger days to increase his appeal to voters in the mayoral election.

Thrusting out his bristles in defiance, the former health secretary told GMTV's Sunday programme with Alastair Stewart that the electorate should consider his policies rather than his facial furniture.

"I told them to get stuffed because, quite frankly, I'm not in the image business. With me, what you see is what you get. If you don't like what you see, don't vote for me but listen to what I've got to say."

Labour insiders later confirmed that Mr Dobson had been asked to lose his beard.

One source was reported as saying: "People were discussing that if Frank wins [the Labour nomination] do we need to change anything about the way he presents himself, and a few people said that he really needed to jazz himself up by shaving off his beard."

fields.headline: Janet Reed
fields.standfirst: Ballerina of classical skill enhanced by a gift for comedy
fields.trailText: Ballerina of classical skill enhanced by a gift for comedy
fields.body:
Janet Reed, who has died in Seattle at the age of 83, was an American ballerina who combined a sure classical technique with a gift for comedy and an adorable stage personality. That personality was to irradiate two early ballets by Jerome Robbins for Ballet Theater: Fancy Free (1944), his first ballet and collaboration with Leonard Bernstein (which was to inspire the musical On The Town), in which she danced the tender pas de deux with the gentlest of the three sailors on exuberant shore leave in Manhattan; and the happy, youthful Interplay, to music by Morton Gould. But her career in the US encompassed a great variety of roles with different companies and in works by Willam and Lew Christensen, Balanchine, Tudor, Michael Kidd, and Agnes de Mille.

Born in Oregon, Janet Reed had early training with Willam Christensen and danced with his San Francisco Ballet from 1937-41. She had the distinction of being one of the ballerinas in Swan Lake when Christensen staged the first full-length version of the ballet in 1940. Subsequently, she danced with Eugene Loring's Dance Players in 1942 and, in the same year, joined Ballet Theater.

She stayed there until 1949 when, at the invitation of George Balanchine, she joined New York City Ballet. With Ballet Theater, in addition to the Robbins ballets, she danced important roles in Loring's Billy the Kid, Tudor's Gala performance (the coquettish French ballerina), and De Mille's bawdy Tally-Ho!

With New York City Ballet, Balanchine soon cast her in his signature ballets, such as Serenade and Symphony in C, and in 1949 created for her the final, joyous section of his Chabrier ballet, Bourrée le Fantasque.

He also used her in Western Symphony (1954) which he described as "a ballet without a story in an unmistakably native American idiom". The blue-eyed, red-haired Janet Reed was ideally cast; no matter how successful in classic and dramatic roles, she remained essentially and unequivocally an American "girl next door".

After marriage and bringing up a family (she leaves a son and a daughter), Reed returned to NYCB as ballet mistress and taught for several colleges before moving to Seattle, where she also staged dance for the Seattle Opera. As well as this work, Janet Reed also appeared on Broadway, with Harold Lang and Nancy Walker, in the play about ballet dancers, Look Ma, I'm Dancin'!, directed by George Abbott.

 Janet Reed, dancer, born September 1916; died February 28 2000

fields.headline: Janis Pearson
fields.standfirst: Secretary of the Scott Trust and its ambassador to Newspapers in Education
fields.trailText: Secretary of the Scott Trust and its ambassador to Newspapers in Education
fields.body:
Janis Pearson, who has died aged 49, was secretary of the Scott Trust, the body which owns the Guardian, for more than 20 years, making her the longest-serving attender at trust meetings.

She worked to three chairmen, beginning with Richard Scott, continuing with Alastair Hetherington, and remaining ever present since Hetherington's retirement in 1990. A discreet and reliable secretary, she was aware of trustees' foibles, generous to their grammar and a great expediter of their business.

Born in Paisley and educated at John Neilson high school, there was a Scottish precision about her. She was also a sweet and calming presence, driven by a desire to be the most loyal and efficient servant of the trust.But she had another, arguably more important, life, which began some years after she joined the Manchester Evening News in 1975.

In 1988, she moved to work for the new editor of the Manchester Evening News, Michael Unger, and it was from this base that she developed a second career - as the papers' representative on the nationwide programme, Newspapers in Education. This was devoted to encouraging the reading of newspapers in schools. Helen regularly visited schools, talked to pupils, gave conducted tours of the Evening News and Guardian offices in Manchester, and spoke at regional conferences on a subject she understood better than any editor.

Janis had put up a mighty fight against cancer for some time. She will be grievously missed by her colleagues, whose sometimes torrid and invariably lengthy meetings she managed to make perfect sense of. She leaves her husband, Alan Sidebottom.

 Janis Pearson, secretary of the Scott Trust, born November 4 1951; died March 11 2000

fields.headline: George Koltanowski
fields.standfirst: Blindfold chess champion whose rare talent set world records
fields.trailText: Blindfold chess champion whose rare talent set world records
fields.body:
George Koltanowski, who has died aged 96, set world chess records for blindfold play. He was the world's best at simultaneous blindfold chess, which requires a player to make moves from memory while his opponents move normally. His daily article in the San Francisco Chronicle ran for 52 years.

Born in Antwerp, Koltanowski took up chess seriously at 14, and was Belgian champion within three years. His family expected him to follow his father as a diamond cutter, but he opted for chess full time and discovered his rare talent. In 1930, he broke Richard Reti's world record by playing 30 games simultaneously, winning 20 and drawing 10 in 13 hours. He surpassed this on September 20 1937 in Edinburgh with 24 wins, 10 draws and no defeats in 13.5 hours, still recognised by the Guinness Book of Records. During the second world war Koltanowski emigrated to the US, where he met his wife Leah on a blind date, settled in San Francisco and began his daily column.

He became a popular showman, performing his special blindfold Knight's Tour in which the knight tours the chess board visiting each of the 64 squares once only. In Koltanowski's version, his audience allocated telephone numbers, addresses and names to each square. The master would memorise the board for two minutes, then with his back to it, he asked for a starting square for the knight. Then he confidently announced: "I go from New York 4032705 to John Roberts to Radish to Gorbachev, to Los Angeles 5585983" as his knight hopped around.

He continued to perform his blindfold show into his late eighties. Koltanowski attributed his skill to study ing memory games during childhood illness, and later to nightly practice on an empty chessboard painted on his bedroom ceiling. As his fame spread, he wrote books, hosted a chess television show, set up youth programmes and became president of the US Chess Federation.

He was a warm, friendly man with anecdotes and a folksy maxim. "Pawns are like buttons," he liked to say. "Lose too many and your pants fall down."

Koltanowski downplayed his ability in normal sighted chess, but in the 1930s he competed several times at Hastings, where one year he had much the better of a draw with the world number one, Alexander Alekhine. On his single appearance for the US team in the chess Olympiad in Helsinki in 1952, he drew with the formidable Russian grand master Alexander Kotov, who was then in peak form. He was one of three founder members inducted into the US chess hall of fame, with Paul Morphy, the first great US champion, and Bobby Fischer. His wife Leah, 93, survives him.

 George Koltanowski, chess player, born September 17 1903; died February 5 2000

fields.headline: Herbert Tayler
fields.standfirst: Architect who designed public housing with people and land in mind
fields.trailText: Architect who designed public housing with people and land in mind
fields.body:
Between 1945 and 1973 Herbert Tayler, who has died aged 87, and David Green designed 700 houses and flats around Loddon in South Norfolk. It was housing of distinction: individual buildings were patterned, while the profile of the whole matched the landscape.

The only permanent homes built by the government during the second world war were for farmworkers; in 1945, many rural areas lacked running water and electric lighting. Loddon rural district council had recognised the need for decent homes to encourage men to stay on the land, and in the late 1930s began acquiring land. When building became possible again in 1945, it needed an architect, and chose Tayler and Green.

Herbert Tayler was born in Java, to a Scottish father and Dutch mother, whose strong personality and large family guided his sensibilities towards an appreciation of north European culture. At Shrewsbury school a kindly art teacher suggested he try architecture. He entered the Architectural Association in 1929, and his student drawings give a unique insight into architectural training at a pivotal period between neo-classicism and modernism. Tayler's gloriously undogmatic approach to stylistic detail may have been determined by the AA's equivocal attitude to the style wars.

In 1938 Tayler and Green were commissioned to design a house in Highgate for the Punch cartoonist Roger Pettiward (Paul Crum). The Studio is a sophisticated first work, one of the first houses to react against concrete construction in favour of a mature modernism. With its strip windows and circular staircase drum, its influences are clearly those of Dutch and German modernism, yet it was built of brick - rendered a careful shade of terracotta - and its windows, specially imported from Switzerland, were timber. The same mix of cool styling and natural materials informed the flat in Kensington that Tayler and Green fitted out for themselves.

Where this style might have led but for the war is unclear. Instead, the war office sent them to Green's native Lowestoft, where his father had been an architect, and to a modest practice designing bank extensions, offices and a few private houses, in addition to the public housing that was their mainstay.

Working in a given area was the secret of Loddon's success. By concentrating his houses and bungalows into long, low terraces, Tayler respected the contours of the landscape. While Green negotiated with the councillors and acted as services engineer, Tayler devised a complex sequence of house plans and facades.

Tayler's first terraces at Windmill Green, Ditchingham (1946-8), extensively featured in the 1949 Housing Manual, were reminiscent of simple European models such as Ernst May's Frankfurt housing, which Green had seen at first hand.

From early colourwashing in pinks and blues he developed a rich palette, ranging from cream to black, and as better bricks became available his patterning ran riot, with chequerboard diamond shapes, textures of contrasting raised headers, curly bargeboards, flints and broken bottles. Large blue brick dates in the end gables were a characterful signature on the buildings.

These ingredients, except the bottle ends, were to be found in the vernacular architecture of the locality, but in Tayler's hands they evolved into a language that still gives distinction to the Loddon area. Asked why he moved away from the simple finishes of his pre-war work, Tayler replied that "people like patterns", and he relished the pleasure the local bricklayers had in creating them. These houses are set to be his memorial.

David Green died in October 1998; with Tayler's death we have lost a sharp wit and perceptive commentator on the architectural world of the 1930s and 1950s.

Loddon rural district council had recognised the need for decent homes to encourage men to stay on the land, and in the late 1930s began acquiring land. webTitle: Swiss use ballot box to bar new citizens

fields.headline: Swiss use ballot box to bar new citizens
fields.trailText: The Avramovic family's application for Swiss citizenship satisfied all the objective criteria set out by the authorities in their adopted hometown of Emmen.
fields.body:
The Avramovic family's application for Swiss citizenship satisfied all the objective criteria set out by the authorities in their adopted hometown of Emmen.

The parents have lived in Switzerland for more than 12 years, have no criminal record, speak Swiss-German dialect and hold steady jobs with a local engineering firm. Their two sons were born and educated in Switzerland and play for the local football team.

But when the Yugoslav couple's bid for Swiss passports was submitted to a local referendum yesterday, along with that of 52 other applicants, their neighbours in the industrial town said no.

Armed with a brochure with the address, photograph, CV and tax details of the 56 applicants, Emmen's electorate - on a 54% turnout - accepted only eight of them, all Italians.

Nonetheless, the Avramovics and the others, mainly Yugoslavs, are still legally entitled to stay in Switzerland with their existing work permit. The exercise appears to be little more than an outlet for fear and prejudice.

The result also confirmed a trend that emerged last year in neighbouring regions, where only EU nationals gained widespread acceptance.

Under pressure from the rightwing Swiss People's party, the practice of asking the local electorate to pick new citizens has slowly been gaining ground in central Switzerland over the past two years.

Emmen's result indicates that the process is institutionalising xenophobia.

While it is limited to only a few dozen nationality applications every year, the People's party wants to expand the process to major cities such as Zurich and Berne - to the alarm of anti-racism groups.

Switzerland's unique system of direct democracy is coveted, and reactions from opponents of the People's party have been muted.

Even the official racism watchdog is waiting for the results of a comparative study of the country's complex array of local citizenship procedures.

"We don't know at all if there's a link between democratic choice and racial discrimination," Boël Sambuc, the vice-president of the Federal Commission against Racism, said. "But this method implies that people judge you on something that's inherent, your origin - not your individual behaviour. So we have to ask about the limits of direct democracy."

In 1999 20,363 people were granted Swiss citizenship.

With some towns and cantons introducing voting rights for foreigners, they may end up voting for themselves if the referendum on citizenship is extended.

webTitle: Japan's police cars under cult influence

fields.headline: Japan's police cars under cult influence
fields.trailText: Japanese police were embarrassed at the weekend by revelations that they sub-contracted the Aum Shinrikyo doomsday cult to write software for supposedly secret operations.
fields.body:
Japanese police were embarrassed at the weekend by revelations that they sub-contracted the Aum Shinrikyo doomsday cult to write software for supposedly secret operations.

As a result of this glaring breach of security, the Supreme Truth cult - public enemy number one since it killed 12 people and injured thousands of others in a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo underground in 1995 - gained access to classified information and earned 2m yen (£11,950) from the police.

It is the latest evidence of the ease with which computer companies linked to Aum have penetrated the top echelons of the Japanese government, including the defence agency, as well as many of the country's biggest companies and academic institutions.

Last month the defence force, which controls one of the world's most powerful military arsenals, had to suspend part of its computer network after discovering that the Aum firm was one of the installation sub-contractors.

According to the Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper, the metropolitan police department contracted IBM Japan to set up a computer system to manage its patrol cars, some of which were likely to have been involved in monitoring the cult.

Part of this job was sub-contracted through a complex series of channels to Vainqueur, a software firm affiliated to Aum, for about 2m yen.

Neither IBM nor the police were aware of the identity of their software provider until a month before the new system was to go into operation in early 1998, by which time the cult had already seen classified data on the deployment of 115 police vehicles, including unmarked cars.

In a frantic effort to minimise the damage, police took some of the cars out of use and changed the licence plates on others.

The revelations represent a blow to the police, whose previously strong public image has taken a hammering in recent weeks with revelations of drug-taking, cover-ups and negligence.

But they are not alone in providing funds and secret information to Vainqueur.

It has also emerged that cult members worked on computer systems at the construction, education and telecommunications ministries, as well as at key corporations such as NTT, Kiyo Bank and the East Japan Railway.

In recent raids of cult facilities, inspectors have found a database with information on thousands of officials at Japanese corporations.

Police suspect that the cult's computer companies stole this and other data.

Neither Aum or the police have commented on the latest revelations.

The 2,000-member cult has recently enacted a series of reforms, including changing its name to Aleph and disavowing the teachings of its guru, Shoko Asahara, in an effort to counter a police crackdown and growing public pressure for the cult to disband.
