fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Neutrals put Al Gore in the lead
fields.body:
Neutrals put Al Gore in the lead

An opinion poll published yesterday showed that, for the first time in the US presidential campaign, the Democratic contender, Vice-President Al Gore, has caught up with - and overtaken - the Republican frontrunner, George W Bush, by wooing independent voters.

The poll, published by the Washington Post and the ABC television network, showed Mr Gore leading Mr Bush by 48% to 45% among registered voters. The lead is no larger than the poll's margin of error, so the poll was declared a dead heat.

But for Mr Gore, the survey shows a dramatic improvement in popularity since last year, when Mr Bush had a double-digit lead. It suggested he benefited more than Mr Bush from the withdrawal of two other presidential hopefuls last week.

Mr Gore inherited supporters of his Democratic challenger, Bill Bradley, and has won over a substantial share of independents who backed the Republican reformist candidate, John McCain. In December only a third of registered independents supported Mr Gore. Yesterday's poll showed he now has the backing of half. Reuters, Washington

Six pilgrims die in crush at Mecca

At least six pilgrims have been crushed to death while performing Muslim rites as part of the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, officials said yesterday.

Two Jordanian men in their 60s were killed on Wednesday and a Jordanian woman, also in her 60s, was crushed on Friday in the crowd of people at the Grand Mosque in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, an official said.

The official, who is leading the Jordanian delegation to the hajj, or annual Muslim pilgrimage, spoke on condition of anonymity.

Youssef Salameh, head of the Palestinian hajj delegation, said three elderly Palestinian women were also crushed on Friday at the mosque.

Safety is a key issue during the hajj owing to the immense overcrowding. About 2.1m pilgrims are expected in Mecca this week for the hajj, which all Muslims are expected to perform at least once in their lifetime. AP, Riyadh

Starvation threatens Mongolia

Mongolian herders will face hunger by May as their livestock die off after the harshest winter for 30 years, the United Nations said yesterday.

"The starvation is going to come, and it is going to be a long-term thing," said Syann Williams, coordinator for the UN Disaster Management Team in Mongolia.

"It is a creeping disaster that will affect the entire country. It is serious," she said after a team report released on Saturday called for urgent relief.

The landlocked country suffered its worst drought in 60 years last summer, followed by a harsh winter. Huge losses of livestock have directly affected 500,000 people, 20% of Mongolia's population, the report said, adding: "The famine will continue for at least the next 12 months."

Mounting livestock deaths in the coming months are expected to add to the problems of the herding population, which has already seen 1.5m animals perish owing to insufficient fodder, it said. Many herders have lost almost all their animals - the only source of food, transport, heating materials, purchasing power and access to medical services and children's education.

The report recommended immediate shipment of animal fodder, food supplements and veterinary medicines. Reuters, Ulan Bator

Russian rocket fails to launch

A Russian space launch ended in failure yesterday, sending its US payload plunging towards earth, a spokesman for Russian mission control said.

Interfax news agency said the payload was a communications satellite built by the US firm Hughes.

Mission control said the Zenit-3 SL rocket, launched from a ship at the equator, failed 467 seconds into its flight. The spokesman initially said it was a Ukrainian rocket carrying a Ukrainian payload but later said it was American. Reuters, Moscow

Sharif wife accused of treason

Police have filed a complaint against the wife of Pakistan's deposed prime minister Nawaz Sharif, accusing her of treason after she criticised the military government that toppled her husband, authorities said yesterday.

Khulsoom Sharif and several leaders of her husband's Pakistan Muslim League are accused of inciting people against the state in speeches in Hyderabad last week.

Under Pakistan's legal system, a police complaint is the initial step before formal charges are filed. Mrs Sharif said she had spoken out against the October 12 army coup that ousted her husband.

"Now they have gone to the extent of framing a woman like me on treason charges," she said. "I have come out of the house for democracy and to save the life of my husband.

Mr Sharif, his brother and five aides are on trial on hijacking, treason, kidnapping and attempted murder charges. Reuters, Karachi

fields.headline: No: 1593 Crash test dummy
fields.body:
Age: 52

Appearance: Mute, expressionless, plastic humanoid.

A career move to presenting the Big Breakfast beckons. At 52? I think not. He's no stranger to the celebrity lifestyle, though, having appeared in TV ads and pop videos.

I bet it wasn't always fast cars, fast women and fastened seatbelts, though. Too right. Our hero started life after world war two as an ejector-seat tester in the US Air Force. Previously, they'd rather recklessly used human guinea pigs. But a number of these "became disabled", according to officials.

So they opted for an artificial alternative. Precisely. But then an eagle-eyed army colonel noticed that more airmen were pranging their cars on the way to the airfield than were crashing the planes themselves, so the focus of research switched.

Thus saving countless lives and simultaneously providing a name for the best rock band to come out of Canada since, um, since . . . Well, almost. But it turns out that the dummy's designers only really ever focused on adult male passengers, and a Channel 4 documentary, screened tonight, claims this oversight may have cost the lives of numerous women and children. Despite all sorts of ingenious experiments - anaesthetised pigs were swung through the air against hard surfaces, men were dropped down lift-shafts and body parts slammed against walls - it never occurred to them to make a female dummy.

Didn't they use children's corpses, though? You're referring, perhaps, to reports that the Renault Clio was tested on child cadavers. Public opinion was outraged, though Papa and Nicole's reactions are lost to history.

Perks of the job: Company car (lots of them).

Downsides: Sometimes, it's like banging your head against a brick wall.

And does the future look bright?

No. The dummies in use today cost up to £120,000 a shot - they're full of sophisticated electronic monitoring equipment - and computer-simulated crashes are likely to render them has-beens pretty soon.

Least likely to say: "Hello? Recruitment consultants? I'm looking for something a bit more challenging."

Most likely to say: Nothing.

fields.headline: Never mind the ballots
fields.standfirst: Carnival time as Spain goes to polls
fields.trailText: Spaniards appeared last night to have re-elected their conservative prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, for a second term.
fields.body:
Spaniards appeared last night to have re-elected their conservative prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, for a second term.

But the 5% lead given him in exit polls suggested he had failed to win an absolute majority.

If the exit polls, released by television stations immediately after voting ended, are correct, then Mr Aznar's Popular party will take between 168 and 173 seats. That is more than the 156 his party held in the last legislature, but not enough for a majority in the 350-seat parliament.

That would leave the balance of power with regional parties - but Mr Aznar might be able to reach a deal with one of the smaller ones rather than the powerful Catalan nationalists who backed his first administration.

The polls predicted the Socialists would win between 131 and 136 seats, down from the 141 they held in the last parliament.

Failure by the Socialists to agree on fielding joint candidates with their Communist allies is likely to mean that their percentage of votes is not reflected in the number of seats they win. The polls gave the Communist-led United Left 12 to 13 seats, with a loss of half their votes compared to the last election in 1996.

Mr Aznar had urged voters not to jeopardise the country's economic success by opting for a leftwing alliance between the Socialists and Communists.

The Socialist leader Joaquin Almunia, 51, accused the government of practising "crony capitalism" which has enriched a few personal friends of the prime minister but done little for the population as a whole.

Mr Aznar, 47, a former tax inspector once ridiculed as too dull to last in office, heads one of the few conservative governments in the European Union.

He cast his vote in Madrid shortly after polls opened, telling voters: "Have a nice election day."

Mr Almunia, speaking at his Madrid polling station, called for a large turnout, something that some political analysts said could favour his centre-left party.

Spain's 34m voters were choosing their eighth government since democracy was restored after the death of the fascist dictator Francisco Franco in 1975.

The threat of Basque terrorist violence has loomed over the election.

On Saturday evening, youths linked to the Basque separatist group ETA threw petrol bombs at a government tax office in the coastal resort of San Sebastian. They also poured glue into the locks of several polling stations.

ETA's political wing, Herri Batasuna, boycotted the elections in protest at the government's refusal to contemplate independence for the Basque country.

But election day passed more peacefully in the Basque country - where a special deployment of 3,000 police guarded polling stations - than in some other parts of Spain.

In Seville petrol bombs were thrown at the Andalusian regional party's headquarters.

In the Canary island of Tenerife, where voting coincided with the end of the carnival, some voters were turned away after they appeared at polling stations drunk and wearing fancy dress.

webTitle: Motorcycle gunmen hit top Iranian reformist

fields.headline: Motorcycle gunmen hit top Iranian reformist
fields.trailText: The mastermind behind the reformers' victory in Iran's parliamentary polls last month was shot in the face at close range yesterday and critically injured in what appeared to be an ominous plot for revenge by conservative political rivals.
fields.body:
The mastermind behind the reformers' victory in Iran's parliamentary polls last month was shot in the face at close range yesterday and critically injured in what appeared to be an ominous plot for revenge by conservative political rivals.

Saeed Hajjarian, an adviser to the Iranian president, Mohammed Khatami, and the editor of an outspoken progressive daily newspaper, was gunned down by a motorcycle tandem passenger as he approached Tehran's city council building just before 9am local time.

"The gunman aimed his gun at Hajjarian's temple but because his hand was shaking, the first bullet struck him in the face," the city council member Mahmoud Alizadeh-Tabatabaei told the state news agency Irna.

The two assailants then fled on the 1,000cc motorcycle - a calibre only police and security personnel are permitted to own. The motorcycle has led investigators to speculate that the attackers were from the intelligence ministry or the Islamic Revolutionary Guards, both institutions dominated by conservatives who are fighting a national struggle with the reformist movement.

Another indication that the shooting may have been part of a wider plot was that the police guarding the city council building, who were armed with submachine guns, failed to react to the assassins, according to witnesses.

Mr Hajjarian, 46, was in critical condition last night, suffering from swelling in the brain and respiratory problems, doctors said. "One bullet entered through his left cheek and remains lodged at the back of his neck," said Mohammed Reza Zafarqandi, head of the Sina hospital emergency team.

The gangland-style shooting prompted the government to declare a high alert. Iran's top security body, the supreme national security council, had an emergency session last night.

President Khatami condemned the attack. "Because the terrorists know they are hated by the people and have no place among the people, they carry out such actions," he said in his native Yazd province. "The enemies of freedom wrongly believe that they can attain their goals by assassinating a pious intellectual who was serving the nation."

As the country expressed shock at the attack, suspicion was rife that it was carried out by hardliners; Mr Hajjarian, a former deputy minister of the intelligence service, had received numerous written death threats in recent months, according to his friends.

The newspaper he edits, Sobh-e Emrouz, has led a campaign to expose rogue agents within the intelligence service who murdered intellectuals in 1998. Mr Hajjarian was also blamed by the conservatives for the reformists' victory in the parliamentary polls of February 18.

Since then, reformers have feared reprisals by their conservative rivals. "Those who chose Hajjarian to be their assassination target knew they would create a crisis in the country by doing so," said the head of the security council's secretariat, Ali Rabiei.

Even if Mr Hajjarian survives, the attack is likely to spark a political crisis. President Khatami will be likely to come under pressure to crack down on extremists opposed to his government. The extremists, who belong to groups such as the basij, an Islamic militia, and the Ansar-e Hizbullah, have partisans within the police and intelligence service.

Such extremists have been at the centre of two national crises in the past two years - the Tehran university dormitory beatings in which more than 200 students were injured in July, and the assassination of four intellectuals in 1998 - yet Mr Khatami's government has failed to implement an official policy to bring them to heel.

"The security institutions in our country over the past 21 years have been formed in such a way that different cells exist within them," said Saeed Laylaz, a political commentator. "We will face a political and economic mafia in Iran which consists of the former members of such institutions."

webTitle: Death toll climbs to 82 in Ukraine mine disaster

fields.headline: Death toll climbs to 82 in Ukraine mine disaster
fields.trailText: Hundreds of grieving relatives gathered at a pithead in eastern Ukraine yesterday to mourn the victims of Europe's worst mine disaster in 20 years as the death toll from the Barakova mine tragedy rose to 82.
fields.body:
Hundreds of grieving relatives gathered at a pithead in eastern Ukraine yesterday to mourn the victims of Europe's worst mine disaster in 20 years as the death toll from the Barakova mine tragedy rose to 82.

The president of Ukraine, Leonid Kuchma, cancelled a foreign trip as a government inquiry was launched into the cause of the explosion more than 610 metres (2,000ft) below ground, believed to have been sparked by a lethal mix of coal dust and methane gas.

The death toll made Saturday's Barakova mine disaster in the small town of Sukhodolsk the worst since 84 miners were killed in a colliery explosion in 1980, also in Ukraine, which was then part of the Soviet Union.

Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the mining industry in the Donbass region of eastern Ukraine has gone into steep decline, making the the region the most dangerous in Europe for a miner.

In a region that now presents a bleak picture of destitution, 297 miners were killed last year, and 360 in 1998. The Barakova disaster brought the death toll in Ukraine's mining industry to more than 120 in the first 10 weeks of the year. Experts have calculated that five miners die in Ukraine for every million tonnes of coal extracted.

The Donbass coal industry employs more than half a million people at more than 200 pits, which are starved of investment. Miners go unpaid for months and valuable materials are routinely pilfered. Safety rules are generally flouted and management knowingly exposes employees to lethal risks to pocket profits.

"Disasters happen every day here," said an EU official who is advising the Ukrainian government on how to restructure its coal industry. "Carelessness is the most common cause of accidents."

At the Barakova mine about 200 miners staged an underground strike last year to demand their wages. Several threatened to commit suicide, and when they surfaced many bore self-inflicted knife wounds, marks of desperation.

The mother of one dead miner told journalists at the pithead yesterday that her husband had died previously in the same mine. "May this mine be cursed. I hate it."

"In all the years I've being doing this I've never seen so many bodies. It was a nightmare," said one of the rescue workers bringing corpses out from the shaft. "They all died of suffocation and burns in the coal dust explosion."

President Kuchma said more than £1m was being made available for the families of the dead. At the same mine last year he accused "unscrupulous directors" at unnamed mines of "criminal dealings" by ignoring safety and pushing production to pocket the mine's earnings. The mine is owned by a Ukrainian state holding company.

The local trade union leader said the management at the 43-year-old pit regularly ignored breaches of safety to increase output. "The extra tonnes are paid for with the miners' lives."

"This is really the worst catastrophe in the history of Ukrainian independence," said the energy minister, Serhiy Tulub. More than 200 workers were in the mine at the time of the explosion, 91 in the vicinity. Officials said the number of dead rose from 80 on Saturday to 82 yesterday, with four escaping unhurt and the remainder in hospital.

The eastern region of Luhansk, where the mine is situated, is also experiencing many cases of tuberculosis. Local hospitals, which were previously funded by the mines, now rely on patients' families to pay for treatment.

fields.headline: Mercy mission
fields.standfirst: Lord Longford: Some think he's a pervert, others think that he's the closest thing to God we have. He just wants, in principle at least, to be nice to everyone.
fields.trailText: Lord Longford: Some think he's a pervert, others think that he's the closest thing to God we have. He just wants, in principle at least, to be nice to everyone.
fields.body:
At 94, Lord Longford, the prisoner's friend, is the oldest sitting member of the House of Lords. He is an ancient will o' the wisp, his head a boiled sweet from which his few strands of hair stand upright as if under electric shock.

His teeth look as if they've melted together. But he is sharp as a tack. "Is this on the record? Stop writing," he orders at one point. "You asked me a question. Let me finish," he barks at another. He spits "No. Never," several times. "Are you a homo?" he asks the photographer, who's taking a close-up. "I support homosexuals, I always have," (though he doesn't believe, he adds, in lowering the age of consent). Does he have homosexual colleagues in the House. "What?" he says. " Elderly gentlemen? Elderly gentlemen homosexuals? There were many homos at Eton and Oxford, but in the House of Lords? Elderly gentlemen. No, no, no."

We're talking in a small dark anteroom, just along from the debating chamber. He spoke last week on the reform of the House of Lords. Twelfth speaker. Just before 6pm. Eight minutes. He always keeps to eight minutes. "It takes people years to understand there's something called attention span. Do you understand?" he says. The day before this he was visiting Dennis Nilsen.

Longford is, famously, Myra Hindley's longest supporter. He implies an indirect involvement in last week's judgment disallowing Brady from starving himself to death. "It's simple enough. He should not be allowed to die because he's in hospital, the responsibility of those who look after him. It would be different if you told me you wanted to die because of an unhappy love affair. But if the man's mental, he's your responsibility." There are pearls of spittle in the corners of his mouth, and on his lapel. "I told them that. I told him that too when he talked to me about it." He bangs the table with his hand, keeping time to his own drum.

He might have banged it a bit too loudly, because it's about then that I tell him he's being a bit frightening. "What?" he says. "Frightening? What? Oh God. Oh God, I'm sorry. I'm awfully sorry. Was I being frightening? I'm sorry. No, no, no. I am a timid soul. Oh God. Oh God, what can I do about it? I'm awfully sorry. Oh God, I am going to have to ask forgiveness. I mean, I'm 'frightening'. What can I do - kneel in front of you?" He has been flopping about from side to side, and now, a Catholic since his conversion in 1940, he makes a flamboyant sign of the cross. It's all I can do to stop him falling to the floor. "I'll have to confess to it later. But how do I? Do I crawl in front of you?"

How seriously should one take Francis Aungier Pakenham, KG, PC, 7th Earl of Longford? In his time he has been called "Lord Porn", "the Loony Lord" (The Sun), "a strayed and silly old goat" (Jean Rook), and "a dangerous and woolly-minded buffoon whose views are taken seriously because of his accidental social status" (Anne West, the mother of one of Brady and Hindley's victims). Dick Crossland described his cabinet career after the war as "farcical". Harold Wilson, who removed him from the front bench to make him leader of the Lords in 1964, said he had "the judgment of a 12-year-old". "People have called me a lot, which is extremely annoying," says Longford, "including effing pervert as you know."

But age has its benefits. And to some Longford has attained the status of a national treasure. "If you want to know what Christianity is," wrote the commentator AN Wilson last week, "look at the life of Lord Longford. Year in, year out has found him changing trains on windy platforms and journeying all over the country to visit prisons. Contemplating his bald old head, I wish there were a God and imagine if there were one he would be just like Lord Longford."

So, I put it to him. Effing pervert or the closest thing to God we have? Longford gives a smirk. "I suppose if I were a holy man I would obtain a whip and lash myself," he says. "Wonderful of Andrew [Wilson]."

Conversing with Longford involves a series of such mental adjustments. Within the good Catholic references to forgiveness and redemption, he strikes notes that are disconcertingly off-key. There is the combination of self-flagellation and name-dropping - only natural from a man who has known Gaitskill and Keynes, Beveridge and Betjeman, and whose close family members include Antonia Fraser and Rachel Billington (daughters), Anthony Powell and Harold Pinter (brother-in-law and son-in-law respectively). At times it strays into moral greyness. He vehemently defends Jonathan Aitken for example, piling scorn on the Guardian for "hounding him". But he lied. "Only a very little lie," he says. "And anyway he acknowledged it." But only after he was forced to. "Well done Guardian," says Longford sarcastically. "Anyway," he adds, "I'm biased if you like. I knew his grandfather, Lord Rugby. I knew his mother..."

So far as Hindley and Brady are concerned, he says Myra is "a good woman, a good Christian woman". But there is something disconcertingly jolly in his description of Brady as "brilliant bonkers". He calls Brady and Hindley's relationship "a marriage made in heaven" and there's quite a long pause before he remembers to add "or hell". He says their cleverness was really "unlike working class people" and that it doesn't surprise him that people find it hard to forgive them. "It's only natural. People are ignorant."

Does he never find it hard to separate the sin from the sinner? "No because it's happened already. I mean Nilsen strangled 12 people-" He makes a comic motion at his neck to illustrate this. "But when you meet him you can't imagine him doing it. If you saw it happening, who knows?"

He has been married for 70 years to Elizabeth, a royal biographer. He can't imagine life without her, but to hope to go first would be: "Very selfish. I will be feeble, but to wish that would be contemptible." They have had eight children, one of whom, Catherine, died in a car crash at the age of 23. I ask if his religion helped him then. He says: "I'm sure it helped Elizabeth. She became a Catholic herself about that time. But for me? Not quite so much. A man doesn't feel the same as a woman."

All in all, he says, he is a second-rate father. "I did my duty. The boys were at Ampleforth up in Yorkshire and I went up to visit them for what seemed like about 20 years so I did my duty." He seems momentarily distracted. "There are some wonderful fathers," he adds. "I saw Lord Shawcross, who is the oldest member of the House (though he doesn't come) and his son, who is himself quite old, at a party a while ago and the son kissed his father on the lips. Well you know that's lovely but it's so remote from the way I was bought up."

Longford's father was a war hero and was killed at Gallipoli. Even his older brother, "the fattest man in Ireland", who died in 1961, had "guts" and came out as a supporter for Sinn Fein while at Eton "so was a hero in his way". Longford was invalided out of the army during the war (after a nervous breakdown) and has taken refuge in failure ever since. "I think that was very helpful," he says. "I was a total failure and now today I'm partially sighted. I hobble about with a stick. If you're a peer, you've been a cabinet minister, you're interviewed by the Guardian, you might think of yourself as superior to other people but old age has the one advantage that you can't."

"I'm a very self-critical person," he continues happily. "My record says that. I started as a Conservative, became Labour. Started as some sort of Protestant, became Catholic. Didn't have much use for Irish nationalism, became a champion- You can't do all these things if you're not a critical person. Even today, I'm wondering how to lead a better life." But doesn't he have a place booked in heaven? "God, no," he says. "I want to be purified long before that. I wouldn't like to arrive in heaven and someone say, 'OK Longford, what do you like playing?' 'I like playing tennis.' 'Come in, we've got lovely courts.' That's a really appalling thought: to spend the rest of eternity no better than you are now."

One of the things that will keep him in purgatory, he says, is impatience.

He calls a halt to the interview then and takes me to tea where he's meeting a neighbour from the country who has some points to raise with him about the position of widows in the House. "I wrote to you," she tells him. "But you must have been very busy because you didn't answer."

Longford, who suddenly appears to have gone a little more deaf, bows his head and sways guiltily. When she goes on to mention another occasion in which he "waved her away", he starts swooning and moaning again. "I waved you away. Oh God, I waved you away. How awful of me. Oh God. What can I do?" She outlines her argument once more. By the time the cakes arrive it's obvious his patience has run out. "Write to me about it, write to me," he mutters, lost in his fondant fancy.

fields.headline: Still sharp as a razor. . . or your money back
fields.standfirst: Last week he won £105,000 from the Mirror for suggesting he was past it.  Stephen Moss finds there's more to Victor Kiam than a great tan
fields.trailText: 'I liked the verdict so much, I wish I could have bought the jury," said Victor Kiam as he emerged from the high court on Friday after winning his libel case against the Mirror.    As we chatted in the taxi taking us back to his suite at Claridge's the quip seemed to please him as much as the £105,000 plus costs he had just won from the newspaper which last year made the   mistake of suggesting he was losing his touch.
fields.body:
'I liked the verdict so much, I wish I could have bought the jury," said Victor Kiam as he emerged from the high court on Friday after winning his libel case against the Mirror. As we chatted in the taxi taking us back to his suite at Claridge's the quip seemed to please him as much as the £105,000 plus costs he had just won from the newspaper which last year made the mistake of suggesting he was losing his touch.Kiam wasn't in London for the money - after 30 years as a successful entrepreneur, he isn't short of that - but for the principle. "What the Mirror's City Slickers had written about me and the Ronson company was grossly unjust. Everything was wrong. When that article ran, we had just gone through six months when we had straightened everything out. But the Mirror said I was about to close everything down. I'm sitting there thinking 'I've worked my ass off but it's all been worth it' and I read a headline saying, 'He's had it, he's over the hill.' "

The Mirror had offered him an eleventh-hour settlement, but he had refused: "I wanted to really win so that the world would know that I won. You have to be careful about what is written on financial matters so that the city pages of newspapers don't become gambling tout sheets."

Kiam spent more than a day in the witness box, and the jury warmed to him. He is a funny, engaging, leathery 73-year-old who looks like an ageing crooner, dresses nattily and talks with a streetwise New York accent (though he was born in New Orleans and can drawl with the best of them down south). "I feel like a 21-year-old who still wants to see the future, and I am enjoying making the future come sooner," he told the court in a virtuoso performance. Mirror editor Piers Morgan and the ex-Slickers opted to miss the show.

The attractive thing about Victor Kermit Kiam II is that, though every inch a successful American capitalist, he is the antithesis of corporate man: he is a risk-taker whose speciality is turning companies round (hence his involvement in the mid-90s with the ailing Ronson). He puts in his own money and then pitches into the management of the company, too. "An entrepreneur not only innovates," he explains, "but works his tail off to make sure the project succeeds."

He loves gadgets and fishes the new Ronson disposable lighter out of his pocket to demonstrate it. His current enthusiasms include a pair of ear-plugs which combat that buzzing in the ears you get on planes and a health light for people who suffer from seasonal affective disorder.

"I like products and services that have something unique about them," he says. "If you don't have something different, you have to create it. For example, Remington: the killer was 'shaves as close as a blade or your money back'; it was a guarantee that it would match whatever you did with a blade. You can't advertise a me-too product, you've got to have some differential. I believe in advertising; my whole career has been advertising."

That statement is literally true because what made Kiam into a household name were the Remington ads - "I liked it so much I bought the company" - in which he starred for 15 years after buying the firm in 1979. When Kiam was discussing the deal, his wife Ellen bought him a Remington shaver to try out, and he was suitably impressed. When he told his UK ad agency the story, they saw an opportunity and thought about getting Kevin Keegan to appear in the ads. Kiam couldn't see the logic in that and insisted on doing them himself. An advertising classic was born.

"I did a couple of commercials coming out of the bathroom in a bath-robe," he recalls. "The other ones I did from a desk, but you couldn't get any depth on the camera because the office wasn't big enough, so I sat on the edge of the desk and was shot from the waist up. People thought I was a midget and they were amazed at how tall I was when they met me in person."

Kiam had an unconventional upbringing, and perhaps that explains his pleasingly idiosyncratic approach to business - and to life. His parents were divorced when he was three, and he was brought up in New Orleans by his grandparents (his grandfather was an artist - significant, perhaps); at 11 he headed north and alternated between mother and father before going to a boarding school and then into the navy, in time to escort Atlantic convoys in the latter part of the war. Post-demob, he went to Yale (economics), the Sorbonne (languages) and Harvard (the all-important MBA), before living out of a suitcase for Lever Bros and spending more than a decade with Playtex.

He left Playtex, where he was head of marketing, in 1968 when it was bought by a corporate raider intent on breaking up the business. He disliked asset stripping then, and he dislikes it still. "I don't go into things because I can sell this, sell that, and be left with a chunk of cash," he says. "I may have to sell some things to keep the core business, but that's only the first step to build. I have one great weakness - once I get into something, it becomes a child; I can't get rid of it. A lot of the businesses I've gone into, I went into because I enjoy. They weren't necessarily money making."

Kiam is chairman of 10 companies - including Remington and Ronson - and has realised that retirement is not for him. "I decided to retire in 1995 and I was going to live permanently in Florida. I loved January; February was OK; March, I was getting awfully itchy; and by April I said 'Is this what I'm going to be doing?' I like to play tennis, but I didn't want to play tennis every day." He still lives in Florida, but the tennis and his beloved bridge are now mixed with the deal-making and company- doctoring that became a way of life after he left Playtex.

Maybe the Slickers didn't realise what they were taking on when they refused to apologise to Kiam. Back in 1970 he approached China, which then had no relations with the US, to act as a distributor for its jewellery. At first he got nowhere. But he persisted, and finally he was invited to visit Peking and allowed to sell their jewellery (which he styled the Friendship Collection) in the US and Europe. One indomitable capitalist opening up communist China. After tackling Mao, he had nothing to fear from the Mirror.

fields.headline: Where Nazis are heroes
fields.standfirst: An anti-fascist partisan in Latvia made legal history when he was sentenced for war crimes - while pro-German soldiers who murdered thousands of Jews go free. Ian Traynor on the case that is focusing world attention on Latvia's disturbing legacy of collaboration
fields.trailText: An anti-fascist partisan in Latvia made legal history when he was sentenced for war crimes - while pro-German soldiers who murdered thousands of Jews go free. Ian Traynor on the case that is focusing world attention on Latvia's disturbing legacy of collaboration
fields.body:
War crimes trials of old Nazis, Bosnian butchers, Chilean dictators and African warlords are now a fixture of the international human rights agenda. But in January, the anti-Nazi partisan "hero" Vasily Kononov, 77, made legal history when he was sentenced to six years in prison in Latvia for war crimes committed in the cause of anti-fascism.

Riga court's guilty verdict against Kononov was the first time in the former Soviet Union, and perhaps anywhere in Europe, that a second world war combatant who fought on the winning side against the Nazis had been convicted for war crimes. "It's a unique case in Latvia, certainly, and perhaps not only here," admits Andris Gulans, head of Latvia's supreme court.

On May 27 1944, Kononov, then a 22-year-old former Red Army soldier who had been parachuted by the Russians behind German lines to command a unit of 18 guerrillas, moved with his men into the eastern village of Mazie Bati in the densely wooded countryside of Nazi- occupied Latvia.

It was a mild Saturday evening and the men of the village were relaxing over a customary drink after their weekly scrub in the communal bathhouse. Kononov and his men wore stolen German uniforms and fraternised with the locals, many of whom were familiar to the young anti-Nazi commander, who had been born in another hamlet nearby. Then the partisans, led by Kononov, unleashed their machine guns on several of the villagers. Six men and three women, one heavily pregnant, were killed.

A few months later the Russians displaced the Nazis as Latvia's occupying power. Kononov was on the winning side. A year after the incident, the second world war ended. Kononov went on to make a career in the police through the years of Soviet rule of Latvia.

Since 1945 there have been attempts to prosecute anti-fascist fighters for war crimes in Austria and Italy. But the attempts failed, says Winfried Garscha, a war crimes historian at Vienna's Wartime Resistance Documentation Centre. "I don't know of any cases like this one in Latvia," he adds.

The Latvian justice minister, Valdis Birkavs, bluntly insists it matters not a jot who won the war or who perpetrated the crimes. "War criminals have to be prosecuted. Innocent men and women were killed. Justice is justice."

But Villis Samsons, a historian and wartime commander of 3,000 Latvian partisans, is outraged at the Kononov verdict, which he sees as a deliberate attempt by the new Latvian state to rewrite history and "condemn and discredit the entire partisan movement that fought against Hitler. Why don't they do something about the real war criminals who organised the Holocaust in Latvia?"

Samsons is not alone in his outrage. Russia is incensed and is seeking international support against the verdict, demanding that the Council of Europe and the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe lean on the Latvians to release Kononov. But, says Birkavs, "the OSCE has no mandate to mediate in this."

Boris Yeltsin, Russia's former president, refused to accept Latvia's highest state award in protest at the Kononov verdict. The acting president, Vladimir Putin, offered Kononov and his family political asylum. The case, Putin warned, could herald "mass prosecution of fighters against fascism". Last week, the Latvian embassy in Moscow was daubed in paint and its windows smashed.

Latvia's troubled wartime past and its current dilemmas in dealing with that past suddenly leapt on to Britain's front pages at the beginning of this year when Konrad Kalejs, 88, a former Nazi collaborator and a member of Latvia's vicious Arajs militia - which butchered tens of thousands, mainly Jews - was discovered living in Britain, in a Midlands nursing home . Then last month, Kalejs, an Australian citizen, fled to Melbourne to avoid deportation from Britain. The home secretary, Jack Straw, had ruled that there was insufficient evidence against him to warrant prosecution in the UK. Latvia, too, says it is unable to mount a case against Kalejs.

The contrast between the Kononov and Kalejs cases is striking. "The Latvians have never asked for anyone's extradition for war crimes," says Efraim Zuroff, the Nazi war crimes researcher who heads the Simon Wiesenthal Centre in Jerusalem and who has been lobbying heavily in the Kalejs case. "Not once of their own volition have the Latvians prosecuted anyone for the murder of the Jews, in great contrast to the energy with which they are trying to bring communists to trial."

Three days after the Nazis arrived in Riga in July 1941, Latvian anti-semites torched Riga's main synagogue. Within six months, 60,000 of Latvia's pre-war Jewish community of 80,000, one of the most prosperous communities in eastern Europe, had been massacred. Latvians played a prominent role in the mass killings.

Kalejs's Arajs militia rounded up Jews, took them to the Rumbula forest and Salaspils concentration camp outside Riga and shot them. The Riga ghetto was emptied to accommodate Jews who had been deported by the Nazis from Germany and Austria.

The Holocaust historian Professor Raul Hilberg writes that "on a per capita basis, the Latvians were represented as heavily as any nation in the destruction of the Jews".

By 1943 there were two Latvian SS divisions and around 100,000 Latvians were in German uniform, either in auxiliary police units or in the SS legion. Unusually, the Nazis dispatched their Latvian collaborators way beyond their native territory, to Byelorussia, Ukraine and Warsaw.

The SS legionnaires are now feted in Latvia as freedom fighters. This Thursday, March 16, the SS veterans will march to the soaring art deco Freedom and Fatherland monument in central Riga as they have for the past seven years. Last year, the government decreed the day a national holiday. This year, however, because of international protest, it will be an unofficial holiday only.

Ausma Rubene, one of the prosecutors in the Kononov case, cites the Allies' charter for the postwar Nuremberg tribunal as one of the legal foundations for putting Kononov on trial, although the first words of the charter specify that the tribunal is to try "major war criminals of the European Axis".

"The Red partisans were stealing food and clothes and torching houses," says Mrs Rubene. "Kononov committed war crimes against peaceful civilians." When questioned further, she admits that the male villagers, in a region that was close to the frontline in 1944, were armed. "They had rifles, but they were not a fascist armed formation. They were given rifles to defend themselves and their homes."

Three months earlier, in the same village of Mazie Bati, there was a day-long battle between German troops and a Red Army reconnaissance unit in which 14 Russians were herded into the village bathhouse and burnt alive. That, at least, is the partisan version. The deaths aren't contested, but Rubene says the bathhouse was set ablaze accidentally by tracer fire.

"We know there were three women killed [on May 27]," says former partisan leader Samsons. "That was unfortunate, but there was a war on and it was very cruel. And the armed men in the village were auxiliary police for the German occupiers. They would round up deserters and turn them over to the Germans."

The bitterness triggered by the Kononov trial and Latvia's ambivalence towards its wartime past is fuelled by its hostility towards the Russians. "Latvia sees the war as two occupations, one bad, one good and the good one is the German," says a western observer in Riga.

It was Stalin, not Hitler, who ended Latvia's independence and occupied the Baltic state in 1940, ushering in a year-long reign of terror that saw tens of thousands of Latvians killed or sent to Siberia. When the Nazis drove out the Red Army in 1941, the Germans were seen by many as liberators.

"It's the Soviet occupiers who have to be blamed first for the Holocaust here," says Professor Aivars Stranga, a Riga historian heading a national commission on the war years. "Not every Latvian was a fascist and not every Latvian wanted to kill Jews. Stalin created the second world war when he divided Poland and Europe into spheres of influence." Kononov's crimes against civilians, he adds, "were terrible, the same level of barbarity as sending people to Auschwitz".

While Latvia has not sought to try Kalejs or mounted any other prosecutions of pro-Nazi war criminals, the authorities point out that the Soviet powers did a thorough job in the postwar years, putting more than 2,000 Latvians on trial for war crimes. "We want to put Nazis on trial but it was all done during Soviet times," says the justice minister, Birkavs. But rather than seeking to put ageing Nazis on trial, Latvia, says Zuroff, of the Wiesenthal Centre, is quietly rehabilitating dozens of convicted Nazi war criminals while prosecuting the likes of Kononov. Zuroff says 41 war criminals have been pardoned since Latvia achieved independence from the Soviet Union in 1991. That means they qualify for pensions and perks denied to old anti-Nazi fighters.

A week after Kononov got six years, president Vaira Vike-Freiberga of Latvia told the Holocaust Remembrance conference in Stockholm that the "precise number" of Latvians who participated in the mass murder of Jews was "not known but was estimated to exceed 1,000".

Nazi-hunters and historians say that that figure is risibly low. But while Latvia is not preparing any Nazi war crimes trials, Aleksandrs Ogurcovs, Kononov's lawyer, says that he expects another six prosecutions of anti-Nazi fighters. "Only in Latvia," he says. "I've never heard of anyone who fought the Germans being jailed for war crimes."

webTitle: 3,000 jobs at risk as Australian rival eyes AMP

fields.headline: 3,000 jobs at risk as Australian rival eyes AMP
fields.trailText: The threat of a jobs cull among a clutch of well-known British insurance and consumer finance firms loomed yesterday as it emerged that National Australia Bank is mulling a £9bn takeover bid for rival Australian insurer AMP.
fields.body:
The threat of a jobs cull among a clutch of well-known British insurance and consumer finance firms loomed yesterday as it emerged that National Australia Bank is mulling a £9bn takeover bid for rival Australian insurer AMP.

NAB already owns Leeds-based Yorkshire Bank and Glasgow-based Clydesdale Bank as well as National Irish Bank, based in Dublin.

Acquiring AMP would also bring insurer Pearl Assurance, asset management specialist Henderson Investors, the former mutuals NPI and London Life, and a 50% stake in Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Direct and Virginmoney.com under one new parent.

NAB is now said to be ready to raise its offer by 20% if it wins a recommendation from the AMP board.

But NAB's prime target is thought to be AMP's asset management interests around the world. Henderson, for example, has more than £70bn under management.

There was also speculation at the weekend that a takeover of AMP would lead to several divisions of the new group being declared "non-core" and being put up for auction even though in the past NAB has denied persistent speculation that it wants to sell both Clydesdale and Yorkshire.

A takeover would also throw into confusion the putative scheme hatched by AMP's chief executive, Paul Batchelor, and Sir Richard Branson to float the Virgin Direct and Virginmoney.com businesses later this year.

fields.headline: Carphone Warehouse plans £1bn float
fields.trailText: Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest independent mobile phone retailer, is planning to go public later this year in a flotation that could value the company at more than £1bn. It would make multi-millionaires of managing director Charles Dunstone and chief executive David Ross.
fields.body:
Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest independent mobile phone retailer, is planning to go public later this year in a flotation that could value the company at more than £1bn. It would make multi-millionaires of managing director Charles Dunstone and chief executive David Ross.

The cash-rich business has no immediate need to raise money on the markets but industry sources said the move would fund ambitions to exploit the international boom expected as the new generation of internet-friendly mobile phones becomes available over the next two years.

The company was said to be close yesterday to awarding investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston the job of leading an initial public offering.

The move is also being seen as anticipating a wave of consolidation among British mobile phone retailers, with Carphone Warehouse reportedly keen to sweep up other independent chains.

Mr Dunstone, 35, who founded the business 11 years ago with school friend Mr Ross and just £6,000 in the bank, is said to be leery of the City but has been persuaded by financial advisers CSFB and Morgan Stanley that the company needs freer access to capital to fund expansion.

Carphone Warehouse already has outlets throughout Europe but wants to consolidate its grip on the phone retail market, as Wap (Wireless Application Protocol) phones take off and third-generation mobile phones appear on the horizon, offering a host of e-commerce and entertainment possibilities.

Earlier this month it took a commanding position in the Spanish market by buying 50 outlets of the VivaVoce chain in a deal valued at £15m. It now has about 750 outlets from Sweden to Portugal.

Sales last year were £350m and are forecast to reach £600m this year. The float would value the company at 30-40 times earnings.

Industry observers said the complicated nature of the new generation phones and the complex tariff packages available would suit the company's reputation for providing independent advice.

Last year Carphone Warehouse became the second UK company to operate a "virtual" cellular network, buying airtime wholesale from One 2 One and selling it on to its customers.

However, the company also has ambitions to diversify out of retailing and become an investor in hi-tech ventures. In January, the firm set up a £30m investment fund for new wireless technology and internet ventures. It was reported to be considering changing its name and becoming an internet acquisition vehicle but this plan appears to have been shelved in favour of promoting the retail brand.

Mr Dunstone dropped out of university to become a computer salesman before starting the company from his west London flat in 1989. His unconventional ideas include deliberately recruiting staff with no previous sales experience and no track record in the mobile phone industry.

He is said to have been reluctant to go to the market for funding because he feared outside investors would try to change his unconventional business methods.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: The Observer
fields.body:
The Observer

British Airways' planned code-sharing deal with American Airlines is set to be vetoed by US authorities early this week, leaving the "Oneworld" alliance little more than a goodwill pact between frequent flyer schemes. The US snub is retaliation against the airline's successful campaign to prevent more landing slots being opened up at Heathrow for other American carriers.

Harland & Wolff , the Belfast shipyard threatened with closure after losing the £450m contract to build Cunard's new superliner, approached the DTI too late for aid in its bid. DTI sources say H&W did not approach it until February 29, and only did so at Stephen Byers' urging.

Sunday Times

The rich are getting richer at the fastest rate ever, according to the paper's rich list . The collective worth of Britain's 1,000 richest people has risen by £31bn to £146bn over the last year, a 27% jump.

British Airways has approached Stephen Wolf , chairman of US Airways, to fill the vacancy left by the dismissal last week of Robert Ayling. Mr Wolf was widely credited with putting Air France and United Airlines back on track.

Gordon Brown has put up taxes by the equivalent of 4p on the basic rate since Labour came to power, according to accountants Pricewaterhouse-Coopers. The £10.8bn of discretionary rises breaks down into £6.7bn higher taxes on firms and £5.5bn rise in taxes on spending.

Mail on Sunday

Consumer groups attacked plans by Barclays to shut 172 branches, leaving 90 towns and villages without a bank from early April.

Sainsbury is to boost its net shopping service amid fears it is being outstripped by Tesco. New chief executive Sir Peter Davis plans to use existing stores for the service as an interim measure.

IoS

Family-controlled Associated British Foods, owner of Twinings tea , is being targeted for a £3bn takeover by a number of venture capitalists. Several firms are said to be studying Associated's books, including Hicks, Muse, Tate and the American fund, Furst.

Interest has been sparked by the tumbling share price and the absence of the chairman and controlling shareholder, Garry Weston, 72, since a stroke last year.

The corporate finance department at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson has threatened Deutsche Bank with a walkout unless its new German owner puts them at the heart of the global investment bank.

Sunday Business

Link, the bank-owned cash machine provider attacked by the government for double charging on cash withdrawals last week, is planning a "dole in the wall" service for those on benefits.

Sunday Telegraph

Knickerbox, the lingerie chain, called in administrators after attempts by distressed debt expert, Gary Klesch, failed to revive its fortunes. While cutting its losses from £3.5m when he bought it two years ago to £500,000 in 1998, Mr Klesch failed to find a winning formula for the business.

webTitle: Bidders told to measure eco impact

fields.headline: Bidders told to measure eco impact
fields.trailText: Takeover bidders should be required to show the social and environmental impact of their acquisitions, according to a corporate think-tank which today calls for a revolution in disclosure.
fields.body:
Takeover bidders should be required to show the social and environmental impact of their acquisitions, according to a corporate think-tank which today calls for a revolution in disclosure.

Ahead of publication on Wednesday of the latest plans for reform of company law, the Centre for Tomorrow's Company warns that greater openness and dialogue with critics is essential for business success.

The centre, which pioneered the concept of the "inclusive" company, says the days of the conventional annual report are numbered because of new technology and new demands from investors and the public. It calls for companies to open their annual meetings to campaigners, customers and other non-shareholder interest groups.

"Companies need to listen more and explain themselves better," said Mark Goyder, the centre's director. "Tomorrow's winners will be those who disclose early and listen to their critics. The losers will be those who only disclose what is dragged out of them."

Mr Goyder said directors needed to consider the interests of customers, employees and other stakeholders but this was difficult when faced with a takeover bid.

"At that point they have to concentrate on the worth of the offer for today's shareholders. We are saying at the very least shareholders should make their decision with their eyes open about the wider implications. So bidders should be required to make some sort of social and environmental impact statement."

The government's two-year project to transform Britain's Victorian corporate legal structure will report on Wednesday. It will reject calls to broaden directors' legal duties and force companies to report on a wide range of non-financial issues. But it is expected to suggest that directors should take a broad, long-term view, and to encourage broader reporting while stopping short of making that mandatory.

In its analysis, The Corporate Reporting Jigsaw, the centre says business is not ready even for the recommendations of the legal review. Conventional annual reports need to be scrapped because they are a symptom of a malaise which has led to public disillusionment with the business world.

Instead reports should include "soft and future" issues, including social and environmental factors, as well as indicators measuring relationships with customers and other stakeholder groups.

"Within two years the glossy annual report will be history," Mr Goyder said. "The challenge is to broaden the range of indicators which are in regular use by companies as part of the process of performance measurement and properly audited reporting."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: CSFB buys Gala for £400m
fields.body:
CSFB buys Gala for £400m

Investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston Private Equity announced yesterday that it had paid £400m for a majority stake in Britain's largest bingo company, Gala Group.

Gala said it would use the backing to grow organically and through acquisition, including a move into internet gambling market. "We see excellent opportunities both in traditional gaming, e-gaming and internet platforms going forward," said chief executive John Kelly.

CSFB bought the company from PPM Ventures, the private equity arm of Prudential. Gala last year turned in a 35% rise in pre-tax, pre-interest earnings to £37.4m on turnover of £190m.

Gala was formed after a management buyout from the Bass leisure group two years ago. The management team, headed by Mr Kelly, is to stay and will continue to hold a 10% stake.

CSFB said it expected more expansion in the bingo industry, which stood to benefit from further deregulation. "In a highly fragmented industry Gala can further consolidate its position as the market leader, and we are excited by the prospects."

Cazenove sews up web link

Cazenove, the blue-blooded securities operation which ranks as one of Britain's few remaining financial power houses, has formed an alliance with online internet investment bank Wit Capital Europe to work on initial public offerings in the hi-tech sector.

The alliance will see Cazenove investing £10m in Wit Capital Europe.

"By forming this strategic partnership Cazenove expects to enhance its origination activity in the UK, particularly in the technology sector which represents a significant part of the market," said Mark Loveday, senior partner at Cazenove.

Founded in October 1999, Wit Capital Europe is building a Europe-wide internet bank which will distribute securities offerings and equity research online.

RealCall heads for market

RealCall, a provider of internet customer relations services, is planning an initial public offering expected to value the company at around £100m.

The firm provides a service which allows e-shoppers encountering problems on a website to receive a telephone call from the site's sales staff at the click of a button. Clients include Barclays Bank, KPMG, PowerGen and Legal & General.

Stephen Voller, RealCall's chief executive officer, said the company aimed to provide a simple and easy method of bringing e-commerce into the real world.

Flemings has been appointed financial adviser for the flotation.

CBI berates Brussels

The Confederation of British Industry is urging European Union countries to cut the red tape which it claims is keeping unemployment high and checking growth.

"EU economies are being held back by restricted access to labour markets, skill shortages, unnecessary regulations and an incomplete single market," the CBI said. Unemployment in the EU is still more than 10%, despite the gathering pace of the economic recovery.

The employers' organisation wants less interference from Brussels in workplace practices. "Employers and employees are best placed to decide on patterns of work and reward systems," said John Cridland, the CBI's director of human resources policy.

fields.headline: Timeless beauty
fields.standfirst: Tim Ashley salutes the Royal Opera's devastating Der Rosenkavalier
fields.trailText: The Royal Opera's revival of Der Rosenkavalier, Strauss's wise, bittersweet study of the impact of time on human relationships, is, without question, the finest thing the company has done since its revamped home opened in December.
fields.body:
The Royal Opera's revival of Der Rosenkavalier, Strauss's wise, bittersweet study of the impact of time on human relationships, is, without question, the finest thing the company has done since its revamped home opened in December. It's a tremendous performance, thoughtful, tender and humane, shot through with intense emotional anguish and wistful humour which far transcends the clunky clutter of John Schlesinger's well-worn production.

Much of its success lies with its conductor, Christian Thielemann. He's a controversial figure with a reputation for being something of an autocrat who has tended to gravitate towards a repertoire which may broadly be described as right-wing.

On this occasion, however, he turned in some of the finest Strauss conducting heard in London for years. Effectively, he sees the score through the Marschallin's eyes: aware that time erodes beauty, love and sexual pleasure, she futilely tries to halt its progress by stopping the clock at night; Thielemann, similarly, seeks to stall the ceaseless flow of Strauss's music by lingering in vain over its elusive, slippery beauty.

The effect is ravishing, but it's also relentless, tinged with desperation. The prelude has a clingy wildness, suggestive of frenetic, yet furtive sexual activity. The Marschallin's great monologue is accompanied by slithering dissonances which rob her of any sense of equanimity. Even in the pause before the great Trio - which Thielemann sustains for a terrifying 30 seconds or so - one has a shocking sense of the opera's impending, painful resolution.

It's the finest thing Thielemann has ever done, and much the same can also be said of Renée Fleming's Marschallin. She's arrived back in London in a blaze of hype, and just for once the fuss is worth it. This is a very great account of the role. Strauss once commented that Octavian wasn't the Marschallin's first lover and won't be her last, all of which Fleming perfectly conveys with her remarkable presence and sexual allure. Yet she sheds new light on the Marschallin's predicament by revealing her as a loving woman who knows that she will never be genuinely loved in return. When she sends Octavian away at the end of act one, she's already aware she's lost him.

Her final gesture is a brief abandonment of self-control as she pauses to embrace him one last hopeless time, her peerlessly beauti ful voice turning clotted and broken with pain.

Susan Graham's Octavian approaches this phenomenal woman with a combination of explosive physicality and touching bewilderment until bashful gawkiness sets in when he finally meets Sophie. Graham is impressive, though one misses the character's sense of violent confusion. Christine Schäfer's Sophie is a model of gauche, bourgeois restraint. Vocally she takes a while to settle, though in the final scene she's glorious. Franz Hawlata's Ochs is an ambivalent creature, young enough and handsome enough to be a provincial Don Juan, yet lacking a certain aristocratic dignity. These are minor flaws. The whole is a devastating experience which demands to be heard. You miss it at your peril.

In rep until April 10 (0171-304 4000).

It's a tremendous performance, thoughtful, tender and humane, shot through with intense emotional anguish and wistful humour which far transcends the clunky clutter of John Schlesinger's well-worn production. Much of its success lies with its conductor, Christian Thielemann. He's a controversial figure with a reputation for being something of an autocrat who has tended to gravitate towards a repertoire which may broadly be described as right-wing. On this occasion, however, he turned in some of the finest Strauss conducting heard in London for years. Effectively, he sees the score through the Marschallin's eyes: aware that time erodes beauty, love and sexual pleasure, she futilely tries to halt its progress by stopping the clock at night; Thielemann, similarly, seeks to stall the ceaseless flow of Strauss's music by lingering in vain over its elusive, slippery beauty. The effect is ravishing, but it's also relentless, tinged with desperation. The prelude has a clingy wildness, suggestive of frenetic, yet furtive sexual activity. The Marschallin's great monologue is accompanied by slithering dissonances which rob her of any sense of equanimity. Even in the pause before the great Trio - which Thielemann sustains for a terrifying 30 seconds or so - one has a shocking sense of the opera's impending, painful resolution. It's the finest thing Thielemann has ever done, and much the same can also be said of Renée Fleming's Marschallin. She's arrived back in London in a blaze of hype, and just for once the fuss is worth it. This is a very great account of the role. Strauss once commented that Octavian wasn't the Marschallin's first lover and won't be her last, all of which Fleming perfectly conveys with her remarkable presence and sexual allure. Yet she sheds new light on the Marschallin's predicament by revealing her as a loving woman who knows that she will never be genuinely loved in return. When she sends Octavian away at the end of act one, she's already aware she's lost him. Her final gesture is a brief abandonment of self-control as she pauses to embrace him one last hopeless time, her peerlessly beauti ful voice turning clotted and broken with pain. Susan Graham's Octavian approaches this phenomenal woman with a combination of explosive physicality and touching bewilderment until bashful gawkiness sets in when he finally meets Sophie. Graham is impressive, though one misses the character's sense of violent confusion. Christine Schäfer's Sophie is a model of gauche, bourgeois restraint. Vocally she takes a while to settle, though in the final scene she's glorious. Franz Hawlata's Ochs is an ambivalent creature, young enough and handsome enough to be a provincial Don Juan, yet lacking a certain aristocratic dignity. These are minor flaws. The whole is a devastating experience which demands to be heard. You miss it at your peril. In rep until April 10 (0171-304 4000).

webTitle: He's a 60-year-old Marxist with four kids. So why would anyone cast him as Macbeth?

fields.headline: He's a 60-year-old Marxist with four kids. So why would anyone cast him as Macbeth?
fields.standfirst: Corin Redgrave talks to  Mark Espiner
fields.trailText: It's easy to forget that Corin Redgrave is a hard-left revolutionary, with his soft voice, sensitive turn of phrase and shy manner.
fields.body:
Corin Redgrave: a life

Born July 19, 1939 , the middle of three children. Attends, and hates,boarding school before moving to Westminster public school . Wins a scholarship to Cambridge , where he gains a first-class degree. Joins CND shortly afterwards, then the Royal Court as an assistant director. Marries Deirdre Hamilton-Hill in July 1962. They have two children. Joins the Workers Revolutionary Party in 1971. Leaves Deirdre in1974. In the 70s and 80s becomes political organiser for the WRP. Leaves in 1985 and founds Marxist Party . Marries Kika Markham in 1985. Two more children. Forms the Moving Theatre Company with Vanessa in 1993, with the aim of joining politics and art.

It's easy to forget that Corin Redgrave is a hard-left revolutionary, with his soft voice, sensitive turn of phrase and shy manner. Yet he has served his time on the barricades. He spent almost 15 years in the Workers Revolutionary Party, years in which his first marriage collapsed and he stood as an MP and encouraged his sister Vanessa to join the organisation. The pair then broke away to found the Marxist Party. His political career ostensibly blighted a promising acting career: he has suggested that his connections with the WRP got him blacklisted at the BBC and may have lost him film and theatre roles.

But Redgrave is a member of one of Britain's most celebrated acting dynasties, and that world would never be entirely closed to him. He never stopped acting, he says, never lost sight of it - although he was out of the limelight for the best years of a performer's life. And now the 60-year-old father of four is enjoying a belated popularity. A powerful performance in Noel Coward's Song at Twilight - which has just finished in London's West End - followed a spate of acclaimed stage and screen roles. Now he is about to play Macbeth. He seems unstoppable.

Surely 60 is rather old to play Macbeth? "Maybe it is something that audiences won't be comfortable with," he says, sipping lemon tea in a Soho cafe. And, he admits, the schedule makes no concessions. "I am hurtling towards a production that has only four weeks rehearsal and three weeks playing. Shall we know anything about the play by the time we reach the end of that?" But he does have one ace up his sleeve: he has played Lady Macbeth. He recalls how his father helped him to research that role, showing him what sort of eye movements to make during the sleepwalking scene.

Life often comes crashing into art in Redgrave's world. Hugo Latymer, the character he has just been playing in Song at Twilight, is a repressed homosexual. After publishing his self-serving memoirs, Hugo is forced to confront his past by two women central to his life, a former lover (played by Redgrave's sister Vanessa), and his wife (played by his second wife, Kika Markham). "He is so buttoned up about himself," he says, "and is really intolerant. The play is about repression. And people who are repressed very often become the worst oppressors. It applies sadly," he continues, digressing almost by reflex into politics, "to Kosovo in the way so many Kosovars have worked out their feelings of loss on the Roma people."

While that may be true, there is a much more personal parallel to his performance. His father, Michael Redgrave, had gay relationships, one with the playwright Noel Coward, as he revealed to Corin with the words "I think I ought to tell you, that I am, to say the least of it, bisexual" before dissolving into tears. It was this declaration that inspired Corin to write the gentle biographical portrait Michael Redgrave, My Father, published in 1995. "It was helpful to me to write it and is possibly helpful to other people in a similar situation," he says. "It has to do with an apparent reversal of roles. A lot has been written of the problems which gay men have as sons telling their parents, but not a great deal has been written about the other direction."

Discussing the parallels with Hugo Latymer, it is clear that he is enjoying acting again. But is there a sense of lost opportunity? "There are parts that I haven't played and would have liked to have played, but I have no regrets at all. Absolutely none. Coming back to more full-time acting, full of other life experiences, perhaps has made me a better actor."

Has ambition brought him to Macbeth? "Ambition is not confined to the young," he says. "The young are not counting days or months or even years to begin with. As they pass by, so you can afford to be laid back. Ambition is far more troubling when you look at the clock, because then you have to measure where you want to get to by the amount of time that you have to get there, and it becomes a much harsher thing.

"There is one advantage that a 60-year-old has over a 30-year-old in playing this part, and that is knowing what it is like for your way of life to be falling into the 'sear, the yellow leaf'. If you are honorable, loyal and tender towards the feelings of others you had better not be ambitious, because the two things will be in conflict."

But ambition, in Redgrave's case, is seemingly selfless. "In all areas I have ambitions that I have still to fulfil," he says, "especially in politics, which is the area in which one's aims continually fall short." He cannot seem to separate his acting craft from political motivation. He begins to articulate the debt that art owes to multiculturalism and then becomes agitated when he thinks how it cannot grow or develop in "the monocultural world that the Daily Mail imagines people want". It's interesting that Redgrave singles out that paper for criticism, as it was the Mail that paid to serialise his book about his father.

His political choler rises when he starts to talk about the lack of funding for theatre, and he suggests radical measures of protest - such as voluntarily closing all the theatres and kicking up an almighty fuss in the way that French lorry drivers do. "Art and politics," he insists, "can converge."

Macbeth is at BAC, London SW11 (0171-223 2223) from March 24 to April 16.

fields.headline: Inzamam leads the fightback
fields.trailText: Pakistan's Inzamam-ul-Haq helped his team to 256 all out on the first day of the third and final Test in Karachi after Sri Lanka won the toss and put them in to bat.
fields.body:
Pakistan's Inzamam-ul-Haq helped his team to 256 all out on the first day of the third and final Test in Karachi after Sri Lanka won the toss and put them in to bat.

The home side, who once again had to make do without the inspirational but injured Wasim Akram, are two down in the three-Test series but took the field under the leadership of their new coach Javed Miandad and with Moin Khan as captain in place of Saeed Anwar, who had a stiff neck. Mohammad Akram, Ijaz Ahmed, Naved Ashraf and the debutant Irfan Fazil also featured. They soon lost Mohammad Naveed (5) and Ijaz (7) but Shahid Afridi, with 74, and Inzamam, who was eventually run out for 86, helped give the total respectability. Muthiah Muralitharan was the pick of the Sri Lanka bowlers once again, taking four for 89 to bring his total for the series to 22 wickets. Sri Lanka reduced the arrears by 10 before stumps.

 India's captain Sourav Ganguly cracked an unbeaten 105 to help his country to a six-wicket win over South Africa at Jamshedpur and a 2-0 lead in the five-match series. The hosts, set 200 to win, reached their target in 47.1 overs, with Ganguly hitting nine boundaries and four sixes on the way to his 12th one-day hundred.

India's bowlers had skittled South Africa for 199 in 47.2 overs with only the captain Hansie Cronje, 71, making a substantial contribution.

fields.headline: Aussies built a lead
fields.trailText: Australia built up a lead of 165 in their second innings of the first Test against New Zealand at Eden Park yesterday, finishing the second day on 114 for five after bowling New Zealand out for only 163.
fields.body:
Australia built up a lead of 165 in their second innings of the first Test against New Zealand at Eden Park yesterday, finishing the second day on 114 for five after bowling New Zealand out for only 163.

Justin Langer was the best of the Australia batsmen, making 47 before holing out trying to hoist Daniel Vetori over midwicket, but partnerships were again hard to come by as the New Zealand spinners kept the pressure on.

"Sometimes games played on wickets which are a little bit bowler-friendly can be quite exciting and this one's still got a lot of twists to go," said Chris Cairns, the New Zealand all-rounder. "It's shaping up to be a very interesting Test match."

fields.headline: Continuing a tradition
fields.standfirst:
Dominic Muldowney/ BBC Philharmonic
Leeds Town Hall
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Dominic Muldowney/ BBC Philharmonic
Leeds Town Hall
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The civic grandiosity of Leeds Town Hall was the appropriate setting for the world premiere of Dominic Muldowney's oratorio The Fall of Jerusalem, with its epic subject matter of the Romans' siege of the Jewish sanctuary in 70 AD. The sight of the combined forces of the BBC Philharmonic, the Leeds Festival Chorus and two youth choirs and three solo singers, automatically created a link with the great British choral tradition.

But Muldowney's vision of a contemporary oratorio is much more than an accomplished demonstration of bombastic. Each soloist has a precisely defined dramatic part to play. This kind of lucidly-imagined texture is the hallmark of Muldowney's composition - even at the tumultuous heights of the music's abundant climaxes, there is a striking clarity of ensemble.

There may be few innovations of musical language in The Fall of Jerusalem's broadly tonal idiom. However, Muldowney's intuitive sense of theatre creates a musical world that encompasses Klezmer bands, mock-Baroque fireworks, as well as an overwhelming lyricism. As demonstrated by the vigour and enthusiasm of this first performance under conductor Simon Wright, Muldowney seems to have managed an all-too rare feat in The Fall of Jerusalem. Remaining true to his naturally communicative voice, he has created a winningly appealing pièce d'occasion: like a 21st century continuation of the grand oratorios of the last century.

 Tonight on Radio 3 at 7.30.
