fields.headline: Buffett confesses blunder
fields.standfirst: Super-investor pays dear for technophobia but insists market bubble must burst
fields.trailText: Warren Buffett, the world's most famous investor, yesterday declared 1999 the worst blot on his copybook yet, but refused to alter his approach to investment. He continued to warn against stock market excesses as his annual statement to shareholders in Berkshire Hathaway was published on the internet.
fields.body:
Warren Buffett, the world's most famous investor, yesterday declared 1999 the worst blot on his copybook yet, but refused to alter his approach to investment. He continued to warn against stock market excesses as his annual statement to shareholders in Berkshire Hathaway was published on the internet.

Berkshire, the investment vehicle run by 69-year-old Mr Buffett since 1965, produced a return of 0.5% last year, compared with 21% for the S&P 500 index of America's leading companies. Never before, even during times of recession, has the company performed so badly. The dire performance partly reflects Mr Buffett's refusal to invest in hi-tech companies because he does not understand them.

The companies he understands enough to invest in - from General Re, the insurer, to Coca-Cola and Gillette -performed badly last year as they struggled to adapt to changing global dynamics.

In his folksy report to investors, Mr Buffett, writes: "Even Inspector Clouseau could find last year's guilty party: your chairman."

But Mr Buffett was confident he would be proved right in the end. He predicted a "modest" outperformance over the S&P 500 over coming years, citing the intrinsic value of his investments and the fact that the current exuberance of the market cannot continue.

"Our optimism about Berkshire's performance is also tempered by the expectation - indeed, in our minds, the virtual certainty - that the S&P will do far less well in the next decade or two than it has done since 1982."

He also reveals his contempt for investors who believe there is any rational justification for current valuation levels. "If anyone starts explaining to you what is going on in the truly manic portions of this 'enchanted' market, you might remember still another line of song: 'Fools give you reasons, wise men never try.'"

Mr Buffett, who has become the world's second richest man on the back of his "value-based" approach to investing, is likely to face tough questions from shareholders at his forthcoming annual meeting in Omaha, Nebraska. The company's share price, at $41,300 on Friday night, has all but halved over the past year and is trading marginally above the group's net asset value.

Shareholders and analysts have called for Berkshire Hathaway to buy back the company's shares, a move that is often seen as a sign of confidence in future performance. Mr Buffett said he would consider such a repurchase in his annual report but added: "Please be clear about one point: We will never make pur chases with the intention of stemming a decline in Berkshire's price."

Other value-style investors who have failed to take advantage of fast-growth companies include the UK's Phillips & Drew and Tiger, the hedge fund managed by Julian Robertson.

A significant part of Berkshire's underperformance related to its $22bn purchase of General Re in 1998. The move into insurance surprised many analysts at the time. "Huge, abberational" underwriting losses at the insurer were blamed for part of last year's underperformance.

Last year the company made its first hi-tech investment when it bought a tiny stake in Microsoft, the world's most highly valued company.

Mr Buffett, the man who derides corporate excess but bought an extra share in an executive jet last year, has "well over 99%" of his net worth invested in Berkshire.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you consider filing the bane of office life, spare a thought for Albert Pavitt. As a filing clerk of medical records at St Bartholomew's hospital in the City of London, filing is his sole job.
fields.body:
If you consider filing the bane of office life, spare a thought for Albert Pavitt. As a filing clerk of medical records at St Bartholomew's hospital in the City of London, filing is his sole job. "I'm in the basement with five other filers. There are no windows but there's plenty of light and there's air-conditioning," he says. Previously a porter at the London Hospital, Whitechapel, he has been in his current job for six months. "You usually find that people who work in the admin side of hospitals have worked somewhere else before. It's less hands-on than portering and I prefer that."

It may be monotonous occasionally, but his is an important job, stresses Pavitt, 32. "You've always got it at the back of your mind that a file belongs to a real person. If the right notes aren't at the right clinic for the right patient, the patient might not get seen to."

Files make their way to Pavitt from various hospitals and clinics including the London chest hospital, Mile End hospital and the Queen Elizabeth hospital. Appointments for patients are made in advance, allowing enough time for files to be received and sent from one hospital to another.

"When you register as a patient, you are given a specific number. The same number could be shared by a male and female, but otherwise each patient is issued with an individual six- or more digit number which is recorded on his or her file. Once each file is returned, I check at which hospital the next appointment is. I then weed out the file and send it on.

"Files that stay here are divided into two categories - thick notes and thin notes, depending on the amount of records a patient has. We file them in numerical order.

"The job is very samey and it's important to go out for a walk or have a cup of tea to give yourself a break. We're lucky we've got a lovely garden here that we can stroll in."

Confidentiality is vital in Pavitt's job: "We're not supposed to read the files. There are so many notes here that if you started reading them you'd never get any work done. You do see some famous names, I mean everyone comes to the hospital. But really there's no reason for reading them."

Revising and remembering names of hospital departments is part of the job. "There are a lot of -ologys - gynaecology, oncology, urology . . . It does require some concentration."

"There's nothing worse than doing a misfile. Our supervisor is great - if there is a misfile, he'll go through everything and, although it sounds crazy, he'll try to get us all to look at the misfiled number as if someone's read it wrong." If they can't find file 33, for instance, they will look under 83, or 88, reversing the numbers and checking against other pairs which are commonly confused. "It is strange but you get used to certain numbers being misfiled and it's a method that usually works."

As a filing clerk of medical records at St Bartholomew's hospital in the City of London, filing is his sole job. "I'm in the basement with five other filers. There are no windows but there's plenty of light and there's air-conditioning," he says. Previously a porter at the London Hospital, Whitechapel, he has been in his current job for six months. "You usually find that people who work in the admin side of hospitals have worked somewhere else before. It's less hands-on than portering and I prefer that." It may be monotonous occasionally, but his is an important job, stresses Pavitt, 32. "You've always got it at the back of your mind that a file belongs to a real person. If the right notes aren't at the right clinic for the right patient, the patient might not get seen to." Files make their way to Pavitt from various hospitals and clinics including the London chest hospital, Mile End hospital and the Queen Elizabeth hospital. Appointments for patients are made in advance, allowing enough time for files to be received and sent from one hospital to another. "When you register as a patient, you are given a specific number. The same number could be shared by a male and female, but otherwise each patient is issued with an individual six- or more digit number which is recorded on his or her file. Once each file is returned, I check at which hospital the next appointment is. I then weed out the file and send it on. "Files that stay here are divided into two categories - thick notes and thin notes, depending on the amount of records a patient has. We file them in numerical order. "The job is very samey and it's important to go out for a walk or have a cup of tea to give yourself a break. We're lucky we've got a lovely garden here that we can stroll in." Confidentiality is vital in Pavitt's job: "We're not supposed to read the files. There are so many notes here that if you started reading them you'd never get any work done. You do see some famous names, I mean everyone comes to the hospital. But really there's no reason for reading them." Revising and remembering names of hospital departments is part of the job. "There are a lot of -ologys - gynaecology, oncology, urology . . . It does require some concentration." "There's nothing worse than doing a misfile. Our supervisor is great - if there is a misfile, he'll go through everything and, although it sounds crazy, he'll try to get us all to look at the misfiled number as if someone's read it wrong." If they can't find file 33, for instance, they will look under 83, or 88, reversing the numbers and checking against other pairs which are commonly confused. "It is strange but you get used to certain numbers being misfiled and it's a method that usually works."

fields.headline: Living for the company
fields.standfirst:
Firms are offering everything from gyms to poetry readings, to bunk beds for 'power naps'. It sound very caring, but it's actually a way to exploit staff.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Welcome to your working future. No longer do you need to leave the workplace to have an energising swim, squeeze in a session of psychotherapy, get a massage, do your dry cleaning, enjoy tuna or bok choi for your dinner, have an evening tipple of your choice and even get a good night's kip. You can do it all at the office. Sound too futuristic to be true? It's not. According to new research by the Industrial Society, the "corporate village" is gaining huge popularity in the US and it is only a matter of time before it arrives here.
fields.body:
Welcome to your working future. No longer do you need to leave the workplace to have an energising swim, squeeze in a session of psychotherapy, get a massage, do your dry cleaning, enjoy tuna or bok choi for your dinner, have an evening tipple of your choice and even get a good night's kip. You can do it all at the office. Sound too futuristic to be true? It's not. According to new research by the Industrial Society, the "corporate village" is gaining huge popularity in the US and it is only a matter of time before it arrives here.

"Many employers in the UK are already offering services that a decade ago you'd have had to go home to get," says Richard Reeves, director of futures at the Industrial Society. "Most of the big corporations, for instance, now offer company gyms, evening classes and the chance to do your annual-good-deed charity event. Others are introducing or considering on-site running tracks, free subscriptions to dating agencies, 'sleep modules' - bunk beds for powernaps - and even 'free hugs'."

The law firm Mishcon de Reya, for instance, offers in-house yoga sessions and poetry lessons and provides employees with twice-weekly sessions of chi kung, a form of t'ai chi.

At first glance this seems wonderful, exciting and caring. Cynics, however, may counter that it is a trend that is manipulative and harmful. Reeves explains: "Studies show that as a result of these home-from-home benefits, people are becoming happier in the workplace than they are in their own houses. That's why they are not going home and that's where the employers get their return."

Think about it. Implicit in the offer of a food shopping service, television-watching room or assistance with financial planning is the suggestion that you don't have time to do such things at home. Why not? Because you're working, silly. Leaving work at 5pm suddenly seems unnecessary, even rude. In any case, the workplace has become a far more attractive place to be than your empty little flat - because you spend so much time there, your colleagues have become your main circle of friends.

And don't be fooled into thinking your employers can't gain anything from you having a swift pint with the boss after hours. Even if you are not actually in the office, research shows the chances are you'll spend much of your time brainstorming work-related ideas.

"This trend is mirrored by the hottest TV programmes of the moment," points out Judi James, co-author of The Tall Poppy: How to grow to your full potential (The Industrial Society, £10.99). "Traditional soaps such as Coronation Street focus on the family as the nub of people's lives. But in the new ones, such as Ally McBeal, that nub has become work. You never see the characters go anywhere else except the work bar and they don't have any friends or partners apart from those related to work. Work has, in other words, become their whole life which - in a tight labour market - employers believe is a brilliant way of retaining staff, as well as getting the most out of them."

Even if you do secretly yearn to get away as soon as your designated eight hours are up, you don't dare to because nobody else is, adds James. "Policies that stipulate leaving on time where possible are a bit like casual dress policies," she says. "Unless companies actually insist on dressing down, there will always be some that still wear the power suit to look professional to the boss. In my experience, this leads to everyone else slowly slipping back into theirs. The point is that nobody wants to do anything that could lead to them being seen as unprofessional."

Ironically, it is the so-called "family-friendly" services that may be most likely to keep staff at work. Having studied the comprehensive policies of a major US corporation, Berkeley university professor Arlie Hochschild found that people are more likely to use the crèche than opt for shorter working hours.

According to Lucy Daniels, associate of the Work Life research centre, employers who try to make the office more pleasant than home do not gain in the long-run. "UK companies have, for a long time, been told that employees are most productive if they have a good balance between their work and their life. Attempts to overcome this by bringing life to work are totally counter-productive - such employees end up with even less of a balance than in the past. As it is, people in the UK still work the longest hours in Europe."

So serious are the repercussions of work taking over the home, claims the Industrial Society, that it has become the biggest threat to marriages and long-term relationships. Because many workplaces are like families in their own right - and people spend more time in them than at home - they are driving a wedge between couples.

The fact that the corporate family increasingly has its own set of jargon doesn't help. People get home at the end of the day and try to talk to their partner about their work and are, quite literally, not understood. While employees were once happy to go home and moan about work to their families, says the society's research, they are today more likely to "rush into work to moan about the shortcomings of their partner."

Judi James believes that because partners see each other less and less, there is an enormous amount of pressure when they do have some serious time on their hands. "This is typical at Christmas time," she explains. "Families expect that there will be this mythological quality time with oodles of laughter and fun. Because they are so tired and may even be missing work, their dream doesn't become a reality, creating an even greater wedge."

Penny de Valk, managing director of the work/life specialists Ceridian Performance Partners, says, "People pay lip service to the work/life balance and some enlightened firms do make strenuous efforts to ensure that people take lunch-breaks, leave the office on time at night and take their annual holiday. But for employers, the gradual replacement of traditional family structures by the corporate family is seen as no bad thing. If they spent as much time on marriage guidance as they do on team-building, there would be fewer divorces."

And ironically, it will probably be at work where you'll seek emotional support. Stress help lines have been set in up in 39% of organisations. While firms were once keen to include partners in corporate life through annual Christmas parties or summer outings, today's corporate village ensure that only members are welcome. "It is often the case that managers dread being harangued by people who believe that their partner is there too much," says James.

Even weekends may be no longer sacred. James Reed, chief executive of Reed Personnel Services, says, "We have noticed an increase in what we call 'grey time', which involves huge numbers of people emailing colleagues over the weekend. Very often, people do it without even thinking about it as work."

So is there a solution to this erosion of humanity as we once knew it? The Industrial Society believes there is. "The bottom line is that we want to make work fantastic but we do not want to keep people there too long," explains Reeves. "That means companies need to stop providing services at the point in which the workplace resembles a home. After all, that is the point at which they stop going home. More importantly still, they need to ensure the culture is such that people are actively encouraged to have their own lives completely separate from the workplace.

"It is the sign of a progressive employer to introduce anything that makes workers' lives easier, more pleasurable and gives them room for creativity. But it is a defective employer that expects workers to give up their lives."

webTitle: I can't wait to get to work

fields.headline: I can't wait to get to work
fields.standfirst:
Case study: Lynne Cheeseman, 23, marketing assistant

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: I have been working at Office Angels for two and a half years and I still can't wait to get into the office in the mornings. I usually arrive early so that I can either have a swim in the office pool or have a chat with my friends in the canteen before kick-off.
fields.body:
I have been working at Office Angels for two and a half years and I still can't wait to get into the office in the mornings. I usually arrive early so that I can either have a swim in the office pool or have a chat with my friends in the canteen before kick-off. They form by far the main part of my social life and I'm very close to them. In fact, my flatmate is one of my colleagues and when we have parties, most of the people there are from work. In some ways, home is just an extension of the office, which I really like.

Likewise, I usually stay at work late in the evenings. That tends to be for one of two reasons. First, because there are lots of projects to do or deadlines to meet, or second, because I just don't feel ready to go back to the flat.

In this case, I go to the company gym for a workout on the weights or to an aerobics class, or alternatively for a drink in the bar with some of the others from the department. I often visit the gym or bar at the weekends, too.

Fortunately, this company is really flexible about when you take your lunch hour, so that enables me to make sure a colleague is around to spend it with. Generally, I don't leave the building.

It would be fair to say that whether we're at our desks or at the office gym, canteen or bar, we talk a lot about work. Often, that can save me time in the office on my return because I've worked out a solution to something or thought up some creative new way of achieving a particular task.

I definitely don't think of that as overtime. I enjoy my job and enjoy time with my colleagues and so I just think of it as inevitable. You mean to switch off because it's supposed to be healthy, but actually, I don't really want to.

When I talk about my life - which is mainly my work - to people who don't work here, it's not uncommon for them not to have a clue what I'm talking about. I suppose there are words and phrases and processes that they simply wouldn't understand. Sometimes I can't wait to get back into work to talk to someone who knows where I'm coming from.

Last summer, some of us in the office formed a softball team and we met up every week to practise and to play other teams from local companies. Loads of people were really keen to join up and some wanted to spend a lot more evenings practising. I kind of wish we'd thought up an alternative for the winter, but at least we still spend the time together - in the bar instead.

If I was offered the chance to have in-work massages, yoga lessons or evening classes, I'd jump at the chance - anything like that. A huge chunk of my life would feel missing if I didn't have this place.'

fields.headline: The big benefits bonanza
fields.standfirst:
Perks of the job have vastly improved. But not all of them are popular, says Ann Bird
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: How would you like private health insurance, a BMW, a personal parking space, free weekend hotel breaks and use of a Lear jet to fly down to the company flat in Monte Carlo?
fields.body:
How would you like private health insurance, a BMW, a personal parking space, free weekend hotel breaks and use of a Lear jet to fly down to the company flat in Monte Carlo?

The days when the only perk you received was a box of Quality Street from the boss at Christmas are over for most secretaries and PAs, and while you'd be very lucky to be given all of the above, the quality of perks is streets ahead of what it once was. But two recent surveys, by recruitment specialists Select Appointments and Gordon Yates and the Guardian, reveal that not all perks are popular - both with employers and workers.

This may well be because some are taxable benefits or perhaps they have limited appeal - not everyone wants to pump iron at lunchtime in a sweaty environment or head for a Henley hotel at the weekend when really they urgently need to visit Homebase. Some employees would argue that they'd rather have their salaries increased and be free to choose what they spend them on.

Interestingly, what workers want and what management thinks they want can differ enormously. The Gordon Yates survey found that half the companies questioned offered private health insurance, while only 35% of employees found this the most attractive perk.

According to Select Appointments, a year ago a third of companies used performance-related pay as part of their remuneration package, but this proportion has doubled. Staff pension schemes are also on the up, particularly for workers in the financial sector. But other job sectors have their pluses - if you work in publishing or printing, for instance, you'll almost certainly receive free tea and coffee.

Before accepting a perk, say the experts, find out the tax implications. According to Paul Hodgson at independent researchers Income Data Services, "If you're offered a company car, unless you're racking up high mileage which qualifies for tax discounts, it may not be worth your while." Accepting a cash allowance for a car may be more tax efficient than taking a company vehicle. Watch the forthcoming budget closely for any possible tax changes.

The perks you receive are very much dictated by the job sector you work in - and generosity varies greatly. If you work in construction or engineering, you'll be very lucky to be offered a creche, whereas in local government or public services more than a quarter of workers have access to childcare facilities.

Bob Wicks, managing director at Select, says: "Many women, including young mothers and women returners, are specifically looking for flexible work, often part-time and temporary jobs. We would expect and encourage employers to invest in childcare provision to support parents in all these situations. Businesses that don't offer this benefit risk losing highly talented and committed staff."

Rebecca Childs is a typical high-flying PA who enjoys a range of enviable perks from her company, a City broker. The 33-year-old works directly for the chief executive and says, "I travel the world with my boss and it looks as if I'll be spending a couple of months in Australia on business this year. I also have a company credit card, which I can use for taking personnel out to dinner, but anything I spend has to be signed off!

"On top of that, I have a company mobile phone with all calls paid for, private health insurance and a variable annual bonus." So attractive is her bonus package that Childs says she prefers it to an increased salary. "I doubt I would spend my own money on sensible things such as health insurance. But I think it's important to have them." Though she does concede that "being able to travel the world and have a mobile phone makes me sound a bit like a Miss World contestant!"

As a London PA, Childs already stands a better chance of receiving good benefits. This is a simple case of supply and demand - because of the greater employment opportunities in London, the home counties and the south east, employers have to compete through offering higher salaries and benefits to attract the best staff.

Some staff even see perks in a job that their employers don't notice. A spokeswoman for Gordon Yates said that one respondent "considered the stunning view over London from her office as a perk, and another was attracted to work for a small firm because it was close to a watersports school and she could waterski at lunchtimes!"

fields.headline: Elvis - the Concert
fields.standfirst:
Elvis - the Concer
Wembley Arena, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Elvis - the Concert
Wembley Arena, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Fifty million Elvis impersonators must be furious. They have enough trouble competing with each other, let alone a widescreen resurrection of their idol that is capable of packing out Wembley Arena while they struggle to fill Wembley's Dog and Duck.

Considered cynically, Elvis - the Concert is just another attempt to squeeze pots more money out of the dead King. Yet for such a tacky concept, it's a surprisingly affecting experience. Elvis appears in video footage recorded in the early 70s; flab is starting to puff out his face but he still has impeccable cheekbones, his lip still curls sultrily and he still looks like he's having rampant sex when he does that pelvic thrust. His smiling, sweaty face is so mesmerising, anyone could happily believe that the ghost of Elvis is in the building.

Included are some excellent recordings: Are You Lonesome Tonight, in which Elvis creamily asks "Did you gaze at your forehead and wish you had hair?"; a riproaring Burning Love; passionate renditions of In the Ghetto, Suspicious Minds and An American Trilogy that ooze schmaltz but are swooningly beautiful. Only the frenetically paced, dismissive performances of 50s hits disappoint.

A programme note encouraged the audience to take photographs, but dancing was banned: anyone who so much as stood up was scolded by a steward. This would have been understandable in the cinema, but it doesn't make for a fun concert.

fields.headline: Dot.com shares
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Who would have thought that the problem with dot.com companies would be their reluctance to use new technology? While the public, particularly small investors, can't get enough of the new internet start-ups, stock-brokers are becoming impatient with them, with some broking firms even issuing warnings that they will no longer handle some dot.com shares. The reason? These new sexy firms, it seems, are sticklers for old-fashioned paperwork.
fields.body:
Who would have thought that the problem with dot.com companies would be their reluctance to use new technology? While the public, particularly small investors, can't get enough of the new internet start-ups, stock-brokers are becoming impatient with them, with some broking firms even issuing warnings that they will no longer handle some dot.com shares. The reason? These new sexy firms, it seems, are sticklers for old-fashioned paperwork.

These days the vast majority of transactions for UK and Irish securities and equities are proccessed electronically through Crest, a mutual company set up in 1996 to manage electronic trade. Crest handles a quarter of a million transactions every day, worth about £50bn. But membership has never been compulsory, and a company with a small turnover of shares may well prefer to settle on paper. The paperwork is not complex, simply time-consuming, because various bits of paper have to travel to several addresses to be logged and stamped. The time factor does not matter much provided that the share price is not volatile.

All this has changed, however, with the incredible surge of interest in investing - the volume of business that involves private investors has increased by 40% since last November. Officially, there is no explanation for this. Yet it is fair to assume that rumours of overnight fortunes, the photographs of twentysomething millionaires, and the dour warnings that this can't last may have had some influence. The result has been enthusiastic trading in e-business, but many popular e-companies, even the larger ones, are not in Crest. An unexpected result of the boom has been a backlog of paperwork for transactions that take days while prices change by the hour.

fields.headline: Lastminute offer is heavily overbooked
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Up to 250,000 investors are scrambling for the 33m shares being offered in net retailer Lastminute.com, resulting in disappointment for most applicants.
fields.body:
Up to 250,000 investors are scrambling for the 33m shares being offered in net retailer Lastminute.com, resulting in disappointment for most applicants.

With the issue likely to be priced at 380p a share - the top end of the indicated pricing band, valuing the 19-month-old firm at more than £500m - private investors are unlikely to receive more than 50 shares each, worth £200.

Lastminute's advisers, American investment bank Morgan Stanley, and the company itself are believed to be resisting the idea of ballotting share applicants, aware that disappointment might damage the customer base. At the same time they are having to balance public demand with correspondingly high interest from City institutions, which were initially expected to buy two-fifths of the shares on offer. In total, a quarter of the business is being floated. Founded by 31-year-old Brent Hoberman and his 27-year-old business partner, Martha Lane Fox, the firm has expanded from selling cheap flights to a range of products for panic shoppers.

fields.headline: They call me melancholic
fields.standfirst: Give your working life a spring clean and cut down on office stress, says Judi James
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Give your working life a spring clean and cut out the office stress, says Judi James
fields.body:
Depressed? And why shouldn't you be? Work has always been a good place for negative mood enhancement, a sort of instant check-in clinic for depression and paranoia. Office Melancholy (OM) is the new stress, a sort of afterburn for all the hurry sickness that always tends to strike when the deadline panic dies down.

OM is fighting to get a life outside work and then discovering that you don't have one. It's the angst that develops when your remember your friends are all boring and that hobbies are horrible.

OM inducers

 You didn't get that weight off/join that gym for the millennium and you've just realised you're not going to do it by spring, either
 You did a course in assertiveness but you still keep saying yes to all that extra work
 You went shopping on the net but couldn't work out how to buy anything
 The sight of all those grinning teenage Internet squillionaires in the paper each day is making you feel like a very old under-achiever
 You read the Madonna quote that: "Everyone in England seems to be so well-read and cultured" and realised the last book you got through was Bridget Jones's Diary
You can't get the hang of down-dressing
 You just heard your own message on your voicemail and realised you sound like a dork with a mask on
 Your boss has been on a course in motivating staff and his/her behaviour towards you all is now so nice that you have nothing to moan about over the cup-a-soup
 You lost interest in Posh and Becks but the newspapers didn't
 You somehow lost the ability to deal with small decisions and crises. Replacing the battery in your electric toothbrush is somehow beyond your stretch as is deciding between a skinny or full-fat latte

Instant pick-me- ups
 Pay a colleague you hate a sincere-sounding compliment
 Watch Sex In The City without prejudice
 Your office is terminally drab. Wear something bright to give your brain a colour-boost
Visit a museum or a sex shop during your lunch break
Stick up the picture of Prince Charles wearing the Rasta hat back to front. Know you're not the only person able to make a complete and utter plonker of yourself in public
Learn a party trick and perform it at work
De-stress your desk. Spend an hour spring-cleaning it, throwing out all the old papers you never read and even sorting through the garbage beneath it. Untangle the phone wire and create a working pen pot - throw out all the dead biros and only keep the ones you like using
Book another hour in your diary to do all those jobs you hate that you have been putting off
Forget about the diet - decide to stick to healthy eating, instead
Exercise raises your mood. Do some desk-bound ones, like lifting both feet together and holding them a few inches off the ground or pulling your stomach in towards your spine and holding the pose for a few seconds
Learn a useless skill, like yodelling or Morris dancing
 Record a new voice mail message, doing an impression of Daffy Duck
 Empty out all your pockets and spend the cash you find on a lottery ticket
Carry dice with you to make all those unimportant decisions. Or flip a coin
Ring a client up just to say hello, rather than press for business
Buy a clockwork toy and let it loose on the office floor
Buy a gateau and share it round the office, even though it's nobody's birthday
Talk face-to-face, rather than using E-mails

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 10: Carbon paper
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Carbon paper, like the Sinclair Spectrum and Marathon bars, separates the sheep from the goats. Some secretaries may scarcely know what it is for, while for others there will have been a time when they could not imagine life without it.
fields.body:
Carbon paper, like the Sinclair Spectrum and Marathon bars, separates the sheep from the goats. Some secretaries may scarcely know what it is for, while for others there will have been a time when they could not imagine life without it. For carbon paper is one of the sad casualties of the 20th century's relentless technological advance. Along came the photocopier, and carbon paper was suddenly an inky crumpled ball in the wastebin of history.

Unfortunately for whoever made the stuff, this was with good reason, since carbon paper was never a good way to make copies. Placed between two sheets of paper, it traced writing or typing on the top sheet on to the bottom in a rather sickly shade of blue. Ambitious souls who attempted to make more than one copy at a time swiftly developed acute RSI from leaning so hard on the page.

It was all so different in the romantic days of carbon paper's infancy. Although the first reference to "carbonated paper" is by an English inventor, Ralph Wedgewood, in 1806, the Italian Pellegrino Tulli is thought to have beaten him to it by several years. In an implausibly tragic tale, Tulli developed the paper after falling in love with the young Countess Carolina Fantoni da Fivizzono, who had become blind "in the flower of her youth and beauty". The paper, and the elaborate typewriting machine it accompanied, were designed to enable her to communicate with her friends - and her lover - in secret. "I am desperate because I find myself almost without black paper," she wrote. "I will never forget that it is a precious gift made by you."

Unfortunately Tulli's typewriting machine has not survived, unlike the carbon copies of the Countess's letters to her enterprising suitor. So perhaps the inky paper should not be dismissed so easily. It's certainly a more original love-gift than a dozen red roses.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Scared of change
fields.body:
Scared of change

Employers in Britain are resisting calls for greater workplace flexibility, says a report from flexible work consultants the Resource Connection and the Industrial Society. The study, Change? What Change?, found widespread inaction among employers over the flexible demands of the workforce. While two-thirds of employers questioned are experiencing increased demand for flexible work, they are reluctant to alter corporate work patterns. "Employers must embrace flexibility to ensure future competitiveness," says Carol Savage, managing director of the Resource Connection, "but old cultural barriers are blinding them to the need for change."

Woman 2000

A three-day lifestyle exhibition celebrating the role of modern woman at work and in the home opens on June 6 at Wembley conference and exhibition centre. Woman 2000 will be divided into nine sectors, ranging from careers and education to travel and leisure. Visitors will have access to advice, information and products reflecting women's diverse interests and responsibilities. To book, telephone 0870 739 9400.

Incompetent execs

How do you deal with a grumpy chairman, an over-confident CEO, an MD who can't handle the press or an incompetent executive? These dilemmas are explored in a practical new book, Directors' Dilemmas, by Patrick Dunne. The book draws on real dilemmas experienced by a wide variety of businesses, from fledgling start-ups to mature multinational public corporations. Available from Kogan Page at £12.99. Tel 01903 828800 for orders.

RSI payouts

To mark last week's RSI awareness day, the TUC called on the Court of Appeal to raise compensation levels for sufferers of the debilitating "typist's injury". Last year the Law Commission proposed that current payouts of between £2,000 and £7,000 for people who have suffered repetitive strain injury as a result of their jobs should be increased by 50-100%. "Our main objective will always be prevention," said TUC general secretary John Monks. "But if the worst happens, the courts should give sufferers more realistic compensation."

Style on a budget

Good news for budget-conscious travel bookers. Low-cost carrier Go now has an upgrade package for business travellers on international flights out of Stansted. It costs £20 and guarantees space at the front of the short-stay car park, fast-track security clearance, use of BAA's VIP departure lounge and deals such as reduced currency exchange commission rates. On the internet only at <A HREF="http://www.go-fly.com"" TARGET="_NEW">www.go-fly.com

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: They gotta have it
fields.standfirst:
No time to collect your dry cleaning, or pick up your car from the garage? Jenny Hirschkorn talks to someone who provides just the service that every busy office worker needs
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: No time to collect your dry cleaning, or pick up your car from the garage? Jenny Hirschkorn talks to someone who provides just the service that every busy office worker needs
fields.body:
Think "concierge" and you imagine a plush hotel with someone at the front desk to answer to your every beck and call. Need to book some theatre tickets? No problem. Someone to fetch the dry cleaning? Certainly, madam. Taxi to the airport? What time, sir?

But why should the concept be confined to hotels? Why not extend such benefits to harassed office staff, who find it so difficult to fit those nagging little errands into their precious free time? The idea seemed so sensible that when partners at Andersen Consulting saw it in operation in their New York offices in 1991 they had little hesitation in introducing a scaled-down version in London.

Philomena Pettit, the service's co-ordinator, explains that in those days the helpdesk was very modest, but the type of tasks she and her staff now tackle has widened dramatically. "We do all kinds of things, from arranging passports and visas to fixing up car servicing, to personal and corporate shopping."

Personal shopping? "That can be quite a challenge!" she says. "We were asked recently to find an evening dress for a partner's girlfriend. She was in Sweden and knew nothing about it. He had no idea of her size and, to complicate things, the dress had to be in bottle-green velvet. "We finally managed to coax some semblance of a size out of him, and the story has a really happy ending. The couple are now engaged."

Pettit joined what was then the accountancy side of the firm, Arthur Andersen, nine years ago as an administrator when her previous employers moved to Gloucester. Initially she thought the assignment would be a part-time one, lasting just a few weeks. "In fact, it quickly became full-time, and here I am nine years on," she says. Later, she became administrator for the in-house graphic design team, before moving down to the helpdesk around three years ago.

There are about 5,000 staff on Andersen Consulting's London campus, but it is a major global company and any member of Andersen's personnel, anywhere in the world, is entitled to use the service. "We recently did a job for someone in South Africa. We have worked for people in India and all over Europe," says Pettit.

The helpdesk's busy nerve centre is situated in the depths of the company's London offices, on the banks of the Thames. Here, Pettit and her staff mark up on a huge white board all the tasks that must be completed that day. The list varies enormously from day to day, but on the day of my visit included picking up skis that had been repaired, collecting passports from the Spanish embassy, sending out champagne and collecting a car that had been serviced. "Staff sometimes worry that their passports will be forgotten, or their mother's birthday will pass unmarked, and we have to reassure them that everything is under control. We are very organised."

But even the most organised of departments sometimes finds the workload hard to cope with. "We do have to take on a temp from time to time. For example, we needed extra help in December when we hosted a huge Christmas party for the children of Andersen personnel. There were about 600 kids, ranging in age from newborn to 10, as well as at least one parent for each of them, and some older siblings who came along to help. With total numbers of around 1,200, we took the party outside our own premises for the first time and organised a marquee at London Zoo. The theme was Father Christmas on Safari."

Not all the jobs that the department is called on to do are frivolous. On one occasion a child was taken ill while an employee and his family were on holiday in France, but the prescription medicine he needed was available only in the UK. One of the helpdesk assistants obtained the medicine and flew to France to deliver it in person.

Catering to the needs of such a huge pool of personnel means that no two days in Pettit's working life are the same. What she loves most is the job's unpredictability. "I never know what the day is going to bring."

fields.body:
If Eels's last album, Electro-shock Blues, was ideal listening for a stay in a mental hospital, then their new offering, Daisies of the Galaxy, conjures up a post-psychotic pastoral. Front-man E's lyrics have lost none of their pathos, but the music is richer and dreamier, and the slower songs evolve on the understanding that a lullaby has to be healthier than lithium.

So it was no surprise to see that the capacity crowd was fully seated when the "Eels Orchestra" took the stage. Lurking in a lounge-bar soft green mist, the ensemble boasted a violinist, a stetson-wearing drummer, a double-bass player, and a two-man wind and brass section, one of whom was dressed as Father Christmas.

When not playing his acoustic or electric guitar E was at the piano, sitting with his back to the audience, his lazy, croaky vocals resonant against the diverse percussion. Indeed, the lavish arrangements threatened to become soporific. It's rare to attend a gig where, for the first 30 minutes at least, so many people were offering to go to the bar.

My Beloved Monster startled a few slumbering souls with its manic snatches of electric guitar and brass, but the momentum was soon lost to a clap-along Ant Farm. Thankfully, the deliberately elegiac Daisies of the Galaxy was more successful, while the fruity single, Mr E's Beautiful Blues, finally got a few people to their feet. Yet an acoustic and kettledrum rendition of Novocaine for the Soul was disappointing, and a cover version of Can't Help Falling in Love only bemused the audience further.

Group therapy never works with such big numbers.

 Dominion Theatre, London (0171-580 1889), tonight.
